title: How can we equip young people with the skills, information and opportunities to succeed in the world of work?

occupational_idol.description: Now that you got accepted to the job or your dreams, your employer wants to know what should be your area of expertise. The OpenIDEO Student Chapter at NYU-Poly believes that this is where the job-talent test, Occupational Idol, kicks in.
occupational_idol.creator: 8cfd908f431292099d78c0eed0ff589e

comments.text: Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Nice one guys! Although it's focused on entreprenuers rather than employees  you might find some builds and learnings on Dragon's Den: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dragons'_Den

To me, the refreshing part of this concept is not the enhanced employer-candidate interaction, but rather: let's make it into a TV show!We have had shows like "The Apprentice", but the participants in those shows already had jobs and experience. We can have one challenging graduates (or even youths who have just finished high school) to demonstrate their talent and get their first job at the big companies that demand creativity (e.g. famous silicon valley companies, top advertising companies).With a good TV show going, we benefit not only the participants in the show, but educate young viewers on what opportunties are out there, what employers are looking for and what skills they need to equip themselves with to succeed in the world of work.

My first reaction is to say I could not think of a worse fate for this concept than to join the ranks of dime-a-dozen reality TV shows. However having said that if the format was varied so that all the participants derived real benefit (not just the experience or notoriety) it might just be worthwhile.Most reality TV shows are gladiatorial spectacle, remarkable more for entertainment than participatory value. Youth entering the job market deserve better - perhaps if you are looking for the next generation of super sales persons or a new "weather girl" it maybe appropriate.
If a format can be developed that includes a win for ALL participating youth I'm all for it!!!!!

I certainly had no intention of this show following path of the dime-a-dozen reality TV shows.The concept is that the entertainment is there to engage (something difficult to do with disaffected unemployed young people) while the content can educate and give them a wider perspective of the world of work. If the concept makes it into the refinement stage, then we would look into the format in more detail.
Thanks for the clarification Andrew.Looking forward now to more details as the concepting phase progresses.

Hi, I am wondering if this occupational idol test could not in fact be done outside of the context of a specific organization. I could think of a version of it in a career fair (in a university) where several companies (maybe in a similar field) are involved.
Hi again, wondering if this could not fit with the Younth+unemployed conference concept of Ana C. http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/the-young-unemployed-conference-/

Some aspects of this - particularly the early rounds - could probably be tried out on campus through exploring the intersection between disciplines, particularly the soft skills common to many disciplines but also the interactions between them.The biomimicry collaboration for IDEO on the USGBC challenge is a salutary lesson in bringing apparently unrelated disciplines together ( http://www.fastcodesign.com/1643489/biomimicry-challenge-ideo-taps-octopi-and-flamingos-to-reorganize-the-usgbc )It also contains some interesting solutions to connectivity and collaboration.
Way to go Daniella and the NYU Poly OpenIDEO student chapter! I like that this test is really a chance for both applicant and employer to determine fit, rather than being a one-sided hiring decision.
I indeed like the idea of a conversation and a dialogue between the applicant and the employer. I also like the idea that getting a new job is also a discovery for the applicant.

occupational_idol.title: Occupational Idol

incorporating_meditation_into_schools_w_.description: The David Lynch Foundation has established a "quiet-time" program to incorporate transcendental meditation into school curriculum.  Meditative practices have been shown to help ease stress which could help bring kids' focus back to learning
incorporating_meditation_into_schools_w_.creator: f92cd9612ad5db7f2072da94282c3214

comments.text: Quiet time in general is extremely useful, whether it be meditation or similar contemplative time such as practiced in Quaker schools, and I agree it should be instituted much more. As adults we need to set an example in this by providing similar break times in workplaces.Where I work there is a notice saying "You are expected to be working at all times during your shift." While most shifts for the casuals are only a up to five hours this is not true of middle management who can be expected to work up to 15 hours straight, only 8.5 of which will be paid. Let's begin to value people again - young and old alike.

Thanks for your comment Paul - I couldn't agree more.  Setting a little time aside for contemplation and introspection is always a good thing for any of us.In the school system, I believe that pairing this with specific learning activities could be critical for students who need to internalize skills and make them their own.
Should be implemented in every school =)

incorporating_meditation_into_schools_w_.title: "Quiet-Time": Improving Students' Focus & Attention by Incorporating Meditation into Schools

soft_skills_harder_than_hard_skills.description: Teaching young people technical skills can be a challenge, but even more daunting is transforming their habits and behaviors to meet the needs of today's companies.  Can professionalism be taught?  Year Up thinks so.
soft_skills_harder_than_hard_skills.creator: c2c3271b053386f00bf96831873e8625

comments.text: I think this is great inspiration - thanks for sharing.  When I was at school (many moons ago) we had a programme called 'World of Work' but it was actually really stigmatised - it was basically targeted at kids who were likely to leave school at 16 with little or no formal qualifications.  I think much of what they taught in that programme would have been beneficial to all students, but being in that class marked you out as a 'no-hoper'.  There was a real poverty of ambition around the programme that YearUp seem to have addressed.  Programmes like this should feel much more aspirational because they're valuable to everyone.    And as someone who has worked a lot with interns from top universities who might have first-class honours degrees but literally didn't have the common sense to stuff an envelope properly, I know the need for these kinds of skills extends well beyond 'the usual suspects'!

I think Year Up has a good concept for the 18-24 year olds, but I think the process of teaching the soft skills should start in elementary school. We as a society don't put enough emphasis on education grades K-12. There isn't any reason the kids can't stay in school a little longer than usual, especially if it helps them once they graduate high school. They could start learning about finances and how to save and balance their check book. Not just one class, but a succession through k-12. They can learn about how credit will effect everything they do in life, or how hygiene or common courtesy is the expectation. They could learn the correct way to interview. They could learn and start talking about college and the importance of a higher education whether it be with a traditional college or a technical program. There are a lot of things we could be teaching our children at an early age through our schools. A little more energy and thought in what and how we teach our young children now will and should pay huge divideds down the road. Not to put this all on teachers, the parents should have most of the responsiblity, but unfortunately, there are a majority of children that don't get the appropriate care and nurturing from parents. At least the teachers all have an education and are continually learing and growing, hopefully.James T
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
Great stuff, Justin. Am digging the contract system on this.

student_start_up_program.description: A group of young people come together with a group of mentors to develop and set up their own business over a 6 month period.  The program offers students an opportunity to be an entrepreneur in a low-risk environment.
student_start_up_program.creator: 33caa81be5a3967fabf0adcfdcd91be8

comments.text: Hi Caroline,at my university there was a 5-Euro-Business. Student teams started with 5 Euro and had 3 month to create a business out of it. The program was accompanied by lectures.Here you can find more information (it is in German though, but if there are questions on that, Im happy to help): http://www.5-euro-business.de/download/Handbuch_SoSe_2012.pdf Maybe you can use this as further inspiration while your concept evolves.

Thanks so much for sharing that Sabine.  Fascinating to see a project in which there are both significant time and resource limitations.  Do you know of examples of the kinds of businesses were created?  Also, how many 'contact hours' were spent on the project?  3 months seems like a really short time to get something off the ground

Hi Caroline, great questions! I just looked for some information and found some great success stories:A translation, proof-reading and editing business was started with 5 Euro and (with a changed name) has made great progress. Its called Clevoo and you find more information on their homepage: http://www.clevoo.com/AboutUs.phpAnother example is "moneytubes": http://www.moneytubes.de/themes/kategorie/index.php?kategorieid=3 They collected used inner tubes and bought snap buttons from the 5 Euro to start their business. Now they have a wider portfolio.Other projects are card games like the "Nighttett" with cooperation and coupons for the local gastronomy: http://www.nighttett.de/The 5-Euro-contest is only a starting point. The winner is chosen according to a final presentation. I think the time amount spent can vary a lot from group to group. But I was amazed by the results I found during my short nonlinear search.

Hi Caroline -- I've come across a few different approaches to engaging young people in Entrepreneurship that I'd like to share with you...Maybe there are some insights to be gleaned from both...Network for Teaching Entrepreneurship: http://www.nfte.com/Young Impact's Startup Scramble: http://startupscramble.com/, http://youngimpact.com/

Thanks so much for sharing those links Sasha.  It's really interesting to see what else is happening out there.  This idea would vary from those two in that its a much more practical and hands-on approach than NTE and would run over a longer period of time than Startup Scramble.  I think there's real merit in both of those programs, but I also see the need for a very tangible experience of actually starting a business and over a period of several months, so that students are able to understand the entire experience and receive mentoring throughout.
Copy that. I agree...

Startup Scramble was started by a friend here at Babson College. I experienced it and it is a great way to start thinking in an entrepreneurial way. But as Caroline says, a longer program would be much more effective.

I did my masters thesis on the impacts of long-term unemployment on entrepreneurship and the key findings might be relevant here: a lot of people who value entrepreneurship will still avoid it in favour of unsuccessful job hunting, because they crave structure; this is more prevalent the lower the individuals confidence. In my study the confidence was low due to a number of psychological factors related to unemployment, but I'm sure the same would apply to never-employed students. The interesting thing is that this remains true even when funding options are known and available. So a structured programme that fosters the creative, entrepreneurial spirit in a less intimidating way is a necessary way to boost the effectiveness of the various funding models suggested here.If youre interested in the detail you can find a summary of the study and a link to the full document here http://blegrange.wordpress.com/2010/10/24/promoting-entrepreneurship-among-the-long-term-unemployed/

They discontinued Young Achievers? :(  I didn't participate at the time but in hindsight I realised that I could've learnt a lot from it.To me the key point here is that students experience entrepreneurship first-hand, early on in a low-risk environment. The methods of delivering this may vary and evolve as the circumstances change.

Hey Andrew, Yeah, unfortunately Young Achievers was discontinued.  I'm told there's a similar program being run in Queensland called Entrepreneurial Experience, but haven't checked it out for myself.I agree, the method of delivery has the opportunity to vary and evolve given the technological advances - perhaps even collaborating on the project remotely.  How do you think the method of delivery might change?

The University of Queensland now offers the Entreprenuerial Experience Program (EEP) but its limited to university students https://uqfuture.custhelp.com/ci/documents/view/1/AvUE~wpoCv8SPvD5GuEe~yD~JvsY~y7BMv~Q~zr~

I'm recalling that when I watched Young Achievers at work, it was about taking a physical product to market. But now we have smartphones, phone Apps etc. so students could be selling virtual(?) products on the internet.It would be good to have a program flexible enough to allow for innovative products and new markets, but at the same time we need to have the necessary supervision to make sure no-one is setting up an online Ponzi scheme.
And thank you for building on my concept!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Thanks Caroline for building on the TripleE- concept: http://prezi.com/-oxr8gtgcckm
Love how you've built on the discontinued Australian example with the addition of crowd-funding!

Yes - this can actually be extended to a range of jobs in the post secondary non-university sector too.Crowd funding is in its infancy in Australia but may become far more important since, unlike USA, philanthropy is not a strong point of the nouveau-riche.I suspect that crowd-funding will shortly come under the view of the ATO with some questions raised about non-equity based capital raising - it could become another dog's breakfast.

Perhaps Caroline's concept could piggy-back on the Pozible platform for the crowd-funding component in Australia? http://www.pozible.com/ In this case, the money doesn't constitute shares and would work more like Kickstarter. Just a thought...

Yes Pozible held an event in Hobart last week in the middle of my work shift. They expressly forbid equity based capital raising and charitable fundraising too (that would severely complicate the issue with the current tax-deductible status of most charities).Projects need a specific creative component which is why most recipients are in the arts, with a smattering of games and app development.

Thanks for those comments Meena and Paul.  We'd have to choose between the options of crowdfunding or an equity-based model.  My initial intention would be to go with an equity-based model, as that way the young people are held accountable to their shareholders in the same way they would be in any normal company.  I guess there is also the opportunity to explore a crowdfunding model (like Pozible) where the 'reward' is could be one of the products which the company starts producing.  I'm friends with the guys at Pozible, and I think they (and the crowdfunding model) are awesome.  I'm also concious that there's likely to be a 'crowdfunding drain' over the next year or so given the rapid growth in popularity.  I hear friends that comment that they're almost going broke with the amount of causes they're supporting through platforms like Pozible and DoSomeGood.  So in this case I think a equity-based model would be more appropriate as it would be more sustainable and (hopefully) would be more likely to attract investment (given the high chance there is a pay-off in return).  Mind you, if the company decided to create a super-awesome product, maybe going through a crowdfunding model with product rewards would be the more sustainable way to go...

conference_blind_dates.description: At the "Young + Unemployed Conference" proposed by Ana Cecilia companies and young unemployed can apply to a Blind Date. The young candidates pitch their skills and convince the companies to hire them.
conference_blind_dates.creator: 8082a75025cb51e513aff379783121c9

comments.text: Interesting! This definitely brings in competition in the market place (for both the employee and the employer).  Also, the employer is able to see the applicant in real life, rather than simply focusing on a resume.  New character traits can be explored that otherwise would be missing by simply submitting a resume.This concept also brought the idea of "speed networking" to me.  Somewhat like "speed dating", youth looking for work can interview each other and perhaps a new project comes out of their speed conversation.  This can help increase entrepreneurship and enhance project creation when they meet like-minded people.

Thank you for your feedback. I like the idea of speed dating, too. For me this is also connected to get to know new people. I believe, when people meet in person and talk to each other candidates can present additional skills which you cannot see in a CV. Speed dating between the candidates is also a good idea - this works in the direction of entrepreneurship and creating your own job. It could be also used between employer and employee again. Im curious to talk more about this kind of ideas and concepts to bring the right people together in oder to find or to create jobs.

comments.text: I gave nod to your concept within LAB21.  It would be amazing to kick off a pilot with a conference like this!Also wanted to share The Feast with you because I think that so much of the ideas being generated now for the 'not so young anymore', can be just as beneficial to youth around the world.If you get some time to browse through The Feast's website, I'd love to hear your insights.http://www.feastongood.com/conference/Good luck!

An idea to expand the concept.In addition to giving young people the opportunity to pitch to potential employers, it would be great if the conference also presented the opportunity for young people to demonstrate their skills to potential employers. I was thinking that for some trades/industries, the ability of the applicant in completing a particular skilled task is more important than their public speaking ability.Example 1: At a conference for the food industry, people can book the use of an open kitchen that has been set up in the conference hall. Potential employers can observe the food preparation skills of the person, and also taste-test the final result.Example 2: At a conference for the construction industry, there is a competition between teams of young people, to see which team can erect a building frame in the shortest time. There's a prize for the winning team, but most importantly, the winners catch the eye of potential employers.

hi Andrew. I completely agree, completing a certain task might be  a more appropriate selling point than speaking in public, in order to 'land a job'. Although maybe for a specific industry, the employer might want to see their public speaking skills. I love your example for the food industry sector, which is huge!Will be taking this into consideration when updating this concept. Thank you. Shoot me with more ideas if u have any.

We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Our developers are busy working on it. Meanwhile, if you're wanting to iterate your ideas, you can use the comments feature to promote further conversation from others. We'll let you know once the bug is fixed, then you can incorporate your refinement moves into your concept post. Let's be agile, together!
Thank you for letting me know!

Right on! Our development team have been busy fixing the Update Entry bug and we're back on track now. You'll now be able to edit your posts to add all that refinement-goodness to build out your concepts for improved impact. Bring it on, together!

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:There were several events-based concepts but the panel really liked this idea because it democratises the notion of a professional conference or networking event.  We also liked how it turned the usual careers fair idea on it's head by inviting young people to pitch themselves to companies, rather than the other way around. WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:The panel were a bit concerned that the '20 people from every conference are guaranteed a job' stipulation might deter some businesses/organisations from getting involved.  We'd therefore love you to refine this idea so the focus becomes more about gaining skills and experience rather than simply finding work and is for all young people, rather than just those that are unemployed.  We're also keen to hear your thoughts on who will sponsor/run these events...For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine
I'm thrilled, thank you! Great to get your feedback on this, it will really help. I will start refining the concept next Tuesday! Thanks.
Looking forward to it, Ana! And meanwhile  if others in our community have ideas to add here: fire away!
Hi Ana Cecilia, I'm in Brussels today attending an innovation conference for 18-24 yr olds. Would really love love love to see this in London.

Hello Haiyan - I know! I'm following EYIF's Twitter activity and the conference looks brilliant, wish I could be there.. Maybe you could ask some youths their thoughts about if they would find this kind of conference interesting :)Very happy that you like the idea! Would love to hear your thoughts on how to solve the problem of ensuring the rule of *20 young unemployed attendees must leave the conference with a job* that Anne-L also asked me.

Maybe we should organise an OpenIDEO Young Innovators conference :)Hm. The 20 jobs rule is a toughie. Especially in Europe here employment laws are quite tough.What about if the rules are 'loosened' somewhat to be something like employers should come with 20 internships to fill.. or projects to offer.

I love the sounds of an OpenIDEO Young Innovators conference - in fact, it sounds like it should happen sometime soon anyhow. There has been a lot of important and valuable discussions in the past 2 years leaving enough content and future plans to discuss for OpenIDEO!The loosening of the rule sounds like a good solution.. If the employers come up with the jobs/internships themselves, that makes it a more realistic objective! Thank you Haiyan, looking forward to read your write ups about the conference!

Hi Ana Cecilia and Haiyan. Love the idea of an OpenIDEO Young Innovators conference. Regarding your 3rd point for the conference objective, namely, "how they see the world in 2020 and how they will adapt to survive" what do you think about incorporating the idea that young people should not worry about climbing a career ladder, but instead spending their life creating a "tool kit" of experiences, which will lead them to develop skills and information necessary to work in the lines of work of interest to them? As a result, these young people will learn to take charge and direct their careers (which I think will be important in the future to survive and stand-out from the crowd).

hi Karina & Haiyan, too!Thanks for your comment. I'm quite interested in knowing what a Young Innovators conference could mean for OpenIDEO too. I really love your perspective of a 'tool kit'! I think that could be made into a workshop somehow, during the conference, held by an experienced professional. This would mean even if some unemployed didn't leave the conference without a job, they would walk out of the conference with an extremely valuable kit of learnings to start applying to their professional life immediately after.I think this concept can be adapted in many ways, but above all I believe there should be a big emphasis in the Young which ARE Unemployed, and link them with lots of hungry employers.

Certainly agree that there are a lot of different ways this conference could be formatted (which also makes the idea so exciting to work with!). I think one thing which could be difficult is just matching companies with unemployed youth as companies have an overwhelming amount of applicants at the moment. How could the conference be formatted to ensure value is provided to youth (as in skill building, for example) as well as for the companies so that it is not just another type of job fair?

Could you get some event management support from one or more of the companies presenting/speaking? Surely if they are in a position to grow, it's in their interest to support the conference - particularly in exchange for some extra branding or equivalent. Also, do you see an opportunity to incorporate some coaching for attendees who have been on the job market?

I really like this idea cause it seems sooo doable!, I ave been to a couple design conferences and although I met a few people the whole thing did not focus on networking or job positioning. I think that giving more space for students to explore possible employers is a great event I would probably attend. Sometimes we students forget that when looking for a job we are also interviewing our potential employers in the same way they are evaluating us; this would be a good way for companies to attract young talent to their teams also.

Hi Bov!I love your feedback, thanks! I agree - some conferences I've been too as well do not focus as much on networking, in particular for job hunting purposes or showcasing your potential.I love your view of: "we students forget that when looking for a job we are also interviewing our potential employers in the same way they are evaluating us" it's so true! And people forget that, there should be a more balanced approach in the process of job hunting and job matching! thanks a lot, and let me know if you have new ideas to add to this :)

Thanks Ana, I think the complicated part with networking I find is that it boils down to human interaction and good chemistry between potential employee and potential employer., I am thinking the process would have to be something similar to speed dating to accelerate the process of selecting good candidates for both sides , what do you thin?, :D

Congrats Ana Cecilia.I like the idea and I can see the potential. I agree with you that making sure that you have high quality speakers is important. It might be also an opportunity for some of the young participants to reflect on their interests and talents. Maybe there could be a way to integrate the OpenIDEO student chapter concept:http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/occupational-idol/I like the rule: *The conference has one rule: 20 young unemployed attendees must leave the conference with a job*However, I was wondering how do you explain it, articulate it and help enforcing it.  I have no suggestions but I was wondering if you have thought about it.

Hi Anne-L thanks for your comments :) Yes I do believe Daniella's concept could be implemented here. I still think my concept is quite open and at the moment has the problem of how to 'ensure quality' of the whole event throughout.Great question and thanks for pushing me! I think the enforcing of 20 youths employed could be enforced by a contractual agreement between the conference organisers and the employers through, 1) implementing a system of traffic light signage + industry signage like stickers for the youngsters + employers. Maybe after the talks there would be opportunities for workshops where youngsters with similar industry interests as one employer could go over and participate and mingle with them. You would then switch your traffic light sticker for a green one and proudly stick the name of your new job on it! This would be a way to FACILITATE the idea, but not enforce it I guess. Would be nice to do a contractual agreement with the conference and the employers before hand, and make sure there are 20 companies participating that want to employ someone and hope that they do...I'd like to hear other peoples thoughts and suggestions on answering that question...
Congrats on being Featured Concept, Ana Cecilia!
Thanks very much Haiyan, very excited about this challenge, and seeing how it will become real!

Like Paul, I'm uncomfortable with hiring based on pitch alone but also am not a fan of the employers scanning the CVs beforehand. In my mind, the conference is starting to look much like interviewing at a job fair. What innovative elements could we add to the mix to make it feel less like so? In addition toor instead ofdebate and discussion, what if participants completed sample projects? What I imagine is a set-up akin to Startup Weekend (http://startupweekend.org/), but in lieu of creating something anew, the task would be a project for existing companies who are hiring. It would be a multi-day conference that starts with companies pitching projects and jobseekers pitching themselves, then some sort of matchmaking scheme, followed by the largest chunk of time tackling projects in groups made up of both employers and jobseekers.

I'd also like to add that I'm leaning towards a more localized model, versus a huge conference at a quasi-central location like London; i.e. scale would be in number of host cities not number of participants per conference. London could host one but so could Oxford and Bristol and Leeds.

Hi Karolle thanks for your comments! I just want to make it clear that I don't believe the hiring should be based on the pitching of the unemployed youngsters at all - I like the idea of giving them the chance to pitch and tell their potential employers in the audience why they should NOT be unemployed! I don't see it as a job fair at the moment because the ones i've been to I was never given the opportunity or platform to sell myself to potential employers or be inspired by their talks. *Those events are usually focused on employers promoting their companies* This would be totally focused on the opposite with some fun workshops and inspirational speeches through the middle, focused on the potential of the young and unemployed!  Do you have some innovative ideas to help me out to make it look less like a job fair to you and others ?I like the idea of this being a multi day conference, where employers actually get to know the young people a bit better, and so like that we wouldn't have to cram workshops and presentations and networking into one day - thanks for the inspiration! I'm quite open as to how and where this conference would be held. However as a member of this audience (under 25 year old) who lives in London, if there was an unemployed conference here and I was jobless at the time, and if catered to my industry - I'd be very interested in going! I think whats important to underline here is that there would be a lot of research needed PRIOR, to find out the needs of the young and unemployed - what would they do if we gave them the platform to try and find a job? Would they find this kind of conference interesting ? How would they like to interact with the audience/employers? We want to be innovative and help them, so I think the best way would be to ask them first. There are still a lot of questions to be answered and discussed I guess. Let me know if you have any more suggestions that I can update this concept with, thanks Karolle!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Thank you very much! :)  Looking forward to get everyone's thoughts on how to approach this idea.

Very interesting proposition Ana Cecilia.Would these be city based?Could they be mobile?Would potential employers have prior access to youth CV's?Would youth have an idea of the jobs that will be on offer?I don't know the answers to these questions but thought they might stimulate thinking about developing this concept.Hope we can all contribute to refining this concept to make it a solid contender,

Hello Paul!Stimulating questions there, and very useful ones too. I like the idea of employers having previous access to unemployed youths attending. In terms of location I think that would be quite an important decision point as youth unemployment is quite high in particular European countries at the moment such as Portugal, Spain and Greece, so maybe it could happen let's say in a buzzing city like London, and would be open to all EU youths? I believe those questions would be set later on, for example youth knowing what jobs would be on offer. They would certainly know then companies attending, so they could pitch directly to them if they wished (companies would only attend if they were interested in hiring someone)   I'd love to hear more of your thoughts and others on how solidify this concept! Thanks :)

Thanks Ana Cecilia.I liked the idea that the outcome would be actual employment of some participants but was a bit uncomfortable with the choice of successful applicants on the basis of pitch alone. Hence my question about employers having access to CV's etc.My question about location and mobility was in part prompted by experience here in Australia where affording the trip from a regional centre to say a capital city might be a challenge in itself, I take your point that the opportunities are probably in places like London while the unemployment is greater elsewhere.I guess part of the process of choosing employers to participate might be a bit like OpenIDEO challenge sponsors - they take the risk that the community solutions may be more costly or less worthwhile than anticipated.Will keep thinking about this.

the_young_unemployed_conference_.title: A conference connecting the Young Unemployed to future Employers and Mentors

py/tuple: IMPACT & REACH: How much impact and reach do you think this concept could have in helping young people transition into the world of work?
A great deal – something like this would really make a difference
A moderate amount – it’s certainly helpful but probably not a game-changer
Not very much – it’s unlikely to make a significant difference to young people seeking work

FEASIBILITY & RESOURCES: Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible will it be for your community to turn this concept into a reality?  (Hint: when you think about resources, think: people, money, time, technology, infrastructure, partnerships and any other inputs for implementation)
Highly feasible – resources wouldn’t be an issue for my community if we tried to implement this
Moderately feasible – my community could do it if we could get find assistance with some of our resource constraints
Not feasible – it would be almost impossible for my community to implement this concept; it's just too resource-intensive
SUSTAINABILITY & LONGEVITY: Does this concept feel like it could be sustained as a project, business or movement over years rather than just months? Will continue to be relevant in future?
Yes – this concept has enough momentum to stand on its own two feet and remain relevant for years to come
Maybe – it’s not clear how long it would take for this concept to stand on its own feet or how it will continue to be but there’s reason to feel hopeful
No – this concept will have trouble sustaining itself in the long-run and probably won’t be as relevant in years to come
ORIGINALITY: How new or innovative is this idea? Are there many different versions of this concept out there already or is this something more disruptive and unique?
Very original – I’ve not seen anything else quite like it
Fairly original – there are similar things out there but this particular version brings a new element to the table
Unoriginal – there are already too many other concepts out there that are similar to this one
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world
I liked it but preferred others
It didn't get me overly excited

coworking_spaces.description: We believe that there is not a lack of good ideas in the world, but simply a lack of understanding of where, or who, to turn to to exploit those ideas. What is missing are affordable and sustainable spaces to transform those ideas into real projects.
coworking_spaces.creator: 0b15daa205be7c0ee7ce3ab28b58e928

comments.text: I really like this idea, since so many jobs can be done remotely this provides a great way for people to get the valuable input of "co-workers" to troubleshoot, and think through problems or projects without having actual co-workers and could be especially valuable to young people starting out freelancing.
Thanks!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
THANKS!

I like this idea a lot and I've certainly seen a few experiments along these lines in London.  The issue, as far as young people are concerned, seems to be price.  A number of these co-working spaces charge membership fees which are probably beyond the pocket of the typical young person, especially if they are not earning.  I wonder if there's a 'pay as you go' model that could work? Or a way to offer varying rates based on your ability to pay or reputation for example.  But a lovely idea and your English is certainly nothing to apologise for Carlos!

Yes, its true. Im seeking sponsors to charge cheaper for young entrepreneurs. Coworking spaces need money to be sustainable. Other people should put that money, not the young coworker. People, Universities or the Goberment.

Perhaps there might be an opportunity around professional co-workers sponsoring or subsidising youth members. Or some way for youth to earn their membership by helping facilitate the co-working space (like cleaning, restocking stuff, etc) Looking forward to hearing about others' ideas here.
Sorry for my english! I am from Argentina. In touch.

coworking_spaces.title: Coworking spaces!

purpose_workshops.description: Rather than answering the question "what do you want to be?", purpose workshops help young people to articulate what they want their life to be about.
purpose_workshops.creator: 3cecef35c0cd484c61df0b2829a90be4

comments.text: Where in development process are you today? My son needs this now! Any chance you'd like to prototype test it with group in midwest US? I'm happy to support research end. Katie

Nice to revisit this challenge and see this discussion on purpose vs. job vs. career. I work in the education space and currently partner with Junior Achievement India (www.jaindia.net) to conduct JA workshops in low-cost private schools. The program I focus on is called Careers with a Purpose (CWAP), which is delivered to 9th and 10th standards, and has similar intentions as this winning concept. The CWAP run in India is slightly different than the one run in the states, but here's an outline of the latter for illustration purposes: http://www.ja.org/programs/programs_high_careers_purpose_obj.shtml
Thought folks here might enjoy reading this article from Fast Company on finding your purpose & passion: http://www.fastcompany.com/3001583/fast-exercises-find-your-purpose-and-passion-work
Hello Luc,"What is your contribution going to be?".  I love this question and your whole concept all together.  Once you figure out your purpose you will definitely succeed.

Hi Luc!I love your concept.  I don't think I thought that deeply about my 'purpose' while in high school ;-).  But, I wonder what that experience might have been like had I had an opportunity like the one you've designed here.In any case, I gave some more thought to this challenge and it would be amazing to see these concepts complement each other in some aspect -- as they all already do.If LAB21 grows some wings, a Purpose Workshop would kickstart some wonderful things. so I felt compelled to give a nod to your concept within the LAB21 concept.  Maybe these workshops could also live -- in part -- in a space like it.

Hi Sasha!Thanks for this feedback - I really appreciate it.  I agree that there is real integrative potential between this with LAB21 - an idea which I love, by the way.  A space as the "''innovation bedrock' of communities seeking to support youth as they transition from school to work." - NICE!As for purpose exploration, I would love to see it discussed more - generally.  In homes, in schools, in places like LAB21 - the more the merrier!Cheers,Luc

Really like this idea. I've drawn great value myself from workshops/conferences such as Christopher Howard and Tad James which focus on taking control of your life, figuring out your purpose and how to create plans to reach success. I definitely feel that so many people out there lack a definitive purpose, as well as the necessary skills to realise that purpose. I mean, we never learn that stuff at school, it's just something that one day however old we are we eventually stumble upon and hopefully one day find.Are you thinking of running the workshops as part of the main curriculum for schools, as extra-curriculum of schools, as separate from schools and be like night courses, summer courses, weekend courses etc?For outside of school, inspiration perhaps could be drawn from the free motivational seminars that happened in most major cities a few times a year. Thoughts?

Thinking about it some more... perhaps it could be added as training or extra-curriculum activity for the StartupHostel concept here: http://openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/youthhostel/As those students have already taken the plunge, and could really do with such things to help them discover themselves.

Good morning Benjamin,Sorry it has taken me a while to respond.  I'm really grateful for your feedback and no, we don't really talk about this stuff in school.  In fact, I was talking to my father about his life recently in terms of purpose and contribution.  He said "Nobody has ever had this conversation with me before. You are so lucky someone did with you at your age.".Regarding where it fits curriculum-wise, I would like to see it available as part of a core service in schools.  Whether that takes the form of lunch-time workshop sessions or whether a couple of hours in a term out of main school time is given over to exploring individual purpose, I'm not sure.  I think it's important to make it accessible and easy for students to say "yes" to.  Having it as something which sits outside of the main school day would make it easy to opt out of, especially from those already disengaged from school.  Arguably, they need it the most.  Following those sessions up with one-on-one and online refinement opportunities would, to my thinking, reduce the demand on in-school time required to complete the process but the initial engagement should be part of the school day.There are lots of integrative opportunities with this idea and the Startup Hostel is a great candidate.  I see Sasha has made a comment along those lines with her Lab21 concept, which looks awesome.Thanks again for your feedback and, seeing you are new here, welcome to the OpenIDEO community.  Look forward to reading more of your contributions!Cheers,Luc

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:This concept has proved popular in terms of community applause and comments, presumably because everyone identifies with the frustration of putting your heart and soul into an interview and coming away with little or no feedback!  Given that everyone wil have go through this experience in their career, the panel liked the intention to try and turn it into a valuable learning experience. WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:The panel would you to explore best practice in this area as many employers already have policies about giving feedback that perhaps could be applied more widely.  They are also keen to hear your thoughts on how to balance quality of feedback with demands on the time of the interviewer...For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Sorry I think this feedback was meant for the "Job interviews as learning moments" concept :(

We're so sorry we missed your comment & our slip-up, Luc! Here's the panel feedback, with our apologies:WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED: The comments this concept has already attracted is proof of the appeal of thinking less about what you want to be and more about the kind of contribution you'd like to make.  The panel were refreshed by this new perspective on a perennial question, which reframes an uncertainty as an opportunity for self-discovery. WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED: The judges feel this could be an interesting complement to some of the other concepts, particularly those which focus on events and learning in physical spaces, so would love to see this concept developed further into a slightly more substantial proposition.

Very nice Luc,If you haven't already, I definitely recommend that you read Daniel Pink's book, Drive. Lots of research showing that values ranks well above money etc.http://www.ted.com/talks/dan_pink_on_motivation.htmlhttp://www.danpink.com/driveGood luck!Carole

Thank you Carole!  Very interesting!  I really liked his TED talk and the description of the new operating system - Autonomy, Mastery and Purpose.  Love it.  I read a book years ago written by a couple of Harvard professors who wrote about executive reward structures and how they were used based on the myth that they encouraged good performance when the evidence was that they didn't.  Fascinating points about the effect extrinsic motivators have on focus too!

First post!  Don't tear me up!  :)  I think Joshua's comment about vocation (on June 27th) really adds to this conversation.  I'd like to build on that.THESIS:  A great purpose workshop should focus on the concept of vocation, not career.  This can be done by exposing young people to the works of great thinkers and writers who have struggled with this concept.  The book "Leading Lives that Matter: What We Should Do and Who We Should Be" could be a great start: BACKGROUND: I'm an engineer with a background in business design and social enterprise.  As most first-year MBA students I do quite a bit of thinking about career development and positioning.  Although I'm on the young end for our program, I get the strong impression that I've got a leg up on many of my classmates.  My suspicion is (gasp!) that it has something to do with my undergrad work in the humanities.TOOLS vs. POSTURES: If I had to explain this, I think I would do so by drawing a (somewhat arbitrary) distinction between tools and postures.  Engineering professors are infamous for using the tool metaphor to describe education.  Engineering courses like Computer Aided Design, Experimental Measurement, and Heat Transfer provide students with tools that can be immediately applied to solving real world, quantifiable problems.  Many of my colleagues come from disciplines with very similar characteristics: finance, accounting, physics, graphic design, etc.  Humanities programs do not typically provide pre-packaged, ready-to-use problem solving tools.  I have yet to encounter a problem that can be solved by simply applying Geertz's "The Interpretation of Cultures" or "Kant's Foundations for the Metaphysics of Morals."  But for some reason, these readings seem to have been among the most important and valuable parts of my education.  I think this is because a humanities education, when properly executed, teaches one how to better approach life.  It teaches good posture.CONCLUSION: What I've found:Tools (or Skills) are often what get you the job.  Good postures (curiosity, empathy, thoughtfulness, etc.)  are what make you successful, effective, and happy.Many universities are moving toward teaching only skills.  This is not all bad.  I'm convinced, however, that postures are just as, if not more, important.

Steve - no risk of being torn up - great contribution and thoughts.  Thank you.  I also liked Joshua's calling vs career point.  The differences between the questions "who could I be?" and "what should I do?" is a similar distinction.  In an ideal world the answers are connected and support each other.  The book title you mention made me smile.  A few weeks ago, someone said to a friend of mine "you're really ambitious, aren't you?" and they replied "I am in the sense that I want my life to matter.  I want my time to count."... All of this is what purpose workshops are about - finding an individual's purpose, their calling, a picture of who they want to be in the world as the foundation for planning what they want to *do* and making their time count :-)

I am a newbie to this site and was taken by your concept of purpose workshops. I believe that it may be necessary to drill this down to practical application and to ask specific questions such as :1. How old should the people be to begin this process. While many of us spend a lifetime asking what our purpose in life is, it may be possible to start instilling this at an earlier age. It may be viable to consider asking this question at high school or at university, as individuals will already begin developing a sense of who they are and what they can or cannot achieve.2. Who should lead this? If we are looking at asking this question at high school or university level, the question is who should lead this process? It must be remembered that since there are no right answers, there will have to be some form of guidance to the participants in this process.3. What are the outcomes that we want to achieve by asking the "purpose question". Obviously it is to give the individuals a sense of direction in life, but this must then be matched with what they are exposed to. Some answers may be too wide and will need to be honed in more specifically and live feedback is the only way to do this.4. Once the "purpose question" has been answered, then what? How do we support the purpose that has been identified by the individual? We need to recognise that the purposes can be wide ranging, and if we are asking this question at school level, it may be possible to direct the individual into the courses / training etc that would be relevant. But what if we are asking this question of a student at university who has already signed up for a specific programme without any conception of his / her purpose in life and only discovers this midway, and what he is currently doing is not in tandem with his purpose? Then what?I am in awe of what this concept tries to achieve and believe that, with the right direction and practical application, it is one that can and will change lives, one at a time.The key component however must be to answer the following questions :1. What is the purpose of your life?2. Why is "this" the purpose?3. How can it be achieved?4. When do we ask the question?5. Where can we provide support for the people who have finally identified their purpose?I do hope that these comments are in the direction of your concept and do apologise if I have missed or misunderstood anything.

Hi Santhi and welcome to OpenIDEO.  It's a great example of people coming together from around the world to answer some interesting questions with real-world benefit.Thank you for taking the time to really think about the concept of Purpose Workshops, what it could look like and some of the challenges that might pop up.  It is a very generous contribution - thank you.  I will move through your points in order...1. How old should the people be to begin this process.You know, I actually, think this process could begin quite early - even earlier than high school.  Obviously, there wouldn't be much in the way of answers at that point, and it would need to be framed very differently, but I think it likely that there is a way to get children engaging with the matter of purpose earlier than we think.  e.g. dream sessions - where kids are given permission to dream, share and celebrate them - be courageous about their dreams and stretch their thinking.  A kind of warm-up, if you like :-)  For the purposes of *this* exercise, somewhat arbitrarily, I would pick the age of around about 15 years of age.  The reason for this is that hopefully increased sense of purpose will have the added benefit of improved secondary school retention rates - at the point in their studies this really becomes an issue.  If students are seeing their schooling through the lens of the purpose it will help them realise with their lives, perhaps they will stay engaged longer?  Importantly, a high school implementation also means that we won't only pick up those people who go on to higher education - we want to include people who want to go on to learn a trade or create their own business without going on to uni or polytech.At 15 and older, the participants are also old enough that specialist paediatric development expertise probably won't be necessary, making it simpler to implement.I would be interested in your thoughts on this.2. Who should lead this?Most schools have careers advisors, yes?  Universities and Polytechnics tend to have careers centres too.  Perhaps these people could be trained to deliver in-person sessions with a pool of shared resources - video messages from giants in the corporate sector, non-profit world-changers, successful entrepreneurs, sporting champions - and live online sessions with some of the same?3.  What are the outcomes that we want to achieve by asking the "purpose question".I think it's actually helpful for the purpose to be somewhat general (Mine of "contributing to a world where people dare to hope, dream and act to be everything they can be" is fairly broad) but you're right there needs to be a focus or central idea which serves as the pivot for decision-making.  Essentially, mine is about realising potential - that's the central idea - the ways in which I can manifest that are many and varied.4. Once the "purpose question" has been answered, then what?Great question.  I might build on/incorporate some of the other concepts I have seen posted on here to address this.  How do we support people to take their initial steps to giving life to their purpose?  How much support is appropriate?In terms of what to do if they discover what they are doing is discordant with their desired life purpose?  I have a personal view on that which is that it's better not to throw good money and time after bad... I would say "change what you're doing".  Not always easy and I appreciate that for some with other competing priorities it might be something they have to delay but, ideally, the answer to that question would be about how people can realise a life which is aligned with their purpose - despite earlier decisions which they might have made.I'm very very grateful to you for your questions and contribution.  They are going to help immensely as I refine this concept - and I'm now painfully aware at just how little time I have left!!My thanks and, again, welcome to OpenIDEO.  I think we're lucky to have you on board :-)Luc

Thank you for your detailed reply and your kind words.1. Age to startI absolutely agree with you that the ideal age to do this should be about 15 years. The idea of introducing this to younger children is also great and perhaps we can incorporate this into the curriculum under the civil society or civics or general skills subjects. This will give everyone a chance to build on their dreams and for the dreams to evolve with time.  And of course everyone should be included at age 15 and it should not be limited to people who may pursue higher education. Perhaps this will turn into a wonderful opportunity to give recognition and credit to all forms of productivity and not merely those society regards as 'worthy'. What I think must form an important part of this component is firstly that there should not be any dismissing of professions that the counsellors may feel are not up to the mark. Also background information about each individual is important for perspective eg the parents' occupations so that some sense of identification and connectivity can be made, where relevant, and perhaps role modeling can be linked to this as well where the parent or close relative is the source of inspiration. 2. Who should lead thisYou're absolutely right! It would be wonderful to start small with the counsellors being the initial guides for the students at school and university level.  However expanding it into the groups you have mentioned will make it a truly life defining engagement for these individuals.  You may want to check what The Laureus Foundation is doing specifically in the context of sports : www.laureus.com If achieved to the levels you have mentioned, it will truly make a difference.3. Outcomes of the 'purpose' questionAs you have mentioned, a general outcome will serve well initially although it is, I believe, imperative to ensure that there is proper and sufficient guidance to allow individuals to pare it down to specifics. If I may for example suggest that a 15 year old who sees himself as a rock star in the future may possibly achieve this dream but he will need to attend music lessons that support this dream.I believe the outcomes must not only open the door of opportunity in terms of dreams and goals, but also provide a specific sense of direction which must include equipping the individual with the relevant skills as he goes along. Using your specific example of age 15, if an individual is able to articulate his dreams and goals for the future at this point, someone must be able to point him in the right direction, clearly, logically and honestly. This will truly make your project impactful for every participant.4. Then what?I believe if this project can be incorporated, its evolution will result is early enough intervention to make this question redundant in the longer term, except in exceptional circumstances.Thank you and all the best.

By participating in this process perhaps the students can discover and re-use elements here that they can apply to addressing other complex problems.  It would seem that the steps you are suggesting here may be widely applicable - so not only does the participant walk away with more clarity about themselves, but they may also gain some tangible experience for how to look at challenges in a new way.  Perhaps you could sneak in some design thinking approaches...
Yes Susan, I agree - this way of thinking about things is helpful more broadly when approaching challenges in life.  I'll see what I can do about making that point as part of the concept.  Thank you!

We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Our developers are busy working on it. Meanwhile, if you're wanting to iterate your ideas, you can use the comments feature to promote further conversation from others. We'll let you know once the bug is fixed, then you can incorporate your refinement moves into your concept post. Let's be agile, together!

Right on! Our development team have been busy fixing the Update Entry bug and we're back on track now. You'll now be able to edit your posts to add all that refinement-goodness to build out your concepts for improved impact. Bring it on, together!

Luc - I agree with much of your description of this problem.  You mention below that you would be interested in more of the research of Values Focused Thinking and I would suggest investing some time looking for academic research proving that this change in approach to career development will result in more productive and satisfied employees.  Regardless of how this concept takes shape ultimately (whether through an online workshop or as a campaign by an advocacy group in the education/counseling space or something else entirely), I would argue that it is important to have demonstrated that the concept is successful when applied.  I dug around in both education and psychology, but to no avail.  I am pretty sure that there are success stories, but not sure what the correct terminology may be.  Additionally, I think finding a network of people who are currently thinking about this issue may help you better understand the best course of action to implement your idea.

I think this is a fabulous exercise and something I think people should periodically come back to throughout their careers. You may have heard of the book "What Color is Your Parachute?" I'm reminded of that here. It may be worth looking it's goal (in edition general job tips) is to help readers determine what they enjoy and are great at. There could potentially be a case made to create a book in edition to the workshops that takes youth through the process of figuring out what makes them 'tick' so to speak. This could be something available publicly to those that are unable to attend a physical workshop.

Hi Ami, Thanks for this contribution - I agree.  Perhaps the 'book' could also be a compendium of insights gained throughout the workshops?  Real people putting together their purpose?  Their inspirations, values, realisations, aspirations... It could provide really useful stimulation for others considering their own journeys.Luc

Great concept! I would have loved a workshop like this to give me direction as I faced the daunting task of searching for my first career. What if you also provided some sort of apprenticeship/internship/experience program or recommendation at the end of the workshop? Something similar to the Baushaus Year concept. An avenue for people to test the waters and see if their passions and skill sets are going to align with a specific job will give them even more direction.

Sounds great... lining up career possibilities based on the individual's purpose and then getting to try them out - love it!  There might also be some way to encourage the generation of *new* career/entrepreneurial possibilities - ones that don't exist now, I mean - based on an individual's unique blend of values and skills?

Have you ever heard of Keeney's idea of "Value-Focused Thinking" and how it stands in opposition to Alternative-Based thinking? I think the literature around that might provide the research basis for the Purpose workshops you're talking about.A graphic of a decision-making process that can be broadly applied (say to "what do I do with my life?"):http://www.flickr.com/photos/stevehenderson/3730507379/[Note: Parnell is the more recent researcher who developed the image above in collaboration with others]Here's a longer version explaining VFT: http://classweb.gmu.edu/aloerch/Chapter%2019%20final.pdf

Hi David -  no, I hadn't heard of VFT, so thank you for that.  I've had a look and it's exactly what we're talking about - rather than starting with a set of alternatives (doctor, lawyer, accountant) from which to make a single decision, starting with a set of values and generating a range of new, exciting, values-focused alternatives.  A portfolio decision around what we do with our time is also then made possible.  For example, you might decide that you want your life to be about helping people realise their potential.  In that cause you could own a corporate training company, sit on the board of a non-profit which fights child poverty and help the local school with developing a social media strategy.  All bound together by the idea that your time is contributing to building skills, removing barriers and fostering connectivity **in order to help people realise their potential**.Thanks for this contribution.  I wonder what other research is out there in this space.

I absolutely love this concept. As a college senior, I feel that a workshop like this is exactly what I would need to link my values, aspirations and passions to the job descriptions I read. I'd include exercises both to find out what participants are passionate about and to facilitate the connection between "my passion" and "job descriptions" e.g. on job search engines... we tend to think about jobs in terms of tasks that we would have to do and ask ourselves whether we have the skills, rather than whether we have the passion...as I'm thinking about it, I actually believe that matching young people through careers with this approach - i.e. helping them find their passion, rather than "only" their talent or skills - may in the long run decrease numbers of employees with burnout syndrome, etc. - definitely would increase job satisfaction, I believe. I'd applaud this about a hundred times, if I could!

Thanks Judith! Exactly, I think we generally jump straight to job descriptions without being clear about our passion - and sometimes based on skills that *others* think we have.  So we end up being negotiated into a job by circumstance, rather than directing ourselves based on what lights us up.  Wouldn't it be GREAT if we were able to connect young people with that energy and inspiration that comes from being passionate about what you're doing every day?

Great call, Luc! Looking forward to you and others building upon this brilliant start and teasing out details of what this might look like. For starters  have folks got ideas on some activities that would support your list of workshop topics? Looking forward to hearing more on this one...

Thanks Meena - I mean, it's simple, but it's just not a conversation we seem to have very often.  I found that question "what is your contribution going to be?" quite confronting but also really exciting.  I was speaking with a "grown-up" recently about their life and while they are *doing* some cool stuff, there didn't seem to be any evident purpose sitting behind it all. As my friend observed of me, they were drifting. You know? So I asked them why they do what they do. After a great conversation, they said "You know, nobody has ever had this conversation with me before... You're lucky that someone had it with you at your age". So if we can nurture 'purpose development' early on, I think it might help people frame up career plans which are anchored to what gets them bouncing out of bed in the morning.

Luc, following up on my comment above, I think this is a great concept tacking with an important issue. On the one hand, it's about instilling the right mindset from early on.On the other hand, I think that these workshops will be important. You might want to have versions of them earlier - e.g. in middle schools, then at the end of high schools and maybe later on in the first year of college. The content would be somewhat different but the purpose the same.I can imagine having a mix of hands on exercise as well as talks by / conversations with people presenting their experience and showing how passionate they are and how this is what drove their decisions (rather than purely pragmatic factors like salary, jobs offers, etc.)

Hi Luc, here are a few related concepts that you might want to build upon and that you might find inspiring:http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/enspired-in-30-seconds-website-event/http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/first-semester-open-doors/http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/the-baushaus-year/

Hi Anne-Laure, I completely agree.  The earlier the better, really.  They won't have the answer right away and will probably change their minds along the way, but engaging with the question is the goal.  Discovering one's reason-why and realising its importance early on can only pay dividends.  Yes, the content and delivery style would need to be different for different ages but how exciting would it be to design something cool in this space!  And thanks for the links to other concepts.  The 'enspired in 30 seconds' concept also makes an important point - 5 years ago there was no name for the job the contributor is doing now.  This is another weakness in jobs-based career planning - it doesn't flex to new opportunities.  Being purpose-focused in our career planning enables individuals to be flexible and take advantage of those new opportunities, with a strong sense of their reason-why to guide them as they navigate their way through the world.

Luc, great idea. This reminds me of a question it took me 14 years in the workplace to finally ask myself. What is my vocation vs. my occupation. My "calling" rather than a position I simply want to "occupy". As I wrestled with that question it changed my view on the world around me. It also changed my approach to my life path. I think helping young people answer that about themselves can save years of anxiety, confusion, years of misdirected college loans, etc. It's never to early, or too late, to find your vocation, and begin navigating that particular path which I truly believe leads to great purpose and fulfillment.

Exactly! Cheers to asking the question! I'm interested to hear what you and others think about how this purpose development or calling discovery could be facilitated. How could mobile technology help to have the conversation with young people? Social media? What format could the in-person interactions take, do you think?

I love this concept and I think it touches upon a key element. I don't think it's only about having the right "skills", but being passionate and enthusiastic. If you are passionate, you will take the time and find the energy to learn the skills. I was lucky to always try to do what I wanted to do even if people around me (incl. my parents) were not always convinced by my choices and asked what job I will do. My reply was that I wanted to learn what I really like and that I will always adapt when I need to earn a living. I've been lucky but I also believe being passionate and having fun in what I'm doing has helped me a lot.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

py/tuple: IMPACT & REACH: How much impact and reach do you think this concept could have in helping young people transition into the world of work?
A great deal – something like this would really make a difference
A moderate amount – it’s certainly helpful but probably not a game-changer
Not very much – it’s unlikely to make a significant difference to young people seeking work

FEASIBILITY & RESOURCES: Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible will it be for your community to turn this concept into a reality?  (Hint: when you think about resources, think: people, money, time, technology, infrastructure, partnerships and any other inputs for implementation)
Highly feasible – resources wouldn’t be an issue for my community if we tried to implement this
Moderately feasible – my community could do it if we could get find assistance with some of our resource constraints
Not feasible – it would be almost impossible for my community to implement this concept; it's just too resource-intensive
SUSTAINABILITY & LONGEVITY: Does this concept feel like it could be sustained as a project, business or movement over years rather than just months? Will continue to be relevant in future?
Yes – this concept has enough momentum to stand on its own two feet and remain relevant for years to come
Maybe – it’s not clear how long it would take for this concept to stand on its own feet or how it will continue to be but there’s reason to feel hopeful
No – this concept will have trouble sustaining itself in the long-run and probably won’t be as relevant in years to come
ORIGINALITY: How new or innovative is this idea? Are there many different versions of this concept out there already or is this something more disruptive and unique?
Very original – I’ve not seen anything else quite like it
Fairly original – there are similar things out there but this particular version brings a new element to the table
Unoriginal – there are already too many other concepts out there that are similar to this one
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world
I liked it but preferred others
It didn't get me overly excited

anyon_s_curriculum_of_work.description: Social class affects what and how students are taught.  We should keep this in mind as we assess various techniques for addressing this challenge.
anyon_s_curriculum_of_work.creator: 2c458d9414f7e16627f0206986f44aee

comments.text: I found this very powerful - earlier this week I did a talk and workshop for underprivileged kids and was blown away by their lack of creative thinking...  It was particularly frustrating because may of them seemed very smart indeed

This is an important caution. It is remarkable and discouraging to notice that public school administrators in urban school districts and government policymakers for education often send their own children to private or high quality suburban schools, or their kids have already left school. They do not bear the costs "at home," then, of the policies they adopt for other people's children. Mentoring and internships are also much more available to the privileged and well connected. These young people can better find their own resources and they have better connected people to help them.
