businesses_employ_unpaid_young_people_to.description: An agency giving young people experience of the workplace by allowing teams of students work in industry for 2-3 months spending half their time on a competition of their choice, and the other half on work set by the host company.
businesses_employ_unpaid_young_people_to.creator: d9ebac00ba63f50a8c724e3d1d021354

comments.text: I like this a lot. I think opportunity to prove yourself should be open to everyone and that's not something that has to be monetized on the student's end.

While I like some aspects of this the lack of remuneration for the students is a big turn off for me. It perpetuates the current wealth distribution anomalies and work experience as a substitute for payment is false economy. If employers can't pay for work performed then there is a serious flaw in their business plan.The competition aspect of the proposal is novel and would still work well with paid work experience.I can certainly see the appeal of unpaid internships to certain employers and while this is possible in a market of high unemployment it does them no credit.

Hi Paul and Yasha, thanks for your comments and sorry it has taken so long to get back to you! Unpaid work experience has always been a way of getting young people experienced in the workplace. In fact employers do pay for the work performed - they pay in time and effort teaching young people the skills they need to carry out the tasks, and they pay when they get it wrong. I think the main problem here would be employers taking advantage of the young people. I think the time spent on their own projects already significantly limits this possibility. I suppose there could also be a rating system by young people on employers - much like the national student survey on universities?

Thanks for the reply Oscar.Certainly the problem of exploitation is very real, and present.Conditions and practices vary from place to place and are often cyclical. I guess we may have to agree to disagree on the desirability of unpaid internships, or indeed any form of unpaid work experience.From my personal perspective the fact that someone has less experience and requires some training as part of their employment needs to be adequately factored into the growth aspect of business plans. Anyone contributing the to profitability of a business deserves commensurate remuneration and failure to recognise monetary value in work performed becomes, de facto, exploitation. The 'occupy wall street' phenomenon presages changes in social structure that will see a movement in the cycle of this aspect of employment.

Hi, OscarThanks for the great idea. I can foresee the impact and reach of this idea if it can be implemented successfully, as we can see there's a market of demand and supply for young people's work. However, there are probably three aspects I need more clarification: 1. What will be the motivation for firms to participate? It takes time and energy to manage and train those interns. And companies need to consider issues related to information confidentiality and so on. 2. Will some companies abuse this power and make interns do some repeated labor work instead of teaching them new things? Then this kind of experience is just a company name we can show in resumes. 3. How can we manage those companies and make it a sustainable system? Will we hire staff to contact and manage relationship  with them? Thanks!

Hi Maggie,As you say, there is a lot of demand for young people's work, especially if it is cheap and they have a fair amount of experience! - I think employers would appreciate the ability to actively choose their interns dependant on experience and personality. In addition, small firms would love to have flexible 'on demand' project teams which they can draw on as and when they workflow suits - especially in a recession, when small companies have a hugely fluctuating workload.In many ways the admin has been taken off their hands. Contracts can be pre-determined by the agency, all the employers have to do is log on and choose some interns. No more searching through hundreds of out of date CVs. As young people are also taking part in competitions, we could consider asking them to display a 'sponsored by' badge on any submissions - so employers get some credit for their input. - I absolutely agree about confidentiality and training. It has to be asked whether employers are going to wish to invest in these young people if they are only there for a short period, which leads onto your second point about employers exploiting the young people for repetitive labour.  As I as mentioned to Paul below, I think a rating system would be very helpful. The young people are encouraged to rate the quality of experience they got from the employer. This will be shown on their profile, and so under performing firms will find it hard to get good young people to accept their offers of experience in the future. Firms that perform well could be given an accreditation which they can display on their website etc, like an ebay 'power user' in some ways I suppose.  - With regard to your third point, there would certainly need to be manpower to administrate the running of the scheme. This could be paid for by charging employers a small fee to hire teams, to become a featured employer (creating a more prominent profile, encouraging greater interest from young people) or advertising (would a large company sponsor the entire scheme, for example Barclay's Youth Excellence Scheme?).I hope this answers some of your questions and I'd love to hear thoughts!

In an effort to get an industry perspective and further develop Lydia, Brandon and my own ideas, I run an early version of the concept by a small local Architectural firm. This is a rough transcript of the conversation followed by some ideas I think we can take forward from it. Please do comment your thoughts so we can all improve and refine this concept!Conversation with Inspiration Architects, Berkshire:Ozzy: [Explains concept]Brian: So who enters the competition, the students or the companies?Ozzy: The companies would enter the competition, and recruit the help of a group of students.Brian: So the students are basically doing an unpaid internship?Ozzy: Yes they are. The reason behind including a competition element is to encourage companies without much work to take on interns by creating work for the young people to be doing.  Then hopefully the companies wouldnt miss out on the benefits of the scheme, like publicity, a group of forward looking, skilled young people to provide a fresh perspective on projects and manpower to help with the day to day running of the business.Brian: I think you should consider what your idea actually is. What are you going to set up? Is it an agency who companies can contact and are given a team of young people? Should student approach them as a team and ask? Or guidelines to employ interns?Oscar: Yes, there could be an online agency side to it. I think its important for the young people that they have an opportunity to contact businesses themselves, so I had always imagined that individuals would search on a website for local accredited companies and then contact them personally. Accreditation for the company would come as a part of being involved.Brian: Im not really sure what youre accrediting, what is the difference between going through the website and doing it off your own back? Maybe the website could be a networking portal between students to find other people who want to participate in the competition. The new group can then approach companies and ask for them for sponsorship. This sponsorship would comprise of a workplace working environment and the company banner to compete under for example. By going through the website student know they are going to get a good deal from companies and not get exploited. The payback for a company is an on demand, flexible workforce. Oscar: So, as an employer, would you be interested in getting accredited and being able to employ a group of people from a dedicated website?Brian: Yes I would. The difficult thing for us at the moment is finding skilled people when you want them.  As a small company in a really tough time for Architecture, our workload is fluctuating constantly. We need a flexible workforce of skilled people. Short term, flexible and free work is a very attractive idea, especially if I can go to a website, see the students who are looking for places, see their experience and skill level and choose who I want. Oscar: Do you not get offers of free work from students at the moment? Brian: Yes, from individuals every now and again. Oscar: In that case, couldnt you just employ them without the hassle of the website?Brian: Well they all want different lengths of contract, are individuals so cant be put in a team for a project and probably wont be available at the time we get a big job through the door. Id want to hire who I want, on demand. Oscar: Would the competition element be a hindrance then?Brian: I see the competition as slightly peripheral from my point of view. But maybe the website can offer suggestions to employers as to how best they can use the 50% of time they get when the students arent doing competition work. Also, who is paying for this?Oscar: I was thinking that large companies could sponsor the competitions that students spend 50% of their time on, so effectively outsource a project to the web of students and accredited companies. They would pay a fee for the privilege and in return get advertising, experience from countless students and professionals and rights to use the resulting ideas.Brian: Well I dont think theyd need to do it. Companies were doing competitions like this all the time in Architecture and basically ripped people off for their ideas  so much so the RIBA had to publish competition guidelines. Rather than pay to get a bunch of students to come up with ideas, they could call up industry press and get it publicised for free to working professionals.Could the website trall the Internet for running competitions and then accredit them if they are within guidelines? Students could spend 50% of their time doing those. Oscar: Definitely. That is actually very similar to another idea that a different openIDEA member had for this project.Oscar: So a student agency like the one we have just discussed would be attractive to you as an employer?Brian: Yes it would.

A couple of thoughts:1: A service for the provision of short term, on demand workforces of skilled young people might be in demand. 2: Individuals use a site as a networking base then approach accredited companies asking them to 'sponsor' the group to compete in a chosen competition. Young people get a set of specific sponsorship benefits (a workplace, advice, 50% of their work time spent working in industry, resources and rights to their ideas).3: Companies search for interns. As above but the businesses can also ask specific individuals or groups to receive their sponsorship based on their skills, experience and group size. The business benefits from a free, skilled and most importantly on-demand workforce that spends 50% of it's time working for the company.A site that seems allow companies to actually choose interns is http://www.urbaninterns.com - do you think that businesses would be put off by young people interning as groups and working on personally chosen competitions for 50% of the time, or would the like the idea of having their name on a competition entry for free?In addition, the thing that differentiates this idea from urbaninterns is the assurance of standardised and fair terms for both parties, the safety of a group dynamic for those who are apprehensive of the workplace and a competition element to give young people time to focus on what really interests them while getting them used to a working environment. As a uni student myself I couldn't think of a better deal - the resources and experience of a company teamed with 50% of my time on a competition sounds like a deal too good to be missed! What do you think? Do businesses have enough of an incentive to get involved?
Nice one on reaching out to Inspiration Architects & including a transcript here. Amazing to see how ideas grow  OpenIDEO-style!

I think you need to figure out a legal construction to avoid that it indirectly turns into 2-3 month competition to win a job.Companies can't get away with not hiring the winners of such a competition. It would be like saying: 'hey, you're very talented but we're not gonna hire you'. This is not good for the company image. So if you think about it, only companies with sufficient budget to hire will participate in these projects... which makes it a job competition again. You need to think of a legal construction that protects the young participants.What  if half your teams find a job halfway during the project? You need to think of something that oblies the team members to commit to the project.

Hi Miguel, thank you very much for your suggestions! Inevitably there will be a job hunting element to any group work experience scheme, but I agree that the concept is currently too open for employers to take advantage and 'trial run' employees without any obligation. I agree without a doubt that contracts should be exchanged between the company and young people to agree the terms before work starts. Do you think that contract should be managed by the central body or on an individual basis? I.e. should young people (and companies) be guaranteed a good and regulated deal by signing up to the scheme, or should it be up to the companies and students to agree their own terms? I'm now posting a conversation I had with a local company which does actually cover this issue slightly. They didn't seem to have much of a problem hiring people for the short term and letting them go at the end. In fact that seemed to suit their needs quite well, so hopefully small companies wouldn't be put off with an obligation to hire. Have a look and let me know what you think!

Hi Oscar Congratulations on getting selected for refinement! Your concept has two components to tackle in order to be successful: the student / learner side (how do we attract students?) and the business side (how do we get businesses to hire students?). You definitely have the largest risk on the business side and that is what the expert panel wanted you to explore more deeply. Therefore, I think the biggest challenge is how do you make it a valuable proposition to the business to take on your concept compared to whats out there. Will business want to participate in competitions as well as hire students?What if you offered student services to solve real problems companies have vs. having companies compete against each other. Perhaps you could gather more interest in something that has direct benefits to real company problems. For example, there are multi-disciplinary projects that MBA programs offer their students as a perk and as well as a service to businesses in the community.  These types of programs are designed to give students real-world experience while extending the MBA programs reach into the professional community.For example, here is some marketing literature for how Ross Business Schools program works:http://www.bus.umich.edu/MAP/Dev/WhatisMAP.htmYoull noticed after reviewing it, Ross sells their programs to companies by offering the following benefits:1) (Access to Human Capital) Access to top-notch findings and recommendations from MBA students who have diverse skills, knowledge, backgrounds, and work experience2) (Minimal Cost) Minimal cost for the sponsoring organization; these solutions come at a fraction of the cost of a paid consultant3) (Access to Tools & Process) Access to analytical tools and methods that are often not available within sponsoring organizationsTherefore, how can we differentiate this particular concept program that youre proposing and make it enticing to businesses? It seems like we wouldnt want to compete in a similar space - therefore, the following questions come to mind:Are there certain segments of students who have valuable skills that organizations could use, but arent currently being used? Is there a way to use technology to make interfacing with students and businesses easier?How could we reduce the ways that it would cost employers to use our concept?How can we make it valuable to the business (i.e solving problems they actually have vs. what the central body think they have)?CHARACTERISTICS OF SOLUTION:Type of skill offered (purely analytical (A), highly creative (C))Technology Interface (little to none/in person (N), internet based (I))Company Overwatch (hands off (HO), hand-held (HH))Project Choice (business-driven (BD), central body driven(CB))Student Selection (open (O), highly selective (HS))Hire Criteria (project based (PrB), position based (PosB))You can see what happens when you brainstorm across these various spectrums (link to my sketch) SCENARIOS:http://www.slideshare.net/bmcnamara/feedback-open-ideo-challenge-helping-young-people-workScenario #1: Focusing solely on analytical students, this solution would be a high touch, in-person experience. Students would be directed through the experience on a business driven project based on a need theyve pre-determined. To be hired, students will be required to fit the project based requirement. To be considered, youll have to pass a highly selective criteria established to only filter through students who are serious to committing to this work as well as making previous history of accomplishments. Scenario #2: Focusing more both analytic and creative students. this solution would be some technology based as well as in-person consultation. Students would be largely self-directed, with minimal inputs required by the business. A central body would identify types of competitions and then find companies interested in participating. Students would be filled based on a position versus a project/competition based requirement. Scenario #3: Focusing solely on creative / arts background students, this solution would be internet driven and high interaction / instruction on the organization hiring the student. Organizations would determine what type of projects / positions they would need to be filled and the competition they are interested in participating in. Rather than focusing on a particular project need - the student would be hired based on a position theyd like to grow into. Theyd be able to shadow that individual at the company who is a professional. POTENTIAL CONCEPT: Thinking through these scenarios brought to mind a new concept, its a blend of the OpenIDEO / 99Designs concept:1) A company sets up a challenge or problem that they are facing. the give all the background information required to get started as well as keeping open a Q&A section to answer as many student questions as possible. A challenge has a fixed time schedule. 2) Students can apply to work on these challenges based on their interest/background. Using their LinkedIn profile, the students signal that they are working on the challenge and can arrange with other individuals.3) Companies rate and select the winner / winning team. They are then contracted to implement / continue working on the project for 4) Seems like there are benefits to all groups:Winning Students get real work experience which can be leveraged for future opportunitiesNon-winning students have a portfolio and as well as a certificate of completion which can be used for signaling to future employers of their skills. They can show that they worked on the UPS Challenge or the Google Challenge and list that as experience in their profile. Companies get real problems they have potentially solvedHOW DO YOU DO IT?1. Go where companies are already established and can reduce the search cost for finding talent (i.e. LinkedIn). 2. Make it a requirement that all students sign up with Linkedin, this lowers the search cost for companies who are reviewing what students they want to hire.3. How can we lower the cost of hiring? What if you hired the students? Allow the companies to contract with your concept vs. being required to hire the students. Its easier to hire a contractor vs. hire a full time employee. Perhaps you do this as a non-profit?4. Create tiny barriers to filter out students who arent serious about gaining experience. Free work can attract students who might not be 100% committed to the experience. Create small filtering criteria (i.e answering a few small questions, having them write what they hope to learn and how they would apply this to future work, ect.)

Hi Brandon, thank you so much for this comment and sorry it has taken a while to write you a reply!I absolutely agree that there is too much risk for not enough reward on the business side. As this is something both you and the openIDEO expert panel commented on, I have spoken to the director of small architectural firm to get some ideas. I will post the transcript of the conversation along with some points I think are important to note right after this comment.On the back of this extra information, I think you made a really insightful comment about turning the process around so that it's companies who look for the students. It seems that the ability for students to display their skills and experience in one place (whether through linkedIN or another specialist site) would be really valuable for companies. They could, in essence, pick and choose

the students they want to hire based on experience and skill base. I love your range of scenarios, and would tend toward the second. Joining this idea with Lydia's, maybe an individual could sign up to a site (integrated with linkedIN?) and upload their experience / interests. They are then given a range of accredited *external* competitions to choose from. Companies also sign up to the site, upload information about themselves and how many people they wish to employ (or sub-contract) at that time. Then, it is up to both parties to make it happen. Young people apply as an individual or a group to companies. By using the website, young people are guaranteed a workplace, advice and 50% of their time to be spent on the competition they have chosen. The other 50% would be on anything the company needs at the time. On the other hand, businesses can also search for young people. They can see how large the group is and what experience they have before actually asking the young people to come and work for them. The benefit for them is a flexible, free and temporary semi-skilled workforce that spend 50% of their time helping the company with whatever they need doing. Take a look at the transcript and resulting insights to see the reasons for this idea, and thank again for the time you spent on these suggestions, I'm still working through all your ideas!

We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Our developers are busy working on it. Meanwhile, if you're wanting to iterate your ideas, you can use the comments feature to promote further conversation from others. We'll let you know once the bug is fixed, then you can incorporate your refinement moves into your concept post. Let's be agile, together!

Right on! Our development team have been busy fixing the Update Entry bug and we're back on track now. You'll now be able to edit your posts to add all that refinement-goodness to build out your concepts for improved impact. Bring it on, together!
Perfect, thank you!

I don't seem to be able to update the original post, and support haven't got back to me so I'll post the next iteration here for feedback while the issue is sorted, which has mainly just added clarity and incorporated suggestions from the community:Large companies sponsor a challenge to be set by a centralised body. Then, accredited businesses will employ a team of 4-6 unpaid young people to compete in the competition on their behalf. The young people must be out of work and local to the area, which will put a small company on an equal footing with a large international corporation. Challenges would last around 2-3 months ensuring plenty of young people get an opportunity to be involved, there is no large investment in a single person, and businesses can discover the range of talented young people in their locality.The concept is self sustaining, and mutually beneficial for all those participating. Benefits for the key parties include:Sponsors - An opportunity to outsource a project or brief to the web of accredited companies- Advertising- An award or sponsor accreditation- Ownership of resulting ideasBusinesses - Accreditation- Access to talented young people to consider for future employment- An award if their team wins- More semi-skilled people in the office, yard or garage to help with the day to day running of a business (especially important for small companies)Young People -  Experience of the workplace (and all that goes with it) which is not intimidating and does not take them away from full time job hunting.-  Encouragement and experience in the industry they are interested in-  Contacts-  Access to a wealth of knowledge and advice from professionals in their chosen fieldThis scheme enourages young people to use their free time to participate in competitions that will further their understanding of a specific industry and give them the oppertunity to experience the work place in a non threatening way, due to the nature of small, similar aged teams.

Good on you for proactively soldiering on in the face of not being able to update your post, Oscar! Our development team are working on it but it's unclear just now how long it will take. I'll be sure to let you know once things are sorted.

Thanks Meena, it's not a problem. And can certainly be forgiven considering the site is still in beta! If someone sends me an email when it's fixed I'll go through and add the revisions to my original post.

Hi Oscar and congratulations on being shortlisted!  I realise this build is slightly different to your initial concept but I wondered if there was an opportunity to accredit *existing* competitions and work experience programmes rather than necessarily creating a new one?In the UK at least, it seems there is no shortage of competitions or projects for young people to get involved with (lots of charities, businesses and government agencies run them) but the issue is knowing which ones are well run or not.  So rather than setting up the infrastructure for a new kind of competition, perhaps there's a need to accredit existing ones so young people get a sense of which ones meet a certain standard?....Criteria might include:Whether you get to be part of a team or work as an individual?Whether there's any financial incentive to take part?Whether or not basic costs will be covered?Whether there will be regular feedback and mentoring?Anyway, this is just an idea, but if you could create some kind of Gold Standard for great competitions and work experience schemes that was independently judged and allowed young people to compare like with like, I think that could be really valuable.Anyway, just a thought and congratulations again!

Thank you Lydia! Yes, that's a really interesting idea and certainly one which would require less of an infrastructure investment at the outset. Investors in People is relevant although slightly different, and giving an accreditation to participating companies would certainly be an incentive to get involved. A downside might be that you can't regulate team size, investment from host companies or project briefs but the criteria you suggest would certainly help keep accredited competitions broadly the same.I would suggest that creating a new competition structure is helpful in two ways. Firstly and most importantly, competition criteria can be regulated to keep the scheme as helpful and relevant to the young people as possible (team size, project briefs, turnaround time etc). Projects can also be created for industries that don't currently have the myriad of competition options currently open to designers, for example the construction or banking industries (teams could be asked to build an earthquake resistant prototype house or get the biggest return on a small investment respectively). Secondly, with the large network of accredited companies (I love the accreditation idea!) linked into the brand, large firms may well pay money to sponsor briefs. This would provide money to run the website and pay those running it.  A 'Gold Standard' as you suggest would certainly be helpful, especially if an online resource allows you to find schemes in your area. I think in some ways the strength of the concept is that anyone, no matter what industry they want to go into, gets an equal chance to experience a little bit of their chosen career, and the short turnaround time (2-3 months?) means it is not a huge commitment that restricts job hunting. I think your suggestion would be a fantastic way to assess the extent of opportunities young people have, and should we feel that we could provide them something more we can build on the site and brand already established.

Great thoughts, Oscar  be sure to incorporate new thoughts of feedback from others that you're keen on into your actual concept post to acknowledge your idea is evolving. Looking forward to seeing where things go!

When I can get the publish button to work ('oops, something went wrong with our server'?), I have made some improvements to the concept which include your accreditation idea Lydia. It was also mentioned in the OpenIDEO post below so would be worth pursuing I think. I am also working on some visuals to help others grasp the concept. Alongside this I have been thinking about an initial brand name for the accreditation body, something people can latch onto. Does anyone have ideas for this? I was thinking along the lines of 'Investors in future', 'Founders of the future' or something else that would look great on a participating company's letterhead and isn't as cheesy as my suggestions! Words like inspire, empower, encourage and invest might be helpful.I'll also be running the concept by a couple of local companies in the next two or three days to find out if they would be interested in a scheme like this.

Great to hear you're refining your idea Oscar. If you're still having problems with the publish button, get in touch with our helpdesk by hitting the Support tab on the right side of page. (the helpdesk is monitored from the US so you'll usually hear back during their weekdays) And fantastic that you'll be contacting local companies to help iterate your concept  way to go!
Oops! The Support tab is on the left, not the right (sometimes I get things upside down & inside out from down here in New Zealand!

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:This feels like a good, feasible way to get young people engaged in something constructive which will boost their motivation but without taking them away from other things like job searches etc.  It also gives young people experience of contacting businesses which is statistically proven to increase their chances of employability, plus it enables companies to see a broader spectrum of the young talent that's out there.  WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:How are you going to sell this to businesses - i.e. how will you make them see that they need to offer more structured work experience?  Does this need some kind of accreditation scheme alongside it so that it's not just another work experience initiative? How will you strike the right balance so that young people get enough out of it but it doesn't go on for so long that it raises concerns about exploiting unpaid labour? Finally, we'd like to see a bit more detail about the types of competitions that you're proposing to run...For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Great, thank you! Really looking forward to improving and refining the concept with everyone's suggestions!
Interesting Oscar. Might be worth folks thinking about how companies might be incentivised to commit time and resources to an initiative like this. Lookging forward to hearing what you come up with!

ORIGINALITY: How new or innovative is this idea? Are there many different versions of this concept out there already or is this something more disruptive and unique?

Fairly original – there are similar things out there but this particular version brings a new element to the table
Unoriginal – there are already too many other concepts out there that are similar to this one
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world
I liked it but preferred others
It didn't get me overly excited

kids_meet_your_greatest_teacher_failure..description: Deep in our primal brain we are taught NOT to fail. Often in school there are direct consequences to exploration and failure. Incorporate principles of choreographed energy & failure in the beginning students would be much more prepared for reality.

comments.text: Hi Lyden - this morning I read DJ Patil's Commencement Address - it reminded me of your inspiration.  You can see it here:http://www.fastcompany.com/1839432/dj-patils-crowdsourced-commencement-address-topic-utter-failure

This is really interesting - I like the idea of allowing failure as it helps people feel confident about taking well thought through risks and to do things they really love...A build on this - I read this by George Lois in his book Damn Good Advice: "you can never learn anything from a mistake". His point is that you will mess up occasionally, nobody is perfect. But don't let it phase you - onward and upwards...

This is a great inspiration and initiative Lyden.As Meena says - failure has featured in many challenges - and you have restated it well in the context of this one.I can see a couple of concepts arising out of what you and a few others have written.
Thank you for sharing this idea - Ill definitely try the failchart.

Nice one Lyden. Failure has certainly been a big theme on OpenIDEO  in fact on our recent challenge this concept celebrating failure was selected as a winner: http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/ted-positive-sharing-failure/ We're excited to see where you might take this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post it again there too  and meanwhile you might like to check out the Feed Your Idea section here: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire Hoping to see more of you on OpenIDEO.

femtec_promoting_talents.description: Promoting female talents with engineering background in order to bring engineering companies and female talents together and to build a network.
femtec_promoting_talents.creator: 8082a75025cb51e513aff379783121c9

comments.text: WOW. Didnt really think about it but in my last job I worked mainly with engineers. ALL 40 year old MEN.The world is missing out on half the creative insight that it could be having. Women really just dont have that strong of a voice in engineering.Think of what types of innovations could come to life if there were a push to drive female talent in this sector. What a great program that identifies an opportunity.

I really like this idea. We're definately missing a trick not encouraging more women into STEM careers from an early age. We're skipping over a massive pool of potential!...I wonder though whether this same encouragment needs to happen a lot earlier in the lives of girls too? Although as women we're aware we have the knowledge and skills to enter science and tech careers with equal success to that of men, STEM careers are sometimes not presented as favourably or explicitly as they are for boys. We need to get away from gendering work so children, before they even develop into young poeple, feel confident enough to gain the skills necessary to succeed in any field. Really interesting stuff.

I really like your comment about getting away from gendering work. Femtec as programs for different ages: there is a "Try IT" and a "Talent Take Off" Program for high school students. The "Careerbuilding" Program is for university students then. And they also have programs for young professionals. There is the idea of starting early.I like, that they opened the program for high school students for boys. This is a first step to get away from gendering the STEM career path. But in my opinion, there is still a lot of work to do in the field of gender and STEM careers.
Wow, sounds like an interesting program. Very useful, and I like that they apparently start at a relatively early age.Great share.

openideo_my_unemployment.description: Last September, for the Amnesty unlawful detention challenge, I wrote about feeling powerless in my unsuccessful job search. Now I'm gainfully employed and it seems like everyone is looking for talented new people. Where is the disconnect?
openideo_my_unemployment.creator: 7905b5813c35371a21bcc668945f61d5

comments.text: Congratulations - we have shared your story among the whole OpenIDEO team as a reminder of why we're all doing this!  Thank You
Yes, and I think platforms like OpenIDEO help overcome some of the isolation that accompanies unemployment, and helps maintain energy and motivation.

I like this because we all have to find the motivation to use our skills even between jobs. Other people may have self-motivated side projects, but I find it hard to design without a real world problem that matters to other people. OpenIDEO is great for that. And it's a way to feel a little better in very difficult circumstances.

Great to hear you found a job! I remember your story. And I think in some ways, platforms like OpenIDEO can help people in skill development (and showing them off). On top of that, there's a lot one can learn from all the great contributions here, and working together on concepts.Thanks for sharing.

Well related Alex!There are several tensions in the job market - skills vs experience, mobility vs stability, various forms of discrimination, lack of loyalty on both sides - do you know how your original employer's business is travelling? Your experience would seem to illustrate how important are the so-called 'soft' skills, not just for potential employees but also employers.
Congrats and thanks for sharing!

youthhostel.description:
Work at StartupHostel. A hostel entirely run by young people for young people. 

Join or kick-off a start-up at your local hostel. Join or host a class.

StartupHostel is both for the globetrotter and for the entrepreneur.

Make it yours!
youthhostel.creator: 4f33f60372e6bc655f12fa6964b669da

comments.text: Exciting news! Our website is now up at http://startuphostel.org and we'll be opening doors to the hostel soon! :) Register your interest on the website, and we'll get in touch! :D
Simon - very cool concept.  Is there a blog or something I can read to keep up with your progress?  I filled out the survey to get on your mailing list.

For all those interested in seeing StartupHostel coming to live, please help respond to this survey:https://bevry.wufoo.eu/forms/startup-hostel-survey/If you know of someone who might be interested, please share the link with them as well.Spread the word.Thank you.

Wow. Thank you for the all the contributions, feedback and obviously the recognition. It is incredible inspiring and overwhelming.Now, let's turn the concept into action. Anyone keen to help out, join, participate please send Benjamin an email at join@startuphostel.org.Simon
Congrats Simon and everyone that help you develop the idea even further! Well done... I am sending Benjamin and email if you need some extra help!
Whoops, email wasn't working for a bit. All fixed now :)

For all those interested, we've got a basecamp project going with the key players participating. If you're keen to join, shoot me an email at join@startuphostel.org and we'll get you onboard so we can all work together to make this a reality even sooner! :)Our current task is sorting out a survey that we'll send off to interested guests to gather necessary feedback, as well as building our foundations and networks to make this a reality.

Way to go Simon! And if there's an online platform, as you suggest, I imagine it could also collect, share and celebrate stories of youth going on from being part of YouthHostel to succeeding in the wider world of work.

I will be honest. My initial idea mostly focused on the physical experience, but you are absolutely right. The online platform will perform a critical role here.Some thoughts for how it might work. It needs to:1. Create awareness2. Support the screening/interview process (assuming there will be many candidates)3. Allow guests to book stays at the hostels4. Allow YouthHostel members to communicate with each other and the surrounding community (pictures, stories, cases studies, biographies)5. Be the individual YouthHostel member's diary (points, goals, feedback)6. Lower the barriers to entry in the sense that it needs to feel welcoming to people who might not be obvious candidates. They need to feel secure enough to try it out.The more I think about it, the more important the online platform becomes. Potential and current members need to feel that they can relate to the stories and experiences. It needs to speak to their desires to travel the world and see things they would otherwise not have the opportunity to experience.I would love to get some input and thoughts on this before I take a stab at integrating into the overall concept.
Sounds great! And perhaps the site could profile a featured member each month  a bit like we do with our Featured Ideator series: http://bit.ly/oi_featured
Love the idea. We run two Hacker Hostels in Atlanta. I would be more than happy to dedicate development resources to you. check s out at hacker-hostel.com

Hi Simon,Just to let you know, I will be introducing 'Startup Hostel' to our panel of judges this afternoon!  I'm really excited to be introducing your concept because it's one of my personal favourites, so I'll do my best to represent it well, especially given all the nuance and iterations you've packed into it!  We'll be announcing our winners next week but, if you're one of them, we'll be in touch beforehand to let you know.  In the meantime, I wish you luck and I'll do my very best to present your concept in the best possible light!Best wishes,Lydia
Thank you. I feel honored. It was very exciting to follow the tweets yesterday. I would have loved to see the discussion in the room. Simon

Hello Startup Hostil! I've been trying to contact this company on a few sites such as Founders2Be after learning more about the concept. Those may be inactive posts and as I can see, this is the most active thread so far. I am a graphic designer and I am extremely interested in the start-up you have created and would love to join the project! I'd love to show you my talents and my portfolio of start-ups I have worked with in the past. Due to them not reaching the funding stage, sadly they have dissolved and i'm yet again looking for a new project! Please let me know if you need another member for your team; I have extensive experience in designing logos / brands / pitch decks / mock-ups / etc., and have great knowledge in marketing and advertising!I'll create a few mock-up logos for startup hostil for if we do meet but feel free to add and contact me on skype by searching my name: Derick ManlapegBest, Derick
Hi Derick,Welcome onboard. So far it is 'just' a concept that hopefully can/will take off. Please do share your ideas for how it can be improved.
AWESOME! Hi Simon, it's great how your concept has evolved! The business model part I like best. I'm beginning to wish I had had such a springboard at that time. Congrats!
Hi Carmen,thanks for the feedback. It has been really interesting so far.

Awesome, just discovered http://www.projectgetaway.com/ which has been doing something similar for the past 2 years and just starting it's 3rd year. The idea of that is a one month getaway to bali, without the trainings or work opportunities - so some big differences, but they would have already got the network, business, and facilities sorted :)

For the training aspect of things, partnerships could be formed with things like the Lab21 concept and things like General Assembly - http://generalassemb.ly/ - as they are dedicated to that aspect of things.

Looking at the evaluation criteria for a previous challenge where a concept was helping hackathons form and be organised - http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/hackathons-and-user-groups/ - I'll address possible evaluation criteria here.## How well does this concept address a significant pain point?The biggest pain point this addresses in lack of meaningful and inspiring work for generation Y and Xers. Now, more than ever people know aren't buying the work 9-5 til you die regime, instead they just feel dead and bored at work. But surprisingly, a lot of people will use their nights working on things they do care about, and often for free. Which leaves them in a tough financial situation. You work on things together that you don't care about to pay the bills, and work on the things you do care about alone for free. StartupHostel flips this. Having StartupHostels based in 3rd world countries guests can keep their costs down to barely nothing, providing them with the opportunities to travel and collaborate on the things they care about, while learning highly demanded skills that they can take with them anywhere. They may even form their own profitable companies together at the hostels! the other pain point StartupHostel solves is for businesses as there is a serious lack of highly skilled and motivated people available for employment, and when they do exist, they are often working on their own things! StartupHostel helps businesses in this way by hooking them up with guests that need work. Great resources on this:- http://chill.com/balupton/post/5fa8600c2bf7486aa9fd1dfbbdc0df84/rsa-animate-drive-the-surprising-truth-about-what-motivates-us?source=%2Fbalupton%2Fcollection%2Fstartup-hostel&feature=brick about how people are working for free on what they care about- http://techcrunch.com/2012/09/01/solving-the-developer-deficit-in-the-cloud/ about the lack of talented devs for hire## How novel do you think the concept is?There are plenty of things like the StartupHostel - https://github.com/bevry/startup-hostel/wiki/Comparison - however they are all either schools, trainings, or holidays and all for a fixed period of time. StartupHostel is the first to be all year round. And when mixed with multiple locations, work opportunities, recruitment, hackathons, and facility hire for events - we got a winning combination for guests, businesses and hostels. I am unaware of anything that solves providing a home and opportunities to the passionate doers of the world even remotely as well as StartupHostel does.## How easy is this concept to implement and maintain?It will be rather straightforward to put together, providing a dedicated team can afford to live for a few months and do the initial legwork fulltime. After that, revenue opportunities should allow it to be self financed. That initial stretch is the hardest bit as there are so many pieces that have to come together.## What type of organisation is best placed to take this forward?I would say that a standard company with the assistance of local governments, non-profits, startups, businesses etc. However, I don't see why others couldn't work too, just that standard company is easiest and most straightforward.## Overall, how do you feel about this concept?Honestly, it rocks my world. I can't wait to team up with a whole bunch of people and turn this into a reality. Having personally been through the pain that this would solve, I can't wait to free others from that pain and empower them with new amazing opportunities. I want to close the gap between beginner and expert, and provide a home and opportunities for the passionate doers of the world.

Dude. I've been in the process of setting up a Startup Hostel for the past two years!!! Here is my plan on it: https://github.com/bevry/startup-hostel/wikiIn fact, I recently stopped my consulting work to focus on this and my other ventures full time, and I've been scouting locations some more the past few days and even purchased the domain names yesterday. Only came across this through your tweet while setting up the helpdesk accounts for my company.So I'd love to have a chat and see how much we can merge our visions together!!! :) You can email hostel@bevry.me or skype balupton :)
Hi Benjamin. That's fantastic. I checked out your site, and there are quite some synergies.Let's connect and see what we can come up with.

Benjamin and I skyped earlier today and managed to share our ideas and visions before the deadline.What I took away was a validation that there is a real need for something like this.We updated the business model part of the concept (I have left the original version on the Business Model Canvas in place as part of the submission).Benjamin also shared some of his thoughts and inspiration for StartupHostel.http://chill.com/balupton/collection/startup-hostelBenjamin has also provided a much better illustration for the concept.Benjamin already has a group of people interested in doing this, so he will try to get as many of those in as part of the evaluation phase to assess the concept in its current shape.I hope we can get this up and running.Exciting.

From experience working with some of the folks on this team with a similar model (startup workaway) I know this kind of thing is possible and a successful idea. I will definitely be an active guest at startup hostels!

Hi Simon, In the implementation of classes what if you partner up with Skillshare.com?   They are working closely with the StartUp community and they can help you spread the word and use the StartUp Hostel as a classroom facility for other classes teach at Skillshare.com. They are based in NYC and I am waiting to get an appointment with them also for Open Bus.
Hi Swany.That is a great idea. Thanks.

Thanks everyone for all the feedback to the concept. It has been really interesting to work with.I have updated with a new visualisation of the online platform front page (I have proudly used a few of the collaborators as featured startuphostel members).I also added some thoughts on implementation/next steps.

Some thoughts on the implementation of the concept.As much as I would love to go big on the concept and setup fully fletched StartupHostels around the world, the concept is in much need of a reality check.Therefore the best would be to try and get commitment from one or two international hostels, and simple act out the idea for a few days in order to come up with a first workable prototype that could be implemented for real.There would be no initial investment required from the hostel associations except time. If it works, their existing network, resources etc. would again probably be the best starting point.Assuming the concept is sustainable after some time it can either be spun off as a stand alone chain of hostels or simply remain with the hostel association's portfolio.Thoughts on implementation are much appreciated.

Hi Simon, I'm Head of Volunteering at YHA, just seen your tweet.. happy to talk this through with you.  Would need other organisations around the world to get involved, have you approach Hostelling International?
Brilliant. Thank you for responding. I have not approached Hostelling International.Do you have a contact there?Let me know when and how you prefer to connect.
Hi Crewenna. Any chance you are able to connect in the next day or two? With only a few days left of the refinement phase, I would love to get your expert advice on the concept.Thank you.
I have used the business model canvas to draft a business model for StartupHostel. See the file for download.Hit me with feedback.
Great use of the Business Model Canvas to refine here, Simon!
The world is truly getting flat, I definitely would like to extend the network to Kenya

I have updated the concept adding some more detail on the concept description, added a visualisation and generally have tried to incorporate all the feedback received thus far.What works, what doesn't?Keep the feedback coming.
Way to go, Simon  am digging your visualisation!

Let's talk timing. Would there be a minimum length of stay at the hostel? (1 month? 3 months?)  I'm curious to know if you'd market the concept as a gap year gig, summer gig, or post-grad gig  or leave it open to all of those possibilities.

I was thinking to keep it open. I would be worried about a 6 months minimum if the person stops after one day.The points/badges should support keeping people engaged and therefore committed to stay for a longer period. If they collect enough points/badges they qualify for a different position the same place or for a position in another location.What do you think?

Funky idea.My hands down favourite concept is Sasha's Lab 21:http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/lab-21-co-learning-labs-with-21st-century-guidance-counselors/How about putting a few rooms in the back and combine it with a YouthHostel? Open up a couple of Lab 21s around the world and let it be a gorgeous combination of stay-in multi-country/cultural regulars and walk-ins from the local community.Would that work?

:-).  Funky!  This entire challenge is really exciting.  I'm going to spend a great deal of time this weekend fleshing things out some more.I'm especially going to give some more thought to your suggestion above.Congrats Simon!

I love it! I lived in a hostel in Iceland while working on a start-up for a few months in my early twenties and it was definitely transformationalI've heard that couchsurfing.com (the cheaper airbnb) is a the way that some entrepreneurs are connecting/traveling/learning these days. I wonder if there could be an interesting connection there for you guys.
I look forward to what you can come up Sasha.Erica, your comment is really inspiring and together with David's has made me think of the StartupHostel spin on the concept.

Without pork-barreling too much, I wonder if there's a way to allow the Hostel to teach more than hotel management.  Is there a way for a guest to teach the staff their own craft--marketing, art, engineering, philosophy, etc.--in return for a free or reduced rate?  It could become a real barter system of knowledge in addition to the valuable knowledge of how to run a profitable business.

Great suggestion, David. Thank you.I am starting to think that we can turn the concept into more of a StartupHostel than 'just' a YouthHostel. Your idea to teach different skills fits perfectly in there.I just need to figure out how to tie all of it together.

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:Although many youth hostels already permit young people to work there as part of their stay, the panel liked the idea of taking this a step further and creating youth hostels that are social enterprises, entirely staffed and run by young people.  They also liked the network dimension, the ability to earn points and the fact this already gathered such a strong response from the community.WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:The panel would love to see some of the great builds already submitted incorporated into the refined version of the concept and, in particular, how you want to position this so everyone understands it's a different proposition to today's youth hostels.  We're also curious to know if you've heard back from YHA who we understand you've already approached about this concept...For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine.
oops! http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Thank you for the selection. I had given up on YHA, but have tried them again. This time through twitter. If anyone has any contacts at YHA, please activate them now.

I was a little too quick here. Immediate response on twitter. Just send the following email off to YHA. Fingers crossed for someone from YHA appearing here soon.----- email to YHA -----Hi YHA,Thanks for the quick reply on twitter.I don't know if you are familiar with OpenIDEO (http://www.openideo.com).Essentially an online platform combining the creative power of design thinking IDEO with sponsors with volunteer designers. I am participating in a challenge: How can we equip young people with the skills, information and opportunities to succeed in the world of work?My concept 'YouthHostel' has been selecting by IDEO/sponsors as one of 20 to be refined over the next 2 weeks. http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/youthhostel/I am very interested in:1. Your input to the concept (is it feasible?)2. Do you do something like this already? (I know your scope is UK/Wales and the concept is global)3. Would you be interested in trying this out?More than anything it would be great to start a dialogue. By participating hopefully you will discover that this is also a good opportunity for your organisation to try out some new ideas.I really appreciate any input you may have.Please feel free to email, tweet, skype or call.Simonemail: simonfich@gmail.comtweet: @ximenfeixueskype: ximenfeixue

I like the idea, it is vialble too -- there is a couple of youth hostels chains in US and they work in a similar way (people can come over to any of the hostels and work there for couple of hours, and they will be able to live there for free). My kid is into this industry, so I know secondhand :)However, the main idea of the said network is that it needs to be fast. Hostel staff has a quick turnaround, and weird shifts sometimes, and there is no way plans could be made for years. On the other hand, in a year the urge for getting  out and see the world usually subside :). Young people who want to have such an experience tend also to be particulary bad with planning and papers. So! Instead of calling this activity "job" how about we call it 'volunteering' or even 'education'? A person can get into the country as a student, it is much simpler -- and he will be working for decent room, board and some _meager_ pocket money. After all, the pay in a hostel is anyway not high :), and parents are anyway likely to support the kid a bit -- so why not extract the money and the "job" component out of it completely?One more thing. This project must be for young people only AND there must me time restraints. For example, you can be on the program until say, 25 and only for not more that 3 consecutive years. We want people to see the world, BUT we dont't want to create nomadic community. :)

Thanks for the input.I like the idea about setting age guidelines although I would prefer it to be a guideline instead of a hard constraint.Could you provide me with the names of some of the organisations in the US? I would like to reach out to them.Any chance your son/daughter would be available to answer some questions and give some input to the concept?Thanks a lot in advance.Simon

Ha, first of all I really like your passion of telling the story!! And the idea is brilliant too. My only concern: it would be very unfortunate if it would become a network just for school dropouts or low-skilled; to me, the story sound a little like this! (perhaps too dramatic?)

I wonder why you have commented that it would be unfortunate if it only became a network for dropouts and low-skilled. If such a network helped the dropouts or low-skilled enter the workforce (locally or overseas), wouldn't that be a positive thing?

Of course it would be a positive thing, if something like youthhostle.org would help dropouts and low skilled enter workforce.  No one would deny that. Im with you Andrew. I just dont think, it would be a good idea to have a public network (for dropouts/ low skilled only) that is kind of featuring dropout stories. So kids might think, to drop school isnt a big deal respectively wont be negative for their future that was my only concern. Like I said, I like the idea; still.
It's a fair enough concern; Simon can assist here by clarifying/giving additional examples of the groups he is targeting with this concept.

Good point.I built the story around a person who had dropped out of school. Having given it some thought that would be too narrow a target group. I also agree that it shouldn't encourage kids to drop out of school.Rather the target audience should be thought of as broad enough also to embrace kids who have dropped out of school. Therefore kids who have finished their education and simply can't find jobs are also in the target group.

Great concept Simon. I was actually just thinking about youth travel and how important it is to get outside of the "home bubble". I'd love to see your concept come alive, it could then be part of my idea... Where traveling via this program could potentialy lead to a collection of badges/awards from my program.
Absolutely. Great idea.

I love the concept. However, as a foreigner living and hoping to get a job in a foreign country, I personally have a lot of problems with visa and work permit. I share the same dream as Jasmine but to really get a chance to work somewhere else seems like unreachable dream. Most companies will definitely hire domestic unemployed before considering foreign ones since they can avoid many bureaucratic procedures and expenses. How can you solve this point?

Hi Maymee,That is a very good point. I agree that it can be difficult with visas and work permits.I have worked with people from all over the world, and hired people from many different countries. In my experience all you can do is to:1) Have people locally who know the rules (they tend to change all the time)2) Follow the rules and regulations in full (no short cuts)2) Be very patient3) Build a good reputationLet's say you are Vietnamese and want to move to a hostel in Argentina. Let's say that getting the permits can take a year to process. The best option is then for that individual to start out working in their own country until they can move.This is really no different than the reality that most multinational companies are dealing with today. The trick will then be for the organization to build this capability (I would not outsource this to another company).Any other feedback/input?Simon
Thanks for the input so far. I have updated the concept.Keep the feedback coming!
Great updates, Simon. I can imagine (as an imaginary youth ;^) being inspired by Jasmine's feature story and showing it to my parents and discussing with them how I might take part :^)

Thanks Meena. I only stumbled upon the parent angle of the concept as I was updating it. I am thinking there should be a whole set of concepts focusing on the parents and how their role could support their children succeed in the world of work.

Love it - it would be great to see you build this brand from scratch but it might also be interesting to see if an existing organisation like the YHA (www.yha.org.uk) would be interested in piloting something like this.

Thanks.I had a look at their website and they are involved both with fundraising and volunteer work, so taking this concept as a next step could perhaps be easy for them..Their vision is also quite in line with the concept:"YHA has a vision  to reach out and enhance the lives of all young people. We want to double the number of young people under the age of 26 who experience YHA. We need to be as relevant to young people as we were 80 years ago when YHA was first established.Staying with YHA is a unique and special experience. YHA offers people the opportunity to grow and gain new skills, self-reliance and confidence. We enable people to get involved with others from a range of different backgrounds and cultures and with different interests."I have written them an email and asked them to take a look at the concept.

Oh that's great - do let us know if you here from them!  As you say, there's a clear fit with their goals and vision so they could be a perfect partner to help take this concept forward.  Fingers crossed you get a response Simon!
Congrats on this post being today's Featured Concept!

Love it! To build on it, I wonder if you might consider using Google Hangouts for live video chatting as a part of of your online platform? I think if I were 18 year old Jasmine, I would like to have a face to face live video chat with some of the people at the Hostel in Puru. She could do this in a Google Hangout. If the person in Puru had a cell phone/pad with 2 cam's they could show her around the hostel and the town before she goes!
Oh, and by the way, I would be happy to show you how Google Hangouts work, if you are not familiar with it and just want to try it out to see if it might be a nice feature of your online platform.
Thanks for the feedback, Rob. Would it be possible to integrate Google Hangouts into another website and would the users have to signed up to use the functionality?

Yes, a Google Account lets you access a variety of Google products such as Gmail, Google+, YouTube, and many more, so yes people would need an account. I have embedded a hangout button and tried out a live hangout as part of an online class, where students all video-chat live. It is pretty easy to do. Google just added and event scheduling option to invite the people you want to a hangout.

A great deal – something like this would really make a difference
A moderate amount – it’s certainly helpful but probably not a game-changer
Not very much – it’s unlikely to make a significant difference to young people seeking work

FEASIBILITY & RESOURCES: Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible will it be for your community to turn this concept into a reality?  (Hint: when you think about resources, think: people, money, time, technology, infrastructure, partnerships and any other inputs for implementation)
Highly feasible – resources wouldn’t be an issue for my community if we tried to implement this
Moderately feasible – my community could do it if we could get find assistance with some of our resource constraints
Not feasible – it would be almost impossible for my community to implement this concept; it's just too resource-intensive

Yes – this concept has enough momentum to stand on its own two feet and remain relevant for years to come
Maybe – it’s not clear how long it would take for this concept to stand on its own feet or how it will continue to be but there’s reason to feel hopeful
No – this concept will have trouble sustaining itself in the long-run and probably won’t be as relevant in years to come
ORIGINALITY: How new or innovative is this idea? Are there many different versions of this concept out there already or is this something more disruptive and unique?
Very original – I’ve not seen anything else quite like it
Fairly original – there are similar things out there but this particular version brings a new element to the table
Unoriginal – there are already too many other concepts out there that are similar to this one
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world
I liked it but preferred others
It didn't get me overly excited

You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. comments.text: I just found this very relevant startup: http://techcrunch.com/2012/11/18/degreed-wants-to-jailbreak-the-college-degree/

Definitely the idea needs to be preserved and perhaps branding it differently as VERIFIED TALENTS instead of SKILLS. I am convinced the radical changes in our society the 3rd Industrial Revolution, the New technologies and Internet are helping to change the mentality. There are substantial changes in our society to endorse the success of this project. Offer the juniors without potential way through the professional market  with a perspective. I believe as well , that will be necessary  to run into the direction to change  the concept of benefits of corporations, perhaps making consumers aware believe into create more jobs for youngsters with a career plan and/or SKILLS DEVELOPMENT.

I think this idea is good - I like the simplicity of it.One issue though is that depending what age group the concept is targeting there is some "inverse lag" (if there is such a thing) between what employers want and schools need to teach.I think this is especially true with the 'soft' social types of skills, and also things like computer literacy.What I mean is that a school kid of 14 today will not enter the workforce for between 2 and 7 years typically. If that number is closer to 7 (or more) then the work place they enter will be different in some ways to today's.That makes it difficult for employers to be definitive in the way that this concept suggests.I wonder therefore if there is some way to incorporate the thought that the registry could be in some way 'self learning' in that it shows trends, that it leans over time (years) and uses those to make predictions that extrapolate what the employers say they need today to what they will need tomorrow?

Right on! Our development team have been busy fixing the Update Entry bug and we're back on track now. You'll now be able to edit your posts to add all that refinement-goodness to build out your concepts for improved impact. Bring it on, together!

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:There were several concepts around matching demand and supply for jobs but this concept stood out to the panel because it deals directly with the important challenge of 'how do you get accreditation for skills that are not attained academically  and how are these skills recognised?' They were also impressed by the degree of thought that has already gone into the development of this idea.WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:The biggest challenges for this concept will be around implementation so the panel are keen to hear how you will get organisations signed up to this and how you will build trust in your accreditation system?  There have also been some great builds from the community already so we'd love to see those incorporated too...For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Thanks for the feedback! I'm looking forward to working with everyone to build on this idea even more.

Hi David,There is a lot of overlap between our two concepts, with us concentrating on the "employability" skills required in every job (http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/employers-have-the-answers-...-if-asked-the-right-questions/). The panel is pointing out challenges around implementation. For a bit of inspiration in this regard, check out what Bloomberg has done here https://www.bloomberginstitute.com/bat/start/).Good luck,Carole

Our ideas are definitely along the same lines! I like the idea of possibly bundling in recognized testing such as the BAT for industries. That way, those scores could appear as part of a student's virtual resume. This builds on Bendikt's suggestion that it is unnecessary to reinvent the wheel and to look at possible ways to bring together a vast set of resources which already tackle a piece of the puzzle. Thanks for the insights!

I like the idea of employers communicating the skills they seek. A design issue to pursue further is how to address the fact that many skills employers may seek are not like yes-no questions but rather ones where how good you are relative to other applicants is a legitimate criterion for the employer to consider. An employer may want the best writer from among the applicants (rather than an adequate writer) or the most proficient economist, or the one most likely to make good judgments under pressure, or the fastest learner.

Thank you for the feedback! Very true. The binary system described has very large limitations. I'm still wrestling with how to develop an effective ranking system. For some skills, it is possible to break it into small chunks that can be made yes/no (programming is an example) for at least the beginner to intermediate stages of skill acquisition. This could result in a % being displayed for each user that could provide an idea of rank. For more subjective skills like writing, a rating system (by users, employers, experts, someone) would have to be overlaid or some algorithm would have to run each student's portfolio to determine the "quality".

Great discussion, guys. David  be sure to incorporate any feedback & new thoughts that you're keen on into your actual concept post to acknowledge your idea is evolving through these collaborative conversations. Looking forward to seeing where things go!

HI David - What if you provided the evidence for this skill to the employer? This reminds me of a problem that eDocuments face in the eyes of the legal system. How can you tell this is the real, original and authorative copy? To solve this problem, digital document providers keep digital evidence - such as a video of the signing of the document, that could be reviewed in situations where there needs to be an audit or further review. Perhaps you could include the "evidence" of the skill - such as public speaking video, or a video of the person conducting a problem solving set, ect. as a part of the verification to give higher belief and credibility to the ranking system.  Good luck and and I look forward to seeing how things progress!

I like the idea of providing evidence. That's the driving force behind the  concept. For subjective skills (e.g. graphic design, public speaking, etc.), there would a portfolio. As of now, there's no plan to include a verification that someone actually took one of the tests themselves (as opposed to having a friend take it) although I don't know how to verify that as even with a video, they could just be copying a sheet just outside the view of the video. I'd love to hear some ideas!

We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Our developers are busy working on it. Meanwhile, if you're wanting to iterate your ideas, you can use the comments feature to promote further conversation from others. We'll let you know once the bug is fixed, then you can incorporate your refinement moves into your concept post. Let's be agile, together!

Congratulations to this framework - a step towards accreditation & work-place relevance of online education. One question: How would you suggest tracking learning progresses in the countless decentralized learning environment such as udacity, coursera, codecadamy etc. in an integrated format that is marketable to an employer. I guess reininventing the content makes no sense and thus the progress on distributed platforms needs to be somehow tracked. And then one addition: Dependcies between skills and the best learning trajectory towards advanced goals are hard to grasp for a beginner (say I want to build some real-time webapp with mobile integration - which skills to I start with?) Now my suggestion would be to have industry professionals create a learning roadmap for specific skillsets/ very targeted end-products (all in a crowd-sourced manner for best outcomes) to guide beginners in the most effective and efficient manner to their goals.I would be very happy to see what you think!?

I love the idea of building off of all the decentralized learning environments like coursera, codeacademy, as re-inventing content doesn't make sense! Perhaps people could link their accounts on those sites to this system and all of their progress could be displayed in one place.I do agree that the dependencies and trajectories are hard for beginners to get, that's part of the idea behind a knowledge map concept. I really like the idea of having industry created "playlists" or "road-maps" that people could look at and follow. Employers could then contact people who've met some standard on their own personalized prep program or who've met some standard on some general road-map. I'm very excited for us to incorporate both of these ideas. Let me know what else you come up with!

Great to see my comments matching this vision! The next step in my view is a central EduHub with three major components:1. User profiles to track progress, discover learning tracks, give feedback on effectiveness of learning sequences.2. Learning Roadmaps which can be generic, profession-specific and best of all company-tailored (follow learning roadmap X to become an engineer at Y etc. as customized by firms).3. An open API through which platforms such as coursera, edX, udacity etc. certify to this central EduHub the user's achievements (various implementations conceivable here).It would lay the groundwork for accreditation, accountability and work-place relevance of distributed online learning!I would be very interested in pursuing these ideas further!
Great discussion, guys! Loving your collaborative conversation here.
I'm trying to update the entry as soon as possible so that we can all keep building on it. Unfortunately, I keep getting a "oops, server error". I'll update it as soon as I can!

Sorry to hear that David. Would be great if you can let our helpdesk know by hitting the Support tab on the left side of the page. It's handled from the US so please be patient till they start their work week on PST Monday. Hopefully we'll have it sorted shortly & meanwhile, hold onto all those great thoughts!
