a_new_education_is_possible_.description: A new mindset demands new skills from schools. That's the purpose of Escola da Ponte, in Portugal. Students there are not divided in classes but in dynamic groups, and they choose what to study having as the main criteria, what they want to learn.
a_new_education_is_possible_.creator: c5a39899760db70e4936fcae5045da49

comments.text: Improving education is an interesting space. I've also heard about the 'Montessori' educational method which is purely based on collaboration between students (students learn on their own and then teach the other students) as opposed to the traditional teacher-student relationship. Certainly the labour space does not resemble the teacher-student frame ...

Maria i love this revolution and mindset; it sounds better aspirations and learning for our generations based on new ideology beyond the new culture. In Kenya, we are reviewing our curriculum and new aspects of this would be shared. How does it tackle aspect of social exclusion between rich and poor?

Hi! I am really glad to hear about this initiative in Kenya,and would love to know more about it. I am quite a Fan of Escola da Ponte as a teaching method and, as you said, as a shift of mindset. I don`t know if I can really answer your question, because I don`t know how exactly they work this issue there. But I can imagine that this might be a big issue among teachers and also students, since it`s a public school in Portugal and although it is an european country, there is still a lot of social issues regarding poverty there, specially now with a crisis scenario.

Very interesting. It sounds like a build on the ideas of Maria Montessori. What I like most about this, is the idea that we need constantly to look at how we do things, and see it there might be ways to do it differently so that it delivers better results for the demands of society. I believe that's what Mr Pacheco has done with education.
Just found this article from Fast Co. and I thnik it's quite interesting regarding this point: http://www.fastcoexist.com/1679921/going-from-one-size-fits-all-education-to-one-size-fits-one

I agree that it also felt very Montessori.  I think that Google is the big Montessori success story. It is my understanding that the founders still reference Montessori class room experiences in their meetings.
I absolutely believe in dynamic grouping! It makes for a more engaged school community.  I also love when schools turn over autonomy to students.  Was this a methodology the school developed?

Hi Monera, that's actually a good question. I am looking for some further infos about their methodology, and it seems like it has been developed by Mr, Pacheco since the 70's when he decided that the school needed a new/different approach. Basically, from what I know about Escola da Ponte, its methodology is based on 3 values: Autonomy, Responsability and Solidarity. IT's based on this belief that Mr. Pacheco has been working with students, family and community in order to create a better school. On the school website there is thic documento called "the educational project" that explains how the school works. It is in Portuguese, but Mr. Google Translate could give you some good help! :) http://www.escoladaponte.com.pt/

reality_based_education.creator: 17ec44bbbac5e4991ff39a55ce04120b

comments.text: I am right on board with this guy. The first person who ever counted did so because he/she went to get the pigs out of the pig pen. When you take three away you know there are seven left. This person knew in the heart how many pigs there were.You don't really "know" until you experience it rather than memorize it.

This is undoubtedly true Lyden but the two are not mutually exclusive, they in fact can complement each other. Memorization on its own is not enough but memorization in conjunction with understanding and experience can be very powerful.
I agree that learning by doing is effective,i guess more research one the methodolgy of "doing" is needed

I definitely agree that reality-based education is a great tool when used to supplement traditional education. There are many similar models which have been successfully implemented on a smaller scale, but I have yet to see a large scale version of this attempted. I wonder if it can turn out to be too costly in terms of money or infrastructure or time taken to organize - can large, public universities or schools implement this?

I'll add to your questions: what about the existing bureaucracy in public school systems and their commitment to standardized testing? Most schools teach to a state-mandated and -tested curriculum. Overhauling that would require a truly Herculean effort as our institutions are built to resist change. Based on my experience in the US educational system, those who want to try radical things in their classrooms are discouraged from doing so, no matter how good their ideas are. It's sad, really.

I attend a small-scale, reality-based "studio school" in the United States, and one of the core differences that I've noticed is my approach to education and that of friends at larger, public universities.  I feel like one of our core problems is the grading system which is implemented due to tradition and the need for efficiency.  When students are placed in classrooms of 100+ people with midterms and finals as determining factors in their grade, the process of learning seems to be de-emphasized when compared to the resultant letter grade.  My studio school is feedback-centered when it comes to grading. I know what my instructor thinks of the quality of my work along the way, and I have a direction of how to improve throughout the process.  I'm not quite sure how this can be implemented at larger schools, but it really seems to be a valuable idea to encourage students to pay more attention to the learning process.  Maybe this will help preserve the creativity and confidence of students that want to try their own thing and do cool projects.

Academically I love the multifaceted dimensions of the problem. and freely admit I can't conceptualise every aspect. Some time ago we introduced competency based training into our vocational education system. This guaranteed that students were 'competent' in performing certain tasks.and removed the 'stigma' of ranking. Those not deemed competent were given further training to achieve competence or offered an alternative area of skill development.On the face of it this seemed a great approach to providing the skills needed in the workforce. Then employers and industry began to ask 'how competent is this applicant?' because with a number of applicants presenting as competent they wished to choose the 'most competent'. Re-assessing say 10 applicants for a job may be within an individual company's purview but for applications in the hundreds or thousands (as may occur in times of chronic unemployment) is too costly when (from an employer's perspective) the education system could have been used to provide the objective basis of comparison.Certainly there is a tradition in grading but, in the broader view, it is also a response to demands from the marketplace. Besides providing a measure of an individual's capabilities it is also, collectively, a measure of the institution's capacity to deliver.Our vocational education system has re-introduced three tiers of competency, not because of tradition, but in response to 'real world' demands.

I would like to expand on Annie's comment above: "I have a direction of how to improve throughout the process."In the traditional education system there is a strong emphasis on the big exams, which take place after all the subject matter has been taught. While the big exam is a strong and reliable measure of a student's competency, the feedback is too late to change the outcome. Students who fail need to repeat the course or drop out, which is a real waste of both the student's and teacher's time and resources, as well as being very demotivational for the student. The students who take the initiative to learn from their exam errors to improve their level of competence, cannot improve their grades.Annie's comment highlights the importance of a quicker feedback loop that helps students improve as they are taking the course. For the students who are heading for a fail, both the student and teacher will realize this early on and can try to take corrective action. For the remaining students, the early feedback will provide direction on how they can improve their level of competence. Those who take the initiative (which is a characteristic we want to encourage) will achieve their higher level of competence before their exam rather than after, and their grades will more accurately predict their future performance in a job.

Andrew, this is a really important point.Another aspect of education models in common use in this country is referred to as "continuous assessment". This can take a variety of forms - from frequent testing for specific knowledge or skills to more general feedback on the extent of student understanding.You are absolutely right that providing faster feedback is key to assisting students overcome barriers to success sufficiently early. This is one place where technology can assist, although this need not be electronic technology. Traditionally there is a huge difference here between primary, secondary and tertiary levels of education - and differences across geographies too. Objectives in primary education and largely in secondary education are to provide foundation knowledge and skills, whereas the tertiary system objective is often to differentiate levels of capability. We try very hard to allow students to complete all levels of pre-tertiary education then thrust them into an environment more characterised by competition than nurture.Annie is right too since the evaluation of her performance would seem to be continuous in nature, which is really encouraging.It is interesting to note some cultural differences too. I was talking to my current boss in the fast-food outlet where I work. He is a graduate from a mainland Chinese university with a major in computer programming and a recent masters graduate in financial accounting (sadly neither of which he currently sees as something he will make use of in the future). He observed that his grades in China were better because their system relied on final examinations whereas the distributed (assignment based) assessments he encountered in Australia were outside his previous experience.

Great share! Thanks for putting this up! An education revolution is right around the corner( see: crowded classrooms, exorbitant higher education costs, a shift away from manual labor toward automation and innovation etc etc etc) , and conversations like this one are crucial. Brainstorming and prototyping this revolution is going to be a blast. Let's continue to build a bridge wherever we can between what the real world demands of us, and what the education system prepares us for!

I can agree that the educational system will adapt to the changing needs of society - it always does. As in all revolutions (even continuous ones like education) there will be human casualties as well as systemic and institutional ones. About 20 years ago my state introduced a program called 'Reading based learning' which saw a shift towards reading and away from traditional spelling and grammar. It was eagerly embraced. A dozen or so years later it was discovered that many students entering university were incapable of adequately expressing themselves. At the present time spelling and grammar are being re-introduced. Technology is now being used to enhance methods and techniques but the core content is being returned.One issue with basing course delivery on 'real life' is those things not explicitly stated but implicitly required.As you say there is a shift away from manual labour which implies need for greater skills - ironically this increases the need for a good grounding in core abilities.Looking forward to this debate.
great idea, instead of taking care about things like greades we may have some "achievement in projects" list...that will show your real skills.

This is great.  The only problem is kids still have lack of exposure to even determine what they want to study and learn at studio school.  Similar to the problems with magnet schools, if you choose wrong you get stuck in a track and may end up on hating it so there needs to be some ability to move within subjects.

I 100% agree with this. Everything I am learning in business school right now was really relevant 10 years ago. I learned more in one 90 day internship than 2 years of college.I found this startup online, they bridge the gap between companies and students. So students can do meaningful real work and companies can benefit from the output.http://studentdesigned.com/

I agree with Lyden. One thing, among others, that you don't get in college courses -but that you can quite experience during internships- is the price of failure. And failure is a highway to learn and get ready for real life demands.Confronting right on with reality is both more challenging, exciting and rewarding.
I don't think its a question of one better than the other - there will be value in both even if internship seems to have been more relevant.

Learning by doing is great, but could result in the alpha members of the team leading the "project" while the more shy kids might have a difficult time speaking out. Indeed more research into this is necessary to validate the impact of such learning methods.

I think spotting and addressing this shyness in certain kids is precisely THE interesting point of this model. Making them form, speak out and stand by their opinion is a challenge that education has to tackle if it wants to prepare students to the world of work.
Have to agree with Jiri here!There are many models of education that work well, even the older ones. I'm sure this technique has its place along with traditional methods.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

We are seeing the rise of co-working spaces across the globe. Why cant kids just hang out in these spaces as an active member of the ecosystem? Throughout the week they can attend core classes on math, science, literature and art.

comments.text: Hi Lucas, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know by hitting the Support tab on the left hand side of most pages of our site if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

Many teachers never worked in a framework that involved leadership, creativity, curiosity, or collaboration.  Their career is similar to the military, someone else makes the decisions and they are the front-line team that carries out that decision. Do we expect creative talent from the military? No we expect someone who can follow orders. Do we expect to be inspired by the military?  No and neither are our students. Why should anyone spend 12 years in school only to have to escape with curiosity?  They should opt out.

You make an interesting point. Branching off of your thought, many companies-even those claiming to be advocates of collaboration-operate in a similar fashion, operating very military-esque where employees act more as sheep, following instead of leading. It's disheartening to be primed as a creative and free thinker only to be stifled in the workplace.

Interesting inspiration that discusses the military tapping the private sector for innovative ideas:http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/military-and-government-turning-to-the-private-sector-for-innovation-/
Andy have you watched AMC's The Pitch?  I have found it interesting that they many companies claim they want disruptive ideas but they always go with safe in the end.  :-D

I love that show Monera! Just this last week there was a moment that exemplifies your point. The teams were tasked with developing an advertising campaign for JDRF. One young designer pitched the tagline "One less prick," playing with the duality of the message. Though her seasoned executive decided to pitch the idea to the client in the end, the young designer was met with great opposition in the beginning. As expected, the concept was said to be too risky. The designer made a great statement about most companies wanting to be like Apple and Nike and most ad agencies wanting to develop the next "Think Different" and "Just Do It" but neither is willing to stomach the risk involved. And like you said, in the end, the safer idea usually gets picked.

comments.text: hi Bill I like your idea of 'boot camp' style preparation for this audience. It reminds me a bit of my education at Hyper Island in Stockholm, which also prepares you for the digital world through group work with real clients on real projects - it's a real learning experience, I can say that through personal experience as well!I would even say the program could be longer than 2 weeks and leave enough time for participants to really take in and reflect what they are doing.I'm just wondering if you thought how participantes would be 'quality' checked before being admitted to the RSA? Would they attend it for free? How would it be funded?Thanks for sharing! :)

Thanks for your comments! I can see the 'admissions process' being somewhat open. Ideally, anyone who applied would be accepted. That being said, a certain level of commitment and quality is needed for participants, so the staff at the studio could help in this regard by organizing the groups with a variety of more qualified applicants (maybe with more experience or skills) and less qualified applicants. The online registration/application process could easily facilitate the staff's efforts in doing so.Funding the studio is another issue still being explored. Corporate sponsorship, non-profit, or even locally funded by government sectors are just a few options. Any suggestions?
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Thanks for all the feedback so far. From what I've gathered, I especially like the idea of adaptation and refining in order to fit the needs of the area or people. Each module and activity can be tested with a rough prototype before its implementation into the RGS program. For example, a prototype of the restaurant challenge (proposed for day two) could be tested at various schools or with a group of young, willing volunteers.

You have obviously given this a great deal of thought and structured the content to fit together logically and with a progressive outcome.I particularly like:- the inclusion of team elements (distinct from networking);- the fact that it could equally apply to plumbing, business and science; and- that it has a balance between online (and/or theoretical) content and real world interaction.

Awesome Idea Brad!! My MSc modules were very similar to this concept. Although the modules lasted for week, I did really get to learn a lot. I was wondering if this concept can be adapted to teaching a particular skill which encompasses all the work related activities mentioned above. For example RGS-Creativity , RGS- Leadership, RGS- Design Thinking or RGS- Social Entrepreneurship.I think it is possible to teach all these skills within a business setting as you describe above. Young people will get to learn the skills you list above as well as specialise in a particular field (eg. creativity; leadership or business strategy). Also have a look at this-http://www.ac4d.com/home/executive-and-practitioner-summer-courses/disruptive-innovation-10-day-executive-training-certificate/

Thanks, Waris! I really like your idea of "skill-based" programs. If the participant already know about the industry they are interested in, maybe as an alternative to week 2, they could focus on a particular skill like you mentioned (leadership, creativity, etc.).
Can't we make High school look like this for 4 years?
Nice thought Monera  but might be more plausible to propose something that could be more easily prototyped first, like Brad has here?

I think this would work as a summer school option from the end of high school onwards and could be incorporated even mandated in vocational education.The exact point of introduction would depend in large part on the structure of the education system.In Australia secondary education is state controlled. In Tasmania we have a structure of senior secondary colleges for years 11 and 12 for those seeking university entrance although in recent years there has been a vocational education stream too, to bridge the gap to post-secondary vocational training. In other states there is more integration of the whole secondary system.

one_step_back_two_steps_forward.creator: a3d136a62d4fc86ed20b91bcdd02b285

comments.text: My comments on your concept brief:I couldn't agree more that we are living in a world of information overload, and that we should avoid creating another information silo and/or website platform.  There is no sense in recreating an information source.  I agree that a good platform would pull from existing forums and perhaps add data to it and/or make the information more usable.I like the idea of a personal trainer/coach.  I have personally found such one-on-one interactions with professors and so forth to be very effective learning mechanisms, especially given the fact that trying to explain to someone else the thoughts in our head is one of the best ways to learn, ourselves.  I also like the idea of a platform that enables students to share information with their peers and that enables students to rank coaches.  As a working professional and recent MBA graduate, I enjoy learning about the career goals and passions of my friends and classmates, so that I can share something that would be of interest to them.  I think great coaches are the difference.  They are authentically interested in the student, and balance empathy with motivation to get students to lead their lives. I definitely think ranking career coaches and mentors is information worth tracking and sharing.

Sounds great, Guntis. Love the idea of tailored programs. I'm curious to know how you propose the personal trainer virtual professional scheme to be funded? Is it voluntary, paid for by the student or do you envision something else? Looking forward to others joining the conversation here.

Web based (virtual) Mentors and Mentees? It just might work.  In New York City alone, there are countless numbers of young people on the waitlists of some of the largest mentorship organizations in the US.  They're potentially mentees simply waiting for someone older and wiser to shed light on a clearer path.So I see Guntis' idea being a great incentive for those who have considered becoming a mentor but may not necessarily be able to make the physical time commitment of formal mentorship.Its like a Professional Pen Pal for today's communication technology -- the Internet.

Proposal was not so much about Virtual meet-ups between Mentors and Mentees, but about the Virtual platform where less skilled people can catch more skilled ones and meet face to face.I agree with you that people, who like sharing their skills, do not have extra time space. Also, one more Web based platform is just one of hundreds. There is an information overload on Web what makes getting/finding stuff impossible. Light at the end could be  use of EXISTING web based FORUMS, which proffesionals use to communicate between each other. There are forums for gaming, IT, DJs, VJs and many other branches. Usually these forums are very active and you do not need extra push for proffesionals to go there. Design of the forum interface is usually ugly, but funcional. It is the best place to find information and share skills, just have to find a Fun-way how to make it work  as a learning tool.Question of motivation? I dont believe in lonely genius idea and learning in small teams is always more motivating.  Learning by doing(gaming). Real life games like Geocaching  are getting more popular nowadays. I have  tried it ones, and I was surprised, that in so small time you learn so much new... and... it makes so much fun.  So, maybe, there is a way how to use gaming/learning like a drive which is based on these Forums for professionals?
But, to be fair, we all have deficit of time, so 99cents for an good answer(140 characters) could be more efecive,

Thank you for your supplement. I dont think foundation is a problem, governments and chamber of commerce are always interested in supporting and making learning(education+working) more effective, specially in today situation. It is possible to start it as social project which bridge the gap between diploma and "start do something". I thing a problem is to get professionals involved(motivation). I know that some people are interested to share their career mistakes and give a free advice (they get post on their facebook wall: "James just helped 3people on Skillshare" :]. But, to be fair, we all have deficit of time, so 99cents for an good answer(

reverse_mentorship.description: An idea that Jack Welch made popular long ago seems to be back on the rise — getting someone 5, 10, 15 or even 20 years your junior to help you see the world from an entirely different perspective. And in return, you can do the same for them!
reverse_mentorship.creator: 3235e3e7b5e215043e3d5105fef47950

comments.text: Brilliant idea! Be interesting to work out how to connect aspiring mentors, young and old, together. How could make it easier for people find the right 'mentor' for them given there personalities, interests, geography etc.? Also, what support and tools could we provide to help people become better mentors etc.?
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

Having a fun time thinking about the multifaceted aspect of this concept, as applied to the success of our youth.  One thing that has helped me in my career is the ability to communicate across disciplines and across generations.  But how do you teach this?  The empathetic nature of young-teaching-old can perhaps provide a unique and beautiful way to achieve this.Do youth from other cultures that keep their elders close to home have the same career issues that our youth have?  Presumably having your grandparents at home would open the door for this type of "young teaching the old" dynamic.

Fantastic inspiration Katie!As one who has been on both sides of this picture it is a mutually beneficial exercise - a true win-win. Its great for bridging the so-called generation gap and for understanding (on both sides) that we can all learn something from each other.Keep it in mind for the concept phase - its a very valuable tool.
Thanks again Paul!

I love this idea. This keeps the previous generation involved with what's current and for the younger generation preserves the experiences of the older generation. It feels like society places an 'expiration date' on our retirees which is crazy.
Thanks Laura! And yes, I totally agree with you.

Thank you for sharing this inspiration.This reminds me of the mentoring program in university I joined. First I thought that my mentor was mainly sharing his experience with me. But then I found out that it was more about sharing ideas and giving him also feedback from a different perspective. I could bring in my knowledge of the latest technology in my field of studies and on new media. And he shared his experience with me. At the end we had a great exchange beyond barriers of different generations. The mentoring was a great journey and Id like to share this experience as well.
Great idea. And it would combine well with the PieLab part of the ProjectM inspiration Meena posted:http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/project-m-thinking-wrong-doing-right
I like the idea. This could also help big institutes in becomming more innovative/understand social media better.And I like the real world connection and relationship building site of this.

I am really keen on this idea not only because it's totally possible and easy to be implemented, but mainly because it strentghens the bonds between different generations. There so much potential that goes beyond an exchange of information.
I like this idea! This could help the young recently graduated from university to gain confidence in what they know. Someone must give them the first opportunity to start building their carreer.

I love this .... the BBC here in the UK did a series of programmes where they connected teenagers with elderly people in a care home - it was eye opening on both sides.  The programmes aren't available anymore but there is a summary athttp://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00z07p7Really interesting stuff that broke down the perceptions - definitely on both sides.
Great idea! I know that Unilever also had a similar programme called the Hot Chili mentoring programme that was a hit!

I believe there is a lot to build up from this.As you mentioned, one risk/opp of the aging population is the availability of senior individuals, many of which would like to remain useful for our societies longer than we may believe.One challenge in my mind is how to match them in an efficient way to cope strengths and interests...
Nice one, Katie! And great for soft skills around empathy and relationship building for participating youth.

comments.text: It's an exciting story. I like the value of sharing the experience. I guess many people who have gone through a situation can show how they solved it ... we tend to learn from one another, or to inspire from others to shape our own way. Many unemployed who have crossed 'the gap' could be showing how it is possible to do it or inspire others on what to do next. There's this filmed called 'La Soledad' ('Loneliness) directed by Jaime Rosales, which addresses about how in life we may 'feel alone' in many situations. We may feel alone as a son/daugther, we may feel alone as a brother / sister, as father / mother, as a partner, as an employee, as a student ... and yet there is many of us 'feeling alone' in the same situations in life ... why not sharing how we faced it? I am sure many unemployed feel alone in front of the challenge we have ahead.
I agree, the detours are so important.
What a great story Laura, thanks for sharing. Just goes to show how important it is to listen to your instincts and (sometimes) be more than a little courageous!

The experience of failure is critical in the formation of a great leader - someone who understands the risks involved and realizes that a collaborative and supportive team environment is as important as a strong leader and a clear mission.

a_unified_approach.creator: 86f0c2a2387a7662d5537443bb6cfdd5

comments.text: Hi Trevor, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know by hitting the Support tab on the left hand side of most pages of our site if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

i have actually just relocated interstate & a million things on my plate... but what kind of image would I put to it? ...is there something in particular that you were thinking of? ...is there some part of what i am talking about you would like to see explained in a graph or perhaps a diagrammatic representation of the elements of the proposed system?

Hi Trevor, just to weigh in - we use images and visuals on OpenIDEO to help tell our stories, to explain our ideas, and to transcend any language barriers we as a community might face. Any image you'd like to post should help tell your story in ways that you think are meaningful. Just be sure to cite your source for the image in the text section of the image upload.

While the nerd in me wishes I attended the intellectually challenging Classics program at St John's (http://www.sjca.edu/) the creative in me wishes I went to New College (http://www.ncf.edu/). New College lets a student chart their own course.  I have to imagine that doing so would give them a more vested interest to find their passion.

absolutely, and it is nice to hear there is a university out there doing that already......what i have in mind for this would be an open sourced version of something that inspired me from a computer game.the game in question is called "alpha centauri" from Sid Meyer games, and what they did was publish with the game a 'technology tree" which explained which technologies lead to which other technologies.In this particular respect, for example, one must understand basic arithmetic in order to be able to understand algebra... one comes before the other... but there are other fundamental units of knowledge preceding & leading to, and then collaborating together which make an understanding of algebra possible... so if someone wants to study a subject, the only requirement should be, that they can demonstrate a fundamental understanding of its prerequisites according to this tree of knowledge.since the tree of knowledge is itself universal, it is not something which anyone can really copyright, it is simply something which is universal, and regardless of anyone's opinion, will always apply.a bachelor degree program (or any other course) attempts to do this, to use prerequisites to ensure that students have the capabilities required to attempt each new subject... but they are applied to bluntly... each unit needs to be broken down, learned, and assessed in smaller units of more fundamental pieces of knowledge... these can then be grouped together to form minor fields of knowledge, and can then be grouped together to form more & more major fields of knowledge....if someone has no interest in a particular degree program, they should have that freedom to study those areas they choose, so long as they fulfil the prerequisites of each piece of knowledge leading to each other... but it also shouldnt matter whether they study the course at the institution, or just pay to be tested on it, or get a credit from being tested elsewhere...this tree of knowledge and some other bits & pieces designed around it, allow for universal standards, with a great deal of texture generated from the testing methodologies applied....with each successive generation of students (going through education in far looser groups, and definitely not associated by anything as arbitrary as age), the methods of teaching each unit of knowledge will evolve, because there are specific parts of the strategy designed to facilitate the development & recording into the central database of each new way of explaining a concept generated anywhere in the world, and by anyone in the world (whether student or teacher - all that matters is whether it is correct & works for a particular style of learning requirements).

The learning map on Khan Academy does this, especially for math.  The one thing I worry about with each piece unlocking the next is that is not how all students lean.  Bobby Fisher, at 7, detested learning multiplication tables, but he could discuss infinity and prime numbers.

well that's a very good point, but not actually a problem, because learning multiplication tables is only ONE way of getting familiar with numbers & multiplication, and is therefore NOT a core unit of learning, but only a single METHOD of learning a core unit... some children will learn well with this method, and they can use it... others will not like this method, and they wont have to use it, they can use something else.the trick here is identifying what is actual knowledge, and what is a method of learning knowledge.Someone who has come to understand numbers & the principle of multiplication (which are core units) in a different way, does not need to learn multiplication tables, because if they have learned these things properly, a multiplication table is a by-product they can figure out based on first principles.

the other comment that I would make here, is that discussion of infinity, does not actually require an understanding of multiplication, because infinity is what I would call a parallel unit of knowledge, not a derived one... prime numbers do require an understanding (to some degree) of multiplication & division & addition (the core units of the subject field of arithmetic), but they do not necessarily require you to know anything about or have ever once looked at a multiplication table... this is only a method towards understanding multiplication, and that is all. So long as the child can understand the concept of arithmetic, they can understand the idea of a number which is divisible by only itself & 1

comments.text: Very true, Anup, we often learn theory in university / school and then have to learn a whole new set of skills in the real world. I like the idea of a "hustle" program to help apply real world skills. I wonder if it could be something like The Apprentice (though without the bad TV moments), where people are given specific challenges and sent out in the world to execute on them. This could be offered secondary school and in university.

Thanks for the comment Amy! A prototype program called Boston StartupSchool was launched this year by a group of entrepreneurs.It is aimed at students (all fields) who want to start a tech company. They cover essentials like developing a prototype mobile app, social media marketing, web design and stuff like negotiation and recruiting. All aimed at making the student more independent and confident to get the venture off the ground. All in a month.Taking inspiration from it, I thought that such a hustle phase would benefit students as they make a transition to the work force

Nice one, Anup! I wonder if you might be able to add your images as a full size PDF as well so folks can grasp their detail? You can update your post by hitting the Update Entry button up there on the right.

teachers_from_industry.description: Encouraging more people to move from industry into teaching may help increase the "soft" skills that young people need to enter the workplace.
teachers_from_industry.creator: 662f719124598586a5e3d9280b6d0512

comments.text: I really like this idea especially in a way that I didn't have enough expose to industries during my school years. Of course it depends on individual's connection, but school can open up such practical approaches to the youth.

Maybe we could build upon this and other similar ideas to blur the lines between the teaching profession and industry? Maybe people shouldn't be teaching or in industry, but rather in both.Could placements in industry possibly be considered a part of on-going teacher training? Many school districts already have requirements for continuing education to maintain certification, what if that training could (or had?) to be done by working in industry? At the University level, maybe you could have working professionals teach classes? Numerous high-end schools do this. Business School faculty often take on consulting for companies affording them "real-world" exposure. Could that be expanded to other university departments?

Nice one Sally! You might also like to chime in on Jessie concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/professionals-as-sometime-teachers-advisors/ and build upon each others ideas.

virtual_universities.description: An accredited virtual university can address the lack of skills in certain geographical areas by providing frequent classes from professionals.
virtual_universities.creator: 1965552ec364b87b6423e1c283312ff0

comments.text: Integrating the online platform into one that already exists (such as Facebook) would make the initiative more scalable in that it would 1) link into an already established global network already divided along geographical lines, which woud address the fact that specific knowledge sets correspond to specific regions/markets/economies 2) lower the threshold for participation among users and 3) minimize expansion and scaling costs

Interesting thoughts. If you can join groups like on facebook and make your effort visible, this might motivate you and decrease the drop out rate. You also can share your thoghts and troubles with others and help each other.
I think more benefit would come by establishing its own platform.. Integration with Facebook especially would dilute its educational benefits.

Exactly. I thought of integrating something similar to Facebook ; to integrate social aspects to virtual learning so that students have a community to share their thoughts and ideas with each other as well as the professionals. Facebook has been a great tool to increase connections globally, so I thought a similar app would increase participation in learning and finding out specific skills that are needed.  For example: there could be pages for various professions with a SWOT analysis (strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats). Links could be made to these pages that provide direct access to classes.Of course this type of learning environment is only applicable to those who have access to computers and the internet. Therefore, to further this possibility, we can create e-learning hubs in areas that do not have the luxuries of the internet.

This is a really great concept!As you say online courses already exist and virtual conferencing tools too..I see the key strengths in this concept as:- assessment and accreditation (just providing the subject matter with self-assessment is not enough);- tailoring the course (that is, a set of associated subjects leading to a qualification) to locally identified needs; and- where possible linking the students not only to each other but to the industries with the skill shortages.I have participated in distance education at the post secondary level a number of times both pre and post existence of the internet. For a variety of reasons (mostly financial) I have been unable to complete them. On the other hand my youngest daughter is studying a post graduate certificate in oncological nursing by distance education.  This particular skill has not been identified as 'necessary' by the hospital in which she works despite a high proportion of child and adolescent cancer patients.I use my daughter's example to make a case for industry involvement.

startup_pirates.description: Startup Pirates is a one-week acceleration program for young entrepreneurs in the making.
startup_pirates.creator: 705107a8b05187463fa119fe8e58a574

comments.text: Hi Ins, I had the chance to be part of such a program. We had one week and every day at least one new guest, from entrepreneurs to investors. We did some reading before the week and generated ideas and evaluated them using uservoice. Then we had our 5 intensive working days all together. We took our short list and formed groups of 3-6 people. With alternating working sessions, workshops and pitches, we developed a first prototype. The last day we had some investors as guests and every group did a pitch. Then we got some really valuable feedback. It was a very great experience!
Great to hear Sabine!! From our own experience things are working very well and we already have 5 startups running!! It's unbelievable what we can do in a very focus and organized week!!

Hi Ins,Interesting concept. Can you share some thoughts how you can stretch this beyond the one week. What happens if no-one is interested in investing in your idea? Can they keep the network running and continue to share and use each other?Simon

Usually, we have an agenda like this one: http://bit.ly/O1ib1E! Basically, team building activities in the first 2 days, then workshops in the morning and mentoring in the afternoon. It's very intensive and the idea is to turn the idea into a business. The goal of the program is not to get investment, the goal is to quick start the process of creating a business with the help of experience mentors and entrepreneurs. That's why that we send the 3 winning teams to incubators and accelerators. Besides, we have a growing network of people that can help them in whatever stage they are. They have easy access to this network. Thanks for the interest Simon.

Using entrepreneurship to motivate an individual's own self-interest is not new; but it is still a great idea.  BUILD is an organization that integrates entrepreneurship into the curriculum of low-income urban middle and junior high schools.  I used to volunteer as mentor to students in the program, and saw business and entrepreneurship work occasionally at motivating these students to care about their academic studies.  For example, I would work on business plans with these students, and--in the process--help them understand the need for vocabulary, fractions, communication skills, foreign languages, etc.  I also think entrepreneurship and small business ownership are especially effective with students from low-income households.  In my volunteer experiences, I frequently found money and wealth to be effective motivators for students from low-income households.  Entrepreneurship was seen as a way out of the neighborhood and dangerous life of gang banging and dealing drugs.In my opinion, entrepreneurship can be made accessible to youth if we give them proper support and resources and guidance.

I totally agree with you! I actually believe that the potential of entrepreneurship to solve social problems is much bigger that we usually thing. From solving social programs, to integrate entrepreneurship in the school curriculum, to create jobs, there is plenty of things to be done.

Ol Ins! Tambem sou do Porto :) First congrats on what you've accomplished with Startup Pirates, it's a great initiative for youngsters, I like that it's 7 days long too. One question: how do you asess the quality of the startups / ideas created at your one week camp, and is there any follow up with the Startup Pirates following the camp? Thanks and congrats again!

Hi Ana!! Thanks for your comment!During the week, we have mentors, entrepreneurs and investors guiding and mentoring the teams and making sure they improve the quality of the ideas. After the program, in partnership with incubators and accelerators we provide 3 to 6 months of incubation and the participation in national and international acceleration programs.

Sounds awesome, Ins! Hopefully with over a week left in the Concepting phase, you might attract collaborative conversation to build upon this idea even further plus use your experiences and insights to join discussions on others' ideas to strengthen them to.
too no to!

alternative_forms_of_education..description: What about changing the way we educate people?
alternative_forms_of_education..creator: 5525fa2eee4f0e2cb62c9fa9587b2733

comments.text: Interesting post. I would like to offer a different angle on the same question. Instead of  changing the entire way that people are educating maybe introducing a few different subjects into the traditional educational system.One subject in particular that I would have loved to have been taught through primary and high school is 'networking'.A former manager of mine did a survey (I am still trying to find the output) of many people in and outside my former company. The question was around what makes people successful career wise. The single biggest skill/qualifier that was identified up and above any other was 'networking'. People used their networks to be successful in their current job, to find new jobs, to learn new skills.The outcome of the survey did not as such surprise me, however what did surprise me was how distant the 2nd attribute was. Networking was simply and consistently the single most important factor in most of these people's careers. It made me realise that I had neglected networking and I have only really started working on improving this the last couple of years.I think teaching networking skills and creating networks at an early age would be one of the most important things we can do to better equip young people.Today I use my network to learn new things. I use it to gain the information I need. I also used it to get my current job. I have gotten better at networking, but I could be much much better at it.

Interesting suggestion Simon.Networking is a natural outcome of many early educational experiences both formal and informal. I can agree that teaching children to contribute their various skills and energy to achieve a mutually beneficial outcome would be very valuable.

Networking and even more so building alliances is definitely an important and increasingly important skill. Not only for getting a job, but also once you got it.2 more skills I'd like to suggest:(1) Leading / Managing Yourself: I have the impression that young people often lack the skills to organise themselves. This also includes knowing how they get work done, how they like to work, how they collaborate with others, using the tools (software for example), etc.(2) Working in the white space, i.e. feeling comfortable in unstructure, ambiguous situations, where problems are not properly defined. Feeling comfortable with experimentation to figure it out is certainly an important part, that not only the youngsters but also organizations have to learn.
Awesome projects - thanks for sharing. In vehement agreement that a new way of teaching & educating could much better equip young people to get involved in creating a different future...

Nice one, Marc. You might want to add Kaospilots & Knowmads as their own posts and tease out the goodness on these and encourage discussion. More tips on the Inspiration phase: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire Looking forward to seeing more of you on OpenIDEO!

Hi Marc, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know by hitting the Support tab on the left hand side of most pages of our site if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

comments.text: There is definitive an escalation of e-learning which I love. Does anyone know how effective is it? Are people using them? Learning? Changing behaviours?

I have taken a look at this initiative which, in general, I applaud. The effectiveness of the education can be great and, as you say, e-learning/e-training is proliferating. As with most things there is monetization in the marketplace and the euphemism "you get what you pay for" still applies. Proof of skills or training whether conventional or online still rests in the piece of paper that attests to them - the cost of the piece of paper is still a major barrier to the acceptance of e-learning 'qualifications', whether or not the institution offering it has a certain prestige.

comments.text: I love this idea! I think sharing this type of format would inspire lots of people. Using this type of visual tool, people will be able to save so much time comparing different options and making important decisions.

I support diagrams as the best tools for people that understand the world that way. I think it will be an excellent tool for young people that aspire to design jobs, but what could you do to translate this into a diagram for someone that wants to be an accountant and doesn't know that could also be an exciting job?

I agree on your view about self-awareness. Somehow, the Learning Landscape Interactive Resume should be constantly updated by a professional career counselor with a lot of personal connections or rather a pool of mentors in different areas I guess.:)

Absolutely. I agree that it's so important to get feedback from a variety of peers and mentors-  and not just suggestions of how to improve a portfolio, but speculations of what you're good at and what  your first steps need to be...
I love the idea of this as a reflective tool and also an interactive resume.
"Interactive Resume" is really the meat and bones to this concept. Thank you for your succinctness!
Great stuff, Emelia! Loving your graphic prototype and focus on self-awareness alongside professional alignment.
Thank you! I am creating one for myself at the moment, and looking for collaborators to help me make it interactive, so I can post an example!
Exciting! Looking forward to seeing what you come up with.
This is great, and I think it would be very beneficial for job hunters and employers. I'm curious, how is it implemented? through a digital form? interview? conference?

I believe it would be a great tool during an interview or conversation with a mentor, sitting side by side with an iPad. I could also envision employers 'surfing' the infographic on their own time: each element has embedded contact information, each organization listed is linked to their website, each work sample is navigable...
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

comments.text: I think this is a lovely and engaging concept!Its also a cool way to loop in young people who lack direct access to the resources and people that would guide them along this process.Mobile phones are so widespread amongst youth - globally - so this could work with a companion app as well.There's some real alignment as well with Lydia's Experience Bank/CV Lifeline.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

I like your concept which provides something important: the possibility for young people to recontextualize what they learnt in the context of job search and an understanding that they might know more than what they think.I think that this is a good idea and that the difficulty would be in finding the right way to develop the tools to create this awareness. I particularly like the idea of a tool box. I've been thinking of something somewhat related. ... I'll build upon your concept if I end up posting mine.
Thank you! I would love to see/discuss your toolbox concept. The tools will be key to helping individuals promote their current abilities and then actually grow those skills they may be lacking it.
Great new illustration you've added, Amy!

Nice one Amy! And your image from The Breakfast Club is taking me back down memory lane ;^) Perhaps you and others here might like to start to tease out what kinds of topics might be covered on the platform. Looking forward to seeing what folks come up with!

run_the_school_for_a_term.description: Why not allow kids to run the business (as opposed to the academic) side of the school - everything from catering, facilities management, purchasing etc
run_the_school_for_a_term.creator: 662f719124598586a5e3d9280b6d0512

comments.text: I love this idea Sally!  And I think school governors are another resource that could make this idea  a reality.  Governors can be a bit too 'hands off' in terms of understanding what it really takes to run a school (I say this as someone who's been a governor for years but still struggles to read a budget :-() so if they were partnered with pupils it could be a great learning exercise all round....

I think this is a great idea, as it will give many young people experience they may not have had up to this point in their lives.  Its a safe way to teach the students important "small business" roles. However, my only question is, don't you think this will be a bit overwhelming?  A faculty body that runs the school already has years of experience in doing so, and putting the students into these positions may be too much for them at first; they won't know many of the small ins and outs of running an education institution.  I think this could work, its a great idea, but there would still need to be some sort of training or supervision.  What are your thoughts on this?

Thanks for this  .... yes I agree it would be completely daunting for them to do this on their own.  I think the people that actually do the job normally would coach and guide and of course be there to avert anything untoward.  I would also see that it could tie into the general curriculum too so that some of the "training" could be incorporated into maths or whatever to help them understand some of the concepts before trying out the role.

Yep, I think this could definitely be done as long as there is a balance; letting the students do enough so they learn and being coached so they don't feel totally thrown into these roles with no support.  The second part of your comment, I like a lot too!  Because, after all, one of the main goals of education is to apply what you've learned to the real world.

Hi,nice idea Sally. You could also imagine variations of this depending on the grade. For example, in my kids' elementary schools, there was an ice scream stand during lunch break that was run by some of the 4th and 5th graders. They had to manage the money and the stocks. They were helped by some parents. There was also an after school program run by a teacher for jewelry making. The kids were given a budget to make the jewels and then they were selling the jewels they made after school or during recess. The idea was that they were supposed to at least pay back for the supplies and maybe make some profits.You could imagine having some small workshops / after schools or lunch clubs for younger grades so that they get used to "running the school". I also agree that it'd be important to have the adults coaching them.

So as a possible source of inspiration, I'd like to bring up the idea of student self-governance. A commonly preached idea in higher education but perhaps not practiced as much as it should be.I thought you might be interested in the following example: At Rice U., they actually often have students negotiate terms of contracts with contractors for furniture and smaller scale (still up to a few thousand dollars) projects. Also, each Residential College is given over $40k to budget and spend how they will (within a few constraints) using University Purchasing Cards issued to students. That's just a couple of examples of a system that is highly inefficient in terms of performance as students have little experience but it provides incredibly valuable and applicable opportunities for students. That kind of system may provide an in-between as staff and faculty still provide oversight and feedback but students get the opportunity to make real decisions with real money.
Congrats on this post being today's Featured Concept!

Lots to love on this one   and perhaps some learnings from  Garehime Elementary School http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/model-city-schools/ Tip: If you hit the Update Entry button on the right of this page, you could go in and add that post to your Build Upon feature. That way the person who wrote it will get an email notification and is likely to come and join the brilliant conversation you've started here as well. Creativity loves company, right? :^)

comments.text: Heartily agree. And it's an interesting irony to think about -- that a demographic so heavily in need of this type of awareness/interest-building receives so little relative attention from the industry most capable of meeting that need.  There's definitely a two-way sense of urgency to be addressed as we proceed.
Great suggestion Pradeep - maybe this could be instituted further down the education stream too and involve co-learning with parents.

Great call Pradeep. And could this been done in a way that's enjoyable & engaging? (I'm inspired by what Warren Buffet's Secret Millionaires Club does for younger children http://www.smckids.com/intro) Plenty to think about on this one for our upcoming Concepting phase!

a_strategy_for_life.description: Taking a step back to look at the bigger picture can help us succeed both at work and at life.  Often we don't take as much time to apply a strategic vision to our lives as much as we do our work.
a_strategy_for_life.creator: 9b40c7f0ba48e086c3630115cd16775c

comments.text: This is a great piece of inspiration.  As Daniel Pink describes in his book "Drive", financial incentives are not the strongest motivators, and should be used sparingly to incentivize employees. Intrinsic motivation is much more important in determining how successful (and happy) employees will be in their work and their lives.  Humans crave creativity and un-restricted exploration, and too often this is overlooked in the pursuit of a larger paycheck.

Thanks for the connection to the Daniel Pink book!  Creativity and exploration at work seem like important but unspoken issues.  Hopefully employers are also recognizing more and more the value of having employees that are great creative problem solvers, would be great to see something that addresses this in the concepting phase.
Great summary, Joe  and fab link to the NYT article.

carousel_of_opportunity.description: What if companies hired people to the company, not to a specific job and the new hire rotated through departments/projects for a set period of time. At the end of 2-years, they could be offered a permanent position.
carousel_of_opportunity.creator: 4def0ad3168c82a0c39cd6f01bb345b7

comments.text: I worked for a company that had this model for top college graduates. It seemed to work out really well in terms of giving participants exposure to many different types of work/teams and a chance to try it  out for themselves. It was a 2 year program with a switch every 8 months, enough time for the participant to get a really good idea about the role and complete solid projects.

That's awesome that there is an example of this working in private business as well! I wonder how easy/hard it would be to expand this opportunity beyond "top" college graduates, do you know if a rotation system has been used for more than the very top graduates?

Not that I am aware of. Here's a discussion re: rotation programs including Google's, the company I was referencing. http://forums.businessweek.com/n/pfx/forum.aspx?msg=85483&nav=messages&webtag=bw-bschoolsIn terms of expanding this model to include broader life situations (those w/ only high school degrees, average grades) maybe look at how businesses would benefit from the program. How can this add to them being more successful? and How can it impact their bottom line? Perhaps there is an incentive, similarly to how there are state and federal incentives for companies hire those coming off welfare. The rotation programs for "top" college graduates seem like very little risk to the employer. These students have shown through their grades that they can learn, therefore companies believe they are trainable and will be successful. How else can you measure "learning" and predict success, etc... that would make a broader rotation program less risky for employers.

Thanks LinhChi! This is really interesting both for this concept an in general for me. I didn't realize so many companies would use rotational programs as "leadership accelerators" and that wasn't how I had originally thought of using them in the business context. You've given me a lot of great questions that I or someone else can use to build upon this concept and make it more realistic and actionable.
I think this is a great idea -- it also allows people to demonstrate their strengths and prove their worth in a company. However I believe one year would suffice.

Hey Kelly, perhaps you are right! In the end, I think each company would have to figure out what timeframe works best for it although I imagine it would be in the 1-2 year time frame. Thanks for the feedback!

comments.text: An interesting survey was published by Behance through their 99U portal (http://goo.gl/NS2LV). They asked hundreds of their Twitter and Facebook followers "What's the one thing you wished you'd learned in school?"And the results are:1. More Business Training2. Failure3. Work/Life Balance4. Personal Finance and Student Loans5. CreativitySomething to consider when developing the workshops at Open Bus for sure.

Hi Swany -- How's it going....I read an article briefly today and thought of your concept.  The designer Cole Haan is using the food truck concept to sell shoes!Interestingly executed ;-).  In any case, just wanted to share a fully executed mobile truck -- minus the food!I REALLY think you have a great concept and am excited to see it come to fruition.http://www.psfk.com/2012/09/cole-hann-stilettos-food-truck.html

Hi Sasha, Thank you for the link and thinking of Open Bus. This only confirms that the concept of bringing the "experience" to the where the people are can only help building stronger relationships with the community. I can see Open Bus as an extension of many of the concepts being developed in this challenge. As I mentioned before, we are the catcher and by being in every community we can feel and understand the needs of the young people that might feel restricted in leaving their comfort zone and seek help somewhere else. We can send them you way to Lab 21 after we grab their attention!!Thanks again and congrats on your concept too!

I like the concept! If there is any space for developing your idea, I would consider making it an edutainment experience. First of all, having fun generates endorphins which makes it easier to deliver the message and make it memorised. Secondly, the open bus should not be directly associated with people who are "in trouble" - the stigma effect is definitely not the required one. Building on strengths is what I like most. People like to hear what they are good at and what other people like about them. This can be additional "offering" of the Open Bus - learn what others like about you. The Reflected Best Self can be an inspiration.
Very worthwhile concept where resources can be made available.Thanks for the use of Unbounce too - could be very useful for future challenges.
Thank you Paul for your comment. I actually love Unbounce, it is an amazing tool.
Did you use paid service or was that mocked up using the free account - I don't think I can justify a paid service on my budget?
I used the free account, you don't have to worry about the budget! You will have your landing page in a breeze! Enjoy!
Oh... and let me know if you need any help!
Thank you to everyone for the feedback. I finally submitted the final version of the Concept: Open Bus
Wow  amazing refinement updates!
So, so cool. Well done.
Thank you Meena and Simon, it is only the end product of collaboration efforts!
A great collaboration!
Collaborative efforts are the best kind of efforts is what we tend to think here at OpenIDEO ;^)
Sounds like it can link or work in combination with the YouthCafe concept.

Sorry Andrew for not responding sooner, I missed your  comment. As you mention, a mobile concept can work with different other concepts presented in this challenge. We are like the catcher in a baseball game and we throw the ball to the next player.We are also like a basic care medical unit where we take care of the initial check up and then refer it to an specialist. Our concept can work with may concepts in this challenge. Once we do our initial assessment we can refer young people to the YouthCafe, to the StarUp Hostel, to Lab21 or even implement Purpose Workshops in our classroom or have them watch the Unitership.Thank you!

Can this be combined with any existing services like book busses (if they still exist)?Maybe it doesn't have to be a bus, but rather a group of people who travel from school to school from community to community. At least initially.

Hi Simon, Thank you for your comment. I just submitted the final version and in the process of getting it done,  we met with different associations that already are providing counseling to young kids to join the workforce to learn their challenges and get their feedback.What they liked about this concept is that we are bringing the counseling to them -initially a group of people traveling from community to community as you mentioned.  We've learned, that at least in NYC in certain neighborhoods kids will not go out of their area to go to the Youth Development Center because of neighborhood barriers (different demographics for example). What they like about our concept is that it will be helping them break these barriers.

Great idea! I love that since it travels around it will intersect with people who may have not found out about it otherwise. One the other hand, if there any follow up after you have meet with them? And will it be staffed by enough people to meet and follow up with everyone who stops by? Is the career truck open every day?

Hi Christie, thanks for the feedback and the enthusiasm.... I can see the truck opening every day. At the beginning it might be one truck only but as demand grows there can be more of them around the city. The truck has to be a reliable place where young people feel as theirs. As the "coffe-truck movement" grows,  there can be more trucks for specific career paths. I can also see the trucks being sponsored by different companies in order for them to spot new talent.  Let's use Barclays as an example, the "Barclays Coffe Truck" : Young people interested in an Investment Banking career will go to Barclays Coffe Truck to find specific career advise and planning to become an Investment Banker.Talent can be spotted at the truck. The best students might have the opportunity to land a job with the sponsoring company.
that sounds great! thanks for the response.

Congrats! I also had a similar question - as food trucks are becoming really popular, lines for them become very long. Not everyone gets served. I was wondering what ways can other channels exist when the mobile truck is not available or the line is too long. I like what Andrew suggested below was this could work in conjunction with the Youthcafe, which may have locations and hours, or maybe mobile devices to help during the wait?

Thank you Annie, I agree. An online platform can help people following the truck location and scheduling appointments in advance and also the coffee/drinks component can help people that drop in spending time while waiting and use of mobile devices (iPads) as you suggested. We can incorporate The Uniternship concept where people can browse through the online library of reality video profiles of actual job roles while waiting. Great idea! Thanks
Here is the link to The Uniternship http://goo.gl/hyzrK

Hi Swany -- Would you consider multiple trucks that travelled from city to city? ...Or maybe a fleet of trucks that visited multiple school districts in a given week or month or semester?  What if the trucks were specific to a certain industry?It all seems really exciting to look forward to right around the time that most students are graduating and looking for work.  And a super cool mobile truck to look forward to seems like such a bonus.

Hi Sasha, thank you for your feedback and congratulations to you too for your Lab21 concept being selected in the Top 20.As I was telling Christie, as the Career-Coffee Truck movement grows or if there is a sponsor involved we can have different trucks targeting different cities, different schools and different industries. I specially like your idea of bringing the truck to schools for a day or weeks with specific workshops tailored for them. Providing Strengths assessments, resume building workshops etc...

The beauty of a Truck is that it can go anywhere and it can not only target young people and schools, but also human resources executives and companies. Ex. A day a month, the Career Truck can bring a class or workshop to a company on "Creating a Quality Internship program for your company", or "How to provide good interview feedback"

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:This concept received strong support from the panel because it's really costly for young people to travel in order to get advice and so not something they're likely to prioritise spending their money on.  They love the idea of bringing core advice services to young people in places they're already likely to be  it ticks a lot of boxes in terms of reach, impact and accessibility!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:We'd love to hear a bit more about what kinds of tools, materials and services will be available in the truck and who will be providing them?  Also, it's worth considering what kinds of young people this is intended to target  those still in education or those actively seeking work?  One final thing... not all kids are into coffee  you might want to consider a bigger drinks menu ;-)For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Looking forward to keep exploring the Career Truck concept!!!!

Hi Swany. Congratulations on your concept moving forward! When considering who will be providing the services to support young people, it could be interesting to partner with authors, motivational speakers or smaller organizations/individuals working for them as opposed to only larger ones like ING. My thought is that through doing this, young people will have a chance to meet others with a view point not coming directly from the larger companies who will (typically) be hiring them. Looking forward to your thoughts!

Hi Karina, Thank you for your feedback. I love your idea of having different people coming to speak to the Career Truck since it can become a movable platform for tailoring specific needs of schools, organizations or even government agencies helping young people to improve their skills. Linking this concept with the Professionals as sometime teachers/advisors http://goo.gl/vi5e6, the Career Truck can have different professionals giving a class on their experiences at the job and we can even bring a Career day to a specific School as Sasha was saying.

How cool! I love all things that bring things that involve getting, in the right way, the right product, in the right quantity and right quality, in the right place at the right time, for the right customer at the right cost. Similar to Hot Gourmet Food Trucks!

Thank you Rob! Hot Gourmet Food Trucks are usually a place everyone wants to go for a great meal and a great experience because of the great chefs behind them. The Career-Coffee Mobile Truck will be a gourmet one of a kind experience that will advice young people, not only on the great meals available but on how they can prepare them.

Trucking great! ;^) Love how you've included scenarios to help others engage with your idea.

py/tuple: IMPACT & REACH: How much impact and reach do you think this concept could have in helping young people transition into the world of work?
A great deal – something like this would really make a difference
A moderate amount – it’s certainly helpful but probably not a game-changer
Not very much – it’s unlikely to make a significant difference to young people seeking work

FEASIBILITY & RESOURCES: Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible will it be for your community to turn this concept into a reality?  (Hint: when you think about resources, think: people, money, time, technology, infrastructure, partnerships and any other inputs for implementation)
Highly feasible – resources wouldn’t be an issue for my community if we tried to implement this
Moderately feasible – my community could do it if we could get find assistance with some of our resource constraints
Not feasible – it would be almost impossible for my community to implement this concept; it's just too resource-intensive
SUSTAINABILITY & LONGEVITY: Does this concept feel like it could be sustained as a project, business or movement over years rather than just months? Will continue to be relevant in future?
Yes – this concept has enough momentum to stand on its own two feet and remain relevant for years to come
Maybe – it’s not clear how long it would take for this concept to stand on its own feet or how it will continue to be but there’s reason to feel hopeful
No – this concept will have trouble sustaining itself in the long-run and probably won’t be as relevant in years to come
ORIGINALITY: How new or innovative is this idea? Are there many different versions of this concept out there already or is this something more disruptive and unique?
Very original – I’ve not seen anything else quite like it
Fairly original – there are similar things out there but this particular version brings a new element to the table
Unoriginal – there are already too many other concepts out there that are similar to this one
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world
I liked it but preferred others
It didn't get me overly excited

A little to the side of you idea  but I thought you guys might enjoy the video at the front end of this article: Taking Street Art From The Street To Gallery (And Getting Kids Paid) http://www.fastcoexist.com/1680227/taking-street-art-from-the-street-to-gallery-and-getting-kids-paid
