video_gaming_to_save_the_generation_.description: 10,000 hours. That's the amount of hours you need to invest become excellent at something. When I heard this number I was really scared but then I looked at this statistic and I realized that people all around me are already putting in these hours.
video_gaming_to_save_the_generation_.creator: b8873a156dc35dc99b69d0f93ebe22fc

comments.text: Love how accessible this is - it keeps the intended users in mind at all times.It's also so great that this method not only provides participants with something of a road-map or to-do this, but also demystifies the process, thereby reducing the mental anxiety that plagues so many young job-seekers. Great job, and lovely sketches!
Great sketches, Sana!
Thanks Meena I was a little scared doing them because I am not so good at it.  Thanks for the ego boost :)
Great sketches indeed! 10,000 hours and you'll be an expert! OpenIDEO could be your "gaming platform". :-)

Hi again, what will happen when you get to 10,000 hours on openIDEO? In terms of sketching skills? Brainstorming? Prototyping? Confidence? It made me think of the openIDEO ternship concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/openideo-ternship/
That is a very nice concept and it does make sense to have internet interships :)

Sana, I wonder if you have discovered the Roblox online game platform? This is a very flexible environment to build and launch an online game targeted to 8-18yr olds. Most of the games in the platform are actually made by the kids themselves. There are several different genres to include puzzle and treasure hunts. Your gaming concept sounds like a specialized treasure hunt for an ideal career. The Roblox platform could be a quick way for you to build a test and let real kids try it out.
This sounds like a great way to prototype the idea!

SanaVery creative ideas!  Make sure to check out my concepts to see how these ideas could work together.  I love your ideas about the way that games develop mastery skills which is critical for so many career fields in the "information services" field.  Gaming can also be a great way for young adults from various career fields to collaborate across industries and countries.  Great work!

Thanks a lot Jeff.  I got my inspiration from Malcolm Gladwell's Outliers and Jane McGonigal: Gaming can make a better world(TED talk) video .  I agree with you hundred percent gaming is something that most of the young generation is passionate about and why not take the passion that they have and mix it with education.

Very nice Sana and thanks for pointing to the sources of inspirations!I remember attending a talk in a conference a few years ago where a Ph.D student from HK was presenting her research on how World's of WarCraft and its impact on developing leadership skills.I just did a quick search and found a few related articles (although not the academic paper I saw presented):http://www.forbes.com/2010/07/19/career-leadership-strategy-technology-videogames.htmlhttp://business.financialpost.com/2012/02/21/144354/http://news.softpedia.com/news/IBM-Thinks-World-of-Warcraft-Players-Make-Good-Employees-102139.shtmlThis made me think that there could be 2 ways of developing your concept: either developing specific "games" / tracks or building upon existing games and articulating the skills they might provide you / help you develop. If you go for option 1, it will be great to start thinking of prototyping one specific game to test some of your ideas.

I see your point Anne-Laure and I agree that there are already platforms that cater to certain groups of people so maybe this concept can just be a build up on it.  It will also be a good idea to have it be implemented on already available technology  for prototyping purposes.

You could look at some of the literature on these games and how one can measure the learning curve. You could also imagine a game with some of the skills that could be needed for finding a job and then seeing how you could implement in a game.Talking with a friend yesterday about the different relationships to work across generations, I am also wondering how explicit should be the game about the learning goals. If you think of art, ideologically driven art can get quite boring and "dead" because of the explicit focus on the ideological content. Is there a risk that the game becomes too didactic?

Steadily, gaming concepts (piecemeal rewards, viewable progress, achievement badges, etc.) are being incorporated into learning systems (take a look at what Khan Academy does). As for the 10,000 hours "rule", that is a very generalized number taken from the field of skill acquisition and expertise. take a look at this article: http://www.openeducation.net/2008/11/02/deliberate-practice-%E2%80%93-where-self-reflection-work-ethic-and-ambition-meet/ for a more thorough explanation of deliberate practice than what Malcolm Gladwell offers. Any attempt to equip people with skills should take advantage of research over the last 20 years into skill acquisition and expertise.A couple other texts that you might find helpful/interesting are Talent is Overrated by Geoff Colvin and Bounce by Matthew Syed.

Loving this idea.  The sketches capture the flow of the concept nicely :)  I wonder if you could use the Nike Plus mobile and online websites as inspiration for how to engage with users and let them share their progress?http://nikeplus.nike.com/plus/

Thanks Maegan, I love your idea as well. I use Nike Plus on my phone sometimes when I go for a run and  my only question is what will the end result be for the gamer/user with something like Nike Plus? I am just curious

Their online interface has great visuals for tracking your performance and does a good job with providing motivation.  I think that it also allows people to participate in group activities, which may be interesting to incorporate into your concept.
Oh I see your point, I will try to add them into the sketches :)

comments.text: This is a fantastic idea Alanna. I really hope to see it become a reality.I can picture it being of great value for both the professional and the student. An hour the professional offers inspiring and mentoring a student in their given field of expertise, could be followed by an hour the student the gives to the professional mentoring and offering insights on social media or the drivers for younger demographics. There would be a wonderful place for young professionals to bridge this program over the long term and transition students to become professionals in their own right.As you said it best "everyone has the capacity to give to the system to help those needs be met."

I think this is a pretty novel idea.I could imagine getting involved in this myself. Although it is highly rewarding to give your time to community activities if the 'giver' is very busy and under pressure it is likely to be the first thing that they have to give-up.This gives real incentive to retaining it, or even starting to do it in the first place but with what i would describe as a 'safe' incentive i.e. not financial.

This concept gets my mind "going".  Time is the most valuable commodity we have and it puts all on "equal ground".  There is nothing like having an extra person around to handle tasks that need special attention and there is nothing like learning concepts and receiving instructions from experts.  This a beautiful idea!

I like the direction this is going! Do you think of the hours as credits, kind of like a game where you want to do more to accrue more? I feel like youth today already does so much online without realizing there is real value already. For example, they go on Facebook, Tweet, and use countless services for free... will they want to go onto a site and log what they do to exchange hours? Can you partner with a service like Twitter so what they already do results in points earned?

Hi Alanna, really great concept! You went into lots of detail on the time banking/tracking component of your online database. I was wondering how will potential employers and employees interact online prior to the connection and exchange of work hours. Will the other layer of functionality follow a common hiring procedure: employer posts opportunity and prospective workers apply?

Right on! Our development team have been busy fixing the Update Entry bug and we're back on track now. You'll now be able to edit your posts to add all that refinement-goodness to build out your concepts for improved impact. Bring it on, together!

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:Our panel loved the idea of banking your internship time as something else, or in addition, to monetary value. Time is such a value commodity especially in terms of getting mentorship and feedback from professionals.WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:How do you accredit and provide the right resources?  Ultimately, how does this link to a job? The judges would like you to clarify if this is about work experience (i.e. while you're in school) or if it's directed at a broader audience  which they believe is preferable.  For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Hoping the Enspiral team might collaborate with you to come up with some awesome Refinement moves!

Great idea Alanna! I can see it benefiting all who are involved - the community being global and not limited by geographic location. Everyone who participates could make a profile and list what skills they are good at or what opportunities they are looking for. For example, someone who is especially good at editing, can help others proof read their resume and trade in that time for career related services that they need.
Great build on the inspiration of resource matching, Alanna!

work_experience_time_banking.title: Work Experience Time Banking

py/tuple: IMPACT & REACH: How much impact and reach do you think this concept could have in helping young people transition into the world of work?
A great deal – something like this would really make a difference
A moderate amount – it’s certainly helpful but probably not a game-changer
Not very much – it’s unlikely to make a significant difference to young people seeking work

FEASIBILITY & RESOURCES: Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible will it be for your community to turn this concept into a reality?  (Hint: when you think about resources, think: people, money, time, technology, infrastructure, partnerships and any other inputs for implementation)
Highly feasible – resources wouldn’t be an issue for my community if we tried to implement this
Moderately feasible – my community could do it if we could get find assistance with some of our resource constraints
Not feasible – it would be almost impossible for my community to implement this concept; it's just too resource-intensive
SUSTAINABILITY & LONGEVITY: Does this concept feel like it could be sustained as a project, business or movement over years rather than just months? Will continue to be relevant in future?
Yes – this concept has enough momentum to stand on its own two feet and remain relevant for years to come
Maybe – it’s not clear how long it would take for this concept to stand on its own feet or how it will continue to be but there’s reason to feel hopeful
No – this concept will have trouble sustaining itself in the long-run and probably won’t be as relevant in years to come
ORIGINALITY: How new or innovative is this idea? Are there many different versions of this concept out there already or is this something more disruptive and unique?
Very original – I’ve not seen anything else quite like it
Fairly original – there are similar things out there but this particular version brings a new element to the table
Unoriginal – there are already too many other concepts out there that are similar to this one
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world
I liked it but preferred others
It didn't get me overly excited

comments.text: nice thought.. would be interesting to build on this with ways MNC's or governments can make volunteering more feasible for youth that otherwise couldn't afford to spend too much time unpaid. maybe rotation programs like 'teach first'?
I think especially for students, volunteering can give great experiences and build skills and competencies. Good point, Karel.

Indeed Karel  lots of learning opportunities in voluntaring. Here's an initiative which comprehensively brings together learning + the pursuit of social good: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/project-m-thinking-wrong-doing-right/ We're looking forward to further discussion and examples on this topic.

Hi Karel, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. unemployment_benefit_quota_given_to_sme_.description: Instead of giving quota to unemployed, why not giving the money to SME's that give a job to unemployed to be used to pay the salary?
unemployment_benefit_quota_given_to_sme_.creator: 043418a563e036271c39ea6acbe68e20

comments.text: There is a similar practice happening on the other side of the continent.:)  It's not the unemployment quota precisely, but equivalent benefits are given to SMEs and large firms in Korea since November last year, in the form of  'tax refund' for employing high school graduates. It's used to be 15 million won, but increased to 20 million from this year. Unemployment of young people has become a social problem in korea, also concerning ACADEMIC DEGREE INFLATION, students stepping upwards higher degrees because they can't find satisfying jobs, also the rising cost of education. The government got proactive to solve the problem and decided to vigorously support firms that employ high school graduates. It's nearly becoming a social movement to increase employing them.Still there are pros and cons. There are a large number of high school graduates who got employed that aren't satisfied with the jobs since they are paid less than college graduates. Korean government are now considering to begin supporting the employed rather than the employer. Overall, it is helping.

@Minji Kim, I didn't know this was happening in Korea, thanks for sharing! Sound quite good, although as already Paul mentioned, the difficult part here is how to avoid abuse, and not paying what the work is worth is for sure one usual and extended abuse...though if there's abuse there's probably still other people who are getting the benefits. So, We'll think about that, how to avoid abuse seems is definitely the problem to solve....

The tax incentive is an interesting proposition since it would usually come after the employment has taken place.Here (when the socially responsible government is in power) we have a system called employment awards that publicly set out the conditions and wages that apply to particular types of work. Because it is public knowledge employees can complain to the government if employers abuse either the conditions or wages. If the incentive was paid as a tax benefit after successfully fulfilling requirements that could help to avoid abuse since any failure on the part of the employer would cancel the benefit.Again here the challenge is that when the other party is in power they replace the public award system with employer controlled (and confidential) contracts. Under these conditions employers are free to pay employees different amounts for doing the same job.We see-saw between these two philosophies every 5 to 10 years - it can be quite unsettling.
@Paul Reader Seems like it is the free will of the employer to pay the hired people how much they ever want to, unless there is a regulation to pay equally. It's a cheesy matter I guess

I should add when awards are in force there is an option for employers to pay above award wages - but there is no secrecy about it - no special treatment of one person over another doing the same work.

I think this is a good idea, but with certain conditions- these dollars would need to be put to hiring of an additional person who is at the moment unemployed, rather than potentially raising the salary of a current star employee. SME's are the engines of our economy- it is incredible powerful to empower entities that have the capacity to grow, scale, and make potentially hundreds of new hires.

I would love to see a way to make this concept work in practice.Experience here in Australia shows SME abuse of similar schemes that thankfully have only been applied to supplementary payments rather than what is vital life support for some people.If such employment could be guaranteed to be long term, for instance SME's would only qualify for such assistance after continuing a person's employment for at least double the time during which the benefits are received. Employers abusing this would simply be excluded from any other benefit.What continues to happen here is a rapid turnover of short-term subsidised employment which is of little or no benefit to the employee beyond an temporary improvement in lifestyle.I hope we can come up with a way to overcome such abuse because in theory the concept is great and does potentially increase productivity.

@Chelsea, of course that is the idea, I maybe didn't express it right...I'll have to check my proposal,,,but this job+salary should be given to unemployed of course, for new workplaces needed in SME's (not to substitute existing workplaces)
@Paul, your right the biggest challenge here is how could it be regulated to avoid abuse, specially by employers....a difficult one!

unemployment_benefit_quota_given_to_sme_.title: Unemployment benefit quota given to SME's to hire young people

flip_it.description: Traditional classroom learning (1_to_many) is changed from locked in a classroom and placed on the internet. Homework which is normally done by oneself at home is made collaborative in the classroom. What else can be flipped!
flip_it.creator: d1aacd22b4aa8bdc73b7b0053eb8a201

comments.text: I just graduated from a UK boarding school and strongly support the flipped classroom approach. I am personally developing a system of mobile applications to strengthen the in-class component of flipping the classroom. As the pure knowledge is acquired ahead of class through platform such as KhanAcademy/Udacity/edX/Coursera etc., in-class discussions become increasingly important to deepen the understanding through interactive debates. With my project, I am trying to restructure these interactive discussions by automating aspects such as hand-raising and student-selection. The goal is to guide the interactions in real-time to render discussions fairer, more efficient and more creative without constraining the face to face interaction. I presented this concept at the final of the Thiel Fellowship in SFO in April and met a wide set of entrepreneurs in the educational technology sphere.The bottom line: If we want to flip the classroom, we cannot solely focus on innovating outside the classroom but also need to redesign the classroom and student interaction! At the same time, educators but also entrepreneurs in Europe ( I can speak mostly from UK and Germany) need to be more open towards these innovations and their transformative role!

Interesting James. I did my masters online (the brilliantly intense Masters in Design at RMIT) and feel that it prepped me well for my current job at OpenIDEO as I became used to working collaboratively yet remotely. As the workplace changes  there are many soft skills which can be picked up through remote learning alongside hard skills.  I feel there will always be room for classroom learning  yet it's exciting to see so many developments in the online space.
Nice provocation James - it's interesting to think about how we take certain models or processes of education for granted and assume they're the only way!

flip_it.title: Flip It

testing_grounds.description: Have young secondary school students work on weekly projects covering a range of job types.
testing_grounds.creator: a22afee17df6b2501c35806958b4eb25

comments.text: Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

It sounds like you were intending this to be incorporated into the secondary school term and part of the secondary school curriculum?I would suggest to deploy it as a "summer school". It would be done as a fun activity over the holiday break, when the students' minds are not clouded by their school obligations and pressures.
This would be a great summer school projects!
I didn't make that very clear did I! I was definitely thinking summer school. I think having full days to work on the projects is important.

On the contrary I think much greater benefit would be gained by integrating this as part of regular curriculum, particularly for the age ranges suggested. If, as Andrew suggests their minds are becoming clouded by obligations and pressures they would become a great way to relieve that pressure and provide them with renewed energy and vigor thereafter.

It sounds like you're trying to bring design-thinking to the school environment. Which is awesome! You should check out ProjectH's studioh:http://www.projecthdesign.org/#studio-hThey focus on students roughly in the age range you're talking about and they have them work on actual projects that improve their community

I know of them and I appreciate their dedication to real projects. I think that is important, because it gives the projects real meaning outside of academia. I would imagine creating projects for this age group and time frame could be difficult, but I think it is important to do. Especially in this context.

This is an idea whose time has come for being built into secondary school curricula. It is an opportunity for using content in an interdisciplinary way, which is an educational goal independent of career preparation.. Most schools have ways of pulling whole days for activities of sufficient importance. As an example, my son's school has four full days in the year for service learning off site.

I like this idea. In fact, I think it should be offerered to even younger students (8-12). Too often, we underestimate the capabilities of younger and more enthusiastic learners. Given the early opportunity for real-world hands-on projects may not only lead to better employment numbers, it might even give an energizing jolt to hiring companies--passionately engaged employees wired for onnovation!

I agree I think younger could be better. I went with this age group, because I felt like it was when people start trying to make their own informed decisions. However I am certainly not a specialist in child development or middle school/junior high education, so any expertise in that area is appreciated.
Digging the 'design their future' notion here!

comments.text: Glad you found us Gerard! I would love to give you more information on MindSumo to add to the inspiration. Let me know if you have any questions.

Great stuff Gerard! Perhaps you could add a link to your post so folks can easily check out the goodness on MindSumo? Tip: to activate links in your post, hit the Update Entry button up there on the right, then follow the instructions here: http://bit.ly/oi_link

Oh, that seems like a very interesting website and project. There are several inspirations that are in a way similar, of companies using challenges to assess the qualities of students. I posted about the Brandstorm game from L'Oral, which is a recruiting tool [ http://bit.ly/LcIlLY ], Steph Rymer posted about Google's Summer of Code [ http://bit.ly/JRc249 ], which is a bit different, but still; and Phoenix Rudner posted about the Imagine Cup of Microsoft [ bit.ly/Lairwc ]. I think these projects are great ways for students to show off their skills and develop them, plus to get closer to finding a job.It would be interesting to explore how we can turn this into a concept.

transitionning_to_a_multilangual_busines.description: In today's business world is no longer a benefit, but almost a necessity to have multilingual employees. Our world, and today's business world in particular is in the midst of globalizing and we need to catch up.
transitionning_to_a_multilangual_busines.creator: 8cfd908f431292099d78c0eed0ff589e

comments.text: Interesting thoughts. In the May issue of the Harvard Business review, there was an interesting article about how companies can benefit from a one-language policy [ http://bit.ly/HXwMbc ], mainly focused on English. For non-native speakers, this is definitely a skill they need to develop (further). But, there's a catch. In the multinational company I worked in, English was also the corporate language. And, somehow, we non-native English speakers managed to have less problems understanding eachother, than the native speakers. The global English differs from 'English-English'. And knowing how other languages are constructed (building of sentences) helps understand people better. Especially style and grammar can make understanding difficult.But, language is an important factor. Great inspiration.

Thank you Arjan, great input! It makes sense that non-native speakers have an easier time understanding others who are also non-natives because they were forced to think differently. They were forced to think and adjust to a language that is not native to them. That helps them develop the skill to also think differently when others speak to them in that same non-native language.  In other words they develop a flexibility, and broader way of communicating than those who only speak the native language. It can be thought of as a muscle almost. You are better at communicating when you practice different communication techniques or languages.

Yes, that certainly helps. What I notice from non-native speakers (whose language I know a bit of) is that they often use constructions of sentences that are typical of their native languages. From that, you can recognize where people are from. It does help if you understand different languages a bit, because it makes it easier to understand the meaning of the words someone is using and the message they want to convey.

Daniella, I love that you've brought a global consideration to this - you're right that language skills are going to be increasingly necessary for new hires. I wonder how this might inspire our thinking in the upcoming Concepting phase? I can already think of some ideas that promote language development opportunities for young people :)
This already inspired some thought in that direction. Check out Anne-Laure's inspiration: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/livemocha-/

Very good point. I am living in The Netherlands and I am connected to Spanish immigrants looking for jobs in NL, Germany and Belgium. Despite their higher education qualifications, the fact they only speak Spanish makes it almost impossible for them to find a job...
Thank you for your input Joan. I too speak more than one language. I found that it also helps me understand other cultures, which in itself proves to be very helpful sometimes.

Good point Daniella. It will be interesting to see this idea developed at the concepting level: how can you help young people to develop multlingual skills? Looking forward to see this idea developed.
Hi again, today someone told me about a service that made me think of your inspiration: http://livemocha.com/I'll post it as well

transitionning_to_a_multilangual_busines.title: Transitionning to a Multilangual Business World

no_experience_irrelevant_experience_is_t.description: I have hired a significant number of candidates. Interestingly, many of my team's best assets were considered to have no (relevant) experience. Here's why I gave them a chance anyways and how it worked out - most of the time for the best.
no_experience_irrelevant_experience_is_t.creator: ed3793643dc319af7fc8bfb74c14af1d

comments.text: Great perspective and inspiration!A common problem with many job descriptions and criteria, at least in my experience, is that few if any applicants can satisfy the requirements. Also HR departments often have inadequate understanding of the real needs and even less idea of what can be made of the job.I recently had an interview for an IT training position with a firm I had watched develop. Being of a sinilar age to the founder I was certainly an "unlikely" candidate. Towards the end of the interview the owner asked about my experience in networking saying he supposed he would be fortunate to find someone with both training and networking skills. With network experience 5 years out of date I had to admit that my knowledge was rusty. It also became apparent that what was required was someone to share networking administration with occasional training outside the IT sphere.The job being offered was not the job for which I had applied and presumably given my age the risk was too great.

Thanks for you much appreciated feedback and experience Paul.I have been on both sides, hiring and applying and by all means, many things can go wrong which is no surprise when the company hiring struggles to even understand what/who they are looking for.Best of luck to you whether you are still looking or have found a position!
Thanks Cyril!At age 60 it was probably a bit cheeky of me to apply for that position but, even so, I am lacking nothing in enthusiasm for what I can contribute.
With the old age its difficult to find a good positionssearch jobs at search50.net
all right about the jobs herehttp://www.search50.net

Great inspiration Cyril!I think you raise a couple of interesting issues.On the employers part: how can employers give a chance to people who do not "fit" on paper? How can they develop a sense of risk taking realizing that having been able to tick all the boxes on the job description is not all what you need to be a good candidate? This is difficult I think and it goes down to mindset and how you value people. There might be something about the recruitment process. If you haven't got this email from Sandra, you would have never known of her. I know someone who was told in the same week by the HR manager of an international business school that she was very unlikely to get a research position because her research interests and skills were a very poor fit for the school and got an invitation to come to give a job talk in that same school, and eventually got the job as a faculty. Interesting gap isn't it? I'm not saying that we should get rid of HR but sometime they might not have the same perspective. Maybe we need to explain them better what we need and give them more freedom, or get more involved.On the applicants side: how can you learn how to present your maybe not so relevant experience in a way that can be attractive? It is about confidence and communication. The confidence can come from sharing stories as yours and a few others in this inspiration phase. It is then also important to provide applicants with a better understanding of communication tools, beyond the traditional resume that might not allow them to do so. Interesting paths to explore for the concepting phase!

Thanks for your feedbacks and the issues you discuss.If anything, I tried to share my experience where candidates who didn't fit on paper, did much better and more than some who appeared to be a good fit CV-wise. As Paul (shame we can't tag people on this platform... unless I just don't know how) commented a week ago this can be the employer's fault as the job description and requirements are ill defined. In my case, what happened is that I met some candidates and found something I liked and didn't expect. As you rightly said, circumstances are essential. What if I had not been able to see Sandra's email. What if I had thought my time would have been better spent with a client than chatting with "prospect" candidates?As you rightly say, on the candidate side, confidence and communication are essential. But how do you get some attention? a few seconds of bandwidth from the people who may be needing you?I'm highly interested about your "I'm not saying we need to get rid of HR but..." The web (2.0 or whatever) is all about bringing people together, sometimes squeezing in-betweeners. Often I've read we wouldn't need real estate agents or many other professions anymore. It is not happening and won't in the near future. Why not HR? We absolutely need HR. Yet, HR doesn't have to always stand between candidates and recruiters... More to come in the connecting phase for sure!

Hi Cyril,I don't think you can tag someone, but you could put the link to Paul's inspiration. Regarding your point about circumstances, this might highlight the need to rethink the recruitment process: different platform and criteria to hire someone, involvement of different actors, etc.On the actors' point, this raises again the role of HR. Maybe this means that HR if involved should be involved (at least in some contexts with specific needs) only in the administrative process afterwards. Maybe in fact even some part of the process can be managed differently. Regarding communication, this can imply changes in the education philosophy (so that young people feel more confident), offering more opportunities to experiment - through internships and volunteering : http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/re-thinking-the-classroom-only-university/and specific courses focusing on design thinking, communication: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/design-thinking-crash-course/Maybe also sharing stories such as James Turner's teapot story: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/how-a-teapot-and-twitter-got-me-a-job-offer-after-graduating/
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
Wow, thanks! I was able to tell Sandra about all this, and now need even more to get hold of Olivier and let him know about his recent fame...

A recent blog post on HBR (Seven "Non-Negotiables" to Prevent a Bad Hire) echoes your sentiments. They argue that character traits should trump job-specific skills in the hiring process. As a result of assessing cultural fit first and relevant experience second, their organization has almost zero turnover.http://blogs.hbr.org/cs/2012/05/7_non-negotiables_to_prevent_a.html
I can relate to this article indeed. Thanks for this interesting read Sarah.
Same story more recent article on this, "the case for hiring under-qualified-employees": http://www.forbes.com/sites/davidkwilliams/2012/06/13/the-case-for-hiring-under-qualified-employees/
Way to go Cyril! Cheers for sharing these stellar insights. We're excited at what they might inspire in the upcoming Concepting phase. Looking forward to seeing more of you on OpenIDEO.
Thanks Meena! I'm really glad I joined OpenIDEO early on in this challenge.

Really good inspiration. The part of taking a deeper look on the experience of the candidate is as important as any other part of the CV, because experience can be gained not only with a good job, but with many other kinds of events, that we can do. ;)

Thanks for you feedback! I most certainly agree with you.The 2 problems though is that (young) candidates may have gained life changing experiences which they would not write on their CV. Moreover, I am not sure I would have been able to find out about what Olivier went through during a formal interview.

great story ! especially the point about caring for candidates - too often employers see human capital as a commodity.paul's experience is also interesting.. employers ought to be open to new possibilities regardless of age.both discounting young people due to inflated requirements for experience AND replacing older workers with younger, cheaper, labour are detrimental.. its about balance - a diverse range of ages, experience levels, backgrounds allows employers to tap into multiple perspectives and have the best of both.

I agree entirely and applaud Cyril for his approach.I am currently working in the fast-food industry here which seems to be one of the worst industries for commodification of its workforce.By contrast, Stefan has another great example where valuing human capital is paying dividends ( http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/the-secret-to-germany-s-low-youth-unemployment/  )

Thanks Paul for my first Applause on OpenIdeo! Quite the milestone ;)Caring, whether for candidates or customers (or a job offer!) is indeed the most important take away of my story.Seth Godin, among others, said it many times:http://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2012/05/the-simple-antidote-to-a-corporatized-unfeeling-profit-maximizing-world.htmlhttp://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2011/05/caring-965.htmlhttp://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2012/01/who-cares.html

an_educational_network_for_8_12_year_old.description: 8-12 year old students take classes where they build software apps. A non-profit organization hosts a platform that connects students and schools to each other. They collaborate to build great apps learning to network, to create and working globally.
an_educational_network_for_8_12_year_old.creator: 4f33f60372e6bc655f12fa6964b669da

comments.text: Nice one, Simon! And I wonder whether there might be some learnings from DIY (https://diy.org/) on motivating particpation amongst this age group? And do folks have thoughts on how these 8-12 year olds might transition beyond such an intiative given our target age for this challenge is 16-24 year olds? Might 'graduating' members have opportunities to mentor? And anyone got any ideas on a name for this app-ilicious concept? Let's bring on the builds!

Thanks Meena.Perhaps the 8-12 year olds is too far away from the target group. My point was to try and address the challenge before it happens. Also the app needs to be simple enough for a child to use. I have this mental picture of an 8 year old trying to 'code' using an iPad app.Thanks for sharing the DIY link. From my perspective it is quite different, but would be interested to hear other views. DIY seems to be a place to present stuff you have made. The education/application is meant to be a place where you create together. My idea would be that someone in the US could work with kids in India and Sri Lanka on the very same project. Their individual teachers would help with the hands-on coaching. Essentially creating both student 2 student and also teacher 2 teacher networks.I would love to get some input for how to take the concept further.
Updated and cleaned up after my initial crude draft.

design_education_for_homeless_young_peop.description: Through a design curriculum that helps homeless youth. We can provided them with a basic understanding of industrial, graphic and architectural design skills that could be applied in their everyday lives and can serve of inspiration for a job.
design_education_for_homeless_young_peop.creator: 69c68aa1728f4619f316b93298416596

comments.text: I wonder if there's a variant of this idea that could kill two (proverbial) birds with one stone....What if there was a curriculum that provided young homeless people with vocational training in catering and food hygiene by giving them positions in soup kitchens?   That way, they're getting valuable skills (and potentially qualifications) whilst also providing services for other homeless people.Not perhaps as lofty or academic as a design curriculum but another way in which this idea could be scaled/deployed but potentially with double dividends....

I think you bring a good idea into this and I think it has great potential. My first idea was to provide skills to homeless teenagers while training university students (the ones providing the skills) to become good educators. Vocational training could be a sub-wing that homeless teenagers may choose to take. That way they get choices rather that us giving them what we think they need. What do you think?
I mean to say, rather than us giving them what we think they need.

I think the beauty of the original idea is that it lets homeless kids aim high, and aim for something they might not ordinarily wind up in. I am kind of uncomfortable with the idea of training them in soup kitchens. Another approach might be to have them organize and run a soup kitchen, and learn managerial skills. Self-esteem and empowerment really grows when one can help others, and take responsibility for helping others.

I agree on feeling uncomfortable about training homeless teenagers for kitchen soups, as by default elimination options for them without even letting them choose who they want to be. This is re reason why I created this curriculum. In order for them to discover new ways of survival and education as a matter of fact. Once they have/see and experience the options, they get to choose, but we as "privileged" should not choose for them. If the idea of a soup kitchen should be applied, I would rather providing them the opportunity of developing a business plan in which they decide what service to offer.
I would like to suggest that you add a more engaging visual. I was looking for this concept to see how it is doing, and had a hard time finding it as I browse through the concepts.
Tamar,  what do you mean by a more engaging visual? do you mean a different image?

Hello Isabel!It's the first time I've come across a Concept focused on the young homeless, and I'm very happy I did. I'm sure there are already (unfortunately) many young people on the streets through difficulty in finding a job, and they need to be brought back into the job world to gain confidence in themselves too. Coincidently, I was watching an English channel yesterday that was about  http://www.streetwiseopera.org/ - an organisation which runs a weekly music Workshop Programme in 11 homeless centres around the UK. I thought it was particularly interesting to focus on the personal development of the homeless through participation in music making of the highest quality. I'd love to know a bit more how you imagine to design this system for young homeless people in the world.

Hi Ana, thank you for sharing your inspiration. This is what I envision: Use the brain and energy power of university students to help homeless or low-income teenagers to learn about the different ways of making a living. This way, university students develop education skills that could develop great teachers in the future, and at disadvantage teenagers (in this case homeless), develop skills that could land them a job and why not inspire them to get educated. I also envision companies committing to providing small internship opportunities to these teenagers as means of giving them hope, increasing their self-stem and seeing their potential. What do you think?
This is fascinating. I would like to learn much more about it - don't know if that should happen at this phase or at the refinement phase. Really novel, and unique.
Tamar you can see more about this project in the archives of my blog: http://isabelperdomo.wordpress.com/2011/06/

Thank you - it is wonderful.My questions are about the elements that you think might transfer to other people and situations. What items are in your curriculum (it is hard too read the table you posted)? How much of your time was involved? Did you have a budget? Who paid for supplies? What are the key elements? Does it require affiliation with a design school?

Tamar can you elaborate a little more in the question regarding the items? what exactly do you mean by items? I followed a process starting by introducing the teens to the world of design. You see to most of them, the term design is completely alien. Once they knew what design was, they explored how their lives where affected by design. While in that process most of them started finding what part of design they identified with and what part of their lives could inspire such identification. After that I introduced them to the challenge and they started the ideation process followed by prototyping. Because of the precarious conditions of the emergency centers where these teens lived, the curriculum was delivered only for two weeks, and repeated twice with different groups. It may seem short, but I believe it made an impact. I spent approximately $1,500 in materials. Also, we used reclaimed materials and hundreds of plastic lids donated by companies. Before heading to Colombia, I hosted a fundraising event that gave me $600. iDo at SF State University donated $400 and I put $500 of my own money plus my time and the coverage of all my travel and living expenses. Ideally, it would require affiliation with a design school as under perfect conditions, this curriculum could be constantly delivered. You see the teenagers live in this place for a period of 3 to 4 weeks. That means that if there are two pilot 2 week curriculums, they could be re-delivered once a month by a different group of designers on a different group of students. I think for this challenge, it would be wonderful if the curriculum was delivered by people already in the industry. That is designers or firms willing to give a percentage of their time to teach design. That way the teens could get a glimpse of the real design world and perhaps be given an opportunity as interns.
This is very helpful. Also, I think it could work for other fields - film making, creative writing, and probably others. Very nice!

Exactly, that is the beauty of it. That it can be applied in many fields. I almost dream of having three to four of these types of curriculums happening at the same time with the same population, that way the students could truly see what they are good at and what they would like to do with their lives.

I think that's the underlying concept, and your pilot program is an example of the concept. Definitely. You can expand the concept, and point out that it applies to other subject areas/skills. Include the "almost dream"! It is great.

Great stuff, Isabel! Perhaps folks here might like to give feedback and suggestions on how this initiative might be scaled to other areas   and collaboratively build the idea even further during our Concepting phase.

That would be wonderful. When introducing design to the young men at the homeless shelter, I saw a big change on how they saw life. They were much more hopeful as some of them had discovered a new passion that eventually could lead to making a living.

design_education_for_homeless_young_peop.title: Design education for homeless young people across the world

comments.text: Like Ephraim, I think FIRST or other robotics experiences are a great part of an education. To make  it work one needs a volunteer mentor, which would be particularly invaluable if someone offers to work with students who would not normally have access to a technically skilled person. Because these robotics programs are often so expensive because of the cost of buying the kits, it's easier for affluent families and schools to get such a team together..

Hi KadeGreat post - if you put the link into the body of your inspiration it will become clickable ( http://www.lmrobotics.com/  ) In fact if you choose you could use the editor to make a link from any text you choose. You can retrospectively do this by updating your inspiration.I am in complete agreement with your philosophy here - and would extend it further. The class you pictured appears to be beyong basic algebra, geometry and trigonometry but exposing kids at the basic level to possible pathways that can result from taking an interest in the subjects is extremely powerful too. Such exposure could be followed up with simple examples of triangulation, Pythagoras, temperature conversion etc.  I don't know what happens in US schools but I learnt set theory in 12th grade whereas now it's taught through practical application in primary school here.

Is this FIRST Robotics? FIRST gives students the opportunity to work as a design team to find a solution to a problem. Not only do you strengthen soft skills, but you master the engineering process of identifying a problem and creating a solution.FIRST also encourages teams to find an engineer to be their mentor so  they may learn 'real job' habits and tricks from them.

comments.text: Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Hi Sam and the wonderful OpenIDEO community!  This piece was recently brought to my attention and I wanted to reach out as founder of Young Impact and StartUp Scrambles for 2 reasons: 1) To see if there was anything I can add to the conversation, and2) To offer a brief sidebar regarding the Young Impact/StartUp Scramble brands, which have actively served the broader campus and corporate communities since 2001 and 2008, respectively.  Many of the themes espoused above, in this post, are central to the Scramble experience. We continue to refine our approach and program efficacy to achieve higher-impact experiential learning outcomes under rigorous time constraints. Our programs also happen to run 48 hours like you suggest above. With the help of a cadre of friends and field experts, we've bootstrapped, deconstructed, and re-built the company and program into what it is now -- and it's an intense and joyful ride. You can actually see the evolution in the quality of media we've produced from year to year -- from a Flip Camera to professional production =) http://www.youtube.com/user/StartUpScramble.@Sasha, thank you for citing our work above! I personally appreciate the space to share these thoughts and community's contributions.

Hey Sam,This is a really interesting idea! I was wondering, how would you organize these teams? How would people connect and collaborate?You should take a look at Sasha's LAB 21 concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/lab-21-co-learning-labs-with-21st-century-guidance-counselors/Haiyan's Youth Cafe concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/youthcafe/And Andrew's Teens become CEOs... concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/teens-become-ceos....-of-community-projects/They all provide interesting methods for bringing people together that could be incorporated into your idea.Also, I recognized that you are incorporating some ideas from speakers who've given TED talks so I thought I'd provide some links for those who are interested in learning more:Dan Pink on purpose, autonomy, and mastery being the sources of motivation: http://www.ted.com/talks/lang/en/dan_pink_on_motivation.htmlSimon Sinek on staring with the WHY: http://www.ted.com/talks/lang/en/simon_sinek_how_great_leaders_inspire_action.html

Hey David,Thanks for your feedback!Absolutely - yes thanks for posting Dan Pink & Simon Simenek - two very influential TED talks for me, and I should add we're working with a lot of Dan Pink's ideas over at Enspiral (http://www.enspiral.com) .How would it all hang together? Well I would view it as a program which is based over a 6-12 month period, along the same lines as School for Social Entrepreneurs, with some more holistic discussion, action weekends & a permanent space. Simple really.Sasha's LAB21 idea looks great - very much like the co-working spaces which are spreading around the world, except for younger people.  We have one here in Wellington, but The Hub is probably best known around the world for it's work, and I'm a big fan of what Centre for Social Innovation have done in Toronto: http://socialinnovation.ca/Youth Cafe looks good - definitely coming from the same idea space as World Cafe, Open Space, and the next evolution we're developing in Wellington - Collaboration Cafe.  I'm a big fan of small group, conversive experiences which are lightly facilitated for co-creation & innovation.I like Andrew's idea for Teens becoming CEO's, but would add some more offline elements to support the online experience.  Thanks again.Sam

Hi David -- Hi Sam-- I definitely think its a great idea to create opportunities for youth at the intersection of entrepreneurship and social innovation.  Thank you both for making those connections.A few weeks ago I shared Young Impact's StartUp Scramble website with Caroline.  She has a concept called Student Start Up: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/student-start-up-program/.Young Impact's site is: http://startupscramble.com/Its all very exciting and I'm happy to be a part of this experience.

startup_scramble.title: Startup Scramble

making_ivy_league_accessible_for_the_res.description: Nearly every high school student dreams of becoming an Ivy Leaguer (or the equivalent). Some make it. Most settle for "less." Why should they have to?
making_ivy_league_accessible_for_the_res.creator: 55396b7895d28d1618bd9e8fa381897f

comments.text: Very very solid idea from Stanford in my opinion. This speaks volumes to the fact that this college believes in the cause of educating the future, not just collecting the $40,000 tuition.I really connect with this article because some high school students slip through the cracks. Some like me who grew up in farm town didn't think college an option so didn't strive to get that 4.0. What Stanford is doing is democratizing education here.

I really like the idea of making these type of lectures available. Unfortunately, there's still too much emphasis on which school students went to in recruiting. Sometimes the focus should shift to actual skills, knowledge and competencies.

Would definitely agree with you here. As an employer or an HR manager though I am sure it is tough sifting through those resumes. I can empathize with them, it is like automatically choosing the pink gummie treats because past experience says they are most likely to be the best.I do believe that fundamental assumption is starting to change. We are seeing skills based hiring especially for start ups. Corporate just moves slowly but there is progress.

The online courses are about as close to an "Ivy League" experience as one can get without attending the school themselves, and they're definitely a step in the right direction.As a student at an Ivy (Penn), I'd maintain that nothing comes close to replicating the educational experience of actually being a student there. Only part of the educational experience is going to class and doing homework and taking tests -- the "traditional" part of the education that is captured very well by online courses. The rest of the experience -- namely, being surrounded by very smart, driven peers -- is lost. Last year, I learned just as much from my peers as I did from my classes. There's nothing quite like working on problem sets with friends until the wee hours of the morning and learning from their approaches to problems.
Students did not get credit but they did get a certificate. The classes I took were challenging and engaging.

making_ivy_league_accessible_for_the_res.title: Making Ivy League accessible for the rest of us

learn_to_code.creator: 48ecf277b83c64ddfda2e1568408d596

comments.text: While it is undoubtedly true that learning a few relatively simple skills could enable one to provide valuable services in building websites, I think it is important not to underplay the challenge of learning to program at a high level.  Peter Norvig, Director of Research at Google, has written an interesting article titled "Teach Yourself Programming in 10 Years."  http://norvig.com/21-days.html

I would say learning to code is equivalent to learning carpentry. You can't expect to do great work until you have a ton of experience, but you have to start somewhere. There's a much lower barrier for entry in web development than in a high-level programming language like C++. You also have to know your audience. You won't be building a international online brand after taking a codecademy course online, but you certainly can build a website for your Aunt's pet washing business. If we're talking about skills that lead to jobs coding, especially on the web, is a nice skill to have.

True. I also think when it comes to web design, a lot of smaller companies have fairly low demands for what they'd want from a website, and it's also work that I've found is best to learn on the job, so building a basic knowledge from online resources and honing them through practice projects for small local businesses could be an effective approach.

I am currently taking classes on Codecademy, udacity and coursera mostly in web development and program design. Deploying web-apps, understanding the wider context and actually taking the understanding into project work appears to be the greatest obstacle for many in those Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs) , including myself. I hope to see an even stronger emphasis on this phase of learning e.g. with assisted project work, inter-platform trouble-shooting(-->there is a tutorial for everything and almost every problem has been discussed somewhere but how can I just find the exact thread I need) etc. . It would be interesting to find ways to give beginners the most suitable course schedule and order of classes for a given skill in web-/software development which they seek to learn!

Great discussion you've triggered here Mike! You might want to add a link for Code Academy to your post for folks out there who don't know about it. (To activate links in your post, hit the Update Entry button up there on the right, then follow the instructions here: http://bit.ly/oi_link )

I think web design is also a great area for self-education - there are so many free resources available on the internet that teach web development so it's an option open to kids from a lot of backgrounds.

creating_the_open_ideo_classroom.creator: 56ce68eb27a622496b044dccefa7e95b

comments.text: Interesting idea. I think there is a lot of potential in using openIDEO and there are in fact already a couple of university students teams on the platform. It would be indeed interesting to use it also with high school students. Are you thinking of having the mentors located in one specific school and coaching a group of students in that school.One could also imagine developing a platform for high schools with maybe some specific challenges or more specific feedback. This will take away the possibility of interacting with adults, but it might allow to focus more on communication, collaboration and creativity... Just a thought.

To answer you first question, no mentors would not be assigned to certain schools since there are so little OpenIDEO users. There may be as few as zero Open IDEO students in a school at a time. Mentors would be randomly assigned to simulate having a boss. You would communicate through an email system based on the OpenIDEO website.I like your idea of a special platform for high schools. They could be used to fix problems within a school such as tardiness and laziness. Students could interact in a more friendly, creative environment.Overall, I like your ideas, but it would be inappropriate to adopt these ideas as my own. They are very different then my original intentions, so I think it would be best if you built on my concept. I would surely applaud your new concept if published.

Hi Noam,thanks for the clarification on the role of mentors. I am not completely sure about the "simulating the boss" part as it seems to me that it could create some tension with the collaboration taking place on the platform but that might be possible.My suggestion of creating specific challenge was more to be able to create specific challenges for high school students and include the mentors more... but I understand your perspective. I think you could include this as an option in your concept, although I also understand if it does not fit in your focus.

Hi Anne,You're welcome. The "simulation of the boss" would basically mean that the mentor would give students deadlines they must finnish their work by similar to being a journalist. Students would have to publish at least six articles a year and mentors would edit their articles and send them back if need be. Mentors would be like editors of newspapers the way they hand out deadlines and approove articles. They would also be like teachers guiding the students through the process.I guess since it is past concepting time that I must add that second piece to my article. Thanks for the feed back.

Sorry I can't add that second part to my article; it wouldn't work with my previous article. Take this as a lesson. If you want something to be done, do it yourself because sometimes the other person may not be able to complete it for you.
On your first comment: thank you for this clarification. On your second comment: No worries. I did not expect you to add it. I was trying to explore possibilities of growning your concept.
Thanks.

Great Build Noam !! I was trying to put forward the idea that OpenIDEO can be a great platform for building skills.. You have built that idea it into something concrete. Your concept will definitely increase awareness, which will help young people sign up and contribute to OpenIDEO. Facilitating the process using mentors will help students overcome creative blocks and fear of failure which is essential in developing skills such as creativity. That will be extremely useful!
Thanks, but you should be getting all the credit. You came up with the initial idea. Otherwise, I would've never thought of it. Great job inspiring others!
interesting idea... I love the youth inspiration and networking implications...everyone benefits from young people honing their problem solving skills and creativity!
Thanks for the positive feedback.

I think this is a very worthwhile idea (from an educational standpoint, at least) and have thought of doing this myself with high school students where I live. Interestingly the educational institution to which I proposed this, which does after school and weekend programming rather than school day program, told me they have found it very difficult to get high school students to engage in enrichment programs outside of the typical sports/music/service and prep courses for preparing for college application. It would take some marketing.

I plan to have many speakers to motivate those ambitious children who strive for a better world or get a better job. Speakers would be relatable college graduates who tell about how Open IDEO helped them succeed in life. This marketing technique may only reach out to the children, so I also plan on sending flyers home to the parents because I remember when I was a kid, that I never told my parents what happened in school that day.Overall, this program may not reach out to all students, but I hope it reaches out to the ambitious students who strive to better the world or themselves.

creating_the_open_ideo_classroom.title: Creating The Open IDEO Classroom

african_agriculture_getting_its_sexy_bac.description: Africa's schooling system teaches us to 'diss' agriculture and seek scarce office jobs in cities. Yet, agriculture contributes to 25% of my country's GDP, for example. African agriculture has to regain its sexy back, at least to employ its youth.
african_agriculture_getting_its_sexy_bac.creator: 69d136f1df0fbbf9aa106b715d8a4d25

comments.text: A good example of the "brain drain" concept at work. I think this is a good opportunity area to indeed "bring sexy back" to less attractive yet equally important business sectors. Nice share!
Hi AndyThanks for your comment. True, we need to bring sexy back to less attractive sectors such as African agriculture. We can't all fit in a call centre. Have a great weekend.

I would say this is true across the globe. In the US we also have this disdain for vocational school. Many vocations are portable across the globe and are well paying.  We need the "sexy back" in plumbing, electrical, and mechanics. They are good paying jobs and there is nothing wrong with a kid who would rather wire a house than sit with Jane Austen.
Hi MoneraI always presumed since the American economy is so huge, such jobs  as plumbing are done by immigrants.

Good comment, Festus. This is a global topic - being aware of where job opportunities are and promote them correctly. The concept of 'job-related match making' is very important for proper distribution of talents.

Hi JoachimYes it's true. ICT is bandied too much in Africa as an unemployment medicine as if we have Bangalore like outsourcing industries. Once we sort out agriculture can we then consider other buzzwords about earning a living

Totally agree, Festus! Agriculture and food security are ket areas for innovation and offer work opportunities for young people. You might therefor like our African project: TripleE http://prezi.com/-oxr8gtgcckm
Hi ArnoldThanks for your response. Africa can't tout ICT as its unemployment panacea when it can't even feed itself. I will check out your project.

african_agriculture_getting_its_sexy_bac.title: African agriculture: getting its sexy back

swim_against_the_tide.description: When did we start optimizing our résumé instead of following our interest? At the end our résumés turn out to be very similar. Doing something in a different way makes you stand out again.
swim_against_the_tide.creator: 8082a75025cb51e513aff379783121c9

comments.text: Great analogous thinking, Sabine  we're big fans: http://bit.ly/oi_analogous

swim_against_the_tide.title: Swim against the tide

get_100000_to_drop_out_of_college.description: Peter Thiel (Paypal co-founder, Venture Capitalist and the first investor in facebook) started a program called "20 under 20" where he pays twenty kids under the age of 20 $100,000 to leave school and start a company.
get_100000_to_drop_out_of_college.creator: a3b7f8ab29556462485b17de64a932af

comments.text: Interesting articles and will be an interesting experiment to watch.I suspect Thiel is unwittingly contributing to the next "bubble", in entrepreurship, although I expect the market will stand more than 20 new entrepreneurs, and mature age education is gaining ground for those who need to replenish their knowledge-base later.Mind you there are many alternatives to college fed occupations that can provide satisfaction, unless of course you need to become a millionaire - then it seems you also need to start a company.Interesting times - I'm still backing a good education for my grand-children, although not necessarily Ivy League, and not necessarily just a repeat of my, or my children's education.
It is my hope that this will be around when my kids are the right age.  Uncollege.org comes from this experiment.

get_100000_to_drop_out_of_college.title: Get $100000 to drop out of college

understanding_generational_differences.description: One of the biggest challenges facing employers has to be understanding the fundamental differences in the way people work, engage with each other, and find meaning in what they do. Failure to do so will only further alienate today's youth.
understanding_generational_differences.creator: c9731f8b737e93013d40ec2450c3f109

comments.text: Great thought, Martin. OpenIDEO also posted an article on Twitter that echoes your sentiments and is a pretty good read:http://www.fastcompany.com/1838759/to-bring-out-the-best-in-millennials-put-on-your-coaching-hatWorth checking out!

t.o.p_the_opportunity_project.description: Sometime what we need is a good opportunity that mostly doesn't come easy. The Opportunity Project is a one year apprentice/internship program that provide a strong base for the young so they're able to make the right decision for their future.
t.o.p_the_opportunity_project.creator: fbd410f33ad99d117f92cd1f96771efe

comments.text: Hi Mei, great concept. I was wondering if two options for the TOP participants would help them: - to be one year in one project/company to really contribute and get to know one company well (for those who already know in which direction they want to go) - to do a rotational internship in one or more companies (for those who need to see more in order to find the right thing)Its a TOP name, I really like it.

Hi Sabine, I am so agree with you!  That will also help the young people who are still confuse on subject they will take in college or university. It's not easy to find the right thing for us (been there...lol)
ow, and I'll wrote this as on of the value, tx for the input :)
Hi Mel, its great seeing your concept evolve!
Great name, Mei  and fab illustrations! I'm loving the loop of alumni becoming mentors.
Hi Meena, thank you for the comment :)

I love this concept. I hope that when you say "apprentice/internship" you intend for the participants to be paid for their work. While it is a great learning experience, there will be many young people unable to afford to participate if they do not get paid. (Additionally, if they are doing real work, they are legally required to be paid.) Perhaps the companies provide a stipend?

Hi Katherine, yes you're right. I suppose there should be some kind of allowance for them. Ideally those corporate who join this program should be given something in return. Tax reduction for example.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
It's an honour and pleasure to join open iDEO with all the amazing people in it :)

t.o.p_the_opportunity_project.title: T.O.P - The Opportunity Project

the_mind_body_awareness_project.description: At the Mind Body Awareness Project people believe at-risk & incarcerated youth have the potential to take control of their actions and fully transform their lives – they are literally one breath away from making better decisions.
the_mind_body_awareness_project.creator: 58e9027a4a4f9d4dcb8d93d807040cf9
