what_a_waste_of_6570.description: Lack of exposure means lack of choices.  In reality, teens know more ice cream flavors than they do things they can become when they grow up.  Rethinking how we invest in our children's college education isn't just important, it is overdue.
what_a_waste_of_6570.creator: afa74ad3f4cd1db9f61292a40db5df33

comments.text: Interesting comments - apparently we are prepared to promote investment in failure after college but not before - two of my four kids changed their major and haven't looked back since - in fact they are both now better qualified than the two who continued with their first major, although interestingly the latter two are now both working in fields unrelated to their qualifications.One of the modern diseases in the developed world is a focus on individual financial success and financial return on investment. The need for all to focus more on triple and quadruple bottom lines is not far away now.If we can answer why your average 18 year old American knows more about ice-cream than careers I suspect the investment required to overcome that is in the hundreds per student rather than thousands. But it won't stop some of them from making poor choices, that's an important part of their life experience. It's what they do with the failed outcome and the support they get for finding an alternative they can be passionate about that will propel them forward.As for hard work - that is the lot of most of us - labourer and businessman alike.- maybe a few get lucky but the majority are rewarded for effort., although political views may colour the perceived fairness and justice in the reward.Having said all that I can certainly agree investing in a concept around how better to inform students throughout their schooling, and supporting parents to participate, is extremely worthwhile.

Paul, you make a great point!  It's also always been odd to me that there are such different career tracks for different levels of education.  For instance, during my undergraduate study at a state university, I was never exposed to a  number of career options.  I had never heard of a "consultant" and really had no idea what it was to be a consultant.  As an undergraduate, I would have undoubtedly named more ice cream flavors than careers.  Then when I went to graduate school at a private Ivy League university, there were new career paths open to me, including consulting.  I am a consultant now, and I would never have known about this career choice based on a "lower-tiered" post-secondary education.  We are aware of the dangers of putting children into educational tracks in elementary and high school, but the phenomenon is still there in higher education.  We are automatically discounting the experience and professionalism of students based on their educational "track."

what_a_waste_of_6570.title: What a waste of $6,570

template_rejection_letters_are_miss_lead.description: Lack of quality feedback means you can't learn from inteviews. Worse false infomation is misleading
template_rejection_letters_are_miss_lead.creator: bb3729882d9a88b760a13f628b9ea65f

comments.text: This is a good point. I think there's also the point that it's a courteous gesture, as in 'hey you didn't get the job but good luck on the next one'. It's even more frustrating when some companies never contact you back at all so you are never able to get that sense of closure.

Hi Rob, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know by hitting the Support tab on the left hand side of most pages of our site if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

template_rejection_letters_are_miss_lead.title: Template rejection letters are miss leading

sparkmettle_sharing_the_nine_features_fo.description: Last year I set up an "aspirations agency" called Spark+Mettle to help young people to flourish as they map and launch their optimal careers. Our method mashes Benjamin Franklin's self-improvement programme with the 9 features needed to flourish.
sparkmettle_sharing_the_nine_features_fo.creator: ce4f0f52ce7b650578499cc00bda3f6d

comments.text: Oh, I really like this. Great way of sharing and building skills and competencies.
Way to go! And great to see inclusion of things like curating one's online presence  an emerging aspect of entering the workspace today.

sparkmettle_sharing_the_nine_features_fo.title: Support soft skills development as well as hard skills, inc the 9 features of human flourishing

interview_your_heroes.description: Ask your heroes for career advice, and you never know where it'll lead.
interview_your_heroes.creator: 6c0385b2c8468220d8772642a066e692

comments.text: Well thought through - and illustrated!  Was this graphic created specifically for this concept?I resonate with this because it is a low barrier to entry for helping motivate young people toward their goals and aspirations.  Beginning a career can be completely daunting (not having any connections, being unable to decide a career) - often leaving people feeling powerless and paralyzed.  I have been a part of a "career panel" a few times for an organization called New Door Ventures - focused on granting young people employment.  The panel always seems to inspire young people to make more concrete connections regarding their career aspirations.  The process makes the career path more tangible, and less frightening.  Not only this - but as mentioned above - it can lead to great connections and even employment!  Win - Win!!!

I think this is great but maybe at some point help will be needed to sort out conflicting advice. Caution should also be used with the advice that is given especially when some statistically small portion of people succeed on pure luck. But on the whole, great to inspire people to try things. Perhaps have a talk with the people who fail too, for their lessons may be equally instructive.
Great advice and inspiration. Simple to do and everyone gets to pick their own heroes - simple genious! Luvit!

I love this. Creative, plucky and brave. And it paid off - great work!As a build, I wonder if there is an opportunity to create a podcasting service/organisation/something which brokers interviews between individuals and their heroes? Not do the interviews for them but support them to get the interview and do it well. The interview could then be podcast by the service under a single brand rather than each interviewer having their own, if that makes sense?
Inspired to do just that. Thanks for the insight.

I think this is a good strategy if one also has to capability of reflecting on what the advice means for the personal situation. I don't think a blind copy / paste approach is the right solution for young people to find their way.
I absolutely love it.  Great advice.  Also on the flip side people should be open to being interviewed because its a great introduction to fresh new talent.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

I had a project where I did the same thing -- I'd correspond through email with some of my heroes and post up their answers on a blog. Their advice was very, very helpful.Great inspiration -- your podcast looks awesome. Thanks for sharing, Daniel!
Thanks Brett.
Man I have been listening to dorm room tycoon for the last year on my iphone. Great inspiration Dan.
Thanks Lynden - glad you enjoy the show :)
Great story, and good advice. And I agree with Meena, a great collection of podcasts!

Nice one Daniel  what a fab collection of podcasts you guys created! I also had some success with this approach a while back. I pursued various blogging opportunities and would interview folks I thought were doing interesting things in the design for social innovation sector. Scored a number of assignments along the way as well as building a great network in which I was able to connect others for collaborative opportunities.

interview_your_heroes.title: Interview your heroes

lab_21_co_learning_labs_with_21st_centur.description:
Call it an Incubator.  Call it an Accelerator.  You may even call it a Social Enterprise.

Either way, LAB21 is a branded network of co-learning spaces ushering career-minded and goal-oriented 16-24 year olds into the 21st century world of work.
lab_21_co_learning_labs_with_21st_centur.creator: 8482a78370e4b5a84ccf768aedf73d9f

comments.text: The workplace is changing so rapidly.  Do you think that employers would recognize the skills being taught and know how to fit them into existing organizations?  Or, does that not even matter, because lab-goers are not trying to fit in to old organizations but are preparing for organizations that they will run themselves in the future?
Where would these labs be housed?  In high schools? On college campuses? In libraries or community centers?

Great concept Sasha,I have been thinking about how you can attract the right people to come by. So many of the concepts combine an online platform with an offline presence, so I thought about how to do this if it was kept offline.My idea is to use the building to attract people to LAB 21. It should feature the real users, have feature stories and case studies. It could show prerequisites to enter (none). It could have a huge arrow that points to the door. Anything goes to make it easy to enter..I am trying to address that some of the people who would benefit the most from this might be afraid to go through the doors to LAB 21, so it should be as accessible as possible.
Thanks Simon!  I'd love to hear more of your thoughts on why someone would be 'afraid' to go through the doors of LAB21.  Looking forward to building and fine tuning this concept!

Great ideas. I also thought this was an interesting concern too. Someone's timidity could stop them short from entering for a glimpse of the lab. First-timers should know that you can't really comprehend everything about a place from looking at their website. I definitely recall some of my pangs of anxiety when I toured schools for the first time: typical reception area, big front desk, and nice couches that were nice to sit on, but signaled that you were definitely new especially if lots of people flowed in and out of the place. After you tour one school, you felt that you could expect a similar layout and format: sit, wait, watch, then receive the scripted tour.
I think you are on to something Bryann: How can you create a sense of familiarity to someone new to LAB21?I don't have the answer, but I find the question intriguing.

Thanks Simon.  I'll continue to give this some more thought.But, I think its less a question of familiarity and more a question of inclusiveness and openness. It certainly won't be as familiar as something that is already in existence.The intent is to challenge all of us -- youth included -- to think and behave differently and collaboratively, to support young people in achieving success in the workplace. A huge part of the solution will be in the appropriate design of a marketing strategy as well as the design of LAB21 and its various programs and initiatives.  All of these things will be crucial to achieving the intended impact.
Simon -- still thinking about this ;-)...more tomorrow...

Simon, I don't have an immediate answer either. :) Perhaps the concept of scheduling a tour could be reworked a bit in the future.I'm sure there's already some familiarity re: the ideals of collaboration and creativity. It's just that they might already be deluged by other typical workforce programs by local schools and gov'ts that A) preach those same things, B) are marketed to the young as "preparing them for the real world" but C) fall incredibly short of teaching those things.LAB21's concept and approach is more profound and refreshing. So I think Sasha is right about designing its programs and marketing strategy accordingly, especially when it needs to stand out against all the radio noise.
@Simon: More on the question of attracting the right people to come by. There's the proposal of having a physical business library. Maybe some parts of it can be publicly accessible.

Perhaps I'm missing something, but I'm thoroughly confused :( So hopefully someone can help :) What is the advantage of this over existing systems like university, udemy, khan and github? which seem to offer the same benefits of learning and collaboration but in a more fragmented way - fragmentation here actually serves as an asset as companies have limited focus on their particular area providing a better chance of success in their market, and consumers can opt-in to whatever solutions works for them rather than being tied to one company offering everything with a broad focus. My other concern is that it seems just like existing community workshops aimed at small businesses but now aimed at youths instead, which I'm not sure would help solve youth unemployment as such a service would teach students a lot of generalised knowledge in many different areas (making them a novice at everything), versus specialised knowledge in an in-demand skill that employers are looking for (pro at something). Whereas with incubators/accelerators/hacker-schools they all focus on one precise skill area that is in-demand and work it up to rockstar levels. So hope that these concerns help raise some worthwhile thinking to help refine the idea and let it rock on, and perhaps I'm just missing a few things in which case do fill me in :) Either way, all the best, keep up the great work.
Actually, is this more of what you're talking about? http://generalassemb.ly/ - seems their already doing something pretty similar, one of their partners is IDEO too! Nifty.

Hi Benjamin, these are actually some excellent questions. Not sure I can answer them all. I'd like to see previous/current uni students and veterans of udemy et al. chime in about the gaps that LAB21 might fill for them. Yeah, there's always the danger of atrophy when one can't readily apply the knowledge they've learned. This is why I support the addition of external skunkworks projects sponsored by businesses (the innovative ones at least) and designed by lab stewards.  I would like to see that students start building momentum and solving real world problems. Get them engaged in something real and they learn something about practicing execution. I'm hoping that this also helps them out with learning what collaboration, team chemistry, and self-leadership is all about.  I see that the concept has been refined some the past two weeks, so perhaps you can see if it answers your other concerns :)
I've incorporated into the concept, some aspects of Lydia Howland's Experience Bank/CV Lifeline....Thanks Lydia!  Let me know your thoughts....
I love it!  Thanks so much for building it in and good luck as you enter the final strait!

Sweet!  Thanks Lydia.Young people are tied to their mobile phones so it makes sense to build new and rewarding encounters in that space and tie it back to their social media profiles -- particularly if the Experience Bank has  creative and beneficial potential in lieu of their professional lives.

I think this would be a great idea. More informal learning environments are needed to train students in skills they don't get to utilize much in school (collaboration and creativity). I am currently a PhD student at the University of Georgia studying design based learning and how learners share knowledge in a design-based learning activity. I would be interested in assisting with the implementation of creating Lab 21.about.me/gregorywilson
This is a great breakdown of the LAB21's design. Bravo. I was also happy to see some coalescing of ideas with the Partnership for 21st Century Skills.
You're awesome.  Thank you....

Greetings from Taiwan! Recently ran into OpenIDEO...What a great tool! This is an interesting idea to address a critical global issue. I definitely see areas for potential collaboration with other projects as well. For example, the YouthCafe project may overlap in the sense that meetups could be held in Lab 21s. Also, theres the important issue of incentives for local business involvement (an avenue to increase community ownership and sustainability) and integrating Open IDEO-like challenges. The two could be merged. I would assume a thorough interview/assessment process would take place for each new youth member in which key career-oriented questions were asked (a great place to integrate the Purpose Workshops idea as an intake tool). After each youth member has a unique profile, the information could be analyzed to flesh out key topic areas/industries. Then, local businesses would be identified that would match those areas as close as possible. Those businesses would be approached about potential partnerships and the idea of developing OpenIDEO-like challenges specifically targeted to address institutional areas in which they want to innovate and/or current business issues that need to be solved.  Youth benefit from the hands-on experience and learning about the inner-workings/dynamics of organizations doing work aligned with their interests and values. Local businesses benefit from being exposed to IDEO methodologies as well as from the actual work to help them solve key business challenges. It would be important though, to send a message regarding the value of the youths work by offering reasonable payment for services. All the participating businesses, for example, could commit a pre-determined donation in order to become official partner organizations and that money could go to a stipend for the youth(s) assigned to their respective projects. Finally, youth could be matched with mentors to support them through the project development process, thus integrating elements of the Young Adult Mentor/Mentee Network project.

Thanks so much for such thoughtful feedback.  I'm excited to put it all into motion...On another note, in some places, local businesses tend to be small businesses and local tends to refer to a particular neighborhood.Maybe we need to expand the concept of local to include greater opportunities for much larger businesses to collaborate with LAB21...In New York, there are young people throughout the 5 boroughs who never leave their borough.  Brooklyn, Manhattan, Staten Island, the Bronx and Queens tend to live worlds away in the minds of many although they're sometimes 15 - 30 minutes apart by neighborhood.Nonetheless, I digress and have yet to make a direct point....Anyway, Imran Malek submitted a concept that seems similar to what you're suggesting above for local businesses...Feel free to check it out: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/-skunkworks-projects-for-youths-/

Yeah! I like his concept and it's similar to what I'm suggesting. As far as expanding the concept of local to larger business, I think anything that extends the job creation pipeline even further to more stakeholders would be well worthwhile...On another note, I think the HUB network that people have mentioned sounds like a wonderful resource to glean more inspiration. The Business Clinic they are doing in South Africa sounds interesting and an example of an initiative that could be replicated at Lab21 and pull in larger business participation. Good luck!!

I have seen and experienced a similar concept (or complementary) as you suggest for LAB 21. You might have heard ....The HUB. http://www.the-hub.net/ . Since 2009, I am a member of the HUB community and should tell you that I have seen lot young people, mostly 20s/30s, but even 40s like in my case, to achieve what your concept is suggesting! I also see a lot of improvements and new approaches in your case!!! Well done! Looks it work

Hi Sasha!First of all, just wanted to reiterate how cool this concept is! I definitely would want a membership to a place like this.I wanted to ask you whether you have had much of an opportunity to explore some of the other concepts in the refinement stage yet? I didn't get to see all of the comments on this concept, and I'm a little new to openIDEO, so I apologize if this has already been mentioned - but it seems to me that some of the other concepts would work well in coordination with LAB 21.I saw that someone else mentioned the Mobile DIY lab, and I think that this could be a great forum for the concept "Young + Unemployed Conference" (you mentioned conferences in the description, if I remember correctly). But I also thought that LAB 21 could be a great place to initiate the "Building Expertise at an Early Age" concept, too. It's ultimate goal is to have "deep dive" project-based classes added to curriculums in schools.Here's what I was thinking - secondary schools would sponsor "challenges" at LAB 21, being long-term projects that kids could work on throughout the year - they could be about anything, potentially created by teachers and students from the schools. These challenges could be extra-curricular programs that are group-based, where groups come to LAB 21 to do their work. For the students, it gives them a new type of learning style they're not always exposed to in school, and gives them something to do after school. For you, it would mean the active involvement of a local organization. And, it could be a first step towards integrating "deep dive" education into schools - a structure that allows schools to see how that type of learning works before committing to incorporating it into their curriculums.These "challenges" could also be adapted as a recruiting tool for businesses - they could sponsor "challenges" that relate to their line of work. Participants would learn to use the tools necessary to work within those businesses' fields, making them more attractive to future employers.Again, sorry if in any way this does not apply to your concept!
sorry - just realized this idea is essentially just an in-person openIDEO.

I think the in-person OpenIDEO exists for the university level, but not for secondary or primary school levels. The people that are part of OpenIDEO can clarify this.I for one still see your suggestion (i.e. bringing secondary students to LAB21 for in-person OpenIDEO workshops) as something new and something that can bring additional value to the LAB21 concept.

Secondary schools are moving rapidly to incorporate "project-based learning," but they often lack the facilities to support it.  A community-based physical center could be shared by several schools in an area, with opportunity for local community organizations and employers in both public and private sectors to pose project ideas.

Yes, yes, and yes... ;-)I was thinking of tailoring LAB 21 to 16-24 year olds...Its a great way to get them interacting with and learning from each other...Workshops, conferences, Sponsored Projects, Classes, etc are all the crux of LAB21.  There would be room for the LAB21 curriculum as well as open slots space and time for external projects, organizations, people, etc...I'd love to kick off LAB21 with a "Young + Unemployed Conference".Thoughts?

That sounds like a great way to get the community involved from the start! Would you try to incorporate the younger kids into the conference too, or do a separate event for them? I imagine that young people who want to go to college are looking for something different than what the "Young + Unemployed Conference" intends to offer those entering the work force.

Great builds, Sasha! You might want to acknowledge folks who have contributed to your idea via comments using the Virtual Teams field. You can hit the Update Entry button on the right of your post & scroll down to the Virtual Team and add the names of anyone who has helped shape your concept.

LAB 21 I.D cards could be physical cards or viewable by smart phone, as airport boarding passes are. By scanning their cards, they could track their career progress on their profile.I saw a talk once by Dr. Rosa Martey on applying game design principles to research, teaching, and outreach strategies. Members could collect points by attending workshops or events, completing tasks (perform a mock interview, create a Power Point presentation, etc.). Points could add up to badges, which would mark a level of expertise. Members with badges could start teaching others, to promote a collaborative learning environment.Code Academy (http://www.codecademy.com/#!/exercises/0) has a gaming approach to track progress.The Nerdery has short profiles for their employees, including badges for their areas of expertise, which are granted for completing challenges: http://nerdery.com/people#md.
Love it.  Let me know if you'd like to help design some specific ways to utilize the LAB21 I.D Card...

How goes the refinement? :-)I love the LAB/tech stations part of your idea. Would that include a library of tools like video cameras and 3-d printers that people could use for fundraising? (a softer tech version of http://www.hackerdojo.com/) LAB21 could be a great launchpad for creating amazing kickstarter campaigns...

Refinement is tougher than I anticipated ;-).LAB/tech stations for sure!  Computers, digital cameras, printers....Thanks for the intro to Hacker Dojo.  Its precisely the sort of co-learning and co-working environment that we can create and pass on to young people...

Excellent idea,An off-line safe place is important for youths where real-world interaction can provide more than just design skills, but also provide positive self-esteem and ownership. I feel success with youths in the world of work goes beyond just possessing skills, but possessing a positive attitude, empathy, confidence, etc.  This Lab 21 idea is great, by including real-word relationships and interaction it can address those soft skills.    Here is an cool idea that brings innovation to kids via a mobie truck.SparkTruck: A Bookmobile That Brings Rapid Prototyping to School Kidshttp://www.fastcodesign.com/1670400/sparktruck-a-bookmobile-that-brings-rapid-prototyping-to-school-kids#1Arguably, a mobile truck can save costs in comparison to a large fixed classroom space.

I'm totally with you on the 'soft skills' side of things...I'm wondering if there might be a 'softer way' to incorporate these 'soft skills' into the lab....Meena also mentioned Spark Truck so you're both onto something there....

Sasha, This is a great concept! I think there is a lot of overlap to look at in the pedagogy and techniques employed by existing informal learning environments (e.g. Exploroatorium, 826 National) that are rooted in experiential ed. I think tying in to the existing spectrum of learning environments (formal, informal, blended and co-created) is critical to the scalability and long term impact of Lab21. I also like the idea of taking the idea mobile, putting it on wheels so that it is accessible to a diverse set of audiences. Perhaps a small scale version in a food truck that acts as an entre to the main physical space, enticing those who may not normally be inclined to engage to get involved.
On the mobile track: there might be learnings from here  Mobile DIY Lab Let's Kids Test Out Ideas with Cutting Edge Tools: bit.ly/REBins

Thanks Mike -- Let me know if you're able to share some links to some specific readings....I'd love to delve deeper...I also like the concept of making LAB21 more mobile.  Going directly to young people might provide the direct insight needed to tailor LAB21 programming and market more effectively and efficiently to various niche demographics...I see it more like an introduction/orientation/recruitment strategy for the lab.Thoughts?

way to go Sasha! Getting people working and learning together is always an ideal way to facilitate positive externalities. I'd definitely suggest looking into the amazing Hackerspace movement that has totally surged in the past decade with hundreds of them currently active around the world. http://hackerspaces.org/wiki/List_of_Hacker_Spaces I'm also curious as to how decentralized LAB21 could be so as to truly be scalable and adaptable. How can we set up the model so that anyone anywhere can be empowered to set up their own LAB21 space tomorrow? Like Carol Shu mentioned 350.org is great inspiration for this as is The Awesome Foundation which has over 50 autonomous chapters around the world focused around the same model of giving out $1000 grants each month.  http://awesomefoundation.org

Thanks for sharing those examples.  I really appreciate that you've zeroed in on where the concept needs some serious improvement ;-).Continually relocating LAB21 might be a great idea to initially get it off the ground.  I'm still playing with some ideas for scaling the concept and I definitely see some alignment with 350.org and Awesome Foundation.  I'll see what I can glean from both and tailor to LAB21...Thanks so much George!  Let me know if you'd like to help further...

We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Our developers are busy working on it. Meanwhile, if you're wanting to iterate your ideas, you can use the comments feature to promote further conversation from others. We'll let you know once the bug is fixed, then you can incorporate your refinement moves into your concept post. Let's be agile, together!

Right on! Our development team have been busy fixing the Update Entry bug and we're back on track now. You'll now be able to edit your posts to add all that refinement-goodness to build out your concepts for improved impact. Bring it on, together!

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:Aside from being one of the most highly applauded concepts submitted for this challenge, the panel felt this seems like a great way to build community and solidarity amongst young job seekers but also to utilise urban spaces that aren't currently optimised in support of youth employment. WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:The 2 big questions the panel have are 1) How do you make sure you get the commitment and engagement from local business and 2) How will you ensure this concept is sufficiently differentiated fom either a job centre or internet cafe?  We'd love to hear further thoughts on what you think the purpose of Lab 21 is and what a typical Day In The Life of Lab 21 might look like...For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine.
oops! http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Super Exciting!  Thank you OpenIdeo.  So looking forward to improving this concept.

Hi Sasha!  I wonder if you could pair with "hot spots" (bustling and young spaces) to flesh out this idea initially?  Finding a local hip cafe might help quickly iterate on what works and what doesn't.  You could also use this to figure out what is important to local youth.  For example, folks that hang at Red Rocks Cafe in Mountain View, CA are going to give you a different perspective than the crew that hangs out at Port City Java in Wilmington, NC.  This concept needs to be moldable to see success.Thanks for such a great concept :)

Dropping in to add that the idea of a physical lab-space is a fantastic idea for encouraging youth to explore possible new career paths in developing markets. I've personally experienced how lab-like/cafe-like environments positively encourage people to work together, especially when the right tools are available.
Thanks for dropping in Edouard.  Your thoughts are really appreciated.  I would love to see something like LAB21 extended to young people in developing markets!

Sasha, I admire this idea a lot! Nothing beats a physical co-working space to facilitate learning and growth. I agree with teaching creativity and design thinking, and also making those the crux of LAB 21's curricula.I also see some intersection with Imran's Skunkworks concept, too. Perhaps after youths wrap up the curricula in LAB 21, Imran's Skunkworks can be like the last stage  that one "big" project where youths can go out "into the field" and finally test what they've learned at LAB 21. So after learning about creativity and design, they can finally practice on "execution." This could become a brilliant ecosystem. I'd love to collaborate on something like this in real life.
Thanks Bryann!  Took a peek and love what you're doing with Skylance.
Hi Bryann -- Any thoughts on improving the LAB21 concept?

Hi Sasha. Sure, just a few. I like LAB21's emphasis on continual learning and the various trajectories available: workshops programs, events, internships, co-ops. The lab continues to engage someone in "building themselves up." Business problems and social problems can morph and shapeshift a lot. The lab has the potential to evolve along with it, whereas it would take big institutions years to revise or recreate their curriculum.With single workshops or accelerators, there's no guarantee that whatever was learned would be put into execution in the future. This is why I like the internship and co-op aspect of the lab, and maybe even some corporate sponsored skunkworks projects. At least here alumni would have the environment to -continue building and testing something-, eventually improving their creative and soft skills along the way.

Sasha, I love this idea. It offers one of the best solutions I have read for, as you put it "bridging the gaps" of the youth unemployment problem. The localized nature of the Lab provides the flexibility to meet each communities specific needs and while still leveraging technology to get global perspective and resources!
Thanks Amy!  Just shared some thoughts on your concept...
Brilliant idea! I would love to evolve the service provision developed by apple into career guidance; genius bars, drop in workshops, online tutorials, forums. Ahhhh I can see it now!
;-) Thanks Dawnne!  I think that's a genius idea...

Hi Dawnne -- I was thinking about your suggestions and I really like the idea of a 'genius' bar as the first line of introduction to LAB21.  I will visit an Apple store this weekend to glean some insights ;-).
love this idea, and it's unique, never heard of anything like this.
Hi Christie -- Thank you for sharing that!
Nice one Sasha! I wonder, to limit physical infrastructure costs, if an idea like this could piggy-back on existing libraries?

I had that thought too but initially discarded it on the basis that opinion is divided in Australia about re-purposing libraries.Notwithstanding that - my comments regarding building, fit-out and staffing of new infrastructure could be applied to renovation and re-purposing library space the main point being to get unemployed involved from the ground up.
Thank you Paul and Meena.  Another approach might be to just simply utilize/rent office space in pre-existing buildings.I'm inspired by General Assembly here in New York: http://generalassemb.ly/
How about using a resource like Liquid Space (https://www.liquidspace.com/) to identify unused space that can be grabbed up for short-term power runs of this idea?

Hi Maegan.  Thank you for sharing the link to Liquid Space.  Its a great concept.  I'm a huge fan of design, creativity and play in work environments and I think these are things that youth can appreciate as well.Thanks again!

For what it's worth, one of our challenge supporters is a major UK bank and banks often have physical premises in prime locations but don't always have a huge amount of footfall outside peak times.Perhaps certain bank branches could be repurposed to provide this kind of facility?  Banks certainly have the real estate - I guess it's just a question of brand and whether a bank would be a credible provider for this kind of space...I'd love to hear what people think about this and great concept Sasha!
Thats worth quite a bit!  Thanks for bringing that connection back around.I'll do a bit more research on my end based on you've shared.Thanks again!

First off, good concept Sasha, I also thought directly about infrastructure costs of setting up a new physical space. I really like @Lydia and @Maegan's thinking here of thinking flexible and adding value/use of current spaces. I've had this idea of "wasted spaces" lingering for quite some time, and really think our cities are made up of a lot of it - both in terms of empty spaces (shorter or longer term) and in terms of entire buildings or even areas not being used during large parts of the day. The closest I can think about to something like this is some initiatives in Sweden that aimed to get job-seeking and skills-acquiring closer to youth by allocating staff and resources to some "youth center"-type places that would be a natural spot. It had various successes. LAB21 idea, however, builds on a space being designed and co-created and designed by/with youth from the bottom up - which I think is totally essential to its success!! Keep refining. Shout out if you need specific brainstorms! ;-)
Hi Ola -- would you be able to share a link to an example of a 'youth center' in Sweden?

Your idea is great - I would love to be in LAB 21! To reproduce LAB 21 across the globe, the labs/spaces could be networked with each other. I really like how 350.org is a central hub website where people can find 350.org projects near them and post updates, photos, information, etc (http://350.org/). A website like this for LAB 21 would help young people in any location find co-learning studios and projects that they're interested in participating in. Studios in different locations could also then collaborate with each other.

Hi! just read your concept, seems quite interesting.I thought I'd share the link to the blog of the project I am working on currently. http://scatteringsplat.wordpress.com/We are trying to tackle the same challenge and our approach is similar to what you are proposing.Please go through the blog and would love some feedback on the  process and project :)

This is a very exciting concept - I like it very much!Can we somehow make this a greenfields international foundation that involves mentored unemployed people from the very start:- surveyors, draftspersons and architects, interior designers, project managers;- carpenters, plumbers, electricians, other construction workers like brick layers, plasterers, painters etc.;- furniture designers, furniture manufacturers; - delivery services, catering services, cleaning services;in fact as many aspects of putting the projects together as possible.Might the various sub-projects form the types of projects that are suited to Haiyan's YouthForce concept?Could the individual labs be run as co-operatives (or non-profits at the very least) utilising management drawn from unemployed ranks too?As an events venue they could host:Anna Cecilia's Plus Unemployed Conferences( http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/the-young-unemployed-conference-/   );Haiyan's Youth Cafe's (maybe multiple devoting different time slot/nights to different disciplines and including trades)( http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/youthcafe/  );an annual TEDxYouth;just for startersThe building/organisation could headquarter other concepts like Haiyan's YouthForce (in addition to utilising that concept in construction) ( http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/youth-force-a-small-project-job-market-for-young-people/   )I can probably think of more but I will post this first.

Thanks Paul.  Some really great things to consider.  Today's featured concept, The Rising Generation Studio has some similarities as well.  Its exciting to know other people are thinking this way as well.

Hi! just read your concept, seems quite interesting.I thought I'd share the link to the blog of the project I am working on currently. http://scatteringsplat.wordpress.com/ We are trying to tackle the same challenge and our approach is similar to what you are proposing.Please go through the blog and give me feedback on my process :)

...such an extraordinary opportunity to share this space with people who are passionate about creating greater opportunities for youth.  Its something very dear to me and I enjoy reading the inspirations and all of the thoughtful concepts...Thank you OpenIDEO.

Hey Sasha.  Love your vision, and it's in line with my professional life goal: to create a community space that facilitates experiences and programs that help people flourish and gain life skills.  I would love to talk to you about the possibility of making LAB21 a reality.  Could we connect via email?  I'm new to openIDEO, so I'm not sure if I can message you privately.  I don't think so, but perhaps I missed something?
Thanks Erika.  It would love to connect with you!  Might we do so toward the latter part of the challenge or thereafter?
Yes, whenever's good for you.  We'll be in touch!
I love this idea. I assume it would require grant funding and an equitable way of rationing access, since the demand for service would surely greatly exceed the number of members who could be served.

Thank you!I originally imagined multiple locations serving different communities. But, you've raised a great point so I'll work on generating some further ideas for equitable access.I will also give some further thought to your point about a funding model and would love to hear some of your thoughts as well.Thanks again!

I understood you were looking at mutiple locations. My thought, though, was to ask why anyone would choose not to avail themselves of this resource if it developed any kind of a track record for youth finding work faster than they otherwise would. In terms of funding, I can see you might be able to get space economically in the way others here have suggested. Many public buildings are underutilized, particularly during off hours if your center could adjust its open hours to occur when other buildings are free.You might be able to staff with volunteers under the supervision of a couple of profession people with salaries. I think the challenge is less finding money for a pilot than to find a sustainable source over time.

Exciting concept, Sasha! When I saw Blake`s Toolbox Concept http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/toolbox/ I thought about extending the online learning with offline facilities. Then I saw your vision and I really liked it. In an environment like the LAB21 unemployed can get and learn together. Even if the personal equipment (like hardware and software) is not existing. In order to extend software skills, company cooperations could provide the necessary software licenses as well as the hardware. Additionally the motivation gets increased in work groups.Im curious to see this concept evolve!
lovely. spot on. provide resources. public ed. equity.
Thanks Monika!  I have been trying to keep up with a lot of the external dialogue about finding one's passion and purpose and I wonder how that very same dialogue might translate with youth.

py/tuple: IMPACT & REACH: How much impact and reach do you think this concept could have in helping young people transition into the world of work?
A great deal – something like this would really make a difference
A moderate amount – it’s certainly helpful but probably not a game-changer
Not very much – it’s unlikely to make a significant difference to young people seeking work

FEASIBILITY & RESOURCES: Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible will it be for your community to turn this concept into a reality?  (Hint: when you think about resources, think: people, money, time, technology, infrastructure, partnerships and any other inputs for implementation)
Highly feasible – resources wouldn’t be an issue for my community if we tried to implement this
Moderately feasible – my community could do it if we could get find assistance with some of our resource constraints
Not feasible – it would be almost impossible for my community to implement this concept; it's just too resource-intensive
SUSTAINABILITY & LONGEVITY: Does this concept feel like it could be sustained as a project, business or movement over years rather than just months? Will continue to be relevant in future?
Yes – this concept has enough momentum to stand on its own two feet and remain relevant for years to come
Maybe – it’s not clear how long it would take for this concept to stand on its own feet or how it will continue to be but there’s reason to feel hopeful
No – this concept will have trouble sustaining itself in the long-run and probably won’t be as relevant in years to come
ORIGINALITY: How new or innovative is this idea? Are there many different versions of this concept out there already or is this something more disruptive and unique?
Very original – I’ve not seen anything else quite like it
Fairly original – there are similar things out there but this particular version brings a new element to the table
Unoriginal – there are already too many other concepts out there that are similar to this one
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world
I liked it but preferred others
It didn't get me overly excited

comments.text: Great thoughts on subverting  small, initially perceived 'failures', Matt! And there might be some learnings for developing this further from the Admitting Failure site: http://www.admittingfailure.com/
Thanks for the link, i've had a look and it's definitely given me some thoughts. Time for some refinements...

I really like this idea. Whenever I receive advice of this kind, it is always greatly appreciated. However, I think something that needs to be worked in is the context. This would enable people to understand how it relates to them and their current situation.You begin to touch on it a bit with the inclusion of the fact that their careers continued to progress. I think this would need to be blown out a bit more with more specifics, certainly nothing that would compromise anonymity though. These details could be used to sort the advice for easy reference too. Maybe have general business categories and sizes, as well as, potential business scenarios like applying for jobs, brokering deals, speaking with superiors, etc.

You should get in touch with Louise: http://www.openideo.com/profiles/cactuslouise/And her winning concept in the Web Entrepreneurs Challenge:http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/winning-concepts/ted-positive-sharing-failure/

Thanks for the suggestions, Dominic: you are quite right more emphasis on the job position and career would certainly help give some useful background and act as a resource for job positions. I'd imagine some form of interviewee profile could also give details on his or her education and career path too. Without giving away too many specifics ;)Cansu: thanks for the link, I hadn't seen Denise's winning concept, this gives lots of interesting detail to my thought.

guidebook_for_parents.description: Focused on parents, the guideBOOK could be an online and mobile platform that gives parents suggestions for how to further the motivations and reach-for-the-moon dreams of their children that are appropriate for their developmental stage.

comments.text: Maegan I love this idea, especially how you've tapped into a young person's support system to help them dream big  and understand what it'll take to achieve their dreams.
Thanks Ashley.  I am already finding a lot of supporting material that can be used to flesh out this concept.  It will be fun to develop!
I'm totally behind this idea! Particularly the notion of keeping kids on track with their initial "I want to grow up to be an astronaut!" dreams.

Hi Maegan -- Thank you for sharing this amazing concept. When I got the idea for the concept 'The Buddy System', I was thinking about other people of great influence in a young person's life -- namely older siblings and peers. I was thinking, what if these siblings and peers were better empowered to support young people (and each other) with the information, opportunities, etc needed to to succeed in the world of work?I hadn't given that much thought to parents.  But your concept reminds us all that parents (whatever shape or form) are usually our greatest champions and therefore our greatest influencers.These guidebooks would make remarkable gifts of inspiration, purpose and direction, while also rekindling that 'guidance' bridge between parents and today's youth.
This concept links quite nicely with Dawnne McGeachey's 'Confidence Journey' idea - http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/confidence-journey/#c-17f11997d3704871f8abaeeb1d903882
Thanks for the note!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

As a parent age appropriate never works for me and that is true of many children.  I would love to see it done using stages of development instead.  One of the things I have found is people are willing to help if you ask. In our co-op the kids were really interested in cosmology and we contacted the university and they sent us a list of grad students who would tutor them.  The guide book should have some hints on how to connect with experts. Sometimes it is as simple as picking up the phone.

Monera, great point about age-appropriate versus development-appropriate approaches.  I am updating this concept to incorporate your idea and will add your name to my virtual team - you could be a great help if we get to develop this concept in upcoming stages!I have directly experienced the benefit in being connected as an expert to young people, both in my work with NASA and as a product designer.  Let's use this platform to facilitate that.

Great idea.  And much as I wouldn't want to pander to these kinds of myths, it would be great if GuideBOOK could bust some of the more prevalent ones with some hard facts!  For example, I wish I could have proved to my mum that most students who take arts subjects in High School and University do eventually go on to have meaningful (and potentially well paid) careers!  Anything to help fight the tyranny of secure professions like law and medicine and help get parents behind slightly less obvious career paths ;-)

Thanks for your idea Lydia!  I hadn't thought of this outcome, but you bring up a great point - this platform is as much for parent education as it is for young people.  I think tackling both is essential.

comments.text: Nice one Cory! Perhaps you can add a live link to your post so folks can easily check out the goodness on this? Tip: to activate links in your post, hit the Update Entry button up there on the right, then follow the instructions here: http://bit.ly/oi_link

Great website. I will definitly use this in my future projects.1. If we look at this site through an empathetic lens I believe there are some real insights about human beings we could tease out into a few principles.2. No kidding about the job thing! The way in which you tell a story, frame it, and give it context completely changes the way it is viewed. I wish this would have been a part of my education! I would have been smarter for it. If we can understand deeply the person in front of us, we can craft our true story in a way they can understand.There has got to be some material out there that we can get in the hands of students at a young age.

This is so true about how storytelling can help you get a job!  In my first job interview they read my resume from the bottom up and it made for such an interesting conversation where I felt like they really got to know who I was, and I got to see what their values were as a workplace.

encouraging_the_hiring_of_the_unemployed.description: Young people are often unemployed the longest. This idea gives employers a financial reward when they hire the unemployed. The unemployed can also use the cash themselves to start a business. The longer the unemployment, the bigger the reward.
encouraging_the_hiring_of_the_unemployed.creator: 165f07a46a57ca122317ea58425e4214

comments.text: Does the clock start ticking on length of time unemployed at the time a young person leaves school? It would be useful to have data to show how a fixed amount of money for such an initiative would distribute across age groups. I suspect in many places that while youth unemployment is high, the longest term unemployment would not be among the young. Only the data would tell.

That's a good question and not one I've fully answered for myself yet. I think the clock would start ticking sometime soon after school, but not necessarily immediately (because not everyone is trying to get a job immediately after school.)

The issue is further complicated by different definitions of unemployment. As unemployment is as much a political stigma as a personal one governments are keen to manipulate the figures to put them in the most favorable light. Here entitlement to benefit is scaled according to the amount of salary received in a fortnight so even those in paid employment may be entitled to benefit. On the other hand the definition of unemployed is someone who has not performed more than 1 hour of paid work in a three month period (that is the manipulation that keeps the reported unemployment rate at low levels). Because this figure is so grossly abused a second term has been introduced called participation rate but this too is subject to manipulation - it consists of those in paid work plus those actively looking for work (people the general public would regard as unemployed). There is a third group that does not have official recognition (except as a portion of those regarded as participating in work) - those who (like me) are underemployed. Successive governments of both persuasions have encouraged casualisation of the workforce because it keeps the unemployment figures artificially low.On these definitions the clock would be set at the time a person begins actively seeking a job and would be reset each time any form of paid work is received, even if it consists of spending 2 hours twice a week delivering 200 catalogues at 5c each (I know the figures because I have done it.).

Great to see a policy concept being suggested James - governments are key allies in giving young people access to skills, information and opportunities in the world of work.  I think some think tanks in the UK have made similar proposals in the past so it's great to see public policy ideas being discussed in communities like OpenIDEO and not just in the usual policy wonk circles!

Agreed Lydia - there is a great need to somehow reward application of capital towards employment. Lack of job opportunities is, in large part, the result of wealth concentration. Governments can but presently less often do influence wealth redistribution and the market is fundamentally poor at doing so.

Interesting. I think in The Netherlands we/they have/had a similar scheme. In it, companies that hire long-term unemployed people get tax-benefits. I think there even was a scheme where the unemployed could get a bit of startup funding if they decided to start their own business.
Can you find information on that?

There's a law that regulates a reduction of tax on labour. This means that in certain cases, employers can ask for a reduction. In the Netherlands, employers pay a net salary to employees, and withhold all taxes and social contributions, and transfer that to the revenue service. The law aims to improve availability of jobs, research and development and some other things. A bit more information you could find here: http://bit.ly/Nc7CpS [in Dutch, Google Translate normally works quite well]
I don't see anything that specifically covers this concept, but it gives me an idea of what is going on there, thenk you.

It's slightly technical, because of the tax collection construction in The Netherlands. But in principle companies get 'cash' (in the form of tax deduction) if they hire someone that is receiving unemployment benefits. On the linked page (from the revenue service website) there's information on how to apply for this reduction. The law that regulates this, is specifically aimed to reduce unemployment.The beauty of your concept is premium on hiring the person who is unemployed longest. That is not in the Dutch law.There's also a law that allows people who are receiving social benefits because of unemployment or partial inability to work (illness, injury), to get credit for starting up a company. It's called 'Starterskrediet'. In principle it is a loan for up to about 30.000 Euros. More info on that here: http://bit.ly/LDgmH2 [again, in Dutch]I'm just hoping this gives you some extra input for the concept. I think it's a great idea to link benefits to creating jobs.
Thank you!

This is a really interesting concept, James! It will take a while to sink in properly (will come back with more feedback later) but it reminds me of finders fees within a company. There's a real incentive to find someone for the job someone else does and both parties win!

Nice! Tip: It can also come on the form of a tax cut. You will be able to build up a financial business case on how you save taxpayer money by given a tax break when you compared to how much is spend on unemployed social benefits vs this proposal.I can help if taking fwd.

Yes this is an alternative but less immediately stimulatory.Whilst the net benefit is the same the effect is more immediate.I'm not a marketing expert but I know I would much prefer an immediate discount on purchase price than a 'cash back' scheme.

Great initiative James!Looking forward to the development of this concept.There is often talk here in Australia about how to relieve both the fact and the stigma of long term unemployment (regardless of age).Whilst the focus of this challenge is youth I think it is useful to propose concepts, such as this, that are adaptable.Hope to contribute to this as the challenge progresses.

Also like the fact that you have revived this concept from the last challenge and adapted it for this one - another indication of general adaptability.It's another peg on which to hang Stefan Ritter's (OpenIDEO) Feture Suggestion for a Re-Inspire/Re-Concept Button ( https://openideo.zendesk.com/entries/21537618-re-inspire-button )Hope the Digital Assembly Agenda is enjoyable, productive and beneficial both personally and collectively.
Thank you I'm at the conference now. And I wanted to put together something that wasn't age specific even if the challenge is age specific.
Agreed! I like that this concept addresses unemployment and the stigma of going for a long time without work, regardless of age.

encouraging_the_hiring_of_the_unemployed.title: Encouraging youth employment with cash incentives for hiring or entrepreneurship

tryme.description: Most times, entering the market is difficult because you have no chance to properly demonstrate your skills. The only thing people go after is your CV, and that does not do you justice, or show who you truly are.
tryme.creator: b00bad631c623011cae6337e7319e1d5

comments.text: It also gives people a possibility to showcase their true potential without having to rely on past experience or education...

Great video Fabiola! When you mention above the people wouldn't have to rely on their past experience  how do imagine someone would be motivated hire them (eg. the copywriter in your example) if they had no experience listed? Keen to know more and excited to hear from others here too. Looking forward to seeing more of you on OpenIDEO.

Thank you! Well, the whole point is to even out the opportunities, and let talent/work speak for itself - through ratings and stars. This is simply the beginning of the concept, meaning it's meant to be expanded into a platform for employers seeking talents, but most importantly - most jobs are landed through connections. TryMe will give you the opportunity to expand your network, and meet people face to face. In other words, it gives people a tool to get their foot in the door, no matter what field. Also, the real-time aspect allows you to be there faster than anyone else, setting you apart in that way. Did that fully answer your question? Let me know if not, I'm glad to have a discussion about it.
Nice one Fabiola!
Thank you!

A really fresh and disruptive concept - I was just wondering about how you would break through barriers such as firms' privacy, security and some sort of "sanity checks" for the work-seeking. In this regard, you may be interested in how TaskRabbit's founder interviewed all potential workers in advance to avoid pitfalls and ensure high standards.
Yes, that's exactly how I imagine it would work. A video interview process to make sure the person is who he claims to be online. Access to Facebook, Twitter etc. for full transparency.
Is a really nice platform for freelancers or to start your own business locally.

comments.text: this is such a great idea! nice one!

Way to go, Richard  was fab OpenSTORM-ing with you guys! My builds from our session would be that the speed-dating face-to-face events might be rolled out with guidelines like for the TEDx events so that folks all over the world could host their own local events under the Enspired in 30 Seconds brand and not be so dependent on centralised resources. Looking forward to builds from others here.

Hi Meena, it'll be great if you could share more information on the OpenSTORM. The OpenIDEO student chapter at NYU-Poly is trying to organize face-to-face events across schools and with other people in NY. It seems that this could be an interesting concept.

We were a small group and we basically followed the OpenSTORM Lowdown: http://bit.ly/openstorm The thing I'd highlight is snacks/sweets! I forgot and there was a resulting dip in energy towards the end of the session. Good luck.

Very nice! It allows to go beyond jobs' labels which I think is particularly important today where there are many jobs which have fluid boundaries. I can see this concept supporting other concepts such as the ones below. In fact, I had suggested stories from people with interesting jobs for the purpose workshops:http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/purpose-workshops/http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/first-semester-open-doors/http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/the-baushaus-year/The platform could be supplemented by some of the above events.It'll be great if you could do a mini-prototype!
Straightforward, simple, and immediately executable.  Great idea!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Nice one Richard! I love the idea of getting these reflections down in a way that's accessible to everyone (ie: online) but then pairing it with real-world/real-life conversations to ground these lessons in reality for young people. Great job!

L'Oral would be an example.It has an online career orientation game called "Reveal by L'Oral" which evaluates player's skills. The company also hosts a global marketing competition called "L'Oral Brandstorm".

I think its great that you mention RIT, I had the opportunity to intern last summer at an interactive agency in NY and one of the other interns was from RIT. I don't think I exaggerate when I say that their grads walk out fully equipped and armed to take over any design / interactive agency in the city.From making a connection with that one person, I was exposed to a new world of agencies, super talented designers, developers, and creative thinkers.

all_work_is_honorable_and_we_shouldn_t_b.description: Education and society must abandon the image of "success equals a white collared shirt." How are we supposed to grow our specialized labor industries if these people might feel looked down on because they didn't force themselves into an office job?
all_work_is_honorable_and_we_shouldn_t_b.creator: d11f9d146ccd45954f9b552f1920726b

comments.text: hey Dan! I'd like to invite you to check out my concept ... part of the idea is to profile successful, creative professionals in "non-well-considered" jobs. They are modern heroes too!http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/modern-heroes-origin-stories/

I completely agree with your inspiration, but I would like to add how these non-well-considered jobs may teach you a lot for your after college job.I have been combining my studies in Civil Engineering with a summer jobs as plumber, painter, sign writer and drywall builder. In these, I have had the chance to learn a lot of skills that have helped me out in both my studies and work experienced. It is not all about learn how to lay a pipe but about how interactions between bosses and workers are and many other aspects. Moreover, I have got some understanding from the bottom up about fields related to Civil Engineering as building installations and construction in general.

A great inspiration and great comments from all too!I have just been listening to Mike Lazaridis in his address to the 2012 Association for the Advancement of Science meeting in Vancouver( this is where I heard it http://mpegmedia.abc.net.au/rn/podcast/2012/06/ssw_20120609_1222.mp3 it will be available for four weeks )He talks about his "upstairs-downstairs" education. Although he went on to talk about science and innovation, it can be extrapolated all walks of life and the need to provide people with the capacity to realise their potential. Pride in achieving excellence in whatever we do can lead to unexpected opportunities and the other side of the coin needs to be in appreciating everyone's contribution and supporting that excellence. Making choices early in life is not for everyone so we do need to give people both fundamental knowledge and skills, and opportunities for life-long learning.

Yes! Just because you are a farm hand, police officer, or other hands on job doesn't make a person's career any less valuable. We can't all be doctors, we need other skills to make the world go round. There's a big need for skilled labor but few people want to due to the bad media image. We utilize them when our car or plumbing breaks down but don't realize their true value.

Totally agree. There was an article in the nytimes yesterday that speaks to this. The guy is reflecting on all the skills his daughter is learning through being a camp counselor compared to "fetching coffee" at a large corporation.http://parenting.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/05/29/the-camp-counselor-vs-the-intern/?emc=eta1

Great insight. When we grow up, we want to be doctors, and policemen and pilots and firemen. Later, we want to be corporate bosses. But the art of skilled labor, and the value of these jobs, is not highlighted enough. In my career as a management consultant, one of the lessons I learned is that the subject matter experts, the ones with the most insight in what a company is doing, are the ones on the work floor.
Matthew Crawford's NYT's article on exactly this point is definitely worth a read: http://www.nytimes.com/2009/05/24/magazine/24labor-t.html?pagewanted=all

I agree - I taught in a university a few years back and probably a third of the people on courses didn't really want to be there - they were just doing it because it was expected that they get a career in something that required a degree.  Consequently they didn't perform well ... how great would it have been if they'd been tempted earlier into something that was equally cool but suited them better.  I know that in the UK they are doing more to promote science/engineering as cool professions but I think it could go further.  Some of the happiest people I know are those doing unskilled jobs that they enjoy doing but just because it's unskilled, doesn't mean it's not worth anything to society.  Go the working class, go!!!

Mike Rowe has one of the best TED Talks ever on the very same topic of course.I agree with you.Do you know which jobs are the hardest to fill? I wonder if ppl indeed don't apply to jobs because they are not fancy...
Really interesting thoughts Dan. Thanks for chiming in!

Thanks, Ashley! As a 24-year-old recent industrial design graduate who's been actively looking for employment, I fit directly into the group that this project's targeting and know the frustrations firsthand. Will definitely be contributing whatever I can to this project as it progresses.
Great to have you onboard, Dan! And fab personal insights here.

comments.text: Hey Paul, My understanding is that the savings came from the organisation being run as a social enterprise.  This meant it no longer need to generate a significant profit to return to company owners and could offer the same (or even higher quality services) to the Yarra Council at a lower price point.

Thanks Caroline - that's great! - and welcome back to ideating.As i suspected - a great example of equitable re-balancing as one expects from BSL initiatives. Having had some schooling and early work life in Melbourne I'm aware of BSL by reputation although I'm now ensconced in Tassie.I'm particularly glad to see you include this as not everyone has the opportunity for traditional access to higher education but everyone does deserve the dignity of gaining meaningful employment. I guess as a (very) casual part of the fast food industry (at the moment) I am acutely aware of the fine line between truly valuing a person's efforts and mere commodification.

Interesting story Caroline. Do you happen to know where the savings were made - hopefully not through reducing the value of the work performed? I imagine with Brotherhood of St Laurence involved this has not happened.

turn_the_kids_into_makers.creator: 08263a2955ccdb23f255f58d53d7cf16

comments.text: A couple of thoughts on this Connecting effort with results is important for motivation. This connection is most obvious when there is a visible result - the making process creates something to be proud of.Practical implementation of ideas leads to a fuller understanding and allows a more exploitative (act first, reflect later) approach."What I cannot create, I do not understand." - Richard Feynman

Thanks Sarah for sharing these different projects. I think that your point "empower new generations to realize that when there isn't a job available, they can make one themselves" is crucial. I think that there is never really a job for yourself, and that at least, even if it's there, it still requires you to imagine it to find it. More than skills it requires a mindset ... and such workshops and events can clearly help developing it.
We need more full time schools like this in the public sector. Not everyone can afford the 20K a year. http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/brightworks-/

Malcom Gladwell talks about this in his book "The Outliers"...He indicated that many of the top law firms could be traced back generations to their influence of learning from jewish migrants running small businesses on the streets...This does also point out that our current education system are insufficient...the pay back is in future generations...

Thanks Kirpal, I think its a great observation; which must make us realize that opportunities tend to be generational, so for young adults it is their (our) responsibility to be aware of existing opportunities / untapped markets and needs, i.e. tech entrepreneurship, and also identify future opportunities for upcoming generations so that the system can implement this into their educational models.

Yes you and me are on the same page!  My inspiration on the "Go where the puck is" is basically what you just said to me.http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/where-the-puck-is-going-to-be.../On the education models, please look at a great blog on this, this is a school of thought that the education models are out of date, they were designed for the wrong age, and they make you dumber as you proceed...:)http://www.presentationzen.com/presentationzen/2012/03/rethinking-education-learning-the-role-of-school.html

Great call Sarah! I was totally excited the other day, checking out DIY  fab to check out these other examples also. There's certainly a deeper level of learning & engagement which happens when folks get hands-on creative  we're looking forward to the fresh thinking this may inspire in the upcoming Concepting phase.
Thanks Meena, I'll make sure to follow up in that stage.

the_mentoring_wishing_tree.description: Young people place their dreams of what they would like to learn to do on a wishing tree and potential mentors select the young person they are most excited about helping.
the_mentoring_wishing_tree.creator: 6f9c09d414c3a407dca9ae213a4bf7bb

comments.text: Such a great idea! I could see this easily being incorporated into university internship & career centers. I think most schools already have online databases where students can search for internship & job opportunities but a mentor database seems more important for giving students real-world knowledge and preparing them for internships & jobs.

Thanks, Carol. I really important part of this is the other direction. That is, there has to be an attractive way of getting mentors to take interest in particular students. Many people might not want to volunteer to be part of a bank of mentors willing to be contacted by lots of people but would be happy to pick from among the people whose descriptions make it seem like a good match from the mentor's side.

I really like this idea! There aren't enough positive/creative/helpful mentors currently in any part of the work environment, and by having people volunteer means that they are making a personal choice to make a difference instead of people that are forced into being a mentor for young people at the entry-level position. This might be a great concept to integrate into organizations such as IIDA, ASA, etc., so that graduating students or entry-level workers can find mentors directly linked to their area(s) of study.

Thanks. I believe that research supports the great benefit of a mentor in the development of a range of dispositions and skills. The value as a potential reference in the job search is also clear, if the mentor has a track record that suggests credibility.

Really cool fjr. While thinking on the concept you have presented, another direction to this came to my mind.Its based on Achieving Your Childhood Dreams. At the end, we all work towards fulfilling our dreams.What if young people put up their dreams onto to such kind of common platform. With this, various people from various different region, community sharing same or similar dreams can collaborate and work towards achieving their dreams. Even this would help mentor in collaborating with mentee who share similar dreams. It is like Enabling the dreams of others.Ya, you can make out I am really fascinated by Randy Pausch's "The Last Lecture" - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Last_Lecture

Thanks, Sandeep. Your idea reminded me of how some people use vision boards to keep their ideas in view. With sites such as Pinterest, it would be easy enough to share these. Of course the web provides wonderful opportunities to form communities of interest and communities of practice.

I second Meena's suggestion to use an online platform, picturing a color-coded and easily searchable database of wishes for mentors. Now I'd like to open the discussion to two details (1) reach and (2) effectiveness:- By "reach" I mean, the range of skills addressed. Would there be pre-set skills categories from which prospective mentees sort of...check off the experience or knowledge base they're looking to acquire? Perhaps focused on the particular firm's expertise? Or, would mentees be free to define and customize? - As for effectiveness, should there be a feedback mechanism, and what would the timeframe for that look like? Would mentors direct mentees to get certain experience and then move on, or maintain the relationship? To put it another way, I'm wondering what incentives could be incorporated to keep mentors invested.

Thank you, Karolle, for your thoughtful suggestions. In reference to reach, the prospects of a successful match depend on the mentee's not being highly specific. If the mentee selects something highly specific or esoteric, he may not get a mentor at all. There needs to be flexibility on both sides to attract good mentors.Mentors would likely retain the relationship if the mentee showed diligence and promise. The mentoring would likely shift from teaching of skills to interactions about the necessary dispositions and further education or training to move into that field of work. I think the sorts of professionals you want to attract to mentoring are the sort for whom the incentives must be intrinsic. These typically will be busy people whose time is very valuable.

Interesting, fjr! I wonder if this idea might also translate to an onine Wishing Tree as well? I can imagine some great UX wrapped around it so that folks can post to Facebook, Twitter, etc to help spread the whole campaign. Then stories of success could be shared online as well?
Indeed, Meena, an online component makes great sense! Might the visible, physical configuration in a lobby be harder for a lucky professional to walk by every day without responding?

Quite possibly. Though they might also like the wider reach and less of a commitment to physical infrastructure provided by an online platform. Looking forward to onward discussion and builds with other ideators here!

the_mentoring_wishing_tree.title: The Mentoring Wishing Tree

forget_college_some_ideas_just_cant_wait.description: “Every tech story is different. Every moment in history happens only once. All successful companies are successful in their own unique way. It’s your task to figure out what that future history will be.” – Peter Thiel
forget_college_some_ideas_just_cant_wait.creator: c385cf3f4cd658b158f8f5fa55ca6978
