the_great_employer_register.description: Employers like to have "great employees". Lets create a register of "great employers"
the_great_employer_register.creator: b75f37937882fb4178a3d02f287219c6

comments.text: Check out www.glassdoor.com. I think what they have going on is a similar concept. Would it be worth it to develop something similar to that idea in the youth employment niche like you are suggesting? Thoughts on the cost/benefit of this endeavour?

Thanks Bryan.I didnt do any preliminary research for this one - just put it down as it came into my head. The link you have given is a great site that encompasses many of the thoughts I have had subsequently.You are right that the cost benefit analysis would need to be done to determine value in competing.

Do you have any ideas how this concept could be distinguished or morphed to provide value in the present context?Or perhaps posting an alternative concept to enable applicants to appraise the benefits of working for particular companies, apart from salary?

Great question prompts, Paul. It might be a worthwhile thinking of ways in which good employer behaviour can be recognised and rewarded (merit badges, etc) rather than the platform imploding into a gripe fest on their faults. Looking forward to tracking onwards conversation on this concept.

Thanks Meena - I had thought to make my graphic include a scale of positive attributes (just haven't added it yet).Bryan has pointed out a job seeking site that does some of this and includes anonymous salary and other details..As a way to distinguish my concept I was thinking that some way to look at the things that contribute to job satisfaction as well as aspects of the approach to selection of applicants.Certainly I take on board Bryan's question on the cost/benefit of this concept - so I will see how the community helps to give this further points of distinction and value.One of my motivations in this has been that so many of the advantages in the transition seem to rest with the employer in times of high unemployment. Even knowing that a company will be polite or give you useful feedback on failed applications can be encouragement to continue searching.

the_great_employer_register.title: The "Great Employer" Register

millennial_alley.description:
Silicon Valley is now a household name.  

What if young people had a similarly structured community or neighborhood enclave to turn to, in order to gather skills, information and opportunities to succeed in the world of work?
millennial_alley.creator: 8482a78370e4b5a84ccf768aedf73d9f

comments.text: I also agree that there is no substitute for a physical meeting space.  It seems like a space like this could also become known among companies looking to hire young people, as the place to go to find new employees?  And that, with many young people who would likely be at different stages in their career development, there could be the potential for some informal mentorship and peer-to-peer assistance?  Great idea!

Thanks Jessica.  I'm looking forward to fine tuning this concept.  The peer-to-peer relationships will be key.  I'm glad you made that point.  It is friendly competition through friendly encouragement.

It might be easier to find career/job information online these days, but the internet is no subsitute for that physical space where youths are surrounded by support and positivity; a space that leads them to entering the workforce and participating in the community, rather than being stuck in isolated spaces that leads to boredom, disinterest and disengagement.
I'm definitely in agreement Andrew.  Thank you for sharing that.  Getting offline from time to time will help build those soft skills.
Perhaps they could even work as pop-up spaces?

I love that idea.  I had that very same thought a few hours ago! After revisiting your comments on Lab21 about limiting physical infrastructure, I thought a pop-up concept might be another way to really pilot all of these wonderful ideas -- together.

Great inclusion of various ideas from our Concepting phase here, Sasha. Could be great if you might add links to the ideas mentioned on your post  and add names of their creators to your Virtual Team Field. Tip: to activate links in your post, hit the Update Entry button up there on the right, then follow the instructions here: http://bit.ly/oi_link  Looking forward to the collaborative conversations which are likely to follow!
Thank you Meena.  I've made the above changes.
Nice one, Sasha!

millennial_alley.title: MILLENNIAL ALLEY

tan_academy_empower_young_people_to_secu.description: TAN Academy is a platform that provides Training, Advising, and Networking opportunities to help young people discover their career interests, develop new skills, and succeed in the world of work.
tan_academy_empower_young_people_to_secu.creator: a9c11ed750adcbb28cd093e7ed590432

comments.text: Hi, Edward, I like the idea of an Academy! But what I don't understand is who will/could be the advisor, teacher, coach? What kind of education would they bring? Or is the idea about experts/professional out of a company who will be the coaches?

Great stuff, Edward! Love how you've broken down into the 3 user needs and built the idea out from there. Is this an existing initiative or one that you're proposing? Was a bit confused by the line " The easiest way to contribute is by actively participating in TAN Academy's online forums." Perhaps if it's an exiting platform you could provide a link?

Hi,Great idea indeed but like Meena, I was unsure whether this existed or not. If it does not, how are you thinking of developing it? From scratch? or building up on existing institutions? e.g. universities, incubators, chambers of commerce? etc.thanks
This is something I am proposing. So everything is imaginary at this point. But there might be existing services or organizations that could fit into this framework.

Nice one, Edward! Looking forward to collaborative input on this from others in our community. Be sure to incorporate any feedback & new thoughts that you're keen on into your actual concept post to acknowledge your idea is evolving through these community conversations.

tan_academy_empower_young_people_to_secu.title: TAN Academy - empower young people to secure and create jobs

meaningful_internships.description: Internships are important for students to gain an understanding of how a company works, it looks good on their resume and helps guide their career. However, internships can be unfulfilling if expectations aren't managed. Let's change this.
meaningful_internships.creator: 8e84dcee4c3a16638492d06cd11ca88f

comments.text: Great stuff, Louise! I like that you've added the part about apps to also inspire internees who also often need help in this equation. Perhaps there might be other elements besides apps which support them as well? Or some kind of encouragement of companies to devise meaningful contract-type documents with their internees to mutually decide what each of them are going to put in to the internship? Looking forward to builds from others here. And loving your illustration!

Thanks Meena, agree with your comments. I had intended for the toolkit to be a tool for companies to encourage providing more internships but for it to also benefit the internee. A meaningful document that is agreed before hand would be really valuable. It would give the internee the sense of what a real contract is like (negoitable etc!).Glad you like the illustration ;-)

I agree with the idea of a contract - having supervised interns myself, I think it's very helpful to lay out expectations at the start of the internship.  For my less proactive intern, this included specifying how frequently we would check in, letting her know the best ways to approach me with questions, the deliverables we agreed she would produce by the end of her 3 month stay, and a rough idea of her milestones/timelines.  I don't think that level of detail is necessary for every intern, but I've found it can be helpful for intern supervisors to have a checklist or template contract to work off of.

Thanks for your support, Jessica. It's great to hear other's have has similar experiences and can see how this would be a help.I agree that It wouldn't suit every situation, company or intern but people who haven't had the experience we had (and we now know how to tackle the situation differently) may be out off by fear of the I known. Hopefully this would change that!

Useful suggestion on the checklist and template contract, Meena and Jessica. Building on this and Louise's comment, it would be great to offer some offline event, in addition to the toolkit, before and after the internship program. The experienced interns could share do's and don'ts and the new ones could learn and reflect on their experiences as well as connect the dots between this real-life learning and school education.

Ive had a few bad internship experiences myself and really appreciate your concept wanting to prevent this from happening, I think that the most shocking part for me was that the boss(from which I was supposed to be learning) was barely at the studio, ended up moving stuff around and it became very frustrating, I wonder if this toolkit would include a kind of contract in which both parties made some commitment ensuring benefit for both the student and the company?

Great idea Louise. I think internships have suffered in recent years, as interns and their mentors do not always have the same expectations of the internship.  I'd like to hear more about the toolkit itself and the ways in which it could be utilized in practice.

Louise - This is a great, practical and achievable concept within the challenge context.Great input from Jessica and Drew too.By companies comparing their present approach to the opportunities presented in the toolkit it will also give them insight into possible improvements in many of their other internal practices.

Great idea, Louise!  As a college senior to-be at a summer internship, I think I can share some ideas of my own on this subject. In addition to the apps you mentioned, perhaps it would also be helpful to potential internees to have an online community where they could go see profiles of previous interns who have written about their experiences at specific companies.  This would allow the incoming interns to have a good snapshot of what is expected of them, and how they will be treated.  This would also allow for an incoming intern to get in contact with a previous intern to discuss subjects they might not feel comfortable talking about with their manager.You could also expand this idea to a program for incoming full time employees to discover connections to previous employees and other personnel who have more insight (and perhaps more perspective) on what it is like to work at a certain company.  I look forward to hearing more about your idea!

Drew, I LOVE your builds, thank you! Yes, you should be able to see the profiles of those that have been interns and read their thoughts and comments. It reminds me of the social agency in Scotland called Snook - they have a section called 'Snooksters' where their interns/employees write a piece about their experiences http://snooksters.com
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

meaningful_internships.title: Meaningful internships

comments.text: I like the idea behind AStudyIn, to provide a platform where lectures are available on the internet to everyone. Also the other usage of the system - to help high school graduates choosing the university by looking at the lectures is helpful. After having watched a lecture the next step would be putting this knowledge into practice in order to develop the right skills. It would be great to integrate this in the concepting phase.

Hi Sabine. Great thoughts! If I remember correctly, College Confidential (http://www.collegeconfidential.com/) is a site students can use to help narrow their college search. However, I really like your thought of adding a video component - would be a great way to provide even more info to students, which will hopefully allow students to make better choices about which university is right for them (or if any, as there has been much discussion in the US if college is even worth the price; for as we can see by this challenge, young people are still lacking stills for entering the workforce and building careers).

thanks maria!

employers_have_the_answers_..._if_asked_.description: Young people are taught by educators not employers, so the employers must be specific about what they mean by communication and self management skills.  An open-source skills taxonomy will set the foundation of understanding between all parties
employers_have_the_answers_..._if_asked_.creator: 999ac39178a0952d5799610c98e4a936

comments.text: Congratulations to the 6 winning concepts! Very well deserved for such a diverse mixture of ideas. If Carole or I can help you with any information or introductions, please don't hesitate to get in touch with us at www.sbskills.com. Good luck everyone with the hardest, but most satisfying part: the execution!

I love this idea because it hits exactly the right target at the interface between employers and the unemployed.Last week, Hastings Borough Council ran a conference called "Ready Willing and Able". This looked at youth unemployment with a focus on improving links between schools and employers. The consistent message from employers was that they valued attitude and "soft" skills more than technical and academic ability. "If he or she has the righ attitude, we can teach the practical skills". this is especially true when thinking of the kinds of young people least likely to walk into jobs. Yesterday I spoke to young people at a youth centre. All had "failed" at school and/or college. All said "We haven't got GCSE's or NVQ's, so we can't even tick the right box that will get us an interview."This proposal can build up and validate the actual life and communication skills that employers want. It would be easy to implement by schools (especially if they are given space in the curriculum and/or told to integrate it with other learning as they must with literacy and numeracy). It could equally well be done by community learning bodies, college, or the voluntary sector. It could add value of a tangible qualification to a lot of youth activities such as sports, arts and volunteering.There is a methodological challenge in how to objectively evaluate soft skills and attitudes. It should include basic (level 1) numeracy and literacy. And yes, a catchy name. With these, I belive it would rapidly become both popular and essential with employers and young people alike.

Hi Glyn,Thanks very much for the wonderful feedback!I do like the title of the Hastings conference you went to: Young people are "ready" in their millions, "willing" is a question mark for too many, but for those who are,, the "able" will almost take care of itself. Karan Bilimoria has a great saying in this regard. He says "I hire based on 'will' not 'skill'" and has examples to back it up."We haven't got GCSE's or NVQ's, so we can't even tick the right box that will get us an interview." - Isn't that a sad thing to hear, especially when the actual skills gained passing those qualifications aren't going to make them better in the jobs they are trying to interview for!Yes I agree with you  re: the recognition of activities such as sports, arts and volunteering. The "only" thing we need to do it to quantify these accomplishments so employers can more easily use them to differentiate between candidates.Re: catchy name, we are going with "What Employers Want" and are going to publish a book of the same title in the new year. Watch this space!

Hello Carole, I find your concept highly feasible, viable, usable and desirable. I so hope for your success. My apologies for making comments just 3 days before the end of the contest. I wonder if you might consider, to cover all bases, answering the 5 Drucker Questions about your concept? I think perhaps you will be asked these questions in some form, by someone, at some time.  What is our mission? Assumed "To equip young people with the skills, information and opportunities to succeed in the world of work."  Who is our customer? This is a most difficult question as their are many who would benefit. Just for a moment though, what if you assume the customer is a concept sponsor-Barclay'sWhat does the customer value? How, specifically will this concept improve the key performance indicators for Barclay's? http://reports.barclays.com/ar11/financialreview/keyperformanceindicators.html?cat=b#acc4What are our results? Will your metrics be tied to those of Barclay's?What is our plan?I think you already have this, but will it change as a result of considering the customer, Barclay's annual report? Cheers and good luck!

Hi Rob,Thanks for your kind words. We really believe in this and are glad you feel the same.Yes, we too like to use the lens of Drucker's 5 Questions, particularly as he is a bit of a hero of mine!However, although focus is important, I would hesitate to put Barclays forward as the (only) customer or worry about what positive things can be printed in its annual report after the success of this project.Yes, success of the initiative will be good for Barclays' in this respect, but I trust that Barclays will see it as a (very welcome) side effect of a successful execution, rather than the primary objective.Thanks again, Carole

Agreed Carole. Bob is of course correct from a classic "business consulting" point of view. However, but it could be counter-productive in evaluating (most of) the concepts submitted for this this challenge. Besides, I love to remind myself that companies like Google, started with a great idea but no obvious "route to revenue", ..... and Google hasn't done too badly.Taking this concept as an example, working on some model of how to charge employers, educational institutions, and students for use of the system will kill it before it even gets started, and quite rightly so!

Hi John, Hi Bob, Thanks for your comments. I agree with you, John, that planning to charge for such a service is premature and inappropriate. Google was born from a cool idea and didn't make any money until well after it was delivering benefits from its cool ideas.  The whole intention of this initiative (or if you will, cool idea) is to "break down skills into smaller parts until they are no longer disagreed on" so that educators can develop employability skills teaching and assessment frameworks to create precisely what students are looking for ie "a nationally recognised record of the employability skills you have developed..."(CBI/NUS, 2011).  Any further benefits will flow from successful delivery of this initiative. The prototype is ready for populating, there is a growing number of interested parties and I am ready to take on the challenge to ensure this crowd generated open sourced solution does exactly what is intended.

Naming of the concept:As mentioned before, this has been one of the hardest challenges for us. Last week I had the pleasure of meeting the Assistant Business Editor of a Sunday broadsheet. I explained our "employability taxonomy" concept to him and his response was effectively: great idea, I'd be interested in learning more with a view to doing a story, but what a bad name! Then, with the journalistic flair of getting straight to the point he said: "What you're talking about is 'What Employers Want'".He's right!

A very helpful and new concept. In today's economic climate it is essential for us to be employable and capable of securing employment, but there is a lot of confusion what employers are really looking for.Having a conversation with them will help trainers and Universities to prepare their graduates more efficiently to deal with demands and expectations of different organisations.I only wish that this concept had been introduced years earlier.
Thank you for your support Edit.
This concept will benefit millions of people if adopted by uk system because it links the gap between the right job for the right person
Thank you for your optimism Frixos. We share it!
Really thoughtful analysis and concept Carole. At its core, your idea is about language, communication and setting clear expectations for everyone to understand. Sounds like a win/win/win to me!

Thanks Ashley. You're right, 'language' is a good description. I feel that there often needs to be translation between 'academic speak' and 'business speak'. This 'translation' is a big part of this concept. Thanks again for your input and confirming that we're on the right track. Have a great week!
Agreed this is useful for those who didn't get the language and communication fundamentals from school. Also points up the need to go back to basics in the lower end of education.

I think the question on how to get the already-left-school kids involved has been answered so for the rest...Absolutely, using the web to create and socialize the body of work makes perfect sense. Then, once built, you could deliver this as a pilot program with a specific company, preferably a big enough one to garner some media attention as it gets under way and one with multiple outlets/stores/facilities to model how the program could be propagated across geographies. Working with one company can be easier in the initial stages and help guarantee an early success. Since the model requires broad acceptance of a common taxonomy, the early and public adoption by a "brand-name" company also gives you the buzz needed to spur further development and interest. Naturally, this assumes that you've solved the thorny issue of what to call this sorely needed program, so that you can market it accordingly. Maybe these will help start the process:BET - Business and Employability Terms CLE - Common Language for EmployabilityCBT- Common Business Terms

Thanks very much for such positive and useful feedback.We got invited to have tea with Tim Clement-Jones at the House of Lords as he has a strong interest in this area. His feedback was similar to yours and went along the lines of: It's a great idea so 'all' you need to do is get started small and it will snowball from there.He favoured identifying school/uni + employer pairs and then launching with the Government's blessing at a Government hosted event in Westminster. We'll update the text of the concept to reflect this conversation today. Many thanks for reminding us of this idea.Of course Barclays is just the sort of "brand-name" company you describe and one of the challenge sponsors, so fingers crossed! I used to work for Barclays but haven't approached them about this yet.Thanks for kicking off the name brainstorm. I like the idea of a three-letter acronym. Isn't it funny how important finding a good name is!

We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Our developers are busy working on it. Meanwhile, if you're wanting to iterate your ideas, you can use the comments feature to promote further conversation from others. We'll let you know once the bug is fixed, then you can incorporate your refinement moves into your concept post. Let's be agile, together!

Right on! Our development team have been busy fixing the Update Entry bug and we're back on track now. You'll now be able to edit your posts to add all that refinement-goodness to build out your concepts for improved impact. Bring it on, together!

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:The panel appreciated the effort that has clearly gone into researching this concept and strongly support the idea of common language/taxonomy so that there's more transparency between employers and jobseekers. They also applaud the fact it highlights that academic qualifications are no longer a good differentiator of candidates  there needs to be something more, which this concept could start to tackle. WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:The main questions from the panel are 1) do you have any thoughts on how this idea could be delivered at scale? And 2) How could you develop this to include young people who have already left school?  And, some of us feel it could do with a slightly catchier name ;-)For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine

Initial thoughts on the panel's follow-up questions:1) Scalability: Good question! There are dozens (hundreds?) of individual employability initiatives throughout the country and some are very good indeed. However, any sort of a accreditation/award at a "local" level naturally has proportionally less value than something nationally recognised. Scalability is therefore key. One of the nice things about this concept is that it is eminently scalable using web technologies and the fact that a common curriculum/rubrick/taxonomy will cover the whole country. A perfect example of something being performed in a particular industry is the Bloomberg Assessment Test (BAT) and I encourage fellow OpenIDEO folks to check it out for inspiration: https://www.bloomberginstitute.com/bat/start/I have met with the Bloomberg people in London and been shown what they are doing first hand. It's most impressive and the concept is a perfect base on which to build a similar solution for employability skills.2) Including young people who have left school: Back to the idea of scalability, if employability skills are on the curriculum at school then the solution is (relatively) neat, and I understand that Carole is going to be meeting with Michael Gove to explore how this could work. However, once people have left school then the provision of the skills teaching and assessment can be provided by the private sector.. An organisation like the Association of Employment and Learning Providers (http://www.aelp.org.uk/) is perfectly placed to help coordinate this and Graham Hoyle OBE is already enthusiastic about the idea. With a common taxonomy to work to, suddenly service providers will no longer be a heterogeneous collection of 100s of small outfits, but will become a powerful coalition working towards the same goal.3) A proper name: This is important, and sadly quite hard! I hope the creativity of OpenIDEO members can be brought to bear on this. My initial suggestion would to find a pronounceable acronym which included the name of the organisation willing to sponsor the initiative e.g. Barclays Employability Taxonomy (BET), but better! Many thanks, Johnhttp://www.theworkfoundation.com/Reports/273/Employability-and-Skills-in-the-UK-Redefining-the-debate

Further thoughts on the scale-ability: 1) If the skills required are broken down by the employers into smaller parts until they are no longer disagreed on then we can process the skills descriptors into learning outcomes which can be taught at all levels in the education system.  Quality assurance can be ensured if employers are willing to get involved in the delivery of the skills & assessment of the skills at school higher education levels.  Education institutions at all levels ought to be working with employers so having an employability theme running through the education programmes should provide the perfect opportunity for engagement between academia and industry.  Using an industry recognised standard skills taxonomy will ensure everyone is on the same page. I agree the Bloomberg BAT test is a great example.2) Involving young people who have already left school: An "after school" club format is one idea to help young people who have just left school but which could be run on local company premises, co hosted by either the local council or an approved skills provider with young people self selecting based on their preferred industry.  This concept comes back to the idea of employers being involved in the delivery and assessment of the skills at school and higher education level.  Hosting skills evenings would offer employers and local councils an opportunity to engage in outreach.3): An employability taxonomy is not very catchy is it!  We're open to acronym ideas to give it a much more catchy name.  Best regards,Carole

employers_have_the_answers_..._if_asked_.title: What Employers Want

py/tuple: IMPACT & REACH: How much impact and reach do you think this concept could have in helping young people transition into the world of work?
A great deal – something like this would really make a difference
A moderate amount – it’s certainly helpful but probably not a game-changer
Not very much – it’s unlikely to make a significant difference to young people seeking work

FEASIBILITY & RESOURCES: Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible will it be for your community to turn this concept into a reality?  (Hint: when you think about resources, think: people, money, time, technology, infrastructure, partnerships and any other inputs for implementation)
Highly feasible – resources wouldn’t be an issue for my community if we tried to implement this
Moderately feasible – my community could do it if we could get find assistance with some of our resource constraints
Not feasible – it would be almost impossible for my community to implement this concept; it's just too resource-intensive
SUSTAINABILITY & LONGEVITY: Does this concept feel like it could be sustained as a project, business or movement over years rather than just months? Will continue to be relevant in future?
Yes – this concept has enough momentum to stand on its own two feet and remain relevant for years to come
Maybe – it’s not clear how long it would take for this concept to stand on its own feet or how it will continue to be but there’s reason to feel hopeful
No – this concept will have trouble sustaining itself in the long-run and probably won’t be as relevant in years to come
ORIGINALITY: How new or innovative is this idea? Are there many different versions of this concept out there already or is this something more disruptive and unique?
Very original – I’ve not seen anything else quite like it
Fairly original – there are similar things out there but this particular version brings a new element to the table
Unoriginal – there are already too many other concepts out there that are similar to this one
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world
I liked it but preferred others
It didn't get me overly excited

some_loves_are_worth_more_than_others.description: “People keep telling kids to study what they love — but some loves are worth more than others,” said Anthony P. Carnevale, one of the study’s authors.
some_loves_are_worth_more_than_others.creator: 861fc4bab15e61028aee0583aeb85b11

comments.text: Lynn, you make a solid point that young people should be encouraged to explore a number of different areas that might interest them rather than channeling themselves into one track. Approaching learning and life narrowly reduces flexibility. Not only is the world always changing but people find new areas of interest all the time if they are open to them. It is increasingly uncommon to stay in the same precise line of work over a lifetime.

Hi, I agree that young people should be encourage and offer the opportunity to explore various fields. In fact, I personally think that this is also about allowing children to have a broad education as long as possible. I am always surprised when I see middle schools to a certain extent, and then high schools already asking children to specialize. Yet, I am not sure I completely agree with the quote (sorry I haven't read the article) and the fact that young people should not be encouraged to do what they are passionate about. I personally studied what I wanted despite what people around me thought: I studied philosophy and people kept asking me what kind of job I would get. My reply was: I don't know but for the moment I want to learn something I really like and I'll always figure out a way of making a leaving (hopefully in a field I like) when it is time. I was maybe extremely lucky but I ended up always doing things I was interested in although I moved away from philosophy. Looking at my students, I would in fact encourage them to be passionate and enthusiasts instead of looking in a pragmatic way for a job. Students only thinking of finding the perfect job do not "learn" nor "think" (in a deep and broad way), and they don't use opportunities to learn from various fields and experiences. They thus miss opportunities that will allow them to find interesting jobs. I might be wrong... or it might depend of the careers and professions.

Hi Lynn, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know by hitting the Support tab on the left hand side of most pages of our site if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

some_loves_are_worth_more_than_others.title: some loves are worth more than others

comments.text: [This kid is the bomb] Really though, think about how many more life skills he learned by making this in one day than most 8th graders learn in a year sitting in algebra.I believe there should be some way to facilitate this type of learning in curriculum.If you are going to succeed as a young person in the work force you need confidence. This kid has already met the president. We wont have to worry about him.
There is room in the life of most 9th graders for both - and more.I think such possibilities are great. If you want to be a baseball star then maybe that's a different choice point.Great post Avi.

I hadn't seen this write up Avi, but I also posted on encouraging a young community of Makers. DIY is an online community that looks very similar to the Young Makers Program.Glad to see other people and places focusing on these kinds of programs for kids!Thanks for sharing this.

re_thinking_the_classroom_only_universit.description: With the current economy, students graduating from college must have some work experience under their belts.  Some universities, like Northeastern, are incorporating internships or volunteering as part of the curriculum.
re_thinking_the_classroom_only_universit.creator: cf5bdfb40421ac1f30cc4d45b66b5a81

comments.text: Way to go, Mira. I found it interesting checking out more on http://www.northeastern.edu/experiential-learning/ Maybe you'd like to add that link to your post so folks can easily check out more? Tip: to activate links in your post, hit the Update Entry button up there on the right, then follow the instructions here: http://bit.ly/oi_link
Thanks for the tip!  I added the link.

Excellent point! I think it is crucial. I learnt recently that we have an internship course in our department but most of the faculty did not know about it. I was told that only few students take it. I mentioned it to some students and none knew about it.I think that this highlights the point you made which is even when such programs exist (even in a more developed stage as in my department), it's often not very highly seen - both by students and faculty. There is therefore some work to do about mindset and communication.You also make an interesting point about graduating in 5 years. I heard many students talking about the time needed to graduate and they tend to take the fast track. I know that the cost of studies is a big issue, but is there a way to develop these programs so that students can get some financial help. Moreover, it could be that the extra year of studies allowed those who "took the time" to volunteer, participate in extra curricular activities and do internships, will end up with better jobs, or even just finding a job. I tend to think it's the case but I have no data to back up this claim.

You make some really great points!  In my undergraduate study, my program incorporated a mandatory 6-month field study where I gained incredibly valuable experience.  But that was just a tiny program within the university (and has since been cut due to budget issues).  I think it's laudable that some universities are putting experience at the forefront of the students' education.

re_thinking_the_classroom_only_universit.title: Re-Thinking the Classroom-Only University

openideo_live_with_google_plus_hangouts_.description: Lets hangout to see and hear the the passion of OpenIDEO concept creators with others.
openideo_live_with_google_plus_hangouts_.creator: 876caf881055173ada9c5c3a1883a079

comments.text: Which stage of the process (inspiring, concepting, applause, refinement, evaluation) do you think would make the best use of the capabilities and dynamics of the Google+ Hangouts?

Thanks for your question Andrew! Begin with concepting. This would be comparable to the initial tryouts on American Idol(This concept was inspired by the Occupational Idol concept). A person who has a concept presents it live using a hangout to a panel of judges. The role of the judges is not to eliminate, but to offer ideas to help build on the presenter's concept. It would be nice, not required, if the panel of judges were experienced IDEOers, with occasional celebrity guest rockstars from the design world. As Hangout events are live and recorded, the global audience can watch, learn, praise and comment on the live hangout chat stream, or asynchronously on the recorded Youtube in the comments section. This would be valuable to the concept presenter as they could watch themselves after the presentation and also see what judges and the larger Youtube audience thinks. Other OpenIDEOer's with concepts could watch, learn and build on cool things they learned while watching their predecessors.( I am a big fan of social learning) Concepts could be presented, for example, at up to 3 hangout events, giving presenters the opportunity to learn and present their improved concept. Right now, I am experimenting with creating a live hangout event from my cell phone to bring openideo concept hangout events into the field for live human interaction with the real world. Cheers!

Great stuff Rob! We hope you bring it up on our User Forums too: http://bit.ly/oi_forumsAnd just saw this: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/career-hangouts/  would be great if you share your experiences with Shaina in discussion there. Hopefully we can all get a bit of cross-pollination going between the two ideas. Creativity loves company!

Thanks Meena, I actually held an impromptu Google Hangout event on July 3, to test the concept. Here's my notes. 1. I recorded the hangout, live to Youtube, however, as I was the only participant, so I deleted it. Who wants to look at me talking to me for 30 minutes:)2. As this hangout event was not announced in advance and was just a test to see how hangouts might work, no people were actually presenting their concepts, so no new concepts were created.. this time.3. Google Hangouts, of course, only allows up to 10 people in a room collaborating at a time. However, I have been in other hangouts where each of the cam's in the hangout are actually small groups of students in a physical place together. For example, I have been in a hangout where groups of ~10 students each from from USC, Standford and MIT design classes, were meeting to collaborate on a project. In this case, 3 cams=~30 students from 3 campuses were hanging out, with the possibility to add other groups for the 7 other cams from other campuses. And of course, the number of people at each one of the locations could be much greater than 10.4. Would I limit the amount of participants in the live event? Yes and No. It would depend on the purpose of the event. For example, as you may recall, this concept is building on the "Occupational Idol" concept, where, as on the TV show, you would like millions to watch as the person/team presents their concept to the world, live through YouTube video. The number of cams actually "in the hangout" are limited to 10, with perhaps 2 for the "Challenge Sponsors" 3 reserved for the "celebrity panel", 1 for the hangout host/moderator and 4 concept presenters. As with the TV show, each of the 4 who will be presenting their concepts will rotate through to present. Of course the larger audience watching the YouTube may not enter the hangout by cam, but they may participate, by chatting in the event stream that is part of the hangout event. For example, here is the chat stream from this test hangout, from the other day. https://plus.google.com/u/0/events/c0ge2mfd3aa4stdi99p17fm1u8k/1140803890791957743125. If the purpose of the hangout is to do design work, rather than showcase the concept, my personal preference is for no more than 7 people on a team or in a hangout at a time. I base this somewhat on personal experience and an abstraction of Metcafe's Law http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metcalfe%27s_law where communications become asymptotically more complicated when the number of people participating increases.
Thanks for the tip about Shaina's concept! It is very cool and I hope we can build on her concept, together!
Cheers for your thoughtful reply Rob. Was especially great to check out Metcalfe's Law which was new to me.
Hi Rob, I love your idea and am a bit disappointed you've unpublished it. Would you mind making it public again as I'd love to build on it with some new ideas.
Republished and I can't wait to hear your new ideas! So exciting!

we_want_youth_we_love_performance_.description: Support youth employment by changing the mentality in large organizations: from age dependent opportunities to performance dependent opportunities.
we_want_youth_we_love_performance_.creator: 8082a75025cb51e513aff379783121c9

comments.text: I was not aware that many(?) businesses are still on the "age dependent opportunities" system. Can you fill me in on some examples of companies or countries that still run on the "age dependent opportunies" system? Even if companies already run on the "performance dependent opportunities" system, I see that there is a lot of value added by promoting and raising awareness of the emphasis on performance.

Discrimination on the basis of age (old or young) is still highly prevalent in Australia despite laws against it. Performance  becomes equated with 'lack of suitability' to cycle younger workers through low or even unpaid work. There is a judicial inquiry into the practice of putting youth on trial basis work then simply discontinuing employment with no remuneration for the work that was performed. This mainly applies to unskilled work but has been applied in other circumstances too.From the perspective of workers in the 50 plus age group the situation is similar - demonstrated past performance (qualified or otherwise) is ignored despite research showing older workers contribute more positively to improved productivity.

The countries mentioned in the article were Spain and Italy.During my year in Italy I found out, that my highly qualified Italian friends had problems in finding jobs in Italy. Their parents had contracts with good working conditions. But for the young generation it was hard to get into the job market. Some friends also went abroad to find a job. Also my Spanish friends told me about their problems in finding jobs in their country - that only older people had jobs. But for them it is really difficult to find some job.
Despite my (old) age or perhaps because of it I whole-heartedly support these principles Sabine.

Thank you Paul! I totally agree, that a performance based system does not only support young people without a lot of experience but also elderly people. Since at least in Europe the retirement age rises, there should be job opportunities for older people. But changing a job or getting a new one after unemployment is gets more difficult with increasing age. In most employment ads, which I read in the past month, people with job experience form 3 to 8 years were wanted.

we_want_youth_we_love_performance_.title: We want you(th)! We love performance!

training_wheels_redesigning_loans_to_fit.description: Combining education and seed money to launch young people on the path of entrepreneurship.
training_wheels_redesigning_loans_to_fit.creator: f82e1a16e68130027a41c84a9bb2eceb

comments.text: Apparently Richard Branson is pushing an idea like this in the UK!http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/789e5354-6d28-11e1-b6ff-00144feab49a.html#axzz273aH3pF7

This feels like a game-changing idea that helps young people with a skill very rarely taught - managing budgets/making money - which is oddly what most people are employed to do directly and indirectly!  You seem to be working through the details of the loan, which is probably the hardest part.  The expert panel asked "how you make young entrepreneurs aware of it" which is a good question.  The benefit of this idea isn't just the people who are successful but everyone who learns from the process and other people's successes/failures.  A few thoughts (from a marketeer):  - Find your communities of young entrepreneurs.  Scour Facebook/tumblr/Twitter for those who are starting businesses - where do they hang out and ask advice for business plans and funding? Start reaching out to them and also seeding honest, non-intrusive messages in the right forums, etc.   - Build in a mechanic that spreads itself (cf. Kickstarter).  Some form of 'gamification' could really help the concept broadcast itself, i.e. the top projects are opened up to a vote online where the project team need others to like/vote/recommend, or, a portion of funding needs to be generated online from donors with a bank/creditor matching or topping up (again, creating visibility from a wider group of people and passing on the idea of ALT/Loan)- Identify advocates and influencers; who is famous for championing and celebrating young entrepreneurs?  This can be everyone from governments & Bill Gates to local businesspeople.  These people will actively communicate your idea as they personally believe in it, they will also likely contribute skills and time- Find business partners (e.g. bank/creditor) as they will lend credibility and often funds for marketing materials- Develop an information pack/program for schools & teacher advocates.  The process will get smoother when its repeated.  Schools are also well set-up to host events and workshops, as well as having the right audience you want to speak to.  - Find charity partners (e.g. envision/IntoUniversity/Young Enterprise in UK) which work with young people and probably already have accessHope that sparks some ideas!
Fab collaborative conversations here guys  great to see this concept grow!

Hey Erica!Great that our concepts made it into refinement, let's think together!I love how your concept helps young people get a feeling for business before they apply for a loan.The feeling i got from my feedback, is that it's a challenge to come up with a value proposition for banks high enough for them to actually take the risk of supporting someone so young & inexperienced. More and more I am getting the feeling banks are experts in late funding, and maybe it's better if it stays that way?Your support platform will come in handy here:Maybe the mentors will be able to help find alternative funding possibilities. Potentially this platform could be integrated into crowd funding platforms such as kickstarter.com?There was recently a project that manged to get 8million $ funding!http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xa2TC83Vp5ghttp://zombiegamer.co.za/ouya-kickstarter-closes-on-a-massive-8-millionObviously they had already invested allot into building prototypes and come with experience, but that's precisely where your platform could come in!The mentor network could be successful kickstarters who are willing to share their experience back to the community.What do you think?

Hey Stefan!I think you're definitely right that the bank sweet-spot is in investments that are lower risk rather than higher. I've been trying to think of the major types of risk inherent in new businesses and new entrepreneurs and possible ways to counter them:CREDIT RISK (i.e. is this person/business likely to repay the loan?)In a new businesses with a younger person, this risk seems two-part a) do they have a good plan and b) will they stick with the project. Initially I was thinking to reduce this risk by increasing information that the bank has on the applicants by watching them go through the process of a business simulation/startup weekend/bootcamp. Their successful completion of such a project and completion of a financial model for their project and repayment should help with credit risk.Additionally, at least in the US, small business loans and student loans are generally backed by the government. This is less desirable to build into the profit model, but it's definitely an important influence in the loan market.OPERATIONAL RISK (i.e. will the business fly?)Many loans on the market reduce operational risk by targeting loans for equipment (that could be resold in case of default) or funding expansion of working capital/inventory in established businesses. We're trying to do something else here, and aiming to reduce operational risk througha) building a data foundation of a set of new-school business plans and execution data (i.e. the financial progress data) to support a positive feedback loop of learning that allows the bank to efficiently lend small amounts for predictable business models and to flag operational problems before they kill the business. This is the kind of role that Angels/a board often play, but which isn't very scalable or consistent in quality.b) education up-front and mentorship during the life of the loan should increase the chance of execution success.________________________________________________If you're still thinking about further developing a concept for higher-risk projects Breakout Labs (http://www.breakoutlabs.org/home.html) from Peter Thiel's Thiel Foundation might be interesting to you: They have a panel of experts vet high-risk nacent science and technology projects that they fund for up to $300,000, then projects repay once they gain traction and the foundation doesn't retain any long-term stake in the company but does get a solid return on the investment which will then go to fund other projects. It's a cool, potentially stable way to get companies off the ground without hamstringing them into selling half their company just to get started...________________________________________________The idea of successful kickstarters as mentors reminded me of a succes story along those lines that you might like: http://craigmod.com/journal/kickstartup/The Ouya project is a really interesting case. I know a lot of people are having success raising money through the platform, but even some of them who've been working on their products for a long time are having some trouble making good on the pledges they promised to their backers. The project that you pointed to is a great example of the challenges...it seems like an execution miracle if they'll be able to get through the regulatory process, assemble the first complete working units and ship ~60,000 units in the next seven months!Do you know anything about them? Have they produced consumer products before?

Hi Erica - Congratulations on being selected for refinement!I noticed the committee had feedback specifically to how you intent to position this product in the market and make young entrepreneurs aware of it?, so I thought Id address those with some ideas...HOW TO POSITION One question I have is, would this be targeted towards young entrepreneurs who are already getting revenue with their venture or are they pre-revenue and still trying to identify a profitable business model? The reason I ask is that I think youd need different resources depending on who youd be targeting to. If Im pre-revenue, Im probably more interested in learning a white space in the market and how Id build my product. If I already have revenue, perhaps Im interested in how to scale and grow my businesses. On the bank side, what if you targeted this program for small to medium size banks who were looking to expand their community development? This could be a customized program they could adopt without having to establish the framework and the technology. Similar to Stefans comment, what if they partnered with local angel investors whod be able to help share some of the risk and expert network?I thought this article below was good at explaining the challenges that banks have with making small loans, perhaps this could spark some insights on how to navigate around it:http://boss.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/09/06/a-banker-explains-why-small-businesses-have-trouble-getting-credit/HOW TO MAKE YOUNG ENTREPRENEURS AWARE?In the US, there are events called Startup Weekends, where a bunch of individuals interested in building a product gather together for 48 hours. Im thinking your program could be a sponsor and be a part of the prize for winning teams.Also, there seems some benefits of working with entrepreneurship centers. here is a link to a google search for them: http://bit.ly/Rj136iLastly, perhaps you could partner with entrepreneurship education services? Here are a few:http://www.kauffman.org/http://fi.co/http://www.techstars.com/Good luck and I look forward to seeing your progress!

Thanks for the thoughts!The New York Times blog post is really solid. I was thinking about possible ways to reduce overhead in evaluating risk, and the last few paragraphs seem to suggest that big banks could be more interested in these loans if the business risk profiles can be sufficiently modeled by computers. I've been focusing more on the strengths of larger banks (e.g. their advantage to strategically grow new lines of business that benefit from large volumes of transactions and information) partly because Barclays' involvement in the challenge.The Angel concept is an interesting one...it seems like a slightly different concept because most angels expect a higher average return than 6-8%, but angels might be very good follow-on investors post-micro-loan for riskier businesses.I couldn't agree more about leveraging the growing number of start-up centers, bootcamps and incubators. It's a great time to start a business!

We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Our developers are busy working on it. Meanwhile, if you're wanting to iterate your ideas, you can use the comments feature to promote further conversation from others. We'll let you know once the bug is fixed, then you can incorporate your refinement moves into your concept post. Let's be agile, together!

Right on! Our development team have been busy fixing the Update Entry bug and we're back on track now. You'll now be able to edit your posts to add all that refinement-goodness to build out your concepts for improved impact. Bring it on, together!

The bootcamp and the mentorship can be methods through which the bank assesses the risk it would incur from lending to the applicant. The bank can then adjust the size of the loan and the interest rate accordingly.For example, if the applicant does well in the bootcamp and the mentor can see that the applicant knows how to handle a business, the bank may choose to lend more to the applicant at a lower interest rate. Both parties benefit as the risk for the bank is reduced and the applicant is able to get a more generous loan.

We are completely on the same page. :-) I was thinking about other ways to reduce risk for the banks...I'm wondering if there are some newer business models (e.g. ecommerce, some types of services) that have risks and milestones which are beginning to become more predictable, the way that banks have long understood more traditional businesses like restaurants and coffee shops.

congrats! Love the tools you incorporated to help people along the way and navigate through starting out on their own. It would be great to see how people can set goals and also maybe optional flex loan payback plans. This can help people who may have different kind of start-ups who may shorter or longer timeframe. In addition, giving mentor/coaches a way to also financially support the start-up if they are interested so there's even more incentive for success. Just some ideas!

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:As this challenge is supported by a bank, the panel were delighted to see an idea for financial product innovation!  Funding is undeniably an issue for start-ups but this is even more extreme for young entrepreneurs who also struggle to get good advice and guidance.  The panel were impressed by the combination of lending, online tools and face-to-face supportA good mixture of finance, online stuff and face-to-face support proposed in this concept.WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:The panel were impressed with the thought that has already gone into the features of this loan but are curious to know how you intent to position this product in the market and make young entrepreneurs aware of it?  They also wonder if it might be worth joining forces with the folks behind the DIY! Entrepreneur Loans for Young People concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/diy-entrepreneur-loans-for-young-people/For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine.
oops! http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Awesome! That's great news...time to refine!
Looking forward to seeing what direction things go in!

This is a great concept!  Would the students work directly with the banks, or would there be an intermediary (probably non-profit) organization that would accept the loans and then work with the young clients to train and mentor them?  This concept blends in nicely with Sasha Charlemagne's Lab 21 concept -- this could be the space where people can gather, collaborate, learn, and develop their ideas.

Interesting question...it probably depends upon how large this business would be for the bank: if they see making loans for non-traditional businesses as a growing part of their business then they should develop the competency to coach and increase the chance of success for young entrepreneurs. If it's a small part of the business, then it probably makes more sense for an agency that already has more experience with coaching and development. I love the idea of connecting it to a collaboration space!
Good idea of giving children the opportunity to become business men. This idea is great because it actually simulates entrepreneurship better than any computer program or school activity.

Great mash-up of business tools, Erica! You might like to add links for various sites (like Bootcamp) that you've mentioned so that folks can check them out easily. Tip: to activate links in your post, hit the Update Entry button up there on the right, then follow the instructions here: http://bit.ly/oi_link Looking forward to seeing more of you on OpenIDEO.

training_wheels_redesigning_loans_to_fit.title: ALT/loan: entrepreneurship as an alternative to college

py/tuple: IMPACT & REACH: How much impact and reach do you think this concept could have in helping young people transition into the world of work?
A great deal – something like this would really make a difference
A moderate amount – it’s certainly helpful but probably not a game-changer
Not very much – it’s unlikely to make a significant difference to young people seeking work

FEASIBILITY & RESOURCES: Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible will it be for your community to turn this concept into a reality?  (Hint: when you think about resources, think: people, money, time, technology, infrastructure, partnerships and any other inputs for implementation)
Highly feasible – resources wouldn’t be an issue for my community if we tried to implement this
Moderately feasible – my community could do it if we could get find assistance with some of our resource constraints
Not feasible – it would be almost impossible for my community to implement this concept; it's just too resource-intensive
SUSTAINABILITY & LONGEVITY: Does this concept feel like it could be sustained as a project, business or movement over years rather than just months? Will continue to be relevant in future?
Yes – this concept has enough momentum to stand on its own two feet and remain relevant for years to come
Maybe – it’s not clear how long it would take for this concept to stand on its own feet or how it will continue to be but there’s reason to feel hopeful
No – this concept will have trouble sustaining itself in the long-run and probably won’t be as relevant in years to come
ORIGINALITY: How new or innovative is this idea? Are there many different versions of this concept out there already or is this something more disruptive and unique?
Very original – I’ve not seen anything else quite like it
Fairly original – there are similar things out there but this particular version brings a new element to the table
Unoriginal – there are already too many other concepts out there that are similar to this one
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world
I liked it but preferred others
It didn't get me overly excited

give_a_day.description: Every year schools donate one day, where the students go out and work. They get to pick a business, and ask for a job for the "give a day program" The business gives a sett amount of money, which is given to a charity.
give_a_day.creator: 90af48002c956639f4b9846c442c264a

comments.text: Hi Karen,What a great idea - my company has two days a year that our global offices shut down and volunteer in the community. Service days are great teambuilding and learning experiences, so I'm a big fan of an initiative that has the added benefit of helping kids explore and prepare for a future in the workplace. My question is around how you will pitch this to schools -- while the demand for this sort of program is probably there, how do you take a full day (plus preparation) out of scheduled curriculum? While I'm sure everyone would be in support of the concept in theory, what kind of roadblocks (if any) are you anticipating when actually approaching schools?Best of luck to you!Cheers,Bev

Hi Bev, My inspiration is from the Operation Day's Work here in Norway, where most of the schools are in. But i would like there to me an organization that focuses a more on the work, and experiences, the prep for real life. I would pitch this idea to schools by explaining the ground idea, giving the kids experience and inputs of the work marked. Giving them a realistic view on the "real" world. And hopefully giving them a pointer to their dream job. Inspiring them to work hard. I would also say that the schools are there to prepare the youth for the working life, and what better to prepare them for it, than some hands on experience? The charity part of it, will in addition give the school a good name. When it comes to roadblocks there are probably a lot of schools in the beginning not open for it. Loosing one day or week to this, but when they see the benefits they get at other schools, and feedback from the students, I think a lot of schools will change their minds. Maybe it will take a few years before things really take of. But with good PR, hopefully not to long. Having a plan ready for the schools who choose to do this, would help not making it too much extra work.  The site http://www.odwusa.org/ is for the american part of the organization that inspired me. I see that they could use some more PR and a more hands on, go out there organization base. Getting more people informed and inspired by their good work.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Nice one Karen! I wonder if there could be some kind of curriculum attached to the day, where students could learn more about what it takes to be in that career path  what they need to study, if graduate school is expected, what they can earn, etc. That might help ground some of their experiences in the practical, tangible steps they'd need to take to get there?
Good idea! This could maybe be a part of a school day, research in form of homework, or interview for a rapport. A lot of thing can be done around that one day, which will give the students more.

Great discussion, guys. Karen  be sure to incorporate any feedback & new thoughts that you're keen on into your actual concept post to acknowledge your idea is evolving through these collaborative conversations. Looking forward to seeing where things go!

Cool idea Karen!   Do you have any thoughts on how this could be integrated into a regular school curriculum?  For instance, I like how the ODW does it (from your photo URL), where there is a week of educational activities related to thinking globally.  Perhaps we could do a week of activities related to entrepreneurship and really crack that world open for young students?

Thank you Maegan! Yes, having a week of educational activities would be really good! Since this could be a tradition, something you do every year, perhaps the activities could be different form what year your in. So you get more and more prepared for work life. I think one thing schools should have more of, if learning more about application writhing, making a good resume and how to present yourself good in interviews.
Definitely.  Don't forget learning how to network!

give_a_day.title: Give a day!

emphasize_critical_thinking_skills_.description: The ability to see, think, examine, and discern the world and its attributes is highly underplayed in our education system.
emphasize_critical_thinking_skills_.creator: 48368344a5f9cca1f805fda2daa3ac92

comments.text: A couple of difficult questions that depend to some extent on age and existing language skills.I can agree that teaching critical thinking is essential and Monera's curriculum sounds a great approach.As to the value of memorizing, some is extremely useful, particularly vocabulary, spelling (at least for English speakers), times tables and other simple mental arithmetic. That may sound old fashioned (and it is) but the time spent at a young age is not wasted. Far better to teach some of these things to kids who can learn them far quicker than we adults could, and then not have to look up everything later in life. The important thing is to focus on both useful facts and basic skills including critical thinking. We depend on memory for so many things and the average child has far greater capacity than all the formal education they are likely to receive. With a basic toolkit committed to memory they can then be taught first principles on which to build future understanding.Certainly there is a strong argument for avoiding teaching facts alone in later school years although, if the early learning has been effective, it would be difficult prevent them accumulating whatever is presented to them including experience. In fact many of them will have an appetite for knowledge that exceeds the teachers' capacities.

Here is what is included in our Critical Thinking approach: Logic: At this age we are looking at debate and argument. Logical Fallacies.   We will move to symbolic logic as they get older.  Sudoko provides a good base for binary problems. Formal Grammar.  Diagramming sentences. Once one has the atoms of the sentence can they construct their own with the same structure? History: We follow the timeline from First Man on.  It is really hard to make connections when you present history in a hopscotch way. We also integrate philosophy.  The ways man thought about both their fellow man, their kings and leaders, and the common man really inform the decisions of the day. Does one pursue justice or happiness?
Great provocations Lauralee! Something I was keen to also shine a light on with my Learning By Doing post: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/learning-by-doing/

emphasize_critical_thinking_skills_.title: Emphasize critical thinking skills

we_need_grit.description: Teaching students to be gritty -- to constantly improve and push beyond their plateaus -- will ensure that they become leaders in whatever they end up pursuing.
we_need_grit.creator: 1163c06be906a09dcae5e1d579941c6f

comments.text: Yes.  Grit is where it's at.  Just reading today that generalists have the ability to deal with uncertainty more than specialists.  The future of youth could well be in being pretty good (or really) good at doing many things - but also knowing how to get into the messy stuff..
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

Can you really teach grit, though? Or, can you only provide obstacles to overcome? It doesn't necessarily mean that said obstacles will be taken as the opportunities that they are. Also, children vary in personality and disposition. One size won't fit all.

I don't know if we can "teach" grit so much as provide an environment where grit is rewarded; I think that's the best way to help inculcate any value, and grit is certainly a value rather than a skill. For example, we can have teachers give open-ended, long-term projects with no "right" answer and reward students based on their focus, commitment to the task, and their ability to change when ideas aren't working out. And, of course children are different -- switching to a system that purely rewards grit isn't the solution. We need to be able to accomodate those with different learning styles and abilities. That said, I think that having grit is useful in nearly every field, and Dr. Duckworth's results seem pretty convincing. So why not try to inculcate grit in our students? I may be biased, though :)
Fab video & great provocation, Brett!
Thanks, Meena!

We should stop presenting curricula with ready made answers.  Science is not the art of doing experiments with a predestined end, its the are of asking questions about the world around us. We need educators who understand and love the subjects they teach and are willing to invite students to the conversation.  We need to present failure. Situations that are impossible. Problems that are fundamentally unanswerable, but lead to good discussions. Is a chair actually in the room or does our experience tell us the chair is there?   Watch TED Talks with students and spend time listening to their discussions.Allow them to advocate for different opinions. Bring back civil debate, its okay to disagree but lets teach the logic of supporting a claim. Ever since my kids were 5 our hike have always been parent led in and child guided out.  They had to figure the way back. Try paths, get lost, and over come. Be open to their motivations. My 7 year old wanted to attend a Thermodynamic lecture, we said yes.  It was hard but she wanted to prove herself. Stop closing the doors based on social conventions.

we_need_grit.title: We Need Grit

teens_become_ceos...._of_community_proje.description: Online platform that allows teens to identify, create, staff, and implement  team-based projects that benefit their local communities.
teens_become_ceos...._of_community_proje.creator: cbbd80cf9a9127b46fe13c0e4952cfb7

comments.text: How could we connect funders to projects like these?  Some kind of micro-loan? Or micro-grant?

Interesting question.Given the local nature of the projects, I had envisioned that the fundraising would be done on a local level.  In other words, all of the money for a given project would be donated by community members who had a vested interest in that specific project.However, your suggestion is a great one.  If we could also find a way to connect the teen CEO to people or organizations committed to either the project's broader mission (e.g., increasing the number of skate parks around the UK), or the really big-picture goal (equipping young people with professional skills), that could greatly enhance the reach of each individual project and of the concept itself.
It would be cool to create a baby kickstarter or Donors Choose for these types of projects.  It would be a great place to seed and inspire those who have ideas.

I like that idea, David.  Perhaps the fundraising component of the online platform could be modeled after Kickstarter: the teen CEO could explain, promote, and share her idea, and donors could pledge support on an all-or-nothing basis in which the project must be fully funded before any money changes hands.

I love the idea of a Kickstarter-type thing.  This idea really allows the young person control over the project, which is a fantastic and hands-on way of gaining confidence, experience, and personal agency.  I love where this is going!

Micro-funding, or local community based investors, I think a great way to amplify this effort even for future projects would be build a model of transparency with the way funding takes place. Also what would be interesting is a way to allocate a part of funding to various aspects of the project. For example: x amount of $ have been spent of training, x amount of $ have been spent on purchasing sustainable materials. Having this ownership of money being spent will attract future investors and 'CEOs' as they  can learn how to spent their money and be responsible at the same time. Overall, great idea and can't wait to see how this materializes Andrew. Good luck!

This is such an interesting idea! A thought that comes to my mind is that of youth "buy in". In what ways can your program build trust with the youth in order to keep them invested and motivated? I am a former youth worker/teacher who worked with youth who were "hardest to reach". In the communities I have worked in, youth have been exposed to many empty opportunites...that is "drop in" programs (on-line and in person)that made big promises and ultimately offered little results. When great programs/ideas (like yours) introduce themselves to youth, youth are very skeptical to invest their time because it has been wasted before and they miss out on great opportunities. In light of this potential challenge, perhaps one component of your concept can be aggressive outreach to local employers/HR departments to pay attention to the activity on these websites. A couple of ideas: Can you provide employers/HR departments with incentives to stay abreast of youth websites/causes? Can you partner workplace mentors with youth so they feel supported through the process? Can employers login to the youth's website to participate? Perhaps you can develop an online forum for employers to actually interact with youth. I think if youth feel recognized by employers and can see the tangible effects of their efforts their buy-in and motivation will be boosted and maintained. Again, great idea and I hope you move forward with it!

Terri - your experience provides some great perspective here.  I love the idea of having local employers somehow involved in the process so that the teens can more easily understand the benefits of participating.

This is a really interesting idea, Andrew! I think there's huge potential in providing a strong public forum and some tools to facilitate youth led community projects. Following up on Terri's comment re: creating an avenue for employer recognition of projects and potential mentorship opportunities - I agree that having an adult mentor as a member of each project team could help to motivate the team and hopefully provide some valuable teaching opportunities along the way. It seems as though there might be some interesting collaboration opportunities with concepts like fjr's "Mentoring Wishing Tree" (http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/the-mentoring-wishing-tree/), which could provide a platform for getting interested mentors tapped into relevant projects.

This is very similar to an idea I had- where a website very much like OpenIDEO would be opened at the local level (such as a city, county, or neighborhood) and youth could form teams to address a problem, design solutions, and execute plans with businesses/government officials. The website would allow support, supervision, and feedback (like "applause" and comments) from community members monitoring plans' progress. Social media would be heavily used as well. So... overall, nice idea! I'm glad others like you are on the same design track as me!

Hi Andrew -- I think this is a very cool way to get young people involved in their local community boards from the ground up! It takes the concept of student government to new heights ;-).  Imagine the insight that can be gained from just a few smart, dedicated and mature young individuals who in turn share those insights with their peers.  Finding those young CEOs now, sets a real path of leadership.And, as a growing segment of most city populations, young people deserve greater spaces to be heard, so that they too can share ideas for how societies can better serve their social, academic and professional needs.Again, I'm struck by the fact that around the world, young people can legally vote and join the armed forces/militaries at such young ages, and yet have such few authentic places to heard and counted.
I have another suggestion. Regarding that the younger the people are, the better on ideation, hiring teenagers, or a group of them, to share ideas or or brainstorm may be another business form.
Would these projects be entirely on-line or would there be the expectation that they would be implemented/made real?

Hi David.  The projects themselves would be real.  In the example above, the expectation would be that an actual skate park would be built in Barrow.  The web platform would be used to facilitate the actual projects.
Welcome onboard, Andrew! What a brilliant start on joining the OpenIDEO community.

teens_become_ceos...._of_community_proje.title: Teens become CEOs.... of community projects

comments.text: Provocative thoughts, Lyden!
Agreed Meena - sensible questions for debate from a range of points of view.

before_college_multi_internship_program.creator: 309e174bd32684b3c1d70539c89b78e5

comments.text: For certain, your approach is a better alternative for some people rather than going straight to college. Finding one's passion in life can prove to be an elusive goal for some and by finding out what activities/roles one likes (and consequently does not like) can help people find purpose in their lives.
