experience_bank_or_possibly_cv_lifeline_.description: A digital tool that helps young people 'bank' their experiences in an online 'vault' (which they can view as a timeline) and then retrieve at a later date, already formatted into a CV template specific to their job application.
experience_bank_or_possibly_cv_lifeline_.creator: e5da1c40289d2b5455db5f7ee62e5dd0

comments.text: Hi Lydia,I was wondering if I could elicit some feedback from you for LAB21 I.D. Cards...I was thinking of a way to use the card as a progress tracking tool with benefits for the lab and for its young members...For example, lets say the lab collects profile info related to one's purpose, professional goals, skills gathered, internships, workshops attended, projects completed, etc and then visually reinterpreted that info into something like an "Experience Bank" that could live online.In the end, it wouldn't be a typical resume but rather, a unique experience profile that can be shared, updated, etc on social media sites, therefore elevating a young person's 'professional status' on his or her social media profiles.As young people are so mobile, I see an opportunity to cease that space more effectively...Still in the brainstorming phase of this so let me know if you think its far fetched...

Sasha - I am sorry sorry!  I've been so busy with other elements of this challenge that somehow, I've only just spotted this now.  I really am very sorry for the late reply but are you still working on your Lab21 ID cards?  If so, think this is a great idea and it makes a lot of sense - is it too late for you to incorporate it?  Sincere apologies again - not usually this tardy with replies....Lydia
No worries at all ;-).  I'm not sure that I can update at this point in the challenge but maybe I can loop it into the comments/dialogue...Can we 'seize' that opportunity?
Yeah please do go ahead and loop me into your comments bit - it's a great idea and there are still a few days of evaluation left so it's good to get in any more builds...
I was wrong.  I can update during the evaluation phase.  So I'll do both ;-).  Thanks Lydia!

If I were starting out, this tool would feel very encouraging & empowering to use volunteer & small entrepreneur activities as building blocks to a life-long career.   It might be helpful to have a questionaire to determine the strengths a person might have.  Possibly also recommend additional training or experiences to build on those strengths.

Those are lovely builds Joyce - thanks very much!  Sadly, this idea hasn't made the shortlist but I'm still going to refine it a bit further based on all the feedback I've received because, who knows?  Perhaps it be relevant to a different challenge in future.  Thanks again for sharing your thoughts!

I love this idea! I think it would also spur young people to "think outside the box" when it comes to what skills should be included in a resume.  I wonder if a potential add-on to this app would be a function similar to the "Pin-It" button for Pinterest - a button that would live in their browser that would allow young people to tag/add accomplishments like an online article written for the school newspaper, a piece of their artwork featured on a blog, placement on the dean's list, etc.

Great build Hartley - thanks very much!  Some kind of button that would allow people to 'bank' a particular asset/event/experience in their Experience Bank vault is a great idea which I'll definitely include in any further iteration of the concept.  Thanks again...

Lydia, a cool concept, I've been kicking around a idea that might add a different flavour. I think building this solution through a service (such as facebook/Linkined) is good thinking. The user would be presented with a set of tools, methods to develop a combined experience bank profile & CV/resume (I invision the experience bank working in a similar what the OpenIDEO's Design quotient works - but with more detail & richness, according to the users use of the tool). To add to the concept I suggest that great opportunity lies within the recording of user behavior (& not just a 2D record of experience and history). I keep coming back to that age old idea that if you really want something you can put your head down, work hard & with a bit of luck it'll happen. Typically it's hard to present/sell this hunger for a job beyond appearing excited in an interview or thorough correspondence with the potential employer. Keeping that in mind what if the experience bank was able to show the users journey, show what they tried, what the did, showed their decision making & their course of action(s) - such as previous job interviews & any learning outcomes or directions gained).It would be a powerful indicator to potential employers of the users passion & focus as well as an excellent way to create empathy from the employer regarding the users journey. Additional from the employers perspective it only makes sense to employ someone who shows a focus & a hunger for the job.

On reflection what I propose above is maybe just an additional feature of the concept, that if the user chooses to present their experience bank to tell that story then they would be able to - building upon the concept that a good job application is based upon crafting & customisation your CV/resume to the job you want.

This is a really nice build Fraz - thanks very much!  I like the idea of being able to make your lifeline/bank/vault visible (if you choose to share it) so that employers get a truer understanding of what you've done in the past and when you first became passionate about a particular direction etc.  As you say, I think this could work as a feature within the overall proposition but I hadn't really considered the value of a 'sharable' timeline so thanks for opening up this new possibility!

A lovely idea, and coincidentally I came across a service called Pathbrith who are doing something similar:https://pathbrite.com/They seem to be focussing on the things that people don't traditionally put on CVs but are proud of anyway. A summary from a good Mashable.com article:"Pathbrite is a place online where users can display things theyre proud of, but wouldnt typically include on a traditional resume or Linkedin profile. Depending on what job youre applying for, pictures of big accomplishments such as finishing a marathon, winning an award and pictures of family would show your interests, dedication and skill. Its up to you."And here's the original Mashable article: http://mashable.com/2012/07/02/pathbrite-portfolio/

Sorry Matt - really thought I'd replied to you but it seems I haven't.  Thanks very much for pointing me in the direction of Pathbrite - I feel a bit ashamed for not having come across them before as their offer is clearly very similar.  Thanks for the heads up - I'm going to reflect on the points of difference between their idea and what I'm proposing to see 1) if I have anything unique to add and 2) if I think anyone wants what I'm proposing.Anyway, thanks for the build - much appreciated!
Great idea and one that's multi-media friendly!
Thanks Sam - glad you like it!
Great idea Lydia! I love that this could help people build their CV/resume over time, rather than scrambling to write it when they have a job they want to apply for.

I love this idea - I think it ties into a lot of what video games tie into now, which is a sense of achievement and a record of progression. This way, it makes acting in the real world - jobs, internships, volunteering, etc. - into an instant-gratification system that will improve their future. Well done!

Thanks for your kind comment Sayre - to be honest, I hadn't even thought about adding any gaming elements until I read your comment, but now I could imagine people earning badges like they do on FourSquare, "e.g. Congratulations!  You've banked 5 relevant experiences so have now earned your Journalist badge" etc.  Thanks again for your comment!
Great collaboration & build!

A great build from my colleague Andrea Koerselman yesterday - if this was overlaid onto a social network like Facebook or LinkedIn, perhaps it could work in reverse too?For example, if a young person wanted to apply for a job requiring presentation skills, but they weren't sure what kinds of experiences might help them hone those skills, they could search through the experiences of their friends to see what's been tagged as good for presenting skills.  This might then inspire them to make a presentation in class or take part in a play etc.  It could be used to help young people better understand the relationship between particular experiences and skills development.  Thanks for the build AK!

experience_bank_or_possibly_cv_lifeline_.title: Experience Bank (or possibly CV Lifeline)

the_collective_work_pedia_which_erradica.description: An Internet-based platform that allows for different actors (Schools, Companies, Entrepreneurs, Job seekers, ...) to interact to build knowledge that is useful for each type of actors and provides 'eye-glasses' to the young to move ahead on their way
the_collective_work_pedia_which_erradica.creator: 30e4cf98e79ad6962ff3c26a70309578

comments.text: Great thoughts on unifying various players in the youth employment space, Lluis! Would be great to hear from you and others here about who might take ownership of the platform (funding, hostnig, maintenance, outreach, etc).

To me the goal of the platform should not be so much profit but something close to work-place dynamization / revitalization, and it should certainly be an economically sustainable vehicle. So in this line of thought ownership should be a non-profit organization (something similar to wikipedia). Companies could find that sponsoring the platform would show their compromise with society to create better workplaces and better access to professionals. So private sponsorships could be an interesting line of revenues to sustain the business. Successful entrepreneurs / professionals could also profit from sponsoring the platform (i.e Mark Zuckerberg donation). Governments could contribute to the purpose too.As for the rest of issues, such as hosting, maintenance ... I understand there should be a proper team behind the platform canalizing content, curating it and adapting the platform as it evolves with usage (content generation).

Wonderful! It seems to me this could also be a venue that (re)introduces options that we can overlook because the job-titles are too vague or dismiss because of our preconceptions. Can the role of auditing, for example, include something as far from button-down as people making sure companies are getting value from Twitter or Facebook accounts? Can a video made by a surveyor convey some of the challenges and satisfaction that come from solving an everyday work problem?

Thanks tom! That's it. The platform could very well describe an ordinary day of an 'Online Marketing Responsible' so that someone thinking about taking this direction can have fresh insights on what this role means, what type of skills it requires, tasks typically carried out, and where or how to gain the skills to prepare for such role. The platform would also provide knowledge on challenges and satisfactions of such role, as well as countries where there is a high demand for such type of profile.I am not sure I understand your question referring to Twitter ... could you please provide me with some more context?

The twitter/facebook mentions? It was a sloppy way to suggest that 1st-person narratives about their own jobs could move peoples' ideas away from stereotypes. I've worked for two global management consultancies that had their roots in the accounting world and I used to notice eyes glazing over just *mentioning* Anderson or Ernst&Young. To counter that,  I routinely attempted to suggest people who may be accountants (or auditors) do things that are thoroughly fascinating. Maybe I convinced one or two people.  (BUT) A wikipedia of "reports from the world-of-work" could help a lot of people see career opportunities they might not otherwise consider.

I think you are giving a great example tom. There is typically this barrier created by the branding activity of a company on a market plus informal rumors which does not help at all for recruiting purposes (on both sides). There is a lack of space for professionals to collaborate, build knowledge and share it. Stereotyping is a barrier, and to me it is a result of lack of knowledge / understanding. It is about breaking this glass-barriers, these fish-tanks, through flow of information. There are some trends already in a space that is close to this one, such as the so called 'coopetition', which builds on the collaboration of professionals to be more competitive (breaking boundaries to move ahead faster), playing in the boundary between cooperating while competing. In our case, the collaborative content would also help professionals within the same space in different companies understand better their roles in other companies. How many times have we heard 'I am a management consultant' and yet the type of projects the professional is engaged changes dramatically from one professional to another? Access to info allows for people seeing through better, which allows for the 'market chaos' to organize.I once made a project for the Barcelona townhole, and I had this interesting conversation with the responsible of mobility of the city (this is the person in charge of urban police, transport and so on to ensure everything flows smoothly). Believe me, it can be a nightmare to manage thousands of people wanting to see a FC Football match on a Sunday afternoon on a given time, or millions wanting to see the Pope coming to la Sagrada Familia. One thing he said that I really liked was something like:'In the end, I am responsible for managing the chaos generated ... and you know what? there is sometimes a point in which situations are just too big for us to handle and I have come to understand that all I need to do is to provide information to people and do nothing, and people will then decide what to do ... so it's not really chaos it's entropy because there is some sort of intelligence out there... if you provide the info there is this intelligence that puts things back in order.'So I think the work-pedia is about this. It is about facilitating the info so that it allows for human intelligence to put chaos back in order.

Liuis, I really like your idea about speaking the same language through experiences and learning from one another! From my experience this is a very important point. But I also think that a lot of buzz words are disruptive and unnecessary. Means both sides must be open to change/learn.

Hi Carmen! Thanks for your comment. The idea is that the platform becomes a window of information for those wanting to access the working space ... and there is no better window of information than that coming from other professionals in the space. I think you provide a great point in outlining the need for a flat-hierarchy content platform, in which all type of actors contribute with content equally. If the platform is to be useful for all type of actors, it needs to be flat. An example for this would be entrepreneurs emphasizing that VCs profiles are sometimes 'too financially focus, and perhaps lacking of skills on managing people' ... creating a need for VCs to consider other skills when recruiting ... The platform needs to be useful for all players, otherwise it would not dynamically grow.

Beautiful! I just loved this idea first because it is possible to be made and also because it generates shared value for so many different publics! We are experiencing how such kind os networks do work out and there is so much potential of development. One thing that came to my mind was the idea os building an engaged community. I wonder how we could creat connections among these publics. Do you think it is possible that even with so many different interests we could have a common space where all different publics could look up for one common issue?

Hello Maria, thanks for your comment. I fully agree that we've seen a lot of potential coming out of virtual networks in the last years and we have also seen networks evolve, such as linkedin or facebook finding their way through use and value. I would agree with you that at this point the concept is addressing a wide scope of public and possibly sectors. I understand there should be a proper design process, but in my opinion and as an initial starting point the design of the concept should build on:1) The platform should be open to organize content by contributors as it grows, so that as it is being used it would find the right shape to encompass different areas. For instance, venture capitalist may find a challenge to find balanced teams for their investments, so they would start feeding the platform with their learnings on the teams, typical unbalanced teams failures, typical new requirements difficult to find... while entrepreneurs may start feeding the system with their own experiences ... what they missed, what their experience was with VCs, etc ... so two different 'clouds' of content would be created ... and as content grows the two clouds would meet (VCs content meet Entrepreneurs'; and Entrepreneurs' content meet VCs' content)2) Each professional contributing to the platform is somehow identified and some sort of feedback from the network in terms of usefulness is also published (in order to encourage professionals to participate, to contribute and be recognized by other professionals too). Twitter is a network that is somehow doing so in its own way. Foursquare is somehow doing this too. The work-pedia should have its own way too.3) The platform should allow for contacting/interacting with professionals, but probably should not necessarily build 'virtual relationships'. An extreme of virtual relationship to me would be linkedin (there is normally a bond between members that connect, and even the concept of connection is already there steadily) or facebook (through the 'friend' concept). The work-pedia in my opinion would not focus on the relationship so much but on the content (closer to a wiki-pedia) while allowing for interaction between members. The more interaction requests a member has, the more recognition the system should reward him with.4) I guess there should be a space for 'grey area' content (meaning content that has opposite opinions from different professionals of the same field). An example would be a venture capitalist saying that is not advisable to invest in a start up that has a married couple as entrepreneurs (I've heard opposing views on this)5) I guess geographical distinctions would be necessary too ... companies are today operating globally, but acting locally

the_collective_work_pedia_which_erradica.title: The collective-work-pedia which erradicates miopia

now_is_a_rare_chance_to_do_voluntary_ser.description: Longing to be employed makes you depressed? Please don’t think you’re wasting your time. Participation in voluntary service can be a chance to practice professional skills, open your eyes to new opportunities or even enrich your CV.
now_is_a_rare_chance_to_do_voluntary_ser.creator: 4d4728fc3a9e1cfe61313d35b36f29b3

comments.text: Great thoughts! I wanted to pass on that several non-profits that work with homeless or at-risk youth use volunteering as a springboard for paid jobs. Through even very basic volunteering, people can learn the basics of the working world including showing up on time, working a full day, asking their supervisor questions and for direction, etc. Through volunteering, they get something on their resume and are more prepared to enter the working world. Your idea is based more on how volunteering can support more complex skill and knowledge development but it can also be used for the multitudes that need the most basic skills and knowledge related to the working world.

@David Payne Great thing you pointed out there. Giving young people chances to experience the sense of 'system', just like working in a company, can be gained from voluntary work. The better thing about these experience in voluntary work is that they can ask for other roles to join in. Well, it's rather a case of compulsory work but my husband learnt all the administration & paper work in the army, and the experience helped him to work in office afterwards.

Great idea. I do think this is an often overlooked area, and one I can say from personal experience definitely works. I actually quit my job and spent some time volunteering for Engineers without Borders. When I returned I found everyone was really keen to chat to me about it in interviews and it really helped to portray me as a much more rounded individual... and to get the interviews in the first place.Also, one of the hidden benefits is that work such as this often allows people to take on more responsibility, and manage a broader scope of activities than they would in a more usual corporate environment. A great talking point to simply prove your skills and gain experience of, not only your area of education, but of management and organisation and other things.

Great to know your valuable experience, especilly the fact that it helped your interview. BTW, is there any volunteering opportunities or organizations like 'Engineers without Borders' or 'Doctors without Borders' for designers?

@Minji... I'm afraid I haven't come across any design specific roles, but if you are a more technical designer then I think there are definitely opportunities. EWB works a little differently in every country, but I know that in the UK there are a few more design based roles - such as one with SELCO in India working to design/develop/build tools for local farmers, and the project I did to build and test a motorcycle ambulance service (fabricating + on the spot development + ethnography), but obviously in development work you will need to be able to help take your ideas through to reality. Sorry I can't be of more help.
Leila, Thanks for the information though.

I completely agree with the value of volunteering! In Sweden there is a place called www.volontarbyran.se - where NGO's can post their volonteer needs and volonteers can find relevant positions and orgs where their skills are needed. I think that is a great service that could be replicated globally, and it connects nicely to your idea of more young people finding volonteer opportunities to practice skills and broaden their horizons! :)

I hope more websites like www.volontarbyran.se are present so that it can act like a PORTAL WEBSITE to check out the talents in need. Even there are potential volunteers willing to participate, needed opportunities are scattered with too many NGOs to know them all.

comments.text: Inspiring indeed  great share, Ting-Han!
Thanks Meena!

This is a great idea Ting-Han - that could be extended to higher primary levels too. We have used theme parks to extend children's imagination, teach history, teach about the world (we used to have a great theme park on Antarctica here) but it is the first time I have seen an attempt to relate to current occupations.It is a natural extension of the types of games that children begin to play as they become aware of the wider adult world around them

I agree that theme park is a great way to extend children's imagination ... as well as adult's (for instance, Harry Potter's Theme Park). Theme park + occupation can have great potential if it can sparkle young people's interests and link them to resources to "dive deeper" into an occupation. To let a wider age group benefit from it, we might have to set different goals - For kids, the goal can simply be arising their curiosity. For teenagers, the goal may be showing them the more realistic sides.

While watching the challenge brief's video, these words attracted my attention the most (but I can't figure out where to put it in my post, so I'll mention it here):...Theyre between 5-16 and theyre at school. They can see that their brothers and sisters havent got work, and they ask the question whats the point? And they become unteachable.- Will Hutton (Chair of Big Innovation Centre, Work Foundation)

Very important point to address throughout this challenge.There is a growing need to counteract negative role-models with positive ones.That's where I like the inspiration from the Philippines of "street school" which engages children in their environment as a first step back towards formal education ( http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/international/2012-05-11/philippines-ngo-takes-school-to-the-streets/942528 )In addition to lack of affordability of education and/or ancillary costs there is a stigma with having to send kids to school in last year's uniform or shoes.

Thanks for the link Paul! Compared with formal education, mobile classroom has more flexibility as well as challenges.When I was in university, several of my friends  participated in clubs that reached out to underprivileged children. My friends think it was really rewarding to hear those children mention that they want to continue on with their education and someday encourage other underprivileged children to learn. Most of the club members continued to reach out to those children for 3 to 4 years, and the children not only view them as role models, but also as older brothers and sisters.

the_baushaus_year.creator: 116fee19f83200c3abeba614c26191e9

comments.text: http://www.cheapcoachpurseshandbags36.com

Being part of the generation facing this issue in the U.S., this concept definitely stood out to me. I have many friends that struggled with finding employment and ultimately ended up in a job that they didn't necessarily love but wouldn't have known until giving it a try (and wouldn't leave for fear of returning to unemployment). Having the ability to try a few different fields and gain REAL experience outside of a classroom could help students to find jobs they enjoy and in which they can use their strengths while building a variety of experiences to take forward on a resume. Big fan overall!

This is great!  I think opportunity could also start sooner such as the summers between high school years or during. This way, they can test more areas of interest out earlier. I definitely would have liked a program to exist.

This is one of those local grass roots movements that could really make a difference in the lives of students and communities. A couple comments have already touched on when to offer the program - between highschool years, or after graduation - and I see the real value in this is its scalability. Half a dozen local small business could agree to sponsor half a dozen students for two month terms in their year of job discovery and as more businesses join in, more students could be sponsored. I think you are spot on having the program cooordinated by the local chamber of commerce or highschool (and potentially have larger companies sponsor the initiative).It would be a valuable program for all ages and educations too. I would personally love to take a year of job discovery and be able to test and learn from multiple jobs to build my professional skills and grow a  network of future opportunities.

I see in previous comments on this idea there has been a lot of discussion about when this project should be introduced to students - whether it should be in the summer between High School and University, a gap year before University or integrated into the 1st year of University - and I'd like to share with you a successful and similar programme run in my own High School in New Zealand. During our final year of High School we were encouraged to take part in an optional programme know as "Gateway" in which students were able to take on positions working in local business with mentors. This gave students work experience, coaching from a personal mentor and credits towards graduating. You can read more about this programme here: http://www.ens.org.nz/Business+Support/Young+Enterprise+Scheme+YES/Skills+and+Employment/Working+with+Secondary+Schools/Gateway+Programme.html

wow brilliant program! I like that gateway is integrated into the high school curriculum. that sounds like a really smart idea! did you take the program? could you share your experiences? do you think it was successful, or those around you who took it, were they happy with it? did it change the way they thought about their future job possibilities?thanks for sharing!

I didn't partake in this programme first hand but had a number of close friends who did. One friend in particular was interested in boat building and was placed at a boat builders yard for 2 days a week for three weeks. He discovered during this time that his passion was actually motors rather than boats, and so the school placed him at a mechanics for 2 days a week for the next 3 weeks. While working with the mechanics at this business he made connections and was offered an apprenticeship with them after he completed school, however my friend would not have qualified for this apprenticeship with his current choice of subjects at high school that year. The school allowed him to change subjects mid-year with extra help from some of his teachers to allow him to catch up in these new classes so that he would leave with the right credentials to pursue his apprenticeship. The key to the success of Gateway in New Zealand schools can be attributed to the flexibility and understanding of school and workplace staff involved in the programme. They understand that at 15, 16, 17 years old you probably don't know what profession you want to move into, and that you are probably going to change your mind and try different things to work that out. Programmes such as this need to be /flexible/.
Gotta love those switched-on New Zealanders!

This sounds like perfect timing for me. I see lot's of young people in the UK either dropping out of schooling around these ages or being so uncertain of what path to choose that they either freeze or 'just choose something'.

Great idea Stefan!What do you think about building up a curriculum of internships (e.g. web development, marketing, PR, UI design)? Each one would lay the groundwork for an entry-level spot in one of those fields and give clear metrics for success. The feedback from the metrics could help the youth see what they need to do to improve, and successful completion would be a sort of accreditation for them in trying to get their next internship/job.Plus, having a clear format of expectations and types of projects/roles would reduce the overhead cost of running this program for businesses. (When I've hired interns before there's been a constant question about how to make the experience as useful as possible for them and for the business!)

hey erica, i love the idea of giving feedback. when we have interns for just one to three months we mostly assign them to project managers sometimes they stay on a project and become part of the team, other times they move from project to project every two weeks or so, and also move between departments, so they really see multiple sides of the business.maybe the program could be something like this?

Hi Stefan!I'm a huge fan of this idea! I love the Bauhaus school of thought myself and really like this idea of getting real world hands-on experience before choosing a school for higher education. The cost of higher education can be a lot and the thought of choosing a study without any experience can be daunting for high school students. I was fortunate enough to have interned throughout my undergraduate studies which ultimately helped me land my first job. I think that kind of experience being applied even before going to college will better strengthen a student's decision to get behind a major and not pick one based of what they think they'd like to, but rather choose one from experience.

Congrats! I think there are many benefits in having working professionals and academics help develop a program that is also flexible for people who are in transition to reach their goals for success. This also leverages working professional's experiences in the field and schedules. Presenting work in front of possible employers is a great way to also showcase students' work and lead to opportunities throughout the program's duration. Employers can see student's progress at the same time and get to know them.

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:There were several ideas around job sampling but this one felt more focused on internships and therefore more applicable to people seeking work, rather than those already in employment, which made it the most popular version with the panel.  We also liked the extension of the Bauhaus ideology and the idea of organising these years regionally in some way.WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:The main challenge will be around how to implement this  who runs the scheme and how do partners get involved?  At the end of the year, where do the participants end up and what will they have to show for it?  Would this concept be strengthened by some kind of accreditation?  We'd love to see your ideas for how to make sure this idea has real 'teeth' so that participants end up with more than simply experience...For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine

Hi Stefan! I really like this idea in how it provides young people the opportunity to experience different industries/positions before having to make a decision. In bringing this concept to other countries, I suppose the Bauhaus-Year would have to identify where it would best fit. For example, in Denmark when students moved into high school, they have to pick between mathematics, science or languages and in some way already limit where it is and what type of universities they will be able to apply to afterwards. In this case it would be great to put the program before they have to make that decision. Where as in the US, most universities students start their major as "undeclared" where they use the first year to take different classes in order to discover their area of interest. What if in this case the program was integrated into the first year of university? That way young people will have the opportunity to directly learn from the classroom and the  work environment at once.

Hey Stefan! Sounds like a great idea! I made something similiar, check it out:http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/the-bauhaus-semester-2013-fulfill-your-dream/http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/first-semester-open-doors/

ORIGINALITY: How new or innovative is this idea? Are there many different versions of this concept out there already or is this something more disruptive and unique?

Fairly original – there are similar things out there but this particular version brings a new element to the table
Unoriginal – there are already too many other concepts out there that are similar to this one
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world
I liked it but preferred others
It didn't get me overly excited

comments.text: We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Our developers are busy working on it. Meanwhile, if you're wanting to iterate your ideas, you can use the comments feature to promote further conversation from others. We'll let you know once the bug is fixed, then you can incorporate your refinement moves into your concept post. Let's be agile, together!

Right on! Our development team have been busy fixing the Update Entry bug and we're back on track now. You'll now be able to edit your posts to add all that refinement-goodness to build out your concepts for improved impact. Bring it on, together!

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:Another great concept about financial product innovation with a strong virtual team and a lot of applause from the community. There's clearly an unmet need around funding young entrepreneurs so our challenge supporters were excited to see concepts designed to deal with this gaining so much traction.WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:You might want to consider joining forces with the team behind Training Wheels - Redesigning Loans to Fit young Businesses http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/training-wheels-redesigning-loans-to-fit-young-businesses/ because there are clear similarities in the concepts and the needs they're intended to fulfil...For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Let's raise kids to be entrpreneurs.  http://www.ted.com/talks/cameron_herold_let_s_raise_kids_to_be_entrepreneurs.html
Presume you've seen the startup loan for young people. (UK)http://www.startupbritain.org/loans/

It's very cool to see you take your previous winning concept and build it out even further for this challenge! As a potential build: might there be some sort of curriculum or entrepreneur bootcamp that could help young people not only develop business plans, but also understand the loans they're taking out? I speak from personal experience with student loans: it's not until you start paying it back that you realize the seriousness of what you've taken on! :) So maybe there's a way to help young people really understand this loan before agreeing to it? Just a thought....

Totally agree, Ashley! I've just been talking about this tonight.  I took out the maximum student loan under the thought that 'I will only start paying it back once I'm working' and now pinch myself every time I see how much I'm paying back each month!! Students need to be made aware of what any type of loan means...without discouraging them ;-)

Exactly! I'm so glad that I went to school  and I'm also so glad that my student loan payment gets directly pulled from my bank account every month! Out of sight, out of mind I guess :) Otherwise I get sick thinking about how much I pay every month!

So true! Another aspect of student loans might be useful here too: what about reducing the risk to the bank by giving the money in installments that go to pay particular costs? (i.e. like how students are giving funds semester by semester)

The concept brings to mind Kiva - a crowd funding site. At the moment, it provides loans to enterprising business people in less-developed countries. No reason why something similar cannot be used for young people and students. A place where people can make a pitch for loans. http://www.kiva.org/
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Great idea and think it could potentially be really innovative.  Banks already have specific accounts for young people and students so perhaps eligibility for these loans could be linked to having an account with the bank?  What if a condition of the loan is that you have your main checking/current account with that bank during the time you make your repayments?  Yes, this 'locks you in' but it also reduces the risk for the bank because they'd be managing more of your money and that might enable them to offer a better rate than to non-customers...If they really wanted to be innovative, they could credit score you differently too.  For example, what if your social media activity was a proxy for your financial reputation, rather than your credit card use or mobile phone contract?  What if you could take out loans as groups of entrepreneurs rather than individuals to help pool the risk?  What if you could get a better deal somehow if your parents were with the same bank and could somehow securitize your borrowing with some of their assets?  I'm sure there's all kinds of clever stuff a bank could do if it decided to take the risk and innovate.  If they don't, the likes of Kickstarter surely will ;-)

Cool idea. I especially like the idea that youth have value to offer to traditional companies just because they are part of the next generation (the example with bringing social media skills to banks). I think it is key that youth also realize that they have this kind of value and learn how they can use it to find sources of income

I thought about German "Mittelstand" today and discussed with friends about the financing. Local banks who know the business very well give credits to these entrepreneurs. Since in times of crisis it gets harder to get a credit, a specialized financial product should support entrepreneurs in their staring phase but also support profitable growth.Another financial product, which can used as inspiration are microcredits. There group lending is used as concept to secure the credits. Im curious, how this concept will evolve.

py/tuple: IMPACT & REACH: How much impact and reach do you think this concept could have in helping young people transition into the world of work?
A great deal – something like this would really make a difference
A moderate amount – it’s certainly helpful but probably not a game-changer
Not very much – it’s unlikely to make a significant difference to young people seeking work

FEASIBILITY & RESOURCES: Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible will it be for your community to turn this concept into a reality?  (Hint: when you think about resources, think: people, money, time, technology, infrastructure, partnerships and any other inputs for implementation)
Highly feasible – resources wouldn’t be an issue for my community if we tried to implement this
Moderately feasible – my community could do it if we could get find assistance with some of our resource constraints
Not feasible – it would be almost impossible for my community to implement this concept; it's just too resource-intensive
SUSTAINABILITY & LONGEVITY: Does this concept feel like it could be sustained as a project, business or movement over years rather than just months? Will continue to be relevant in future?
Yes – this concept has enough momentum to stand on its own two feet and remain relevant for years to come
Maybe – it’s not clear how long it would take for this concept to stand on its own feet or how it will continue to be but there’s reason to feel hopeful
No – this concept will have trouble sustaining itself in the long-run and probably won’t be as relevant in years to come
ORIGINALITY: How new or innovative is this idea? Are there many different versions of this concept out there already or is this something more disruptive and unique?
Very original – I’ve not seen anything else quite like it
Fairly original – there are similar things out there but this particular version brings a new element to the table
Unoriginal – there are already too many other concepts out there that are similar to this one
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world
I liked it but preferred others
It didn't get me overly excited

ken_robinson_schools_kill_creativity.description: Sir Ken Robinson explains in this great TED talk how schools need to do a better job of fostering creativity, even over math and other traditional subjects.
ken_robinson_schools_kill_creativity.creator: d11f9d146ccd45954f9b552f1920726b

comments.text: I love this talk and the RSA animate video. Both are complementary and a great reminder of the issues of our educational system (and some of the reasons why).

Hi ALFor once I'm not entirely in agreement.Certainly I see fostering creativity as very important but I think Robinson is given to over-generalisation and in some ways "sells the kids short". Nevertheless there is value too in raising the subject for discussion.and value in critically appraising educational systems for adaption and improvement.I'll get off my soapbox now!CheersPaul

I've watched this TED talk over and over...thrilled to see it here as a very appropriate inspiration. One of the most interesting points to me was the idea that we're educating children to prepare them for the future, but we have no idea what that future will be like. As for teaching creativity the way we teach literacy and math, I think part of the trouble is that there's no telling what will bring out a child's creativity -- what works for one may not stimulate another, so it's hard to come up with a "curriculum." It could be that merely adding inspiration and exposure to different thinking (such as this exercise we're going through now) would make a difference, but in the jam-packed school day of today's education system, it's hard to explain taking an hour for unstructured discovery when other subjects are taught in a more rigid, straightforward way. How do you teach something that really just needs to be unlocked?

Good point with the creativity. Your right, we cannot teach this, but try, mostly of the time those teachers destroy even big creativity while trying to teach some. Thats not even bad, thats worse, looking at what they aim to. However a curriculum, as you said, is not the right thing, may be a new way of free teaching should be implemented into education? Why not make classes, where pupils can do what the want, as long as it has a target. Some might not believe it, but I would say, the children will be very creative, or even adults will be.

Thanks for sharing this! http://www.edutopia.org/ might be a plattform to learn from to achieve Sir Ken Robinsons Revolution. It has many inspiring videos, tools, discussions about 21st century learning.

This is a really good talk.  And the RSA Animate video is even better >> http://youtu.be/zDZFcDGpL4U.  I think a lot of what his message applies to many workplaces, too.  Oftentimes creativity is not embraced and employees at the bottom of organizations aren't empowered to collaboratively generate new ideas.
His thoughts and ideas remain a cornerstone in any educational discussions

ken_robinson_schools_kill_creativity.title: Ken Robinson: Schools Kill Creativity

youth.description: A multi dimensional training experience that brings together various individuals and bodies that can help young people carve promising futures
youth.creator: 1ca36cc962c17dd262abfabaa734a77c

comments.text: Manjul - excellent concept. Much like Fraz recommended Outward Bound NZ, I suggest tapping into the lessons of the service-learning programs in different universities and communities. Service-Learning is a teaching and learning strategy that integrates meaningful community service with instruction and reflection to enrich the learning experience, teach civic responsibility, and strengthen communities.  Your proposal is similar with the major difference that you are seeking to help youth develop skills and experience they need for long-term success in the world of work, as opposed to community service.

I like this idea, to me it's a sort of highly focused & specific Finishing school for jobs seekers. It's almost like a practical skills based block course. I was reading your concept & I kept thinking about how this echos many features of organisations like Outward bound NZ - http://www.outwardbound.co.nz/It seems to me that there would be different stages & motivations for doing the couse. I feel having motivated participants would be a completely different experience to participants who are simply placed or told to go.  I am fascinated with the opportunities of this concept, it would be a difficult but fun challenge to design a tailored training experience that understands the values of the participants so that the training is focused & framed around participants thinking and values (sighting generation Y values profiling etc - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generation_Ywhich is a busy read but does have good insight to current challenges). I can see this concept having a great connection & possibly a direct connection to Lydia's experiecne bank concept.
Very specific and well thought out.
Manjui, great concept, I like that it has been thought out in a holistic fashion with viability and stakeholders clear. Great work.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Wow Manjul! Lot's to love on your comprehensive thoughts here. Am digging the core themes of Experience, Exposure, Motivation, Mentorship, Communication, Professionalism, Teamwork & Skills.
Hi Meena - thanks. I do think that the problem at hand can only be resolved when all channels affecting a young persons' life are triggered.

youth.title: YOUTH

building_expertise_at_an_early_age.description: Learning should not occur in silos, and attention to detail across long, multi-dimensional projects is critical to the working world. In schools, students should be given year-long projects that they study using lenses from multiple disciplines.
building_expertise_at_an_early_age.creator: 008830cef02eaeb80ea8390dbae90c49

comments.text: I love this idea of making learning more applied; taking classical skills and honing them on a real world problem leading to actions and recommendations.  There is a continual debate about how we have to "teach kids about jobs that don't exist yet" and this concept puts a focus on analytical, creative, self-motivated, problem-solving skills rather than subject knowledge which should be highly valuable in the workplace.  I see this as helping young people develop soft skills too: working as a team, understanding their leadership style and dealing with obstacles and set-backs.  Is there a way to partner with businesses and charities to set and/or judge the projects?  They would love to engage local young people and get a fresh perspective on their current dilemmas as well as young people benefiting from coaching and senior experience.  Just a thought.  Congratulations on a great idea!

That is a great idea- the organizations that the students work with should give feedback and judge the projects- it would be a good community-building opportunity to bring in the larger community- with leaders in their respective fields- to judge the project as well! Thanks for the feedback and suggestion!

I really love this concept because it's very close to my heart. I graduated last year from a "deep diving" degree in Cultural and Communication Studies - a program that I thoroughly appreciated for the exact reasons that you named. what I missed though was a more focused, pragmatic and socially-oriented edge to what I learned. I wanted to take all the theories and put them into action, not just talk about them in isolated academic circles.One example that immediately comes to mind though is San Francisco's BrightWorks school: http://sfbrightworks.org
Thank you for the feedback- definitely agree that the most learning occurs when insights and theory are applied to real-life action. I'll check out BrightWorks!

This is a terrific idea! It makes me think of the "T-shaped" person that IDEO's Tim Brown discusses here: http://chiefexecutive.net/ideo-ceo-tim-brown-t-shaped-stars-the-backbone-of-ideoaes-collaborative-cultureThe typical school-model tends to focus solely on carving the facet of knowledge acquisition and (at it's best) knowledge discovery. More facets are needed, especially in: character, resilience, initiative, deep-thinking, independant-thinking, collaboration, and contribution...This concept gives agency to students to discover and think independently of teacher expectations and the typical curriculum "right-answers."
Thanks for the feedback- I'll watch that video by Tim Brown! Agreed that the facets you mention are in critical need- if you have any ideas toward implementation, would love to hear.

Hi Guys - I saw a bit of discussion about the value of team projects vs. individual projects.  I'll admit, I see the value of the individual projects, but I'm biased toward team-based learning.  What can I say, I'm an MBA student.Anyway...  Would it be possible to split the year in two, with one semester devoted to an individual project, one semester devoted to a team project?  Perhaps the two projects could even be (loosely?) related.I think you could split the year in two without losing the importance of the deep dive.  I'd love to hear your thoughts.  I think I could either way...

Hi Steve- thanks for your note, and suggestion! Splitting the year in two is definitely a good suggestion for getting around the individual/team project debate. I think this would be more powerful if the two projects were interrelated somehow. Maybe all students, in their individual projects, studied some issue related to economic development. In their "group" semester, they could collaborate, having built expertise from their individual projects, and build and test a pilot program addressing the larger issue. What do you think? I think this gets to the larger topic of the importance of teaching- at a young age- the skills to actively test and develop solutions to large and complex problems. A group of highly-committed people is what will change the world's future for the better- it would be great to teach these skills at a young age! Would love to hear what other insights/best practices we could incorporate from your MBA program, and what has been the most valuable to you in this program!

Hi Chelsea,I think your example for a project on economic development is right on.  I've been thinking about this concept over the weekend and I've become more and more convinced that I would have loved it as a kid.  My most memorable K-12 project was in the 4th grade.  It was called "Galleon."  We spent four months as the captain of a ship sailing from Spain to the New World.  Each day we would spend an hour solving problems and making decisions that would effect our progress.  We learned about maritime history and developed team work, strategy, and problem solving skills along the way.I love your idea because it takes this concept to the next level.  I'm really excited to see what you can do with this!
Awesome- I definitely have the same memories from similar projects as a kid :)Do you mind if I list you as a Virtual Team Member?
That would be great!  Thanks, so much!

I definitely think this is an interesting idea. Project based learning allows for simultaneous development of very different types of problem solving skills, and of course, application of knowledge to an actual problem promotes much better understanding of critical concepts.What might be worth refining is what kinds of projects are best. The challenge for today is not that we don't have smart people but we don't have as many inter-disciplinary experts. The big problems of today are all cross-sector problems, and require integrating knowledge from many different fields. Unfortunately, most people's educational path is based on the paradigm of narrow specialization, even at the graduate level. You mention topics such as global warming and poverty. Hopefully the projects that are designed will convey exactly how complex these problems are.... poverty does not just have "economic" solutions and climate change does not just have "technological" solutions!The core of the solution you propose lies in the "early age" exposure to such projects. Since many types of complex and integrative thinking are established earlier in life, your idea can help create future generations that grow up to be complex, multidimensional thinkers!

Hi Sobhil, thank you for your note! I completely agree that project-based learning does develop- at an early stage- the multi-disciplinary thinkers that our generation needs. I also agree that the size of the topic is definitely critical- global warming is no small task to address. However, the benefit of having students study huge topics like this is their hands-on education of how to approach these  huge topics, break them into more manageable pieces, and recommend/research targeted solutions and design specific methods of measurement. What is your recommendation to allow students to both study huge topics (like poverty), yet structure them so that they can be broken into manageable parts and scaled down to a size that students can actually propose and test pilot projects? Would be very interested to hear your thoughts! Thanks again for the great feedback and nsight into this concept!
Apologies- I meant to write Sobhi**! Apologies- thanks again for the note!

I am not sure if it would be feasible for every student to create an actual pilot for every issue of interest. That is thousands of pilots!! But maybe one could operate on an apprenticeship model? Say a school matches a student's problem of choice to an organization working on that problem. The student works with that organization, or does a comparative project where 2 or more organizations are compared on one or two factors. After 6 months - 1 year of apprenticeship, the student could suggest some specific changes that could be incorporated into just a small part of the organization's work.... just one small change. The student then also evaluates the outcome. If it works, then the student can help the organization expand that solution to a slightly larger scale etc. We have apprenticeship-based education in a few different countries, but they're always in the industrial sector not in the social sector. Do you think this sounds viable?

But you know what, just a lot of group discussions and 'thought experiments' can work really well too. When I taught public policy to college freshmen, it was amazing how much even a classroom debate impacted their thinking! Things like questioning your assumptions, questioning the validity of your information sources and trying to build arguments for what you think is the solution... these are not skills everyone is taught unfortunately, and I've seen students respond really well to this type of interactive, debate-based learning. Especially for complex issues that are not black or white.

I definitely love the idea of the apprenticeship model- and this would really be great to help students build relationships for potential future employment! Great idea- students would get to work in the community, identify changes to help their host organizations improve/grow/etc, and also make key connections in their industry/area of expertise.

I will definitely work that aspect into the final version of this concept- thanks so much for this suggestion! Agreed that group discussions and 'thought experiments' are also a valuable learning tool- would be interesting to take students' real-world experiences in their apprenticeship and work them into a larger class where they could present their individual projects and hear their peers' feedback and suggestions, coming from their own growing area of expertise!
Good luck with refining your idea!

Great discussion guys! Chelsea  if you'd like to acknowledge Sobhi's input you have the option to add him to your Virtual Team. Just hit the Update Entry button up there on the right of your post & scroll down to the Virtual Team area. We dig folks who design better, together!
Sounds great! I'll be sure to do that. Thanks!

Really dig this idea.  Project-based learning offers a different method than a lecture/test-taking approach, but it also offers a different way of measuring success.  Different students are going to excel at a long-term project than excel at test-taking or paper writing. To me, the tangibility of the result is what's so exciting:  to actually see yourself solving a problem is immensely empowering.As you imply below, I think the key next steps involve age appropriateness.  Would there be collaboration between students?  What is the instructor guidance going to look like?  Giving the student the choice of problem at the beginning of the year is no guarantee of sustaining their attention - I worry about young students feeling lost without a guiding hand (as happens to so many PhD students).  Collaboration with other students offers so much in terms of socialization, working with others, and dealing with mistakes, but can lead to free rider and collective action problems.  Students will need help managing the scope of the projects.I would really love to see this type of project be piloted out there.

Thank you for the great comment! I totally agree- I think longer-term projects bring out an entirely different skill set than do more commonly-practiced education methods, such as test-taking. I am also a firm believer that sustained perseverance in the direction of an established goal lays the groundwork for success, which longer-term projects can help build students' grit and determination in the face of potential roadblocks or challenges during the project. I see your point about the tension between group and individual projects (we have all encountered the brilliant Ph.D without much practice in building/leading teams). I think both need to be integrated to create a successful program. The real question is how? Would love your feedback on this. One idea is to have each student self-drive their individual projects, but collaborate on reviews, critiques, ideation, etc. I also completely agree that students will need a guiding hand- more in the younger years, less (but still present) in older years. Similar to honors/masters thesis, it would be good to have a dedicate class/curriculum to these projects. However, seeing that the education policy world is very rigid, these longer-term projects might be interwoven into existing class structures (such as taking 15 minutes at the end of every topical class to apply/work on individual's thesis/project). Again, would be interested to hear your thoughts. Thank you for your great insight- I would have loved a program like this in elementary (late), middle, and high school, and would also be interested to see how a pilot would do!

How about something like the following (I have in mind the high school age range):Each student has a unique project that they alone are responsible for, but they are also paired up with another student to bounce ideas off of and give detailed suggestions to.  Perhaps once a month, all of the students participating in the program (15-20, say), meet, along with an instructor, where students can demonstrate the progress they've made, perhaps at some point give presentations or make pitches if it's a business-like idea, etc.  I'm just trying to get the benefit of the feedback of others while maintaining the individuality and responsibility that each student feels for his or her own project.  In between these meeting, I think the instructor should be available to answer questions (and potentially address any issues that arise between project buddies).My instinct is that a 15-minutes-for-working-on-your-projects approach in the modern classroom is going to lead to not a lot of progress being made.  For me, fifteen minutes of independent study always turned into fifteen minutes of play time and socializing. : )  I definitely hear your concern about implementing any project-based program into the modern curriculum, though.  I feel like at least some time is going to have to be blocked off.  Not sure what the latest research is re: block scheduling, but I know a lot of schools have moved to having longer class periods with the idea that students are better able to focus.  Wish I had some better ideas.  If I come up with something, I'll let you know.Another consideration is interim goals.  It can be difficult for students to measure how much progress they're actually making, especially for those on the younger side of the spectrum (but even for college kids).  I think meeting monthly goals (or something along those lines) could keep a cohort on pace.What about some sort of event that opens the year, before people have chosen their projects, that helps them get inspired and decide what they want to do?  Another idea might be to have students get a preview of what it's like the year before they enter into the program.  So, for example, if you start in fifth grade, have fourth graders shadow fifth graders or come to some of the meetings to prep them to come up with their own ideas.One of the advantages of targeting kids early on, is that by the time they graduate from highschool they might have done a whole host of diverse projects touching on all sorts of different disciplines (law, engineering, education, business, medicine, etc.).  The more that students get a feel for what, say, a research doctor actually does, or an engineer, or a designer, the better career decisions they can make.

Hi Chelsea,Couldn't agree more. The (so called) soft skills trump the 'hard' skills every time! Once had a chat with Karan Bilimoria about this once and he came out with a brilliant quote: "I hire for will. not skill". Obviously there are limits to this - e.g. I wouldn't want to be operated on by a very keen, but unqualified, surgeon(!) - but I love the concept that if you have the will (and the 'soft' skills) there is nothing stopping you learning whatever 'hard' skills are required!The title of your concept also rings very true. Do you know Brenda Bigland?http://www.bitc.org.uk/about_bitc/leadership_at_bitc/leadership_teams/education_leadership_team/brenda_bigland.htmlShe's the poster child of the idea that it is never too early to start equipping young people with so called 'adult' skills, and she's proved it by the amazing things she's done at the primary school she leads. I've only met her once, at a conference a couple of years ago, but her thinking made a big impact on me.Good luck,Carole

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:Another concept that's proved popular with the community, the panel admired the ambition to recalibrate the school curriculum to give a greater focus on depth of exploration and problem solving.  This concept won support because it seeks to redesign educational policy which is ambitious but almost certainly a core element of solving this challenge.WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:What does a PhD for school-age students look like?  The panel would love to see this idea developed with support from educationalists and policy-makers to ensure it's both feasible, scalable and can be accredited fairly.For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine

Thank you for the note- I am working on pulling together supporting research, and will be submitting this in the next few days! One question- should I add this supporting information to the original concept, or should I just include this in the comments section below? Thank you for the clarification.
Hey there Chelsea  add your builds direct to the concept post so that folks will be able to easily grasp the full picture when they come to evauation. Looking forward to seeing what you come up with!

It makes sense to model a failing or troubled education systems after the best ones (such as Finland). Moreover, I think an approach where students are able to be passionate about learning and problem solving will lead to building an expertise at an earlier age.The issue, at least in the U.S., is that there are at least 50 different standards for education across the country in addition to Federal law (think No Child Left Behind Act signed in to law in 2002).But to comment more specifically on your great idea, is that it would be good to pool data, information, and knowledge gained from each "experiment" and have next year's class build upon it.One question: by "early age" do you mean high school? If not, then what age?

Thank you for your great comment! I think by early age, students can begin a deep-diveo certain topics as early as the 5th grade (we did this in my school, and to this day I can still remember what I learned). However, what is important is both what students are learning AND the process/method of building expertise, developing a project to maturity, and be able to know enough about a certain topic to begin to apply it to potentially diverse concepts (for example, knowing enough about cars will naturally lead into learning mathematical concepts, engineering, design, etc). I do think this process can start as early as the 5th grade, and continue through high school. I like your idea of pooling data and information gained from each class and having further years build upon it... however, I also think students should be able to pick any topic they are interested in, to begin a "deep-dive," much like a honors thesis or Masters degree. Thank you again for the comment! Would appreciate any feedback that you might have.

building_expertise_at_an_early_age.title: Building Expertise at an Early Age

comments.text: I believe the introduction of this methodology within schools will provide the tools and experience for students to answer, for themselves, the very question that is driving this challenge.There are other design organisations pursuing similar objectives:http://designtoimprovelife.dk/education/

During my times at high school there were topics like books to read, where some teachers involved us in the selection of the books. Afterwards the motivation during class was much higher. Since central exams for all schools got introduced in order to provide more comparability this flexibility is very limited now. But what about creating an extra curricular activity where design-thinking gets taught?

There was a teachers one.  We worked from the NGO one.  ;)  One thing I noticed in the case studies it that it was adults using the framework to make decisions for children.  Has anyone turned it over to a team comprised of children, teachers, and parents who used design thinking to solve school problems?
Did that kind of thing ever happen at your daughter's Model School?

I did not try to introduce it at Garehime.  At Garehime students can run their own business or they could be part of class corporations. In the class run business there were many aspects of collaborative team work that did happen. Some teachers were really great at letting the students innovate products and other teachers were more set in their ways.  Teachers needed more hands on experience with business decision making and design thinking.  The other possibility could have been having more mentors available to students. This would free the teachers up for doing classroom work and allowed students to have a different perspective on projects.  I helped do the branding work at Garehime and it was the first time many of them had been through a creative process.  That did help expose the administration, teachers, and parent stakeholders to more design thinking, If we had more time we could have tried to integrate more.  One issue is in our district there are a lot of time constraints on schools that are hurdles to real growth and learning.

design_thinking_for_educators.title: Design Thinking for Educators

comments.text: So one thought is to add onto/expand this by looking at what the military does. They are focused on constant situation based training iterations (basically, role-play) that involve setting training goals beforehand and conducting an after-action review  (AAR) afterwards. This provides the forum for focusing on improving an individual soldier's and the team's  response to a situation in the future. I'm sure there are better resources out there but here is a brief overview of AARs:http://www.armystudyguide.com/content/powerpoint/Training_the_force_presentations/conduct-an-afteraction-re-2.shtml

Great example, thanks David!  It's a great analogue - role-play training iterations and review sessions afterwards to assess, analyze, and improve.  If the military finds this a valuable process for training soldiers for combat, I'm sure it can be adapted to provide value for young people going into workplace environments.  Thanks for the tip.
role-playing is always a good altenative for teaching specially for this new generaton, that works not only on a cognitive way.
Good point!  I'm hoping this will help increase emotional and creative IQ as well.
Joe, I love the case study/role playing idea and have used it myself in teaching. I think of it as experience provided in a controlled, low risk setting.

Absolutely, this can give people a chance to learn and grow over time in a very comfortable setting where failure is acceptable, and even encouraged, as a means to grow both professionally and socially.

how_do_you_find_your_passion_randy_komis.description: Short video clip with great advice for people paralyzed by the question "How do I find my passion?" by Randy Komisar.
how_do_you_find_your_passion_randy_komis.creator: d93ee4ddd87dbf36fcee4149be49a904

comments.text: Another angle on this one is that a tool that may help unemployed three see through and reinforce their way is to meet people on their way that share similar passions, no matter where they come from or what education they have. They may act like a mirror, and may be a powerful tool help 'fill the fuel tank' and give light to a 'next move'.
I loved this one too. Passion is the fuel that makes us move. And it's a requirement to move ahead and make things happen.

"I was passionate about everything."  As a student with many seemingly unrelated interests, I can relate to this video.  It has been difficult for me to decide on a major, let alone to define what my ultimate passion is, because it feels like I'm closing doors on so many other interests.  I like Komisar's idea of keeping many passions alive and being open to unconventional career paths (why limit ourselves to a narrow, predefined idea of our passion), while at the same time being pragmatic about taking action on the opportunities in front of us.  Because we can't make progress without making decisions, taking actions, and learning from whatever happens.

Same. I really identified with what you and Randy said. I don't know what I'm going to end up doing. I'm an engineering major, yet I love history and literature -- which makes some people's heads explode when they find that out. I don't even spend all of my time contemplating math- and science-related issues. Instead, I like reading, thinking about philosophical topics, and learning about design or business on the Internet. I'm undefinable, which is a strength and a weakness because I feel like I'm constantly having to "optimize", as Randy said.Watching that video was liberating, to say the least. Now I'm going to put more of an emphasis on taking action instead of trying to funnel myself down one, conventional path.

I loved this video. Unfortunately, not all people you will encounter will be this open.  I remember one of my first mentors, who I greatly admired, told me that my interests were so scattered that it would be difficult to advance if I did not decide on one path to pursue.  Years later I was, as Mr. Komisar described, paralyzed by what THE path was and felt lost/stagnant.  It took some time to realize that the intangible gains of an indirect career path are sometimes harder to summarize, but no less worthwhile or important. While I have not taken the most 'direct" path in my career, I have found that keeping many passions alive diversified my skill set, allowed me greater variety in job selection, and provided opportunities to satisfy many of my interests instead of just one.

how_do_you_find_your_passion_randy_komis.title: How do you find your passion? (Randy Komisar)

one_click_company.creator: 4f33f60372e6bc655f12fa6964b669da

comments.text: Fun idea. So what does the back-end look like? Who does the work? I know of a model in Sweden where freelancers and start-ups can start doin their work (consulting, selling their product, etc) while billing it through "the Company Company". That way you cut all the hassle and the time to market if you will, you just kick in and start billing :)The actual model behind it is an employer-employee relation. The individual entrepreneur bills customers through the company and get their money as salary after a cut has been taken by the company. Would that be an option? Could it work globally? Interesting indeed!

Thanks for the input. I was thinking that for it to work globally that it would almost have to be a government body running it behind the scenes. Governments would also have a strong incentive to get young people to work versus having to support them.What is your view on government versus the employer-employee relation?I have tried to open a company in Denmark. Even though it is fairly easy there is still a lot of room for improvement. When I opened the company I could find plenty of resources that would advice me how to open a company, but they wouldn't actually do the work (for free). This concept is that the back-end handles all the hazzle, you just need to focus on the product. AND it needs to be a consistent experience wherever you want to setup shop.

one_click_company.title: One-click company

No one else is there to shape your evolution, but oneself; and yet everyone else is there to potentially listen to you and potentially do something about the reason why you may be interacting with them. comments.text: Hi Neha!I'm so glad to find this post here, because from what I understand it's relatively new.I was lucky enough to have the chance to hear VFA Founder, Andrew Yang speak at Launch Fest last month in New Orleans.New Orleans is one of the cities that is also currently experiencing growth and many opportunities for startups and also growing in sectors like health and green construction.It's extremely important for recent grads and businesses to realize that while markets that tend to be magnets for people looking for jobs, (like NY, SF, Chicago, etc.) there is a relatively untapped opportunity and need for professionals in cities that are growing like all those you mentioned in the post and New Orleans.New Orleans is a specially interesting case because the reason that it is providing such an opportunity for growth is largely attributed to the natural disaster it went through in 2005, hurricane Katrina.So, it's highly advisable for people to be on the lookout for places that have been subject to severe financial, or natural crises because they will become hubs for jobs and new businesses.

Glad you liked it, Sarah. I hope and think that the untapped opportunities in New Orleans and similar cities won't remain this way for long. VFA recently posted an article about how new graduates are open to working for a lower pay if the jobs suit their passions. Judging by the kinds of opportunities available in these cities (ones that allow young individuals to make real and significant differences to the community), hopefully this leads to a brain drain reversal!
