susan_cain_the_power_of_introverts.description: In a culture where being social and outgoing are prized above all else, it can be difficult to be an introvert. But, as Susan Cain argues, introverts bring extraordinary talents and abilities to the world, and should be encouraged and celebrated.
susan_cain_the_power_of_introverts.creator: 030e489e35bffc50cfa75de5417d528c

comments.text: I'll tackle your questions:1) I think extroverted people will generally have a leg up on newly available roles, due to their (apparently) better ability to network and make connections.2) One way to change recruiting is to try and center on the ideas that get introverts excited. As an introvert (even though I seem extroverted, I feel like being social drains my energy and alone time restores it), my experience is that introverts aren't introverted around everyone. Around people they really care about or when working on something they enjoy, they open up a lot. For recruiters, then, I think the magic is to find out where the introvert's strengths lie through asking them good questions -- asking what inspires them, for instance. That way, they can find whether the things that really excite the introvert dovetail nicely with the position's/company's mission.  3) As you experienced, having good mentors is key -- for everyone, not just introverts.

extroverts also have a leg up due to being better positioned to sell themselves in an interview..but interviews aren't representative of the work environment, and don't show how someone might perform after becoming familiar with a task and the people around them. how could we augment the interview process to be fairer to those that take longer to come out of their shell?longer interviews/mini-internship? interviewing groups of friends on campus? paying more heed to tutor recommendations or character references? probably the biggest problem though is to convince employers it would be worth the extra effort/cost needed to dig a little deeper - extroverts are low hanging fruit

I think you guys are both spot on -- the 'lessons' here help me understand interactions between all candidates, recruiters and employers -- not just introverts. On the whole, it feels like career-prep education teaches students how to join the masses -- unfortunately, at present, the masses are unemployed. Something here is broken. Maybe a solution lies in creating educational programs to prepare students for emerging industries, new technologies and novel career paths? (Long before the recruiting phase of employment.) This would help alleviate the employer cost burden and empower young adults to solve their own career challenges in non-traditional ways.My own career path has been so defined by one of my Freshman year professors who said "I can say with certainty that when you graduate, many of your jobs will be working on, for, or with technology that doesn't exist yet." He was right.

susan_cain_the_power_of_introverts.title: Susan Cain: The power of introverts

Kirpal - you are right about adding more layers once you have initiated a concept. For now the inspiration is enough and the picture is great.Take a quick look at this concept from the last challenge http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/winning-concepts/connecting-entrepreneurs-and-experts/ (or any of the other concepts from past challenges) to get an idea of the process. Wow this is powerful stuff, I need to work through this to see how it all hangs together...

Hi Kirpal - Ashley pretty well sums it up and the link Meena gave you indicates how concepts might grow out of inspirations - so looking at the benefits of Toiastmaster membership you might look for other inspirations around communication and leadership skills development (both other examples you may know and some suggested by others).. If you look at Priyanka's concept you will see how it addresses the focus questions What kinds of resources will be needed to get this concept off the ground and scale it? andHow will your concept support web entrepreneurship?Each challenge will have different focus questions (which are a good guide to translating inspirations into concepts).We don't yet know the focus questions but the questions you have already asked will stand you in good stead.You have a couple of other advantages on which you can capitalise - given your membership of Toastmasters you have others around you with whom you can collaborate physically (as well as the OpenIDEO community around the world); and since Toastmasters is international you have another community from which to draw and revise ideas.Your concept doesn't have to be presented 'complete' - the process is designed specifically for growing ideas over a few weeks and dont be surprised if your idea spawns others with a slightly different focus.Finally, this challenge is sponsored by Barclays and The Work Foundation both of which , like Toastmasters, have an international view.Looking forward to what emerges from this.

Thats great, ok, so before start jumping ahead, start exploring, see if there is "anything other ideas" you can incorporate, help others do the same, connect the dots... basically the cross pollinator innovation pattern right...http://www.space2lead.com/2012/05/cross-pollinator-innovator.html

By all means start developing your concept(s) now using whatever resources you think are relevant - the focus questions will probably emerge from the challenge brief and missions so re-reading them is appropriate.Again if you look at Priyanka's concept you will see that it is built on a few other inspirations and/or concepts - and that others have built on hers.About the only thing to avoid in developing a concept (and I am happy to be corrected on this) is suggesting simply ploughing funds directly into existing programs/enterprises - on the other hand if you are suggesting innovative additions or adaptations that could make them (more) relevant to the challenge that's fine.The emphasis is on new initiatives.You are spot on with regard to cross-pollination - the more we can share and build on one-an-others ideas the better

comments.text: Interesting concept. I think it is interesting to provide a platform providing information on how / where to build skills by linking it with online courses. You could of course imagine that it could also be linked to face-to-face courses people will take. I'm wondering if there would be a way to recognize learning in practice as for the skills you're looking at practice is essential.

Thanks Anne-Laure! You are right that the core skills require a lot of practice, especially leadership and emotional intelligence. I dont think its possible to learn leadership without practice.People taking related courses can be awarded points and credit by the course instructor. my I can have a instructors section, which will enable them to award points. However, they must affiliated with a known institute. Project based learning (PBL) courses will be offered greater points or credit than pure theoretical courses. Moreover PBL courses can have an option for the instructors to provide a reference for student..outlining the skills the student may have learned. Similarly internships and work experiences can be awarded. Does that answer your query?
Thanks Waris. I think it's great if you can include this in your platform. It might make things a bit more complex to implement but it will clearly make it a much more valuable tool.
Thanks a lot for the feedback.

Great visualisations, Waris! I'm keen to know how potential employers will engage in a young person's my I profile? Will the young person send it to them when they are applying for work or do you imagine something else. I wonder if there might also be an opportunity around collaborating with folks like LinkedIn so that you could add a snippet from your My I profile to one's profile there? Looking forward to comments and builds from others on your great idea!

Thanks Meena. Young people can post the link to their my I profile on their CV and their application. Most of the jobs applications today do ask the applicant to provide links to their blogs, websites or twitter profile ( if they have one). It is quite similar to how IDEO asks potential applicants to post the link of their OpenIDEO profile. Yes you are right that my I can be integrated with platforms such as Linkedin, Coursera, Udemy and other similar platforms. Even universities can grant credits to students on their my I profile.This can be done in form of a plugin. Thats how I imagine it to be. A universal skill management platform that eases the entire process of building skills and get recognised for it. Linkedin's current skills section can somewhat be inaccurate (Young people may find it tempting to exaggerate).  my I can act as a virtual replacement that will be accurate ; live and interactive; and accredited.

As for the engagement bit I have added a crude mockup of what the platform will look like and how one can browse a my I profile. However, I intend to be more interactive than it currently appears to be.

For folks who don't know about the notion of a T-shaped person here's a low down: http://chiefexecutive.net/ideo-ceo-tim-brown-t-shaped-stars-the-backbone-of-ideoaes-collaborative-culture (Waris  you might think about adding that link or something similar to your post to help people who don't know this term?)

the_uninternship.description: Job sampling through an online library of reality video profiles of actual job roles.
the_uninternship.creator: c9e55fc0be18bed4a9c695a6d8ac2840

comments.text: Thanks for providing an update on this concept, and for making it a reality. It's needed on several levels. All the best!Suzanne

Hi Vishal,  Just to let you know, I will be introducing 'The Uninternship - Remixed!' to our panel of judges this afternoon!  I'm really excited to be introducing your concept because it's one of my personal favourites, so I'll do my best to represent it well, especially given all the nuance and iterations you've packed into it!  We'll be announcing our winners next week but, if you're one of them, we'll be in touch beforehand to let you know.  In the meantime, I wish you luck and I'll do my very best to present your concept in the best possible light!Best wishes,Lydia

Big thank you for this afternoon. It's good to know that you're introducing the concept and that it's happening this afternoon. Wish I could watch it happen. Just in case there's confusion about the name with the judges, I added the 'Remixed' part to the name of the concept when I updated it in the refinement stage to indicate it was updated.
Hi Lydia, is it possible to get feedback on what the judges said about the concept e.g. strengths and weaknesses.
Very cool - I hope to see this move forward into actual production!

Thanks. It would be great to see this become real. It is unbelievable how much knowledge has been collected on this openideo platform in all the inspirations and concepts posted for this challange.  This shows  how powerful the community here is and useful the community could be to move this concept to the next step.

I love this idea!The psychometric analysis function is what makes it work I reckon. It's basically internet dating for youngsters and future jobs.When I was at that stage of life my view of what future jobs were both available and attainable was rather narrow. Perhaps I had poor careers advisers, and perhaps the focus was too academic, but I think that something that aligns young people to jobs based on the things that they truly love, rather than the school subjects they do well at is wonderful thinking.
Thanks for the feedback Mike. I'm glad you like this function, I think it makes the job search a lot more effective.

Hi, VishalIt's a great idea. I've developed this kind of user-generated-content (UGC) website before. A great challenge of UGC website is that as it is a multi-sided platform. It's hard to find a balance between two groups of audience you serve, the content contributors and content viewers.  I'd like to know more about: 1. Who will be targeted contributors? What are their incentives to videotape their internship experience? 2. What will be the methods to get the first batch of content to make it sufficient and rich enough to attract users? 3. How to avoid biased opinions due to sampling problems? 4. Whether the content is time sensitive as job features and benefit can be varied with economic up and downs? Best,Maggie

Hi Maggie. Great questions on issues that do need thinking about if the concept is to move forward to realisation. This is my attempt at answering them - hopefully you and the community can correct me where I'm wrong and suggest better alternatives. 1. Targeted contributors and incentives: -We will provide the videos by acquiring existing databases. -Mentors who naturally enjoy helping young people find their way in life will contribute podcasts and images of their jobs from their viewpoints. They will also provide comments on videos and answer questions that are posted to a particular career. They will earn contribution points like this openideo website. Podcasts will display number or views, applauses and comments. Contributing comments earns points and more points can be awarded when comments are applauded. - Young people. The decisions they make on liking careers will feedback into the career matching system for future users. They will post questions on careers that interest them and they require clarification on certain issues. They may invite their friends to have a look at the website or ask their parents to contribute as a mentor.- Companies would post their internship opportunities. The company and young person both benefit from this. Perhaps this could be connected to a large source of mentors or vice versa (the mentor requesting their company to post an internship).2. The content consists of videos, podcasts, images, comments, career matching and internship opportunities. Videos and preliminary career matching (unrefined by users) would be acquired from existing databases as mentioned earlier. Podcasts and images would have to come from e.g. setting a recording booth at a careers fair in a university and getting company representatives to make a recording in which they would answer a few questions. Then encourage them to add images and internship opportunities to their profiles which have been set-up for them on the website.3. Hopefully if there is a bias video then comments would identify the particular areas that need to be looked into. If this question is referring to the career matching system...let me know your thoughts!4. . I think as an information source to show young people what's out there, following economic ups and downs maybe going too far. Job features will change with time, but the things that make them attractive to certain people will not change so rapidly. I think it's more about finding an area your passionate about as oppose to an exact profession.

Vishal, great job on refining your concept! I agree with using psychometric analysis to match users with career videos. In addition, users can subscribe to careers that they are interested and/or follow their dream companies online. This can keep the users looking and exploring potential careers actively while being fed "optimal match ups."

What do you think about the change to the source of the career videos from being self-made by mentors (or companies or industry associations as suggested below) to acquiring existing databases of videos? Do you think the barriers to making quality self-made videos can be overcome (considering scale)? I'm aware that perhaps some of the benefits of self-made videos may be lost but on the other hand they would be pretty difficult for mentors to make if they are to contain enough content to describe various aspects of a career/job role and edited to make them concise and good quality. Maybe the benefits of self-made videos can be captured in other ways by having podcasts made by mentors (suggested by Nnenna O) in addition to the career videos from existing databases.

Although the career videos on www.gadball.com provide a comprehensive selection, I think these existing videos are outdated. It appears that many of the videos were recorded in the 90's, and by acquiring these existing database can have some significant downfalls:-the videos do not reflect the proper work environment-the daily tasks and/or procedures associated with the job can be different-young users can feel disconnected from the jobs in the video; cannot relate to the older technology or ways-the commentary and visuals did not create a personal or meaningful video. The voice over sounded like a robot, and the clip had a lot of generic/common visuals (e.g. calculator, desk, cubicles)I would like to see videos that show the current state of jobs. This include the technology used, work environment, and completed projects. This type of personal videos will add more value to career discovery.I do like the idea of podcasts, if videos are too time consuming to create. I think hearing a person talk about his/her work will make users feel connected (one-on-one relationship) to the topic and mentor, therefore, they would want to continue learning more about the job.

This is great. You've really pinpointed the benefits of self-made videos. I think it's worth re-addressing some of the difficulties of making videos and see there are ways to make it easier or alternatives that would have an equivalent benefit.

I know using a flip-camera improves the quality of videos, and minimizes the editing time. Although people may not want to spend money on it. Ideally, if a company purchases a communal flip-camera, then all employees can put up videos to support the career option and/or company. Advertisement for a company or industry is a valuable benefit. Unfortunately if people are still having a hard time editing the videos, then the only way is to bring on technical support to refine the raw videos uploaded on a daily basis. This would add to extra costs.The podcast alternative can also include pictures. I think visuals of the work place and projects will give a good sense of what the job is like.

Check out the update on how the concept will help navigate users to careers they might like based on a system that matches psychometric information to careers and every user strengthens the capability of matching system! Also check out the website mock-up!
The Uninternship has been remixed following great feedback from the community.
Great updates! Loving the visualisation.

This kind of inventory would be a great tool. The only concern I would have would be related to transparency. Since they are videos, the identity of the person would be very public and that could affect how transparent they may want to be about less favorable aspects of the role. This is particularly important for professionals still active in the job and/or industry. Another observation is that the typical roles that may be described in a job announcement sometimes change substantially once the job begins for various reasons. In the end, perhaps this would work better, and perhaps elicit more candid feedback, as a podcast inventory (with people on a first name basis) versus being video-based?

Right on! Our development team have been busy fixing the Update Entry bug and we're back on track now. You'll now be able to edit your posts to add all that refinement-goodness to build out your concepts for improved impact. Bring it on, together!

Hi Vishal, I really like your concept. It allows everyone to get an insight and a better understanding of a job. I found it always difficult to find short term internships, which I could fit in between two university terms. I think your platform also helps to get a first contact and insight. To contribute to a companys success - long term internships are a great thing. And your concept would help to narrow the possibilities down and make a first pre-selection.

Thanks Sabine. It's key to get that first contact and insight early on....when your a young person....so you can narrow down what careers interest you and target your efforts over the next few years towards building the right skills, experiences and qualifications. This will also help target the effort that goes into finding and completing internships - you can use your time wisely and test the careers that interested you from the videos.

Hi Vishal, there was just a thought coming to my mind, Id like to share with you. Do you also consider cooperations with companies? They could produce videos with their workers as job descriptions. You could have two views on the job then - the one of the company and the one from the volunteers / mentors. Im curious about your thoughts on that.

Different views of job role would be useful - great suggestion. If companies also contributed the number of videos would be higher for young people to inform themselves. I fear companies may glorify job roles and use the videos for marketing as oppose to the volunteers giving a more honest and real account. What do you think of that possibility? Perhaps measures can be put in place that allow companies to post videos that follow the ethos of the online library. Maybe an incentive for them could be to attach information about internships that they desire young people to do.

Great thoughts. I agree, that companies may glorify job roles. Since there is ideally also a video by a volunteer, young people get two sides of one job. That can be very interesting. The benefit to link internships to the videos would be a great benefit. Then interested young people can get their own picture of the job - and upload a video as volunteer as well.

I wonder if by working with industry associations as opposed to companies a more balanced representation of the role could be created. Also, the quality of the job is really a question of subjective fit so perhaps the videos could address psychometric "fits". Eg. You will love this job if you ...

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:The panel were impressed by this concept not only because it deals with the challenge of helping young people really understand what certain roles/jobs/careers are all about but because it's highly scaleable.  As a resource, it has the potential to grow and grow and makes this information accessible to a far wider audience than a single internship programme ever could.  WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:The comments show this concept has already been refined quite a bit but we'd love to see those builds included in the refinement stage, plus there were a number of other (very similar ideas) that deserve an honourable mention and could perhaps be incorporated into this concept in order to flesh it out even further...For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine

One way to flesh it out is to identify how quality videos will be produced. One idea is to get in touch with the film/media departments at universities. They have the equipment, skills, willing students, and (hopefully) relationships with friendly employers who will be happy for them to come in and film "a day in the life of" type documentaries. Good luckCarole

what_do_young_people_seek_in_their_place.description: In "Cities and the Creative Class," Richard Florida analyzes the "three T's" of urban employment for young people- Tech, Talent, Tolerance- finding that good urban planning has yielded city-specific industries that attract and foster young talent.
what_do_young_people_seek_in_their_place.creator: 8edf4a05b5d59f8a5c1b86109159c46c

comments.text: I really like this as a concept for how to help young people become more "employable." By focusing on all the ways that young, 'talented' people can stimulate the economy, it positions them as a prize that cities should be vying for.  We have seen in this recession that the places that best attract the creative class (San Francisco, New York, Austin, Seattle) are the ones that have best managed to hold onto jobs.It seems that the question is almost flipped - instead of 'what can we do to help young people become more employable'; it could be 'how can cities help attract the kinds of firms that will in turn create jobs for young people?'

Great post - thank you!  In a previous role I was involved in a project that looked at UK cities and attempted to rank them according to some of Florida's criteria.  London and Brighton were perhaps predictable winners but one slightly less predictable one was Leicester; it scored highly because of the ethnic diversity of its population and the high number of patents applied for per capita (a city of garden shed inventors clearly).At the time it struck me that Universities ought to make more of the geography in which they're based as a way to attract students.  In most prospectuses, the focus is on how cool the nightlife is or good the transport links are.  What if there was some ranking of universities by how creative a city they're based in?  That would be in interesting indicator of post-university prospects and would definitely turn some the the current league tables on their head....Certainly I think Leicester University missed a PR trick on that occasion!

Thanks for this inspiration  and especially for pointing out the very serious limitation of focusing on those who can fit the mould. Nevertheless, to the extent that economic development in one area requires the provision of ancillary services such as building, cleaning, hospitality etc., some opportunity is provided for those (young and old) without 'talent' (as defined).

ever_the_hopeful_ever_the_optimist.description: A story of growing up and finding my way.
ever_the_hopeful_ever_the_optimist.creator: da3fecfaf8e0e216205c20b64bce3972

comments.text: Great sharing of experience. And valuable advice to look at other people and ask for their stories. There's so much we can learn from others.

Lovely reflections Amy. Thanks so much for sharing your thoughtful and personal experience with us. I think so often we focus on the end-goal, and forget the importance (and necessity) of the journey. As you described it, it's all about stepping stones!

I think it's important to let young people know that you don't have to figure everything out right away (there's no pressure!), and that the first job you land might not be the one you want but one that will give you that real world experience. It's never too late to switch careers or pursue other interests; you build on what you have as you go along.I always kind of wished there was more of that in college--"real world" interaction. In my graduate program, we're required to do a practicum that allows us to put our theories to practice and give us exposure to our particular field of interest. I also had a very similar program at my high school (and found myself falling back on those high school skills rather than college when I was working full-time!). It was in college that something was lost in translation, and I think it would be great if more colleges (and high schools, too!) incorporated practicums or internships into the curriculum. It would help open doors for students, provide them with hands-on experience as well as different perspectives and skills, and help bridge that gap between the academic bubble and the real world. In addition, it also allows schools to become a better resource for job searching and general career advice.

comments.text: Hi AmeyThis is very true. I often have discussions with my teacher friends about this very thing,There is value in committing some things to memory such as times tables because they may be useful in a wide range of situations but it is essential to provide an understanding of what is behind them. To use a trivial example suppose you are presented with some apples set out in 9 rows of 5 and a row of 2. It is easier to recall that 9 x 5 is 45 plus 2 is 47 than to actually count all the apples.However I can completely agree with you that understanding is the real key to the real world and I support your call for a very necessary change in education system in your country.

comments.text: This is a very interesting inspiration.It reminds me of a phenomenon in Germany. The problem which comes up here is, that more people start studying mechanical engineering, when there is a big demand. The problem is, that they finish university 5 years later - then then a lot of graduates enter the market. Therefore it gets more difficult to find a job then. In years of a low demand of engineers, less people start studying this subjects. And 5 years later, there are less graduates and therefore companies have a hard time searching for young talents. This phenomenon (pork clycle) is described in this article: http://www.spiegel.de/unispiegel/jobundberuf/0,1518,465889,00.html (in Germany though).To find a way out of this problem and at the same time managing the freshman according to the industry demand is a great challenge. Im looking forward to a great discussion and more ideas on that.

Interesting thoughts Aleksandra  looking forward to hearing more developments on this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post it again there too  and meanwhile you might like to check out the Feed Your Idea section here: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire Hoping to see more of you on OpenIDEO.

comments.text: Love this, Ashley. I especially like the idea of a mentor who had no sons or daughters but could "adopt" a young person to bring to work. And think about those young people who have no parent that is able to support this idea but had a desire to go to work with a professional? Shadowing is such a powerful experience.

I'd forgotten how much it meant for me to visit my dad at his office as a kid. Seeing my drawings on his office walls made my day. Playing with his computer (early 90's) was amazing, and seeing the social aspect of work really made an impression. I was reminded of this very recently, when I visited his work environment, some twenty years in from my previous visit. I immediately drafted the company some marketing material, and I have now inherited (loaned) all the management books from my dad's shelf. Inside I still have that boyish feeling of awe from the original experience. This is a very good idea, and should be a strong part of corporate culture.
I'm so glad to hear this resonated with you Thomas. It's amazing how strong those childhood memories can be, and what a pull they can have on us.
You're right! I hadn't thought of it that way, with regards to this challenge.  An idea that is simple, free and fun!
Thanks Tamar! I'm glad you enjoyed this.

I think it's a great idea. It give young people a good sense of what goes on in the world of working. And to do so at different stages, with different 'assignments', could really help them to make choices and to find the right career to pursue.
Oh I like your build! Let's remember this for Concepting :)

What an adorable photo, Ashley. My dad has always had his own business, working from home so I got the chance to experience an office (albeit small) from a very early age. It's amazing what you learn from watching, asking questions and helping out on a range of tasks.
So true! My mom is a small business owner, too and I agree - I watched and learned every day!
Me too! Worked at my Mum's surgery in school holidays and learnt a lot about "being in service" of others.

excelling_in_flux_.description: The economic landscape is morphing and traditional education and approaches to employment are no longer entirely adequate. A new generation of initiatives based on collective empowerment are bridging the gap and redefining paths to success.
excelling_in_flux_.creator: 269a82314376d15f4864117ff4cf4115

comments.text: Love this. This is also why I think playing competitive sports is very helpful for kids -- it helps them form good relationships and overcome adversity in order to achieve a common goal. Even though it is very conventional, I don't think we should dismiss how helpful they are in some kids' development.

Have you ever played the Game Fluxx.  http://www.looneylabs.com/games/fluxxMy kids love this game and so do most of their close friends (GATE kids). The game rules change during play, both the way each turn happens and the ending objective to win.I never really understood the huge difference until I tried to teach a classroom full of 3rd/4th graders and their parents this game. (my daughter was a 2nd grader placed in their class). They were such in the box thinkers that the idea of Flux in a game threw them and they quit. All the directions are written on the cards so its really not that hard to keep up. The notion that things change was incredibly frustrating to the room. We pulled her from that school soon after.
Have you seen the Fast Company article about 'Generation Flux'?

excelling_in_flux_.title: Excelling in flux

youthconcert._a_recurring_combined_music.description: The idea is to host a series of small 1-2 day music festivals in different locations. Young unemployed people can volunteer to help arranging the events in their locations. A non-profit org. will facilitate and at the same time host a job fair.
youthconcert._a_recurring_combined_music.creator: 4f33f60372e6bc655f12fa6964b669da

comments.text: Just heard about The Concert  being run in post-earthquake Christchurch, New Zealand: http://www.theconcert.co.nz/the-concert To attend the concert you have to volunteer. Thought there might be some learnings from their approach for your idea here.

Thanks for sharing. This is a great page here. The whole aspect around collecting ideas, the approach to engaging the targets audience are all aspects that can be incorporated on a larger scale with the Youth@Concert concept.

I really like this idea and the tradition from Denmark that's inspired it.  In the UK, the mobile operator Orange came up with a similar idea but with a slightly different twist:  http://www.orangerockcorps.co.uk/The deal is that you can only get a ticket to the RockCorps gig if you done some kind of volunteering to earn that ticket.  Some people object to the idea that volunteering has to be rewarded with an incentive (http://www.guardian.co.uk/society/2008/jul/10/rockcorps.volunteering) but, on the whole, it's been well received and very popular.However, perhaps they've missed a trick in not linking the volunteers who've won tickets to employment opportunities?  These young people are clearly already motivated with good skills and experience so a careers fair like you're proposing (based on the Danish model) could be a good build for next year's event....

Thanks for sharing Lydia.I just want to clarify the Grn Koncert concept. They have no links to jobs, however they have become an institution in Denmark and are extremely popular with young people. What we can learn from them is:1. How to attract sponsors (Tuborg, part of Carlsberg has sponsored them for as long as I can remember)2. How to attract the right target audience by bringing in the right bands and by creating a format that works well with young people3. How to attach a good cause to the whole concept (muscular dystrophy)They have various sponsors and then of course make money on ticket sales.I like the idea of volunteering to earn a ticket, which would make the event more accessible to our young target audience.Keep the input coming, please.

Very true, in my experience working with young people (14-17) sometimes you need and "incentive" to get them in the door, but once they're engaged and interested they truly blossom and gain a whole new set of skills and job etiquette, and are no longer there for whatever incentive pulled them in to start!  It seems like, if they are volunteering to put on a music concert, some sort of interaction with the band(s) e.g. meeting the musicians ... or other music/band-related incentives (ticket to future concert etc.) could be one option?
Hi Jessica. Absolutely - the music/artists/bands could/should act as a catalyst and incentive for the young people.
Great use of a scenario to explain your concept here, Simon.

youthconcert._a_recurring_combined_music.title: Youth@Concert. A recurring combined music festival and job fair.

re_structure_demand_supply_landscape_to_.description: If there are gaps which are affecting the employment landscape, we must come up with instruments to bridge those gaps. My model addresses the 'skills' gap - the gap between what the industry requires and what the job seekers provide
re_structure_demand_supply_landscape_to_.creator: 2ec61248fe1d25dd65f5402eb502a49e

comments.text: Hi Subhadeep  what I really like about your concept is that it recognizes there's a 'matchmaking' element to employment: job seekers and hiring managers need a way to find one another. It sounds like industry in particular would be making a financial commitment to helping pay student tuition and guaranteeing jobs upon graduation  do you have a sense of where this funding would come from? Are there companies that perhaps already 'sponsor' student programs like this that we might learn from? I'm eager to see how this develops!

Hi Ashley, Thanks for your comment. While I was developing this idea, I came across certain programs where corporates do reimburse part of the tuition fees of employees. Currently it does not work the way that I have proposed in my model, one has to be employed with the companies in order to be eligible for the tuition support programs. Here are some links for more info:http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-12619365http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/15/education/15iht-SReducation-mba15.html?pagewanted=allhttp://www.unitedfriends.org/programs/education/college-sponsorshiphttp://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/05/10/tuition-reimbursement-10-companies-that-pay_n_1507188.htmlTo answer your question regarding where the funding, that the companies would invest to pay tuition fees for currently 'adopted' students, would come from: Usually a new recruit in a company undergoes a training upon joining. From my experience, this training lasts anything between 1 and 4 months. During this period, the company pays the recruit his / her full salary and benefits. According to my model, since the company involvement with the adopted students starts from the student's first day at University/college, the company gets an indusrty ready employee, who can be put into production from day 1 without any further training. This opportunity cost of training can be a possible source of funding towards tuition fees. Furthermore, many a time, companies hire external consultants to train their new recruits (a common practice in the IT industry, from my experience). The proposed model will also save these consultants fees for the companies which can be channelized towards reimbursing tuition fees. Its a win-win situation for the students as well as the companies.

Great thinking! Thanks for clarifying on the funding side - I have a much better picture of it now. Really it's just shifting the investment costs associated with on-boarding and training to an earlier part of the process. Makes sense!

re_structure_demand_supply_landscape_to_.title: Re-structure 'Demand-Supply Landscape' to bridge existing gaps!

first_teach_students_how_to_live_healthy.description: Before we can show students how to succeed, we should show them how to live a healthy, sustainable lifestyle
first_teach_students_how_to_live_healthy.creator: 1163c06be906a09dcae5e1d579941c6f

comments.text: This is a very important, but oft-ignored element of competitiveness in the workplace.  Have you checked out the HBO special "Weight of a Nation"?  In it, they describe how there are so many overweight and obese children in this country, and how this affects our ability to compete in a global market.

Interesting thoughts, Brett. Could you elaborate a bit on how you think this could help young people succeed in work?I do agree with you that a healthy lifestyle is important, but I don't directly see the connection to how it helps finding a job.

Simple: those who are able to live healthy, sustainable lifestyles will be better, more reliable employees. Consistency is very important at any job, and living healthily is one way to ensure that one performs consistently. I don't think everything should be about merely finding a job. I think we should be concerned with promoting the practices that maximize students' performance on the job. Better performers are better employees.

first_teach_students_how_to_live_healthy.title: First: Teach Students How To Live Healthy Lives

gap_year_required.description: There have been some discussions on OpenIDEO about the benefits of gap year. What if every high school graduates is required to take a year off before he or she applies to universities?
gap_year_required.creator: 6e75a6fc07caaa04191c4cbe89e9433c

comments.text: In part, the inspiration for a Gap Year came out of a desire to see greater opportunities for international travel granted to young people who would not typically be afforded such opportunities.Broadening a young person's worldview is an essential ingredient in readiness for the world and the 'work' necessary to fully take part in that world.Perhaps there is a market for a more structured and formalized 'optional' gap year that is part academic, part leisure, part pause and reflect, part 'do-good' and uniformly supported by government, academia, business and the social sector.After all, these young people wouldn't all necessarily be counted as 'unemployed'.And, if we're partly moving toward a world where we all work together to quickly solve issues relating to poverty, unemployment, education, the environment, etc, it seems logical to include young people from the onset, as vital problem solvers of these issues.

This is an absolutely important issue, and it does make the difference indeed. Gap year is such a simple and possible option for helping young students exploring and making up thier minda about their future. Some places like Scandinavian countries do have it as a a habit and it is impressive to see how life changing a gap year can be. I think it should be thought as a cultural element and incentivate youngsters to do this.

Maria, I also think that culture plays an important role. I'm from Taiwan and all of my friends go to university straight after high school. Perhaps it's because during our K-12 education, our personal progress was not that valued, our rank among our peers was much more emphasized. As a result, we were worried that entering university later than our peers would be seen as a failure.

Same here Ting-Han! I am from Brazil and heres it is the same. There is a lot to do with our social/cultural context, but that's why I think it is so crucial to discuss it and let teenagers here and there know that it can be different.  :)
I hear you on the cultural front, but if it became a national policy then students wouldn't have to worry about missing out by taking a Gap Year, don't you think?

That's right Sasha!but I keep wondering what should the trigger be... I think that it could be more possbile to influence national policies if we started building a cultural movement. That's what I tray to do with my relatives and kids I know.... I try to show them that trying an alternative way can be quite valuable and maybe even better. When you thought about changing national policies did you have any ideas? If so.. they could be really interesting. :)

YES YES YES! This is such an important concept. However, a lot more research needs to be done on costs involved. Who's going to pay to support that student for a year? Will they get paid or will it be volunteer? Perhaps students could receive a living stipend and educational award like AmeriCorps? Also, I'd propose that the government works with non-profits to help come up with projects. That's how we built the national parks system!

I know many people who have taken gap years to do varying thing, from an extended vacation to work experience. The idea of a gap year is fantastic, but it is really dependent on how young people use this time.On a related note, as a former teacher I always found my older students to be more mature in their arguments, more focused in the classroom, and generally better students than those who entered university straight out of school. Real life experience can only improve their academics once they return.

Think this is an intriguing idea (I certainly got a lot of out my unplanned for gap year!) but I'm a bit concerned that further education is already expensive and pricing some young people out of the game and an enforced gap year might exacerbate this further.  I'd be interested to discuss creative ways for financing this gap year.  Who could step in to ensure everyone could really make the most of this opportunity?  Could banks introduce a new kind of loan for gap year students and perhaps offer preferential rates to young people doing voluntary work vs. travelling round the world for a year?Just an idea - would love to hear what others think and thanks for starting the conversation Ting-Han.

Lydia, thanks for bringing up something new to discuss! A gap year is meant to encourage young people to explore their interests, and we should try our best to factor out their financial conditions. I like the idea of offering different loan rates depending on the way people plan to spend their gap year. Besides cash, providing food and accommodation can also be a form of financial aid (especially for overseas volunteer work). Speaking of funding, crowd funding also came to my mind...wonder if that's feasible when gap year becomes a norm. Hope to hear other's thoughts on the funding issue!

Though it does change the idea of not even being accepted until completing a gap year, colleges and universities could be encouraged to offer an incentive for completing a gap year. Offering a scholarship, discount, or even bundling a gap year into the program to make it possible to support with student loans.Have a nice day. :)

I know more and more graduate schools are looking to accept only students with experience outside of academia. Some business, law, and other schools won't even accept students straight out of undergrad. This oftentimes fits in well with 2-year job commitments as people will become paralegals for two years before going to Law School. Maybe this kind of "directed" gap year is the way to go whereby people get some experience at a low-level in a field they are interested in. That kind of work-requirement could begin to be adopted by undergraduate admissions.

Speaking of graduate school admissions, I know that Harvard MBA has a 2+2 program. It is a deferred admission process for college seniors. Upon graduation, people accepted to the 2+2 program will spend 2 years working in a professional and HBS-approved position. After that, they will enroll in Harvard's MBA program.Maybe universities could have something similar. High school graduates can first get accepted to a university (but not a specific major), then they have to fulfill certain work-requirement before they can actually enroll in classes.

Assuming you could impose this requirement, does closing the option of going straight to university benefit the people who are ready to jump right in or only those who aren't ready? Could you also consider a variant of this option that doesn't hold young people back who feel ready to fly?

This is a great question, and a wonderful idea! The gap year to an undecided student can be hugely beneficial, but there are some students who are ready to jump into continuing education right after high school. Perhaps high schools could implement this during the seniors last semester? The "gap semester" would still count for credits, so there is still the incentive to graduate, they're still able to explore options, get outside their comfort zone, and narrow down what they eventually want to spend the next 4-5 years studying.

Thanks for pointing out your concerns fjr. It is indeed important to make the policy flexible for those who are ready to fly. "Should I head straight forward to university?" - this is a question each high school graduates have to decide for themselves. What we could do is to help them clarify their thoughts since their decisions might be influenced by several factors. For instance, peer pressure, family pressure, admissions' preferences (will this university favor those who took a gap year or those who didn't), etc. Another possible solution is incorporating the gap year into part of our formal education, like Laura's "gap semester" idea. If it is count for credits, maybe people will be even more motivated to plan ahead for their "gap semester".

This could be a great option for many who are not exposed to all the possibilities available to them in both university and professional life. If nothing else, this option helps expose high school graduates to more areas of focus.

Thanks for the comment Robert! As you mentioned, being exposed to a lot of possibilities is beneficial, and perhaps the sooner the better. In Taiwan, we enter university with a specific major and it is hard to switch majors - most of the time you have to be the top 5% in your original major (which you probably don't like). Also, I think having the chance to do internships helps clarify things - For instance, one might like the biology course in high school, but does he/she enjoys the life style of lab or field research?
I once hear the following: "Would you let a 17 year old choose your career? Well, that is what we did".  This gap year can definitely assist in bring clarity to so many options out there.
Thanks Caroline. I really hope people could explore many options when they are 17!

gap_year_required.title: Gap Year Required

inter_company_rotation_program.description: Like big company rotation programs across different divisions, but across companies instead
inter_company_rotation_program.creator: 7771fbb20af6ef10827c593daa3aff7b

comments.text: Amy, brilliant idea, I just realized I posted a similar concept:http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/the-baushaus-year/I was thinking, in Austria for example there still is a military service, and one way to get around that is to help in a state run business or in an NGO instead. What I realized when I was doing my social service was that allot of people actually ended up staying in these companies. I say this as a sort of proof that this would work!When you do your social service you get an income payed by the state, so you are in effect free labour for the NGO that hired you. Some took horrible advantage of this situation, but some actually offered their civil servants a career they previously hadn't thought about.If the work is payed for by the state, we would need some kind of feedback/control system to prevent companies form treating their ACROSS interns badly.

What I especially like about this is how it moves the idea of apprenticeship away from the old mindset that I should choose a career when I am young, study for that, look for work in that field, and then slowly work my way up from the bottom, never straying to one that celebrates the value of cross-disciplinary learning and diverse view points. I work in a bank now after studying to work in a bank and I am definitely weaker for that narrow focus. The question, though, is: am I more or less employable? I know youd be a better banker in the long-term if you started your career with six months as an apprentice plumber and six months as an apprentice ships navigator, but I suspect that youd find it easier to get hired at the end of that first year if you had simply spent it as an apprentice banker.This might not be true. But if job seekers think the same way, then when they select the companies through which they rotate they are likely to choose a too narrow band of companies/ trades to boost their perceived short-term employability. And if they do that they will miss out on much of what makes this idea so potentially valuable.To make this stand out from a normal apprentice programme you will need the roles to be diverse but to make that attractive to a job-seeker you will need them to be confident that a diversity of roles is valuable. So I think there is a question of perception youd need to address too. I think it would be great if you could get a few big employers  especially ones considered old fashioned - to publically endorse this sort of a programme so that you might have a major motor manufacturer looking for junior-level technicians with plumbing, fashion design, and teaching experience; or a major retailer looking for junior store managers who have worked on a fishing trawler, in a bank, and as a chef.

These are great points Brendan and offer something for both employers and prospective employees to consider.As a baby-boomer we usually expected jobs for life. That has changed in the last fifteen or twenty years some for the better and some for the worse. Cyril Lebel's inspiration ( http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/no-experience-irrelevant-experience-is-there-such-thing-let-s-give-them-a-chance/ ) is relevant here.Sometimes what seems irrelevant training or experience can bring true innovation into a workplace.

I agree, nothing productive is really 'irrelevent experieince'. I just had a related thought now though, when we bring new people into an organisation we often start indoctrinating them straight away with 'how things are done around here', quickly negating the value of diverse backgrounds. This idea though presents a great opportunity for companies to get genuinely fresh ideas, one that shouldn't be wasted by simply placing a candidate in the usual pool of interns. So I'd build on my earlier point by recommending anyone that hires diverse interns should first put them through a 'no training given' programme.Interns with diverse/ interesting backgrounds would be given no background information on the current processes in the employer and instead would be given just the name of a programme or process that is performed and asked to brainstorm how they think its done or should be done. So Barclays might just ask an intern to spend a day imagining how they would control the risk of bad debts: drawing from their experiences as a cruise ship singer, a plumbers assistant and a house painter they might just think of something that no one who has been taught to manage risk the traditional way would have; they might come up with something stupid too but it is a no risk opportunity to potentially unearth valuable creative problem-solving talent. It also offers people with that mindset a different route up the corporate ladder - something I would definitely value.

Really interesting idea.  I like how it flips the conventional wisdom of companies keeping a tight hold on their employees.I can see how young people would benefit from getting experience with different work environments, cultures, and responsibilities.  In some sense, companies may benefit as well, if employees rotate and return to a company of their own accord, and with added experiences.

Hi Amy,Interesting conversation that's been going on around this interesting concept. I think it's a good idea because governments are the ones with great contacts - nationally and internationally - and have the power to create these bigger scale programmes. I wanted to share with you a program that is quite famous in my home country Portugal, operated by the government and other public institutions called INOV CONTACTO -  http://portugalglobal.pt/PT/InovContacto/Paginas/AboutInovContacto.aspx . It's a 6month paid internship for recent and unemployed graduates in the business or arts fields (you have to be unemployed to apply) and you go through a long process to be accepted (about 3 interviews). You can be sent anywhere around the world, from Spain to China. During the interview process who have no idea where you are going to be sent, and a month before you go you find out the company + country you are going to! Usually you'll do a  1 week trial at the affiliate office in Portugal (if the company has one). Last year for financial reasons the programme didn't happen but this year it has gone ahead again. Unfortunately it's the only programme of its kind in the country, and to be honest favours quite educated individuals, and not often ones who are unemployed AND no univeristy studies, but still, it's a great scheme. I know some people who have participated and remain at their companies now with a full time job.I think these programmes should become more available and accessible to anyone at the present times, which are particular hard for the younger generation. But, competition to get in these programmes is only getting tougher, too. I wish it could be an easier logistics/business plan to create these!With your concept do you mean one individual person works across for ex, 5 companies in 8months? Thanks for the inspiration.  :)

Hi Amy, great thoughts! As we were discussing this morning, I think this might work nicely as a social business where an organiser creates 'circles' of businesses, perhaps in similar industries, which young people can rotate through.There might be different 'circles' depending on the experiences the young person is looking for.It would be vital here to have a motivated organiser, or organisers, to champion this and create partnerships with businesses.Looking forward to seeing this idea evolve!

Love the concept Amy.This can be a very powerful process!We used to call it 'secondment' and it allows for both employees and employers to benefit.Although it may seem not to be directly related to providing jobs to those without them, it can be a way for organisations to realise that employing people with apparently irrelevant qualifications or experience can be surprisingly productive and lead to unexpected innovation.I am reminded immediately of two things:- the inspiration in the e-waste challenge referring to IDEO's involvement in USGBC Biomimicry Challenge ( http://www.fastcodesign.com/1643489/biomimicry-challenge-ideo-taps-octopi-and-flamingos-to-reorganize-the-usgbc ); and- (from my own experience) in the late 1980's the Australian Taxation Office introduced a position of Workplace Health Officer (sadly it didn't last more than 5 years). This position was filled by a registered nurse who not only fulfilled the required duties but brought a whole new perspective to the local office.

Cool idea. The nature of the government support would be the barrier to implementation. What are your thoughts? Government subsidizing of wages for trainee-rotation workforce might be the answer, but that would mean more government spending, which may encounter some push-back from various parties. Tax breaks could work. Thoughts?Building on this concept, maybe instead of having a formal rotation program, companies were to introduce a new kind of job category. Something between an internship and a formal position. Internships typically last a couple months, a summer, etc. BUT what if there were positions available that looked and felt like internships, but they were longer in length, paid, had a bit more responsibility involved, but still had a tangible learning component? Companies could be given tax breaks(which are easier to pass than tax increases) from the government for hiring this category of worker, which would provide incentive to hire.A reason that something like this could be beneficial is because its so difficult for people to break into a new industry without prior industry knowledge. With a hiring tax incentive like this, companies would be incentivised to bring on more volume of entry-level workers, give them meaningful responsibility, and provide a good place to learn the trade/skill/industry.Does this resonate with anyone? Anyone else have ideas to build on here? I know this is a bit loosely formed, so feel free to tighten up this idea.

Thanks for the comments, Bryan. Agree that government support could be a barrier. I love the idea of putting the onus on companies and offering a tax break as incentive. How might we help ensure that the jobs are learning oriented and provide benefit both to the young person and the company?
Maybe by linking it to a rating system being discussed in the comments here? http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/job-interviews-as-learning-moments/

Thanks Amy, that's a great point. The learning component is key, and what's to prevent companies from using this theoretical category of employment as low wage workhorses who don't get the mentoring that this type of position calls for(see: typical U.S. internship). My first thought is something like a program website, where people are invited to post reviews, updates, etc. about their experiences. Something like a blog/yelp/ratemyprofessor.com/glassdoor.com hybrid that makes companies accountable for a learning-filled experience for the duration of the employment.Maybe there could be different criteria for grading the company/opportunity. Example could be grading 1-10 on attributes of each program/position at the company such as: "pay", "treatment", "responsibility", "learning goals reached", "skills attained", "mentorship provided". Just shooting from the hip on this stuff, curious what you think. Feasible? Cost/benefit?

I have seen this type of thing being implemented between business and government sectors in better economic times.With regard to Bryan's concerns and suggestions - Australia has had a variety of government supported schemes for traineeships (subsidising employment of someone to learn the skills required in the industry). It's a really great idea and some employers have properly embraced it but sadly more often than not (and the big internationals especially franchise models) tend to abuse the system: dismissing the trainees on completion and engaging another for further subsidy. The last such scheme required training to be provided through a registered training organisation (RTO) which divided the subsidy between employer and training organisation. My boss actually said to me that he would like to become an RTO so he could collect the whole subsidy.A part of the scheme was intended to either lead to permanent or better paid employment but the more usual result has been for the employer to treat it simply as a way to reduce labour costs.

inter_company_rotation_program.title: Inter-company rotation program

openideo_ternship.description: Encourage young people to learn and develop skills by contributing to OpenIDEO
openideo_ternship.creator: 6be42609fd85352195b8c311d3fcf4de

comments.text: Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:The panel were flattered to see that people believe that OpenIDEO itself could be used as a tool to help young people build skills that will make them more employable in future.  They were excited to explore the potential of using a social innovation platform like OpenIDEO in a classroom conceptWHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:The panel would love to hear from teachers about how they might integrate OpenIDEO into their lessons and curricula  it's already being used in a number of educational contexts, but mainly with University/College students rather than those of a school ages so we're intrigued to see what benefit it could be to younger people...For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Thank you ! Thrilled to see this!!

Brilliant idea! Here we all are getting creative by using the excellent OpenIDEO tool, but you are the first one to say "Hey, what about OpenIDEO itself?". Fabulous out-of-the-box thinking, and my guess is that will be something easy to implement.

Thanks Carole!  By reading and reflecting on experiences of members at OpenIDEO, one can easily see that people do learn a lot by contributing to OpenIDEO! That made me think why cant OpenIDEO be a possible solution to this challenge !!

What if instead of students contributing to OpenIDEO, which may be challenging to get them on the interface, we had teachers and parents collaborating together? When we discuss youth, it almost always has to do with their parents and the teachers who need to be influencers, and those two parties don't always interact. Would a service like OpenIDEO help bring everyone together to discuss job creation and employment? Teachers could announce when they need something done, and a parent could volunteer their child, so maybe it's little projects that become larger.

The participation of volunteers through IDEO is very important, to demonstrate this experience in the online community it could be created an application that allows companies (future employer) to have a report of the candidate and his/her participation in the IDEO challenges.

Hello Everyone!! Any thoughts on how we can refine this concept!! I have sent emails to quite a number of teachers and experts on education to build and provide feedback on this concept However, I have not received any response. I need a lot of feedback to refine this concept!!

I read someone talking about timing being a problem and I think thats a major concern. I wonder If we could habilitate OpenIdeo so that schools can submit their own challenges and deadlines and use the platform to support the curriculum?
Interesting idea, Bov  sounds like this could play out kind of like the way that NING does http://www.ning.com/ but based on OpenIDEO functionality.

Yes Interesting Idea guys! I was wondering whether challenges created by a school would only allow its students to participate or would it be open for all? How similar would it be to the existing or past challenges? It does seem that this might be useful for schools as they can tailor a challenge according to their context ! Curious to see what other OpenIDeators think about this!! Or What if OpenIDEO can post a challenge a year especially for schools and conduct it around around a semester! This will enable several schools globally to participate on a challenge.Thanks Bov and Meena!!

this could also serve as a filter for projects to always take on a social problem rather than designing just for the practice of it. OpenIdeo would be responsible for approving or questioning the benefits of working on challenges submitted by design schools around the world. I wonder if this would restrict and scare away people from submitting projects and using OpenIDeo as a platform at their institutions? , what do you guys think?

Thanks Bov. No I dont think that would scare schools! There are only a limited number of challenges OpenIDEO could take a time, which is absolutely reasonable. I think schools will understand that! I think participation by schools on a challenge matters more than submitting one!!

Hi Waris, interesting idea. I think that as it is now OpenIDEO does offer students or young people a way to practice certain skills and learn new ones as they go through the process, and interact with other on the platform. Some students have already started creating their own groups (one of them is the OpenIDEOstudent chapter at NYU-Poly but other students from other universities - e.g. a team from Cornell CIPA Hackathon -are participating and meeting offline. In fact OpenIDEO is also supporting this effort: https://openideo.zendesk.com/entries/20451883-introducing-openideo-universitiesHowever, what your concept is suggesting is to be even more intentional about this and maybe "formalize" all of the elements mentioned above.I'm not sure exactly how though. Are you suggesting that OpenIDEO will support a team of students during the whole process? How being an intern will look like? I'm curious to know more. Thanks!

Hi Ann!! Thank you for your thoughts !! Yes I was initially suggesting that OpenIDEO develop a formal and structured internship process. However, I think Haiyan is right in that essentially employers value the work the person has done, which OpenIDEO (kudos to them !!) provides a platform for as you metioned above. Moreover, a separate internship might not be conducive to spirit of OpenIDEO. A young person taking the initiative to do something meaningful (that too voluntarily !!) at OpenIDEO might be much more impressive to an employer today (or anyone else for that matter!) rather than a structured internship ! I guess this is also what Haiyan might be alluding to !! However, I still think that OpenIdeo as a platform can be very valuable in addressing this challenge as I mentioned in my reply above. I would be grateful if you can provide your thoughts on this. Thank you

Hi Anne-Laure and Waris, your comments make me wonder if there's a version fo the NYU-Poly student chapter for young people who have graduated some time ago and still looking for work.What sort of tools would you recommend for such a group? How would that be different from a student group?

Hi Haiyan, this is an interesting question. The chapter is young: not a year old yet (would be in September) as it was inspired by the Impact challenge last summer. So there is no situation yet of young people who have graduated some time ago and are still looking for work. One of the co-founder graduated and another member also graduated. The other is graduating this winter. I'll ask them to reflect on this question. I have the feeling that the students currently involved do learn a lot in terms of articulating ideas, thinking about problems in different ways and communicating ideas (through personas, storytelling and prototyping). All of this are important skills in thinking about what you want to do and in looking for a job.

Hey guys, awesome to see so many comments here, just by reading a few of your comments, I wanted to add that I also think it would be valuable to provide a way for students to showcase their active contributions in forums such as openIdeo, it seems to me that we are learning so much by collaborating with so many people here that it would be a waste not to showcase it when trying to sell yourself to a potential employer., I recently started thinking about it because I wanted to add openideo as part of my experience list in my website. I also agree that openIdeo should have bigger presence at universities as being part of the curriculum even!

Thanks Bov! Sure it would be useful to provide a method which will enable students showcase their contributions. Right now, it is usually done by posting the link to your OpenIDEO profile. I think an OpenIDEO plugin can be developed, which will make it a bit easier!! Any thoughts on how OpenIDEO can be incorporated into the curriculum?

Hi,Great to see all these discussions.Regarding the way to showcase your experience, what I've seen is people putting the link to their profile in their blog or even CV.Regarding integrating openIDEO in universities and in the curriculum, there are different ways. The OpenIDEO team is already involved in this effort. You can find more at https://openideo.zendesk.com/entries/20451883-introducing-openideo-universitiesOne informal ways is having students clubs or chapters. As mentioned above, there are several formed, including the one I know best at NYU-Poly. I also have been using the participation to openIDEO challenges as a "project" in a course on design thinking where students work in teams on a challenge. This has been very successful in terms of learning and feedback from the students. There have been several faculty experimenting with this (again see the link above for examples).It is not always easy to use openIDEO for a course project as there might sometime be some mismatch between the course schedule and the challenge, but overall if one is flexible, it's feasible and very fruitful.Last, we are now working at NYU to introduce a platform internal to the university using the OI engine: http://ideaexchange.nyu.edu/While it'll be student driven, faculty members will participate providing content, mentoring students, and some (like me) will use it as their course project.

Thanks a lot Anne-Laure for the feedback ! I have studied the OpenIDEO at universities thread and it is useful! What I feel is missing is a structured approach (as you say informal) to implementing OpenIDEO at Universities and Schools, which can be good as it might allow more freedom for creativity in implementing OpenIDEO. However at times, teachers (and students who wish to open a chapter) might find it difficult to implement. This leads me to think that whether a general DIY Kit for both teachers and students can be developed, which provides general guidelines for implementing OpenIDEO in classrooms and opening clubs or chapters. This will give them a kick-start as well as the freedom to be creative in its implementation! Also I was thinking- on a tangent- that teachers might want to use past challenges as a guide to teach students!! Students may learn a lot from how past challenges were solved!!

I think it would definetley be useful to make past challenges available to schools but I can hardly imagine people going through every single comment and concept, would be awesome to make the whole challenge visible., something like a virtual space in which you can zoom in and out depending on how much detail you want to explore. I think IDEO was starting to do something like this but I never actually figured out how to use it., It would probably take a lot of coding but ideally I envisioned this to be more of a 3 dimensional project that you can explore, massive collaboration visualized as if you were entering someones brain and following the traces of an awesome thought. hahaha :D

We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Our developers are busy working on it. Meanwhile, if you're wanting to iterate your ideas, you can use the comments feature to promote further conversation from others. We'll let you know once the bug is fixed, then you can incorporate your refinement moves into your concept post. Let's be agile, together!

Right on! Our development team have been busy fixing the Update Entry bug and we're back on track now. You'll now be able to edit your posts to add all that refinement-goodness to build out your concepts for improved impact. Bring it on, together!
Thanks!!
OpenIDEO in the Classroom !! Very relevant case !! Just read it! This has got me thinking!!  http://www.openideo.com/fieldnotes/openideo-team-notes/openideouniversity/

I think promoting OpenIDEO at schools an universities is a great idea. Students in different classes could potentially use OpenIDEO to supplement their studies by creating and completing their own concepts as an assignment, or collaborate with a team of students to create an Independent study centered on an OpenIDEO concept they create and see through to completion and earn credit for, perhaps in conjunction with a volunteer activity or internship that relates to their concept. I don't think that a formal internship curriculum through OpenIDEO is the best approach, mostly because I think initiative and the completely open table on which students can create is more valuable and telling of their abilities. OpenIDEO is such a great platform! Love, love, love being part of it!

Great Build There Celestial ! Thanks. It would be great if OpenIDEO could act as a platform for students where they could apply their learning. Moreover, teachers can devise a curriculum based on a challenge  at OpenIDEO and subsequently students can learn what they require to contribute to the challenge. OpenIDEO can therefore act as a bridge between theoretical and practical learning.  And Yes Indeed OpenIDEO is such an amazing platform where one can learn so much and meet great people ! I feel blessed to be able to contribute at OpenIDEO.
I have modified my OpenIDEO-Ternship concept that I posted earlier Thank you so much Haiyan and Anne for your suggestions.

Hi Waris, thanks for your idea and your thoughts on this issue!In terms of evolving this further I would suggest perhaps considering if an internship 'accreditation' is the direction to go in or if what would really help young people is to showcase their work from OpenIDEO.Would employers value the credit or the history of work performed and what that work says about the individual's abilities?As OpenIDEO, we would love to help young people grow their creative confidence through the platform. We're a very collaborative team and I'm not sure if we would feel comfortable to award a certificate or prescribe an internship curriculum.What might be really valuable is for users such as yourself and others to create a guide to OpenIDEO for young people. What can they do to get involved? What would you recommend they take up based on their different backgrounds?This sort of user-generated guide is more in keeping with the community spirit of OpenIDEO, I feel.

Hi Haiyan!! Thank you so much for clarifying the essence of what I was try to articulate. I thought    How can OpenIDEO act as a platform to help young people in the world of work? The only way I thought we could develop this, would be a formal internship, which after reflecting on your thoughts really need not be necessary. Indeed I do feel now that a separate or formalised internship process to address this challenge might not conform to the spirit of OpenIDEO as it might foster competitiveness rather than collaboration.It did not feel right to me initially but I was not able to think of any other approach to develop the above idea!  This also probably takes care of the drawback I mentioned above as we can reach out to far more young people and help them contribute rather than taking on a limited number of interns.I think we can reframe the challenge now How can we encourage young people to join and contribute to OpenIDEO to develop skills and do meaningful work? We should definitely not be sending out the message (even subtly) that Join OpenIDEO to enhance your job prospects... However, I do think OpenIDEO can address some aspects of the challenge and can really help young people. Therefore we can further explore this...Perhaps a starting point would  be to learn from seasoned OpenIDEO users and how they have benefited from contributing to OPENIDEO...Also we can think of removing any barriers that young people might face in joining OpenIDEO and hence, make it easy for them to contribute. .Thank you for building on this Haiyan !
Here's an example from an OpenIDEO user which you might find interesting along these lines: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/openideo-my-unemployment/
Thanks Meena !
