py/tuple: IMPACT & REACH: How much impact and reach do you think this concept could have in helping young people transition into the world of work?
A great deal – something like this would really make a difference
A moderate amount – it’s certainly helpful but probably not a game-changer
Not very much – it’s unlikely to make a significant difference to young people seeking work

FEASIBILITY & RESOURCES: Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible will it be for your community to turn this concept into a reality?  (Hint: when you think about resources, think: people, money, time, technology, infrastructure, partnerships and any other inputs for implementation)
Highly feasible – resources wouldn’t be an issue for my community if we tried to implement this
Moderately feasible – my community could do it if we could get find assistance with some of our resource constraints
Not feasible – it would be almost impossible for my community to implement this concept; it's just too resource-intensive
SUSTAINABILITY & LONGEVITY: Does this concept feel like it could be sustained as a project, business or movement over years rather than just months? Will continue to be relevant in future?
Yes – this concept has enough momentum to stand on its own two feet and remain relevant for years to come
Maybe – it’s not clear how long it would take for this concept to stand on its own feet or how it will continue to be but there’s reason to feel hopeful
No – this concept will have trouble sustaining itself in the long-run and probably won’t be as relevant in years to come
ORIGINALITY: How new or innovative is this idea? Are there many different versions of this concept out there already or is this something more disruptive and unique?
Very original – I’ve not seen anything else quite like it
Fairly original – there are similar things out there but this particular version brings a new element to the table
Unoriginal – there are already too many other concepts out there that are similar to this one
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world
I liked it but preferred others
It didn't get me overly excited

multiple_paths_to_a_diploma.description: Everyone is different, and so should their paths towards their diploma. Far too often students are stifled by the rigidity of curriculum. A model that encourages students to seek education in all aspects of life doesn't just enlighten, but empowers.

comments.text: I love the experiential aspect of your "requirements." All of these illustrate that today's student needs to be more active in their education;  they are not vessels to simply be filled with knowledge. I've taken all these classes while sitting on a chair and taking notes - it wasn't inspiring then, and it isn't now. But an "educational event" - that sounds like fun!!  Nice work!

The experiential side for education not only helps inspire students about what they are learning, but helps to reduce the fear and shock impact of the workplace once they step into a job. At that point they will already have experienced many of the things a job can throw at you, including putting their ideas out there, dealing with criticism, and developing as an employee.
Great examples under your Avenues for Education title, Duncan. Loving the local focus.
Thanks, Meena! The local focus would also help reduce "brain drain" from communities where people often don't consider there to be much educational value.Have a nice day. :)

hidden_talent.description: New tv series on the UK’s Channel 4 on finding people’s ‘hidden potential’--going through a series of diverse tests around physical, mental, sensory and creative skills, in order to discover unknown aptitudes (not traditional knowledge).
hidden_talent.creator: 17540aef7b8470cc3ea8b2b9046af3b6

comments.text: To me this makes me think that sometimes the talent is not so hidden as it may appear. Sometimes people are conscious about what their assets are ... and it is the recruiting space that is blind for certain type of talent. I've heard recruiters say 'we tried MBAs people, but it did not work out, so now we are looking for another profile'. And what they be missing is that what they need is not strictly related to MBAs qualifications and instead may have to do with a type of talent that some MBAs may have and some non-MBAs may also have, being the MBA qualification the wrong glass to look through. Miopia in the recruiting space makes the gap grow.

Earlier in life testing of less traditional aptitudes would be a great place to start. But, how about later on in life to anyone who isn't sure about what they want to do? Often if someone has weaknesses in one area, they will compensate in another area. I don't think that these compensations will be fully manifested until later.

Wow - this is incredible and I know what I'll be watching over the Bank Holiday weekend.  I *wish* I'd had some kind of aptitude test while I was younger. The closest thing I've done is a Myers Briggs test recently and found it fascinating and genuinely helpful in a work context.  But the point being I was already in a work context by the time I took the test and it's very much geared towards people working in professional environments.  A school-leavers version would have been invaluable to me when I was younger and I'd still be interested in doing something like that now!

This is terrific!  The tests are already available through organizations like Johnson O'Conner Research, Highlands, Gallup and others who have been successfully providing talent assessments to interested businesses in some cases for decades.The biggest barrier to wider spread use is the stubborn belief that specific talent doesn't exist and that given enough training and practice anyone can do anything.Everyone is talented and can do amazing things when their skills and knowledge are built on and around their very unique natural talent and passion.

This is a really good point. Allthough I wonder how those tests could be done with millions of young people without having well trained staff. The point of working out unique characteristics is very interesting. There surely is a lot of potential lost to traditional learning environments and non individual teaching programs. So how could the individual test himself or friends each other? Is it possible without a professional support?

hidden_talent.title: Hidden Talent

comments.text: Excellent comments Christian and sadly often both underrated and overlooked. Unfortunately the lure of money overshadows the need for ethics.

thanks a lot Paul, if at leat i`m able to call someone attention i`ll be more than glad. :)i`m aware that i have a lot to learn about gain people attention; i`m new here so there`s no rush to become the most seen yet. anyway you comment motivates me to keep learning and participating!

Welcome to OpenIDEO and glad you will keep participating Christian.We don't really need to attract attention but I understand how you feel.I am happy to answer any questions here.You might like to find another idea you agree with and tell them what you think. That will help you understand a little about how it works. At the moment we are sharing ideas we already know about. This will help us to think of new ideas that we can share in the next phase (concepting) which starts in just over a weekI'm in Australia so you may find my replies a little slow - its 1:30 am (Tuesday)here at the moment so for today I will be in bed soon - I think you are in Columbia where the time is 10:30 am (Monday)RegardsPaul

_a_2_year_fellowship_program_which_wil_l.description: Connecting the dots, an organization that provides a 2 year mentorship for recent college graduates to work in development. 1st year they will work in the bay area with top notch organizations and the second year work internationally in the field.
_a_2_year_fellowship_program_which_wil_l.creator: 2d3e41e4ef31716e29992febecfcbbcf

comments.text: Great concept, Viria. A win-win situation for the social sector and recent grads. There are plenty of young people who are striving to create social impact and this is a great way to make a career out of it.Organizations such as Ashoka (http://www.ashoka.org/about) can be great avenues for college graduates to get a head start.

Dear Manish,Thank you very much for your advice to look at Ashoka as a model.  I admire Ashoka's approach to seek out social entrepreneurs and provide resources to support their efforts. I read the book "How to change the world" by David Bornstein, which documents Ashoka fellows's work their accomplishments and challenges. It's very inspiring to know about the creativity and social solutions that are being implemented all over the world. Thank you!-Viria

Viria, it's really nice to see you push this forward, given the seeds of your thinking two years ago in Banny's Large Scale Sustainable Transformations. Check out Stanford EE Professor My Le's Gap for Good (http://www.rusticpathways.com/gap/gap.php). I can see partnerships with impact investing groups to sponsor students for these periods. I also wonder - there is an opportunity for those who want to do good in the world to be armchair travel companions - how might a fellowship be crowdfunded by sponsors who might not be able to travel to a developing country but want to support a young college grad to do so and still participate in the wonder and amazement of being somewhere new and supporting a distant community. Good luck Viria!

Hi Emily,Thank you very much for your comment and suggestions!Here are quick thoughts that come to mind:Your question really made me think hard about funding models and how to better involve donors and supporters. As you mentioned, there are people who might want to be engaged with the program but are not able to travel with recent graduates to the field. The idea of the program is currently structured to be a 2 year program, where the first year will have a strong emphasis on learning. For the first year, I see a great opportunity for supporters to be involved as mentors and advisors, give guest lectures, share case studies, and personal experiences. The first year recent graduates will be working with partnered organizations in the bay area, so this would make it more convenient for supporters to travel.For the second year, during recent graduates field work, recent graduates are required to have an interactive blog to document their experiences as a way to share, inspire, and learn. Graduates will face challenges while working on the field, and it would be helpful to address the challenges as they come up to the greater community. The web platform will serve as a medium for supporters and the public community to brain storm, provide resources, and support the recent graduates while they are in the field.To strengthen the donor relationship, I had a 1-1 funding model idea. Where a recent graduate is paired up with a donor. Donors can play a crucial role and be involved in the process. Thank you very much for asking hard and important questions!  A lot more work to do! .-Viria

_a_2_year_fellowship_program_which_wil_l.title: A 2 year fellowship program for recent grads that leads to a life long commitment for social change!

the_secret_to_germany_s_low_youth_unempl.description: In the German speaking countries Austria,Switzerland,Lichtenstein,and Germany there has been a long tradition of low youth unemployment, mostly thanks to a learn-on-the-job apprenticeship system - a system seamlessly integrated into higher education.
the_secret_to_germany_s_low_youth_unempl.creator: 116fee19f83200c3abeba614c26191e9

comments.text: As many as 60% of under 21's in Germany go through an apprenticeship. This is much higher than in any other European country. The interesting questions might be: How might apprenticeship be re-imagined for the 21st century? What new skills and disciplines should be taught via apprenticeships? How could we make it much easier to launch and support apprenticeships within businesses?
New skill: being a generalist (like you mentioned almost a year ago in a NYC (?) university.

Interesting questions Tim.I think they will actually answer themselves as the century progresses. Provided Germany continues to foster a truly reciprocal basis for employer/employee relationships I suspect they will remain at the forefront.

Great synopsis Stefan!Interesting to contrast the commitment of both the employers and unions in Germany with attitudes fostered through conservative governments in Britain, Australia and possibly USA. In Australia 12 years of driving unions and employers apart here has led to many employers seeing apprentices as simply cheap labour and government subsidies as a means of adding to profits. Commitment to training is grudging and as soon as subsidies cease most employees are sacked, whether their training is complete or not.Germany's example is useful too in demonstrating that entrepreneurship, while undoubtedly important, is not the be all and end all of opportunity.

Apprenticeships and mentoring surely are time-honored paths to preparing people for the workforce or for independent economic activity, particularly when unemployment in their location is the result of a mismatch between what employers need and what potential employees are able to do.
true! I also like that it's institutionalized, so you can continue your education at an university, making the pupils more independent from the first company.

the_secret_to_germany_s_low_youth_unempl.title: The Secret To Germany's Low Youth Unemployment

comments.text: Clearly the old-fashion way of sending CVs and waiting for a call is not the only way to get a job nowadays.Good perspective on elements that should be encourage in training programs which ultimate objective would be to get a job or start a business...

I agree Juan. My first thought when reading this list was that sending CVs and the "wait and see" passive approach was not included. Rather young people need to have an understanding of how to be active and how to build upon these stills to aid in landing the job.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
I think that young people should indeed be more aware of the different way to get experience or connect to job opportunities. It seems that in some schools not enough attention is paid to that.
Great list. My favourites here are networking + internships as they strengthen your own pulling power as well as relate to both entrepreneurship and employment opportunities.

discover_careers_together.description: "Discover Careers, Together" is an online library that collects and organizes each individual's efforts. If you spend hours to research on an occupation, why not share your works and benefit others?
discover_careers_together.creator: 6e75a6fc07caaa04191c4cbe89e9433c

comments.text: Loving that this includes students on the making and sharing of career-oriented videos!

I agree with Meena. I also find really interesting that there is such a course in Taiwan. It will be great to use this as an opportunity. I'm also wondering if you could interview other people than university professors as this might provide a limited set of examples.

Thanks Meena. I think it is valuable to learn from your peers because you are in similar situations (thus their questions might be yours as well). Also, they are your potential competitors when looking for jobs...and it's always better to know your competitors well!

Anne - recalling the course I took, although it was called "Career Planning", our teacher focuses more on helping us to discover our college major (when we apply to college, we don't apply to the school alone, we apply to the major+school). We did more discovery on careers while in college. For instance, interview alumni and publish it on our major's publication, invite guest speakers to talk about their career path, etc. I think these information could all be uploaded (like MIT's OpenCourseWare) to benefit others. Since not every school have resources to invite prominent speakers. Also, sometimes the same speaker is invited to our college 2-3 times in a semester...by a school club, a professor, and our career center.

discover_careers_together.title: Discover Careers, Together

skillshare.description: Skillshare is a community marketplace to learn anything from anyone. We believe that everyone has something they want to learn and something they can teach to others. This means our communities are really the greatest universities.
skillshare.creator: d1aacd22b4aa8bdc73b7b0053eb8a201

comments.text: I think this form of community of practice- or practices- has tremendous potential. It is ideal if the same set of people isn't always doing the teaching but if each person is sometimes a learner and sometimes a teacher, regardless of age.

Love the notion of 'regardless of age'. The dogma today is that there is an aging population = crisis. But just because the world is aging, doesn't mean that economies are doomed. Platforms such as Skill Share enable retirees (who would otherwise leave the workforce entirely) a way of staying productive, earning a living as well as contributing back into the economy.

Such a great initiative. I particularly like the idea that enables people with real expertise, in whatever area, a way to unlock the value of all the time/energy/passion they've invested in developing that expertise. So rather than pursuing your passion being viewed as a distraction 'from getting a real job', it becomes a highly credible and viable way to earn a living. Bravo!
Beautiful iniciative and with a tremendous potential!

I love that skill share leverages the community in person.  I am currently working on raising the visibility of Skillshare in Las Vegas.  We unschool and the more Skillshare classes they are, the more my child has the opportunity to learn from passionate people who are vested in the topic they choose.
This is a different way of seeing education, but it would be great if this were complete online courses so everyone around the world could have access.

There are numerous outlets for online courses, but Skillshare isn't the learning/teaching tool itself. It's a platform that connects learners and teachers within specific communities. Online learning has its benefits--scalability, self-pacing, etc.--but I'd argue meat-space learning offers (a different sort of) engagement we can't get via the internet and thus remains essential. While I hope those online outlets continue to grow and evolve, I also want to see alternative education and beyond-the-classroom venues like Skillshare grow and evolve in tandem.

James  do you work for Skillshare? I notice you've put "we" in your summary. If it's a quote from their site, perhaps you might put the text in quotation marks?And for everyone else  check the video clips. They're an inspiring watch!

skillshare.title: Skillshare

learnup.description: LearnUp is a real-time job skills training platform that connects job-seekers and employers.
learnup.creator: cb0e09c205b2413162b95a8b79401432

comments.text: Sweet! thanks for posting us. LearnUp is an innovative startup that crowdsources job skills training from professionals and employers directly. Launched on stage with Pres Clinton at CGI last week, and rolling out to 16-24 with partnerships at CA Community Colleges and more. Would love to chat further and engage with the openideo initiative. email: hello@learnup.me
Thank you Alexis! Congrats on your launch and wishing you great success.

This does indeed look an interesting initiative.I'm curious how the employers contribute to training and how partnering at the college level would work. The site itself provides minimal information on thisDoes the site also accommodate learners who may not be either college graduates or currently at college?If so, what job success rate is there for non-college learners?

Hey Paul, Thanks for these great questions. Anyone can access LearnUp from around the globe... from the highschool student to community college student to the jobseeker of any type/education/age. As a start, colleges are actively distributing this to students as a way to help them gain relevant job skills and get hired.Leading employers are already contacting "top learners" on LearnUp for open jobs! (including both college and non-college learners). Employers are also sharing job training modules for anyone to learn:www.learnup.me/Stapleswww.learnup.me/Gapetc....Alexis

comments.text: The only thing I want out of these online course websites is some way to prove that you know the material from the course. That way, people can show that they're really continuing their education online instead of embellishing on their resume.

That's an interesting point - they certainly encourage you to share your accreditation on your resume:  http://help.coursera.org/customer/portal/articles/502521-can-i-display-these-courses-on-my-resume-will-it-help-my-college-job-etc-applications-...but I wonder how else they might help you demonstrate your aptitude - maybe making coursework public?

On this issue I have just asked Coursera if there is a list of those courses that provide a certificate of satisfactory completion. This is a common weakness with online informational courses that ultimately results in them being undervalued for lack of proper student assessment (not withstanding the reputation of the institution providing the course). I guess it is a case of "you get what you pay for" - even in conventional education a substantial cost component is in providing a proper assessment against a standard.As I have said elsewhere the education system starts out attempting to give everyone an equal opportunity to learn, even up to the end of high school but then at the tertiary level often reverses this emphasis. I well remember one lecturer telling our economics class "look to the two people sitting nearest you - remember only one of you will make it through" For some people this would be an incentive while for others an immediate 'put-down'

haha yeah, when i saw the challenge it was the first thing it came to my mind, perhaps Andrew Ng should submit coursera in the Cencepting phase :PAlso, i can see you are taking the HCI class too! guess i will see you in the first assignment grading  :)
Yes indeed, it's turning out to be an amazing class so far!

service_exchanges.description: The lack of youth employment doesn't depend on a lack of demand of services, but rather on financial limitations in the economy. The next step needed might need to be building the infrastructure for a complementary economy of service exchange.
service_exchanges.creator: 71efcb97b36e5dbddf6d2b71e82586e3

comments.text: Hi David. To be honest, the first reaction I had to your proposal was that financial limitations are not the reason the main reason for not hiring. Some companies are sitting on record high amounts of cash, Apple has more cash on hand than some countries. There has been piles of cash on the sidelines for the past 4 years, at least.But I'm glad I kept reading...A network of service exchanges, I think, could spark some innovation. This is especially true in early stage companies or companies that do, in fact, have the financial limitations.An idea worth discussing.

For sure, it's not the only reason. Though I don't think that Apple is a good example to use as an index. If companies mirrored Apples performance I don't think we would be facing these challenges. I think the problem is that there are not financial resources sufficient for hiring, or to compensate for doing. In these cases I think that financial compensation could be replaced by a compensation of exchange.

learning_by_doing.description: Learning by Doing heightens exploration, engagement and empathy – blending soft and hard skills.
learning_by_doing.creator: 0ebfe65ca16ea82675e4294e27747639

comments.text: Thanks for the inspiration, I think that encouraging the kids to do real life problem solving, allows them to explore and discover natural talents.  Also to see the benefits of learning first hand, and to motivate them to push themselves to learn more outside of class. I think we also need to figure out how to attract better quality teachers and motivators to our schools.  The classes where i had an engaging teacher and who wanted to push us was when I learned the most or had the most benefit. I grew up in Iowa where the education system was one of the better in the country, and still felt like the majority of the faculty was unmotivated and punching the clock.  Maybe we can pose the question to the students of helping to create the lesson plans and give them more of an opportunity to get engaged.

This is an argument going back to he 80s, donald schon wrote a book called the reflective practitioner and educating the reflective practitioner, which set out design and architecture as the exemplary model of education for pretty much all disciplines, because it was learning by doing, or as he said reflection in action.

I'll take this a step further:I think we should encourage learning by doing in a way that places the student in an uncomfortable position. No, I don't mean forcing students to practice difficult yoga poses, but I think we should force them to figure things out as they go and deal with uncertainty. The solution? Designing open-ended, possibly group-oriented, projects that require students to learn new course material (or go beyond the course material) in order to solve a problem would do wonders for developing critical thinking skills and the courage to move forward with one's intuition. In addition, students could learn from other students' or groups' approaches to solving the same problem. Yet another great inspiration!

Great inspiration, Meena. I also think it is important that learning-by-doing needs to happen at ALL levels of education. I've been lucky enough to participate in entreprenuership programs that allowed me to run my own business in high school, and I've been pleasantly surprised to encounter this at the university level too. My university has project-based classes where hands-on experience has been the focus of the class and exams were nonexistent. Students were instead graded on reports, presentations and evaluations from their supervisors (at the company they were paired with) - much like the real world! These classes allow students to work with local companies, world-renowned corporations and start-ups while still actively learning from faculty and training materials. They were almost like riding a bike with your training wheels on - getting the exposure to real world work situations while still having the safety-net of your professors to fall back on! The perfect dry-run before starting real world experience!This really should become mandatory at every educational institution, especially higher ed ones.

Thanks for sharing this video Meena. I found it interesting at two levels: the process for the students involved in the redesign process and the output for the 5th graders. I am convinced that learning-by-doing is crucial in the learning process based on the literature and studies, but also my own experience teaching. I also found the video interesting as it is a great reflecting exercise, which I think should be part of experiential learning.

Hi Meena. During a project in jr. high school, a friend's parents shared with me the "see one, do one, teach one" methodology. This simple phrase has stuck with me and while learning by doing is certainly important, to close the loop and solidifying the concepts learned, teaching what you have learned is a great way to do this.

learning_by_doing.title: Learning By Doing

mentor_a_young_person_in_your_community.creator: a21810a01d3fe0df4291d7d3e7abbd1c

comments.text: Fab inspiration, Annie  and loving the image you chose to go with it!!

Hi Annie and thanks for the inspiration!I don't do anything quite as direct as mentor a young person but I am a Community Governor at my local primary school and I find that really rewarding although, if I'm honest, I think it's my own personal development that I value and perhaps I could and should be doing more for the children directly. One thing that this challenge has made me realise (and I think other contributors have raised this too) is that some kind of voice from the 'World Of Work' should really be represented on the Governing Body.   There's already the requirement to have 'community governors' but these are loosely defined and, in practice, tend to be people who live or work locally.  It would be great if there was a way to get local businesses and employers more engaged with the governance of schools, especially at secondary level.I think it would help teachers understand the needs of employers better (especially around soft skills) and also inspire young people about real people running real businesses in their area.I hope your mentoring continues to be a success - it's certainly made me think harder about how I volunteer my time...

mentor_a_young_person_in_your_community.title: Mentor a young person in your community

career_day_career_year.description: A new curriculum which begins in elementary schools and ends upon graduation of high school.
career_day_career_year.creator: 1965552ec364b87b6423e1c283312ff0

comments.text: Hi Caroline, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know by hitting the Support tab on the left hand side of most pages of our site if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

Returning to the present and to feet-grounding discussion I think this has enormous potential,I know the new dream seems to be to become a self-made entrepreneur, probably now outranking entertainers in popular ambition: and some of the inspirations point out that we don't know the jobs of the future. Notwithstanding this there are a huge number of roles that are likely to remain well into the next generation.One job I considered training for was radiography - at the time it was almost completely x-ray based, ultrasound and whole body scanning were the province of research rather than practice. We may not know what tools will be available in this field in the future but it is likely there will be more specialisation and that people will be involved - this (in my opinion) would in no way diminish the value in learning about the existing jobs in this (or any) field for current school children.I accept that it is exciting to focus on the possibilities for technology but there are other things in life too - food, fresh flowers, art, music, literature.

It is interesting that this practice of bringing people in to talk about their work is common in grade school but much less later in schooling. The Take Your Child to Work Day programs (the flipped version of this option) do cross more school grades, but that experience might be more broadening if kids could go to different places of work rather than only to their own parents places of work!

There are many possibilities here. Excursions, school visits from industries, parent participation. If the school has adequate resources some excursions could turn into video documentary making, if this was instituted then there is the possibility of documentary exchange with other schools - perhaps interaction between urban and rural schools (we are often told that some city children don't understand where milk comes from). A documentary starting on a dairy farm might progress through pasteurisation and end in a high-tech chemical laboratory investigating infectious diseases. All of these things, as well as informing about career opportunities, could be related back to specific learnings in the core curriculum.When I was in high school it was recognised that Friday afternoons and Monday mornings were the least productive times of the week (since here the only school associated activity at weekends is sport).Little was done about Monday mornings but Friday afternoons were devoted to whole of school recreation. Some of this was pure entertainment but some of it was craft or science based. In 1965 the music sessions were very popular (Beatlemania etc,) but during the next two years I participated in creative writing, historical research, and two friends and I got involved in making Bakelite, building two different 3D chess sets and developing electromagnetic propulsion systems.There was still plenty of time to undertake the formal educational components.

One of the strengths I see in this concept is the continuity between different educational levels. Just as mathematics builds on basic number, sorting and collecting skills towards algebra geometry and trigonometry this concept could build (flexibly) on broad notions of industry and perhaps jobs that are obvious within the community towards specific careers and specialties  that inspire imagination and passion.

I don't know what inspiration you had for this concept - perhaps it just emerged in your mind (as did mt "great employer" concept) - or perhaps it came from some of the inspirations posted during the Inspiration phase (for example Jamie Beck's Wasted Investment inspiration   http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/what-a-waste-of-6570/     If you find other inspirations and concepts that are complementary or have strong associations you can choose to link them by using the Built On links in the concepting/updating process.This does two important things:- it alerts the originator of the other inspiration or concept to the fact that you think their contribution and yours are associated (which may lead to them collaborating with you); and- the two contributions then appear linked together on the interactive collaboration map shown in the sidebar.

Thank you Paul for this example as I was unaware of it.  Jamie Beck's proposal definitely expands on this concept.  The way I came up with the idea was basically by looking back and seeing what I was missing when I was attending school.  Many times I thought to myself why my high school did not create such possibilities.  As Jamie Beck mentions, "how can we become what we don't know".

As an elementary school teacher I try my best to connect work done at/for school with possible careers.  I don't see this concept as a new curriculum but rather as an addition of "career connections" to whatever skills are being studied and practiced in existing curriculum.  Bringing "real" career activities for kids to explore best makes that connection between the skill and the work that can be done with that skill.

I think it can be both.How often does your school assemble together and for what purposes.School structure and operation will vary considerably across the world and also between elementary/primary and middle/high school/secondary college. I certainly agree relating work done at school to possible careers is an essential and possibly regular component of classes. In many schools excursions can sometimes serve this purpose  Bringing the 'experts' to the school can be complementary and equally valuable, and sometimes more resource effective.

career_day_career_year.title: Career Day ---> Career Year!

comments.text: I see a recurring theme of redefining education. And this is a great example.Also: lovely how some projects/examples are popping up in different challenges.And I agree with Meena: emotional intelligence is an important factor that is overlooked by education too much, still.

I totally agree Arjan! Do you know The School of Life in London? Is this amazing school opened for eveyone and you can apply for any of the amazing classes they offer such as: -how to find a job you love-how to be cool-how to face death They also have a guide for everyday living...  and many others focused on an education for life. I recomend a tour on their website! http://www.theschooloflife.com/
Great call on emotional intelligence, Maria!

Thanks!  I just remembered Mr. Edgard Morin and his amazing theory about the seven teachings necessary for education in the future, and how it hasd everything to do with emotional intelligence and focus on soft skill too: Educate for the anthropo-ethic, taking into account that the human condition  simultaneously includes the individual/society/species.Educate to understand that the presence of error and illusion is part of the construction of knowledge.Educate to favor the natural aptitude of the mind to formulate and resolve essential and general problems.Educate for the emotions: since emotion is essential for total intellectual development.Educate to teach understanding between people, as a condition and guarantee of intellectual solidarity and  the moral advance of humankind.Educate to teach about the multifaceted Destiny of human beings: the individual, the social, the historic, that of the species, all interconnected and inseparable.Educate to abandon the narrow-minded vision that defines the human being by rationality, technique, utility activities and obligations.

comments.text: I am currently in a Rotational Engineering program for a construction management company in Manhatttan, NY. I am currently in my second of three rotations and I completely agree with the above. I have found that it is very nice to be able to move around positions. I really did NOT like my first rotation, but now that I've moved into the office I have come to enjoy it more and have been learning a lot more about the industry. I strongly recommend these rotational programs for any recently graduated student. They are flexible and really do allow you to figure out where your strong suits are.
Great to get insights from someone actually participating in this kind of initiative!

comments.text: Indeed, the only way to go is to create more jobs by creating more entrepreneurs!

This is less than half the story Arnold - we need far more than this."And what is true of a shopkeeper is true of a shopkeeping nation." Josiah Tucker (1766)Certainly innovation, entrepreneurship and design are the buzz words of the decade - they need to be coupled with notions of fairness, caring and community.I'm listening to Mike Lazaridis talking about his success - but he also points out that RIM employs 15000 people (not all of them are entrepreneurs).
Instead of what job can you create, how about one step further-what can you create?
If by this you mean what can you create that provides opportunity for others I can agree.

Sounds like a very interesting institute indeed. I think it's very important that we get so many educational inspirations here. It's good to see there are so many schools (at each level) looking to change education.

I agree to an extent - we also need to be careful not to throw the baby out with the bath water - educationalists here are recognising that teaching grammar (which was abandoned several years ago) is actually one of the key elements underpinning some soft skill development. In addition, although we all use calculators today, some of us still need to know how long division works to understand the iterative process underlying the program built into the calculator.Having said that there are creative ways of teaching grammar and maths as a means to ends rather than an ends in themselves.

ask_yourself_what_job_i_can_create_inste.title: Ask  yourself ,What job i can create ? instead of What job i can find ?

the_buddy_system_peer_to_peer_mentoring.description: The Buddy System stems from the idea of formalizing a peer-to-peer mentoring network within school systems; thereby allowing a greater network of shared knowledge and experience amongst students transitioning into the world of work.
the_buddy_system_peer_to_peer_mentoring.creator: 8482a78370e4b5a84ccf768aedf73d9f

comments.text: I love this idea - it's so simple but I think rings true for most young people.  When I was younger, the last thing I wanted was to be lectured about proper resume font, typically from people whose career paths didn't resonate with me.  I think that peer-to-peer mentoring is critical!  How can this process be formalized within the school system?  Alternatively, the program could potentially be one of those things that thrives from being amorphous (in other words, create a format that is distinctly different from the too-often tedious and lifeless career center).

Totally in agreement about creating something distinctly more interesting than the 'lifeless career center' ;-).Could it be more of a planned system for nurturing those relationships as opposed to checking in to some physical space?Maybe the school can brand those relationships, create discussion around them, share with universities, etc...You've given me a lot to think about!  Thank you.

This is a great concept!  I just finished conducting focus groups with high school level students throughout the US. The focus group was focused on how these students chose a university.  In each of these groups, the HS students said that they tend to or would like to talk to current university students of alumni from a particular school mainly because these two groups already have the experience and "know" what it it like during and after school.  It seems that HS students really want to find someone or something to relate to.
Hi Bijal -- I'm curious to hear more about your travels conducting this research throughout US high schools.Where can I read more about your findings?  Would love to hear more...

the_buddy_system_peer_to_peer_mentoring.title: THE BUDDY SYSTEM

sim_startup.creator: 9c78d2970452794013457bbcf72b452b

comments.text: Hey Maegan, this is a wonderful idea! You might be able to use some ideas from khanacademy.org who has done a lot to "gamify" learning.  Also academicearth.org has a mechanism to create "playlists" of courses. This might provide inspiration for a mechanism for linking disparate modules together. Also, I posted a related concept a little while ago that may provide something useful. Be sure to check out the concepts I built upon as I think some of their ideas could really help to make yours even better!http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/verified-skills-academy/
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
This sounds like so much fun. Being, I guess, a member of the target audience, I can tell you I'm pretty certain I'd use this "game".

Thanks!  Looks like a lot of people are coming up with gaming concepts, so I hope we can bring these ideas to the next level.  I will probably use the game too - always want to learn new things and it could also be applicable to continuing eduction.
For some further inspiration, check out Ayah Bdeir's TED talk: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YguB-keZ4Tk"Building blocks that blink, beep, and teach"
I enjoy the "Epic Wins" reference, was SuperBetter an inspiration for this?

Oh yes!  Jane McGonigal really knows how to phrase it right.  The game design really needs to be engaging.  That is potentially the biggest challenge.  I'm thinking "Unreal 4" graphics...  It's time to bridge the gap between gaming skill and real world skill.

While it's certainly awesome to use tech like Unreal Engine 4 for this, what kind of platforms are you looking at? Unreal 4 in particular while looking great has some really hefty demands when it comes to system requirements.

I figured you might say that.  By saying "Unreal 4" in quotes, I mean that this game must not have an 80's-style graphical interface.  It should be something anyone would want to play for its utility and general addiction-factor.  That being said, it also needs to be accessible to young people from all socio-economic groups (i.e., not just gamers with the latest tech).  You're right - there is a balance here.

HI Megan! Great Idea for training young people !! Something that young people do desire to have. You might want to have a look at the work that Allen Interactions is doing,  to build the concept. Thanks!http://www.alleninteractions.com/

I love how Allen Interactions is applying a similar concept towards multiple roles.  If it gets to that point, it may be worth talking to them to see what works and what doesn't, when it comes to usability and user enjoyment.  I like to think of the SIM StartUp idea as less training and more creative "play time" with a set of tech blocks.  I think we'll be surprised by what folks come up with given the tools.
Digging the ideas of being able to generate a portfolio and of linking advanced players to mentors!

Thanks!  This would be such a cool way to make a gaming experience really have an impact.  I struggled to find something that would hold weight in the "real world"; the portfolio/mentor idea might be the key.

_gamify_career_exploration.creator: a47c8d069204f91f562c96922f7cf970

comments.text: It's like playing life in 'sandbox mode' to get used to it and learn more about it before you actually get out there and try stuff. Amazing Idea.Also, I totally agree with how the youth of today approach a 'career'. Being a member of the community in question, I can tell you you've got it spot on!Looking forward to seeing this up and running. Cheers!

Love how accessible and user-friendly this is. In working with people entering the job market, what I've seen over and over is that in the first months a sense of powerlessness leads trips them up; in later months fear of rejection further slows them down.However, those who develop real passions that they pursue via community projects/volunteering, Kickstarter, Etsy, or similar outlets never seem to lose momentum. By building up that "gaming" confidence and offering a healthy coping mechanism you not only give them experiences (and maybe access) that make them more attractive to employers, you give them a way to manage the emotional stresses that come with the job hunt. Great thoughts!
Oh very cool Jeff, and very thorough.  Good job :)
Interesting thoughts, Jeff! You might like to rethink the IDEO Labs name as it's already being used here: http://labs.ideo.com/

MeenaThanks for the comments.  I will update my concept and was simply trying to capture the essence of the IDEO concept.  As a therapist I am trained in "systems thinking" and there is great potential for using the type of "innovative design process" that IDEO employs to help generate ideas for new businesses and to expose young people who are full of creative ideas to this type of "out of the box" thinking while at the same time showing them that even with innovative ideas, there has to be some structure and a process to make sure that the "creativity is captured" in a meaningful way.

Interesting idea, Jeff - the question I would have for this is what actually encourages players to keep coming back to the game? Do you have any other incentives in mind aside from the nebulous "better career"?

Imran, thanks for the question.  I updated my Concept to further clarify the internal and external motivation system of this type of game.  Make sure to see the section about the leaderboard and the various types of "power" within the game.

comments.text: Thanks for bringing this up. I am a young professional and this has been weighing on my mind; I'm glad you are making this more widely known.Some of the dilemmas you bring up are already being faced now. A.I. has not reached the level where they are displacing all humans from their jobs, but robots are already displacing many humans from manual labour jobs. This "robots vs. manual labour" issue is a more immediate manifestation of the "end of work" future as you have described. We need to start addressing the "robots vs. manual labour" issue now and this will provide the foundation for resolving the dilemmas at the "end of work".

the_future_project.description: The Future Project is an enrichment program for high schoolers that provides support, mentorship, and resources for students to take on passion projects to benefit their respective communities. Currently in D.C., New Haven, and New York City.
the_future_project.creator: e517980d4febfc10594c3bba5b729e8d

comments.text: Hi Karolle -- I recently learned some more about The Future Project and wanted to revisit this really great inspiration.I understand that a new role of 'Dream Director' will be introduced into schools in New York City, New Haven, CT and Washington, DC.I'm looking forward to learning more...

SashaI apologize that I didn't see your comment sooner. My internet access was sporadic in July, and I happened upon your response just now while revisiting old challenges. I'm not affiliated with TFP, but you can learn more about their latest outreach on their website, and they are accepting job inquiries at jobs@thefutureproject.org.
A really good initiative, because the key to good workforce is education in early stages.

The problem with many schools' curricula is that they think kids "learning" the material is the same as them understanding it. Thus, if it's covered in class, the administration gets to wave their hands and say that the kids "know" the material, so they've done their job.However, programs like this ensure that, if based around the material that students are supposed to learn in class, they truly understand the material once their project is completed. Finding a way for curricula to include the time to teach the material and design projects around it would be a big step in the right direction. However, educators are too focused on their students "knowing" the material rather than actively understanding it, which is a huge distinction that goes overlooked. Also, what's interesting is that this form of learning doesn't cover many traditional types of classes. How are you going to do beneficial, community-based projects for a history class, for example? Or an English class? Great idea -- and your questions are better. As Meena said, thank you -- very provocative inspiration.

Nice one, Karolle! I really like the questions you've framed at the end and look forward to collaborative conversations this might provoke. I was keen to promote similar discussion on my post on Learning By Doing: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/learning-by-doing/ Exam-based assessment provides a barrier to experiential learning in the classroom. Perhaps folks may join in discussion and have examples of experiential learning working within formal education to a significant degree. And hopefully these discussions will promote some great thinking for our upcoming Concepting phase!

Hi Meena and Karolle. Here is an example of an education program that requires a full time internship as a graduation requirement for a master in international management: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/the-cems-global-alliance-in-management-education-/However, are there any existing concepts that are more scalable and do not require a degree to participate?

Very nice indeed. I like the experiential part but beyond the learning in practice, there is also a key element about tapping into an individual's passion, giving them a chance to realize it and thus give a sense of accomplishment and confidence in their abilities. It was also crucial to note that several of the future fellows mentioned their coach and how crucial it was. Coaching in that case seems to be about iterative and personalized feedback, trust and role modeling.

Here is a project that was mentioned in a previous project and made me think of the Future project: http://creativearts.sfsu.edu/reader/creative-sparks-blog/2012/03/14/1646-thesis-student-teaches-design-homeless-children-colombiain its spirit: to give a chance to high schoolers to try out and experiment.

Anne-Laure highlighted the coaches' influence. Thinking back to the umbrella theme of preparing for success in the workforce, what can we say about the role mentors play? What are venues for young people to seek mentors and develop that mentor-mentee relationship? What are things to look for in a mentor?

Karolle, I agree these are great questions to think about and keep in mind. I'll see if I can find some inspirations or interview some people around this theme. If you have any ideas or insights on these, that will be great.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

the_future_project.title: The Future Project

Interesting, thanks Arnold - the tricky thing about tie-ups with MNCs is helping them see the ROI. There are few MNCs who consider their social impact to be of greater importance than their bottom line. Any ideas?

Julian, it would already be great if they go for a triple bottom line. Also the 2012 IBM CEO study says:"Collaboration is the number-one trait CEOs are seeking in their employees,with 75 percent of CEOs calling it critical".Also the sec gen of the UN is (continuously) call for a new model and the urgency for sustainability. So, many signs are encouraging.

teach_for_america_loan_forgiveness.description: Teach for America encourages new university graduates to teach in inner city schools in exchange for loan forgiveness up to $10k.
teach_for_america_loan_forgiveness.creator: 7771fbb20af6ef10827c593daa3aff7b

comments.text: I respectfully disagree with the proposition that Teach For America is good inspiration for addressing the IDEO question. The majority of the teachers quickly leave after they've had their loan repaid.  We put some of the most enthusiastic teachers into the worst school systems and then overlay a bureaucratic school district on top of it. In just 2-3 years, we burn out the teachers:"...more than 50% of TFA teachers leave after two years, and more than 80% leave after three years." Furthermore: "The question for most districts, however, is whether TFA teachers do as well as or better than credentialed non-TFA teachers with whom school districts aim to staff their schools. On this question, studies indicate that the students of novice TFA teachers perform significantly less well in reading and mathematics than those of credentialed beginning teachers."(http://greatlakescenter.org/docs/Policy_Briefs/Heilig_TeachForAmerica.pdf)Worse, these targeted, academically disadvantaged kids are given novice teachers who don't perform well. Whom does that serve? I am unconvinced that teachers or administrators can solve this problem. Teachers are told what to do by the higher-ups, sometimes to the minute. Someone willing to spend a career being told exactly what to do is neither a doer nor a maker. Very few careers require micromanagement trickling down from the Federal level. The great thing about Democratic Free Schools, such as Sudbury, is their partnering kids with passionate guides with domain expertise.

Hi Monera,Thanks for your comment. It is great to get context from someone who has worked with the program. It sounds like it needs some adjustments. From what I see on the website, it sounds like they attract highly motivated teachers, so hopefully there are some really great and inspiring ones in the mix! In terms of whether it is good inspiration, I believe finding creative ways to help students pay off debts and helping them help others in the process are two really powerful elements that we can consider in this challenge. Amy
Inspiration and insights certainly come in many forms  including through critique, opposed viewpoints, analogies, etc. As always, we welcome constructive discussions.

teach_for_america_loan_forgiveness.title: Teach for America: Loan Forgiveness

comments.text: I would say it is our responsibility to get the OpenIdeo credibility out there. If we attribute our success in the workplace to OpenIdeo, or if employers happen to notice a lot of game changers coming out of this community then we could develop a reputation even outside design/innovation industries.

You are right. OpenIdeo is a great platform also from a recruiting perspective. I would like to add one more thought. Since I'm still new on this platform, for me it is also a way to try things out and to learn more about myself. In this way I can reflect on myself and give some good and profound answers in my next job interview.

So true!Participating in OpenIDEO can help develop so many skills - problem identification, problem solving, evaluation etc. And of course, it provides so many opportunities to learn. I think if employers are able to look at a candidate's OpenIDEO profile and their contributions, they would be able to understand the extent to which a candidate's critical thinking skills are developed. IDEO - Is there any way to leverage SEO and have OpenIDEO profiles come up when you search for a person on Google? I know I for one would love it!
I think that, if you'd like an employer to find your OpenIDEO profile, you'd have to put a link in your resume and subtly suggest they take a look at it. That's the safest way to do it, IMO.

Yup. That's part of the reason why I'm here -- I've still got another 3 years until I graduate from college and I would love to make a pretty big mark here so I can get a good gig as a byproduct of doing something I find immensely enjoyable (and help out the world at the same time). Participating on projects I enjoy thinking about in an open community that I also enjoy is addictive and fulfilling. *sigh* I love you, OpenIDEO.

I was just talking to someone about how Skillshare can be a platform for finding candidates. The person who comes to an iOS class might just be the next passionate employee. It is possible that the Jobvite keyword trolls might skip past them.

I'll chime in with our values here: Our values: Inclusive, Community-centered, Collaborative, Optimistic, Always-in-Beta  perhaps providing further inspiration for folks. We look forward to what thoughts these might spark for upcoming Concepting phase!
Oh  and by the way... I was hired by IDEO via my participation on OpenIDEO ;^)

comments.text: I did the Year in Industry too. It's one of the best things I've ever done.A lot of jobs nowadays ask for a minimum of two years experience, which most graduates don't have. So getting work experience through  schemes like this is really vital.

Great sharing of your experience, Louise! And it sounds like a brilliant initiative as well. Very suitable for people to get a bit of a grip on what work looks like, and maybe make better informed choices for their next step in either education or work.

I really like the idea since we can not tell the taste of banana unless we try it :) I just wonder if we can make it shorter. Let's say 3 months. Or maybe one year industry trial for few different industry.

Fab to hear from someone who actually participated in this initiative, Louise! And for folks who want to check out more on Louise  here's our Featured Ideator piece on her: http://bit.ly/oi_insights_9

comments.text: This is an interesting one. There are apparently many projects, apprenticeships, competitions and games that companies put out there in which young people/students get a chance to experience work, show off their capabilities etcetera. Maybe it would be good to connect these during the inspiration phase. The Microsoft Imagine cup was also posted as inspiration. http://bit.ly/LairwcOn the user forums there's a how-to on how you can connect inspirations (and get some additional DQ points): http://bit.ly/L2m9Ux

the imagine cup sounds great, though think the aims are quite different.. i guess what stands out here is the redistribution aspect: supporting non-profit, social or open source initiatives that need talent but can't afford it. for youth struggling to find employment, volunteering is a natural interim option - which would be made all the more viable with a source of financial support.I'm sure there must be a lot of other examples out there, would be great to see more!

Good point about the aims. However, if you look at it from the student's perspective, they both give the opportunity to gain experience, improve skills and build competencies. Elements that can lead to better job perspectives. I think from there on we can build some very interesting concepts later on.

judge_by_character_not_skill_and_ehm.._f.description: Skill can be taught, but character is what makes people strive and succeed. Creating a recruitment tool to sort people based on the business character.
judge_by_character_not_skill_and_ehm.._f.creator: fbd410f33ad99d117f92cd1f96771efe

comments.text: While I agree that character is the foundation of a person, how do you demonstrate this as a possible employee and how do you trust your decision to go by this as a hiring manager? How do you show this except through a history of previous work (often called "work experience" or a "portfolio" on the resume)? As seen in the motivating story, it was necessity and not choice that led to the hiring of the unknown. I would be very appreciative if someone was to provide me with examples and methods of going about hiring for character! Then we could figure how to apply this for 16-24 year olds!

Hi Naman,I believe it is very difficult  for 16-24 yo to have a good and strong background as they were just finish school (or even not). So in order to see their willingness to learn and work hard, we gave a 3 months trial. And within this 3 months we also gave them basic training. Usually those who are not serious about working won't survive the first month. And the rest stay with us happily.

It'd really good to know that bold iniciatives like your do work, Mei! I work in a big comapny here in Brazil and we have been trying to hire new employees based mainly on values than on skills. It is not easy to chance this mindset, but seeing good examples such as yours gives us a new and good perspective on the future of the organizations.

Dear Maria, thank you for your comment :) It wasn't planned at the beginning of the business. We realized this by learning from the staff that manage to steps the ladder from very low position to managerial position. Of course they got internal trainings to raised their skill. But I am happy to say that good character is what makes them succeed.Recently, a psychology friend of ours helped us create the recruitment tool.

Great to hear your personal insights, Mei. Indeed  it's becoming more common for even corporates to seek qualities like 'collaborative' and 'empathetic' in prospective employees. These can be viewed as 'soft skills' and there are examples being posted across the challenge of initiatives which nurture these. eg. http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/project-m-thinking-wrong-doing-right/
Hi Meena, thank you for the comment and the link. I believe we can adapt some values in Project M :)

judge_by_character_not_skill_and_ehm.._f.title: Judge by Character, Not Skill (and ehm,.. forget background)

interactive_and_virtual_.description: How about creating a GIS platform with data indicating types of employment needed and where. For example: a map showing 'teachers' needed in X country.  Also, we can link this demand by providing access to virtual universities.
interactive_and_virtual_.creator: 1965552ec364b87b6423e1c283312ff0

comments.text: Perhaps ideas to build upon at http://www.indeed.com/jobtrends.jsp
Thank you Rob, yes definitely a great starting point. We can add more sections such as areas of studies needed, specific skills needed, and increase geographical locations.

Nice! Concept A could also work as help for young people in selecting a career path they may want to follow. By knowing what sectors have a surplus of employees and in which sectors there is a large demand for employees they can make a better informed choice. i.e. balancing personal interest with job possibility. If you include salary ranges and career opportunities I think this could become a really powerfull instrument to help young people in the first steps of their career.

Nice concept indeed. It could also provide ideas to people. Imagine someone seeing that they are several service designers jobs (or any jobs) in NYC and that the person did not really know about service design, or did not really think of service design and they might get inspired of exploring this option.

I really like this too - given the range of possible jobs within various categories and industries it would need to be segmented.In my 'great employer' concept Bryan has put a link to  www.glassdoor.com. which is principally a job search site that incorporates elements of feedback about the employers too. The site has links to other job search sites too so that I could actually find a job advertised in my home town at the bottom of Australia.In order to effectively create such a map it would probably be appropriate to integrate real-time data from as many job search sites as possible.Technically this is not too difficult but we need a 'hook' to make it attractive for such sites to participate.Given the double-edged nature of this concept ie, the ability to show concentrations of certain skills -Do you think it would be useful to be able to overlay complementary data from institutions about prospective output of graduates in associated disciplines? And even course intakes.

This concept can go some way towards resolving a perennial problem of the time lag between identifying skill shortages, supplying training and filling positions. This would make it equally useful in times of high and low employment.

Returning briefly to practical questions.Would this best be constructed top down or bottom up?If the latter what would be the most appropriate geographic level to compile data? Town (city), local government area, region?Given that the vacancy data might naturally come from vacancies listed on job-seeking sites would there be a point at which drilling down in the aggregated data leads to the participating job sites and the individual available vacancies?Similarly, going in the other direction might lead to course places in institutions and identifying opportunities for establishment of your  industry/professional supported 'virtual universities'.

I think the best way to start is via a small scale platform- in order to test and adjust easily.  Complexity will naturally occur once we add all the different layers.  However, we can use a large city to start this map so that it isn't too simple.  This would also provide us with large pools of data and also actors to get involve.  I think once this is up and running, the model could grow organically and than become instituted in other parts of the country and world.Partnerships with institutions, recruitment agencies and the like might have to be more formalized.  Data mining could be bottom-up as there is much access on the internet. The 'hook' to make it attractive for other sites to use could be as simple as a guarantee in more traffic!
You should look to get Google on board :)
Would be good if this could be done without monetization or profit basis too :)
Perhaps it can be an open source project, where communities, firms and the like can all update the data
Yes! Excellent idea - perhaps it could be a candidate project for Haiyan's YouthForce.

I realize I should have expanded on my comment, rather than just saying "we should get google on board!"I was imagining that we could update the google map facilities (or another provider) rather than starting from scratch. For example, in addition to the weather, webcam etc. layers, we could have a "jobs" layer. Also, google would be able to data-mine the job postings and peoples' searches on the internet, resulting in more real-time information than if we only relied on manual updates.The ideas above do not exclude the possibility being open source and without monetization; it'll depend on where the priorities lie and the partnerships that are established.

An extra layer (with sub-layers) would be great!  If we decide to create it with monetization, proceeds could support under-served communities as this would assist many in seeing new opportunities and adding to their skill set.

What a great idea Caroline! I really like that people could use maps and data to best understand where opportunities lie (and like you said, where there is already a high concentration of a specific kind of professional). One suggestion: you might think about adding a separate submission for Concept B. They are both great ideas and while they compliment each other, they could also be built out separately too. Great work!
Hi, I agree that concepts A and B can be stand alone. They are complementary but could be developed separately.

Hi, I agree too - please launch concept B separately - I'm sure you will find the community will help to flesh it out and develop it further.I admit I am a proponent of uniting concepts but on this occasion I see better value in developing these in an independent but complementary way.In another thread I suggest that overlaying institutional intake and output data might be useful to see if institutions are responding to real world needs - that information could also be useful in determining the efficacy of establishing the 'virtual universities' your second concept proposes.

Apropos of the suggestions here to separate the two concepts you can reconnect them using the Building On/Built On aspects of the Concepting/Update process (as I mentioned in your Career Day --- Career Year concept).I'm looking forward to all your future contributions on OpenIDEO - keep up the great thinking!
I will make a new post and connect them using the Building On Tool. Thank you!
You are most welcome!Collaborating here is so much fun - in fact I'm almost addicted to it.
We should make an app for the addicts!

Indeed. something like this one: http://www.openideo.com/open/impact/concepting/an-open-ideo-app/In fact, the OpenIDEO student chapter at NYU-Poly has been thinking of developing a prototype! :-)If you have any suggestions, let us know
Haha - will be good for most OpenIDEATORS - I don't even have broadband, let alone a smartphone.

Oh by the way - you will find you can literally edit and update all aspects of your concept by using the update button in the top right hand corner then republishing. Part of the process is to refine and hone the concepts. If someone makes a suggestion you like you can choose to incorporate it (in your words) into the concept. That way it doesn't get lost in the ebb and flow of the conversation.
