job_interviews_as_learning_moments.description: What if every employer was incentivised to help each applicant learn from their interview? I remember when I was straight out of art college, finding a job in product design was tough.
job_interviews_as_learning_moments.creator: d7d03fc4ed767b64ad78b2fdbcd6324c

comments.text: Rather than tweak/optimize the product itself, lets discuss the key choke-point - Adoption. "employers will visit the site after the interview" - why would they?"the employer can be rated by the candidate on aspects such as the interview experience" - while this is useful feedback for a company to improve its hiring process, I disagree that future candidates will look at this site to gauge the company as being a "great workplace" or not. That leaves us with a key question: how do we incentivize adoption?From a user utility point of view:- Interviewer - costs them time/effort, minimal reward- Interviewee - large benefit, but fearful of burdening their potential employer with any additional requests. Now, I'm not one to highlight a problem without proposing a solution. It's by no means perfect, so feel free to hack at it:What if we first made a site that is the "go to interviewing portal" where employers and employees meet to conduct video (skype) interviews. If we gave away a tool that adds value to both sides of the table, by providing a calendar (scheduler), video chat link (skype), and THEN your Cand.Id feedback system - then we make constructive criticism a default part of the process. Although this only would apply to Skype Interviews, they are quite prevalent, and furthermore - would be a good cohort of early adopters to test the early prototype on. Food for thought!

If we apply the Lean Startup Product Development approach, (http://theleanstartup.com/) to understand what features this web solution should have and which direction to take, we need to validate our riskiest assumption. As Shaan was mentioning, if Interviewers do not go to our site, there is no viable solution. So, how do we get Interviewers involved and get them as early adopters? Lets find out what are their major frustrations during an interview process and lets build features that will solve those frustrations. If we save them time and make them more efficient and effective they will get involved.How do we find out? As Lean Startup states: Lets Get out of the Building and interview a few to find out how do they conduct their interviews now and if can we help them have a better experience around the process.  That will give us ideas for a  product that will engage both sides.

Excellent Swany!Will keep this approach in mind for future challenges too.Of course for best feedback a direct approach between interviewee and interviewer is preferable - although as Louise Wilson points out it's frustrating to get no response (either pre or post interview).
Shaan - really great feedback, thanks! I've updated my concept based on this excellent build.

Really great concept here, Nathan! I consider good feedback as a piece of information that is specific, useful, and actionable. The interviewer providing good feedback can have this simple model in mind when making suggestions. The interviewee can be the judge of whether or not the feedback is good, but at least the employer is structuring it in a way so the comments are likely to be helpful.Perhaps a framework can be created to guide employers on providing feedback on the spot after an interview.
Thanks Amy - great idea - I'll add that in too.

It seems like there are many concerns about the potentially negative experience of someone who doesn't like the feedback. To offset that, what if the interviewer and the interviewee were provided some seperation via time or a third party "good cop?" Time - Feedback isn't provided unless the interviewee requests it, but then it isn't provided until after the final decision is made. That would give both parties the ability to focus on themes instead of specifics. It also gives the interviewer the ability to say "You were a 99, but we had a 100 that had x." (Downside is time will increase the liklihood that memories of the interview will be different).Good Cop - Often there are multiple interviewers for a position. Companies could leverage this by having "good cop, bad cop" feedback. A "good cop" interviewer could compile feedback from the other interviewers and provide guidance from multiple (blind) sources. That person then shares the feedback. Even though feedback would have the same information, the interviewee would be much more receptive because they could assume the more "harsh" feedback is from the other interviewers.
Thanks - great input here - I've updated my concept thanks to all the great feedback I got.

I really like the idea, becuase you never know where you fail in your interview/resume. Was it the way you spoke? was insecurity? It is difficult to see yourself in perspective to know your weak points.There is a Spanish construction company, Acciona that has a blog about job search with advices and so on. It could be something similar, either posting common failures with specific examples (without the name, obviously) or the compromise of the company to "help you out" for your next interview. It would be something that the company could state on their Human Resources or CSR.
Forgot to say: How do you guys think we can encourage companies to do that? What benefits, apart from a good reputation, could the company get from advising people?

A good reputation should and probably will become of increasing importance in the future marketplace. Employers that provide good feedback to applicants, even if it is just a polite rejection, deserve to be acknowledged.

Agree, Paul. It's very frustrating to receive a 'no' email and no further feedback. Companies who don't provide feedback need to realize that people talk and the message spreads. There's the 'great place to work' survey in the Uk - I wonder if feedback could be included in the criteria!?
Thanks guys - great input here - I've updated my concept thanks to all the great feedback I got.

I fully support this idea, but it is not really feasible in practice. For example, in these harsh economic times the employer has to go through a larger number of interviews. Job interviewers should indeed be more empathic by giving more feedback, but this is too time consuming. And if they once run into an argument with a disappointed applicant, chances are big that they will no longer continue the feedback process for future applicants. Last but not least, and this is really the main reason why somebody with the right skills still does not get the job: the interviewer does not like the applicant for personal reasons... .
Thanks - I've updated the concept and added a web component based on your feedback - let me know what you think and whether you have any more builds.

I like the concept. The implementation of this would be the tricky part. Maybe there could be a website where the interviewee can "rate" the interviewer(or employer) on a ratemyprofessor.com type of interface. Positive experiences would lead to more of whatever the equivalent of what you are considering "merit points" to be. This could even be a recruiting tool for companies in the sense that strong candidates would be drawn to employers with a good track record of giving good interviews.This may lead to more accountability for the employer to be civil, treat the potential applicant with respect, not string anyone along, not low-ball any applicants, etc.  Great idea!
It's like a Yelp for employers! I like it :)
Bingo! Great call!
Nice build! We were also discussing this for rating internships over on the Inspiration phase. Great way to incentivise employers to make positive impact.

Great idea and important one. I truly believe that an interview should be a conversation going both ways. Indeed, the implementation is the tricky part. It will be important to make sure that interviewees know also what they are rating as you should be able to rate high an employer who does not give you the job but explain you why and in fact inspire to go and explore another direction! Incentives might work but I'm worried that it can introduce a willingness to "game the system". There might be also long term approaches in helping employers see how they will benefit of this approach. I'm not sure how though.

Thats the stuff, Bryan! Sites such as glassdoor.com are already doing similar things like what you have suggested albeit it's more geared toward a general job seeker screening companies to apply for and it is more one sided with the majority of reviews coming from past applicants. The trick is getting as much user participation from both sides to really make the project come alive.

That was a gret idea Nathan. I have always thought interviews teach something about market's needs and the chances to gain knowledge about unexpected questions, so that I can be prepared for next time.
Thanks everyone - especially Bryan - I've updated the concept and added a web component based on your feedback - let me know what you think and whether you have any more builds.

We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Our developers are busy working on it. Meanwhile, if you're wanting to iterate your ideas, you can use the comments feature to promote further conversation from others. We'll let you know once the bug is fixed, then you can incorporate your refinement moves into your concept post. Let's be agile, together!

Right on! Our development team have been busy fixing the Update Entry bug and we're back on track now. You'll now be able to edit your posts to add all that refinement-goodness to build out your concepts for improved impact. Bring it on, together!

It would be great if interviewees can get some decent feedback from the interviewer. As mentioned by Bryan, the tricky part is the implementation.What if the interviewee disagrees with the feedback, takes it the wrong way, and then (in the extreme case) pursues some kind of litigation for unfair rejection? For example, comments on the interviewee's presentability may lead to interviewees arguing that they were unfairly rejected as they were not as good looking as the chosen applicant.In the era of social media, any feedback from the company that's a bit off-the-mark can be instantly posted on the web, and all of a sudden the company has a public relations nightmare.Because the feedback can open the door for litigation or bad public relations, companies may be reluctant to give feedback. Mechanisms need to be put in place (e.g. training on what is permissable as feedback, legal disclaimers) so that the companies feel safe enough to proceed with this concept.

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:This concept has proved popular in terms of community applause and comments  presumably because everyone identifies with the frustration of putting your heart and soul into an interview and coming away with little or no feedback!  Given that everyone wil have go through this experience in their career, the panel liked the intention to try and turn it into a valuable learning experience. WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:The panel would you to explore best practice in this area as many employers already have policies about giving feedback that perhaps could be applied more widely.  They are also keen to hear your thoughts on how to balance quality of feedback with demands on the time of the interviewer...For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine.
oops! http://bit.ly/oi_refine
This is a cultural change that will benefit everyone. It will be as easy as some honesty at the end of an interview without promises. I would like to see this more often.
The feedback loop is critical.  Both benefit. Intrinsic motivation makes it self-sustaining.

I like this idea, I always thougt that a job interview should be a moment for us young professionals to analize the opportunity and to also interview the interviewer. I think it has become socially accepted to be somewhat exploited during Internship opportunities and dissmised without much feedback as a job applicant. I can only see this changing  if Universities prepare students for this siuation, a change in mentality is required on both sides I think.
Great concept Nathan!There is opportunity for two-way learning here.If it ok with you I will add this as a building component of my "great employer" register concept.
Of course Paul!

lets_not_presume_too_much.description: The challenge is to disseminate the existence of these free resources that we all know of and love. Reverse engineer this article.
lets_not_presume_too_much.creator: a6877ecc19c5784056e35444801eb4cf

comments.text: Interesting article. But could you tell us what you think of it, and what we could/should do to create (equal) opportunities for young people?

Hi Arjan,I could not say it better than commenter #3 "ryanc86" in the comments section of the article. In short, flabbergasted but also not surprised.  The filter bubble is strong among the citizenry of the internet.  The challenge is to step back and acknowledge access issues and critique the appropriateness of these services that we accept as given.  Is Code Academy appropriate? In the context of limited time and resources probably not. However, Black Girls that Code and Hacker Dojo might be a better platform in this instance.

Wow. I'm stunned that something like that was even posted. Regardless, I think we can take this message out of it: when we develop any type of product (for free, even), we should ask, "How can we make sure people actually use it?" That means focusing on both the dissemination (marketing) of the product, as well as its utility.
Yup I was stunned too. But, it highlights an unbridled techno-evangelism that is fairly pervasive even in more sensitive circles.

lets_not_presume_too_much.title: Lets Not Presume Too Much

toolbox.description: A online area where skills like Powerpoint, Excel, and any others that we can think of are taught in various forms. Print versions, Videos, Interactive do as you go lessons. It would really help fill the gaps in higher education.
toolbox.creator: 77f663204b060c92ae55d0172b2edfb5

comments.text: congrats! In addition to Lynda.com, Khan Academy: http://www.khanacademy.org/ is a great platform that has over 3000 videos in different fields and skills that are free to watch and learn. What I think is great and you could also incorporate is the skill testing sections that help you apply what you learned. cheers!

As a corporate IT trainer in some of these software packages I think this is a good idea and yes testing would be very appropriate, particularly in the self-instruction approach.A couple of things that can make a difference to an employee's usefulness (depending of course on their role) is a more in depth knowledge of how to apply some of these effectively.For example in Excel - my son now works in student administration for our local university - the staff time sheets had been set up in Excel with instructions to complete start and finish times with minutes as decimal fraction of an hour. Within a week of engagement he demonstrated (and had a change accepted) to record real start and finish times (with appropriate calculations). This is one of several efficiency dividends he has provided to his employer which are not really what he was employed to do but now make his position more secure because his skills are valued.Such a site as Toolbox might distinguish itself from others by providing real world scenarios and problems (not just exercises) to challenge the thinking and application of participants. Getting to know which tool is right for a given job is a skill that seems to have fallen by the wayside to some extent.Also suggest open source alternatives be included - especially for European situations.

As much time that students spend on their computers, they could be learning more then what is expected of them. I love this idea, though, I would imagine getting students inspired to learn these skills is a major hurdle, but perhaps that issue could be a part of the toolbox's approach?

Congrats - this is great! Similar to Khan Academy are other wonderful platforms out there for learning (both free and paid). Ones that I love include Coursera.org, Skillshare, CodeAcademy, and iTunes U. What I love about your idea is that your focus is on software that virtually every office looks for in many postings. In terms of how I can see this being executed, I would hone in on key software, then break each one down into sample case studies pertaining to specific industries since Excel knowledge would be different for someone working on an online SEO campaign vs. what a merchandise planner for a fashion wholesaler might need.

I want as many people as possible to give me input for this. What should the "tools" be? I want your ideas, let's shoot high and pare down from there. It's a whole lot easier to contract than expand. Put them in here in the comment box. Also if anyone can build this out, I would really appreciate that. I have no true technical knowledge so any assistance I can get would be so so helpful. Also another question I have is should we have SOFT SKILL work-spaces? I think that could add a whole new dimension to this. Let me know please! Thanks everyone!Tools-PowerPoint-Word-Excel-Oracle-SAP-Prezi-Outlook-Chatter/Jive/Moxie/Yammer-Anything else??

Creating feature-rich PDFs might be a good one too. And I wonder if you might reach out to some young folk to find out what kinds of tools they're currently using to see what directions they could extend into. And Lydia's suggestion about checking out Lynda.com is a great one, methinks. How might this kind of platform be tailored for youth? Excited to see where things go!

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:The panel felt that this idea addresses a very real but often unacknowledged issue  that many people simply aren't confident or competent when it comes to using basic software tools.  This idea is deceptively simple in that online learning isn't particularly new but it has the potential to scale and reach audiences beyond just young people  everyone in today's workplace needs to be familiar with these tools but polishing up your skills online is a good way to build confidence and competence without having to publicly admit you're not as good as you'd like to be.WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:The panel would like to see a few technical experts collaborate on this idea to help bring it to life a bit more  the intention is sound but the execution will be crucial so they're excited to see how this can be delivered in an engaging way that also gets results....For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine.

Thank you Lydia and Sabine, I think both of your ideas are great. I see this working with both of them. I want this to be almost Wikipedia-esque. Where people can post content to help young people excel in their first jobs. I am a 21 year old recent grad who just landed a position. I know that those first few weeks can be really really stressful. What would have helped me is just a great place to find basic tutorials about certain functions that I will probably use. If the tutorials were sorted by industry, with constant feedback, this could be an amazing site.I'll explore the two other sites further, and if you have any other suggestions I would love to hear them!

They provide great online training videos for people of all abilities but it's very much focussed on adults already in professional roles. I think you're idea is a great build on what they do already and I wonder if they might make an interesting partner for this concept (or at least source of further inspiration)?  I could see them hosting a section of their site called 'Get Ready For The Workplace' and putting together a curriculum of tutorials introducing young people to all the basics of the main software packages most employers would expect them to be familiar with.  Hope this is helpful - love the idea!

fake_it_til_you_make_it..description: Underrated soft skill: being able to pick what you want to do and tell a convincing story about how you chose. Paralysis of indecision can be a much greater risk than making the wrong decision.
fake_it_til_you_make_it..creator: 131ef8d572e0bad4e09aea8b42efe72f

comments.text: Great post. Made me think about whether we could do more to help young people through the big 'transition' moment from formal education into the working world. Yes, there are some that find the transition easy. For for many, they feel completely underprepared and perhaps suffer from having the wrong expectations placed upon. Could we design a new 'transition'... to replace the job hunting, taking exams/finals, summer holiday, start work cycle.

Just wanted to repeat a point you made here "The people who seemed to have it figured out, really just decided to figure it out."Something can be said about the power of just deciding. If you are right or wrong, you will be sure to find out.

I SO agree with you. How much time do people looking for jobs spend writing their CV vs crafting their story?Both are equally important BUT what it is more important is that you believe it.How many opportunities we let pass by looking for the "perfect" one that "aligns with my passion" and gives me the money?We rather focus on learning how to make a good job great! (Note: even entrepreneurs end up doing lost of little things if they are not careful).But, how can this be learnt?
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
Given you've told the story of this Inspiration very well, I can assume you're deemed to be a success. Certainly gave me a lot to reflect on!

I found your post very insightful too Joanne and it reminded me of the adjacent soft skill I wish I'd learned earlier in my career too - 'busking it'.  By which I don't mean faking things or being a charlatan but simply being okay sounding a lot more confident and convincing than you're actually feeling at times.  In my first job, my inability to 'busk it' when required and preoccupation with always having the courage of my convictions before doing anything got in my way a bit.  At times, I watched people who were no more skilled than me get ahead faster simply because they were prepared to 'wing it' at times and their confidence carried people along with them.I'm still not very good at 'busking it' but I've got better and I've found public speaking and presentations a good place to start.  You don't know what questions you'll be asked, you'll have to think on your feet and you can usually get a sense of whether your audience thinks you're still credible or not.  Thanks for the provocative inspiration - got me thinking too!

Funny - in my family we call it 'act as if' - that is, act as if you feel confident or act as if you know what you're doing. You may not always feel certain, but sometimes just pretending a little bit can help get you over the edge and start really moving forward. Great insights Joanne!

It is all about the sizzle. The greatest factor of "faking it until you make it" is confidence. Until one enters the work force and interacts with others there is a presumption that people actually know what they are doing. Those that figure out early to just start, and figure it out as they go along are leap years ahead. Great synthesis.

Hi Joanne. This is a great inspiration and a topic that was recently featured on Katie Couric's new video series "Katie's Take" where she interviewed Dr. Meg Jay from the University of Virginia. In her new book, according to the interview, she talks about how taking a job, any job out of college is important, for as you note, you'll most likely not end up in staying on one career path. Instead it is rather important to have a starting point, learn and then move forward. http://news.yahoo.com/blogs/katies-take-abc-news/mistakes-twentysomethings-125425006.html#more-id

Hi Joanne, I agree that taking a decision in the first place is the toughest part - because it feels like excluding so many opportunities. We are living in a world of data overflow; it requires a certain skill set to create sense out of all the data around, prioritize them in the context of your personal preferences (convert them into information), and then use this information to take a decision.Can this skill set be taught? Coaching?

I do think that it can be taught by presenting kids/young adults with opportunities to fail. The way you learn this is through trying something and failing. You realize that your world did not end and you can change gears.Did Steve Jobs take calligraphy because he knew one day this class would lead to an unmistakable design aesthetic? He took it because he liked it.

comments.text: Hi Kirsty, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. One of my best friends WWOOF'd a few summers ago and came back a changed -- and much improved -- person. In my discussions with her, she said it was one of the best, if not the best, experiences of her life. That said, how does this address the challenge? How does WWOOFing give people skills they need to succeed in today's ever-changing economic landscape?

skills_that_they_have.description: 16-24 is a fairly wide range that comes with a fairly wide array of qualifications, behaviours, and skills. I think we need to figure out who exactly are we building for before we can figure out what we are building.
skills_that_they_have.creator: 8aa1ef9afbb2e0799af4c96103a078e1

comments.text: That's true, but in previous recessions an 18 year old could stay in education, gain a useful qualification and be fairly sure that the economy would've picked up by the time they graduated.  It might be useful now to think 16-24 because we're looking at - at best - a jobless recovery and, at worst, a prolonged period of little or no growth of the kind Japan has faced since the '90s.

That's true. So maybe what would be really helpful would be looking at trends in the economy to see where the job growth is and encouraging 16-18 year olds to pursue education in those areas, and maybe even show specifics about the cheapest/most cost-efficient way to get education and experience in those areas?I think targeting high growth industries is something that some more experimental vocational schools have been picking up, like one in LA that was featured in Good Magazine whose name I can't remember...

Thats a good point, Jonathan. Perhaps thats one of the reasons why the question-framers decided to target the 16-24 range. At the same time though, 16-18 is an inherently different age than is 18+ because your life, technically speaking, is *not* in your own hands at that time.   I think this will play a big role in trying to answer the questionI do like Ollie's take on the problem. Although if we were looking at trends, we should be careful to account for what will be required in 10-15 years, if not longer, not just in the next 5 years. I also want to point out that higher education, i.e. college, doesn't necessarily equip you with real world skills except for vocational schools. College, as I see it, when not useful for vocational degrees is but a medium for maturity. If that IS true, then maybe the problem the underlying problem here is the lack of maturity and not necessarily lack of skills. But the solution to the economic problem is still skill! So, I think, what we need to start doing is raising awareness within the age group  (16-18) to allow them to appreciate economics and consequently, partake in skill building (whether that be through school or work opportunities.)

Nice take on the bigger picture.  Working for a small vocational-based university in a city that's experienced a post-industrial decline, I am nervous of the suggestion of focusing training on new industries - they've come and gone increasingly fast in the past 20 years in Dundee and in Scotland generally: NCR, Motorola, Hyundai, computer games firms and more.I like your suggestion of moving our focus on to maturity, and think that ties back neatly to helping young people gain a broad range of experiences, on the premise that we mature through gaining experience, by living life.How would it be if the final year or two of education was built around an experience curriculum rather than a didactic curriculum, when where what my children would describe as 'epic fails' gained you the grades, rather than regurgitating information from a set of textbooks?

Hi all! Interesting conservation. I like the thought about focusing on maturity as well as skill recognition. Furthermore, something that I think even individuals coming out of university have a hard time understanding is the difference between skills and strengths. Knowing this could provide young people with a great tool to succeed at the start of their careers.

Jonathan, thats an interesting point about training in new industries, especially in times of post-industrial decline. What usually happens in this period? I'm thinking that maybe focus should be shifted to skills that can be applied remotely like programming, or those required for telemarketing...?Didactic curriculum was going to be my next suggestion! Most universities, that I know, have some sort of internship component or foreign exchange built in. I would propose to take this one step further and follow the master-apprentiece model where the student is working directly with somebody and so is able to leverage their experience. Also, as you pointed out, marking systems will have to be changed to encourage failure; as that IS a big part of learning!You know Karina, thats a very good point. I find that most people, including some with years of experience, aren't sure as to their strengths and weaknesses. Then again, how to go about these except through experiencing the world; so this reinforces the point of gathering different experiences, which leads to maturity!

Important thoughts, Naman. We can't treat all the same. But what I think is valuable, is to understand what skills are needed to not only give youth the best chances to be productive, but also the economy the best chances to make a better recovery. And from there on, we could break that down into how to help certain age groups.

Yes of course, I completely agree. But I think we need to account for the fact that different age groups have different conditioning/circumstances which make them suitable and receptive to certain skills in certain areas.Let me copy/paste an excerpt from my first reply to Jonathan Staal:But the solution to the economic problem is still skill! So, I think, what we need to start doing is raising awareness within the age group (16-18) to allow them to appreciate economics and consequently, partake in skill building (whether that be through school or work opportunities.)
What about the home situation? Living with parents or on their own?
Excellent point, Anita, added!

skills_that_they_have.title: Youth Perspective!

comments.text: This is a great idea for the economy in general, and their may be some flow on effect to youth unemployment by encouraging young entrepreneurship/businesses... but think this idea is not directly targeting the people who are actually likely to unemployed.   People who'd likely be targeted, in my opinion, would already be the ones likely to find employment. (Sorry to be black hat).

Hi Tristan, thank you for your feedback. I agree that this concept does not fit all young and unemployed persons. Two reasons made me come up with this concept:First talking to an entrepreneur I found out, that he does not hire the ones with the best grades. For him it was very important to hire passionate people. So he hired some enthusiasts without the perfect CV who were unemployed at that time and gained great new team members. Thats why I think the personal contact is very important. Some kind of platform could help there.Secondly I was surprised finding out during my studies in Italy how much young and very talented people are without a job there. Nowadays its very difficult for every young person to find a job. So there it is difficult to say who would likely to be unemployed. A lot of time its about knowing someone. Here also a platform could be one possible solution.Im really curious to get your feedback on my thoughts and get a deeper understanding during our discussion.

Hi Sabine!Happy to have inspired your concept :) I like they way you've described how each of the three audiences 'can do' things. I'm sure that'll trigger interest from them. How could we make this event stand out even more, amongst the existing big events like Le Web and other events showcasing startups? Just wondering what your thoughts are on this it's a tough industry out there and I also think I might have the same problem with the Young Unemployed Conference, and making it stand out when we launch.

Hi Ana Cecilia,you raise a very good question. Thank you for sharing this thoughts. I just had a look at Le Web and found as slogan "perfect mix of entrepreneurs, large companies, influencers, VCs and journalists.". One differencing factor is the focus on talents and involving them. In my eyes this is also one of the highlights of the Young+Unemployed Conference. To stand out next to the existing big events is a great challenge. A pilot event with success stories can help. As well as the support of governmental organizations.Id love to elaborate further on this with you. What are your thoughts on this?

primary_school_exposing_the_children_to_.creator: 5484563cef1f121eed6f115440959554

comments.text: NishantI work with a school in Hyderabad, India, where oftentimes the emphasis is just getting through each page of the text, not necessarily engaging with it. And between holidays and exam days and such, teachers seem fairly pressed for time "to cover" the material. When do you think would be the best way to fit something like reading newspapers? Convince teachers to put off the lesson and read articles as classwork? Offer it only for students in tuition hours? Any further ideas/thoughts re: engaging the real world in India's classrooms would be helpful.

On a tangent  I thought you both might find interest this Inspiration we got way back on the Low Cost Education Tools Challenge which is more about self direction than monitored reading of newspapers: http://www.openideo.com/open/how-might-we-increase-the-availability-of-affordable-learning-tools-educational-for-children-in-the-developing-world/inspiration/enhancing-knowledge-sharing-through-expression-magnets/

Hi Karolle,First of all, one have to understand the education setup in India concentrate on the wrong factors. Emphasis on 'covering' material isn't going to work out unless the material is properly understood my the students (an insight who must have had in your experience).A school day is usually is divided into periods. One can dedicate one such period (30-45 mins) for a class, where their 'class teacher' can engage them in this activity. It would not require any preparation for a socially aware person (read teachers) to engage in such activities. There should be clear rules that this specific time period should not be used for any other purposes...More Ideas? Take the course from just text based to visual based. What I mean is:To teach English (any language), Show them good english movies with subtitles.To teach History, show them History Channel. For Geography, show them documentaries like Frozen Planet. Integrate various documentaries (should be chosen for their impartiality) in the pedagogy.Make them aware of real world with documentaries like An Inconvenient Truth, Inside Job, Too Big to Fail.... but enough work should be done beforehand so that the audience actually understand what they are watching...

dual_education_system.creator: 9c679ade98a2038026b2a5dc3dc3178b

comments.text: In Germany, dual education is also established on the tertiary level. Students have a contract with a company throughout their undergraduate course and work between the semesters. Usually, they have the possibility get involved in different departments and hence gain experience in various fields as well as decide what they like for themselves. One university offering such courses is the Baden Wuerttemberg Cooperative State University: http://www.dhbw.de/english.html

This used to be a feature of Australian tertiary education too.With an upturn in the number of graduates from appropriate disciplines there was a gradual decline in this followed by a downturn in manufacturing this has all but completely disappeared.Globalisation has contributed too.I am glad to see these approaches surviving elsewhere.Certainly we have adopted a similar model to the Swiss one as Australia focuses more on service type industries.

dual_education_system.title: Dual Education System

work_experience_as_part_of_secondary_edu.description: A while back, we had the son of a manager visiting our office for a week, to experience the life in a workplace. This week was an integrated part of his education. Obviously, we created a nice program for him, so he got to see many facets.
work_experience_as_part_of_secondary_edu.creator: 6fed0e6f1ba44f0520bc14fceee3663d

comments.text: Wish I had done more work experience as a teenager to see multiple fields......

Interesting story Arjan.My wife works as a teacher in the senior secondary system here in Tasmania. We, along with the rest of Australia, have a VET (Vocational Education and Training) system where students take blocks of paid work experience as part of their schooling.The payment is of particular importance, and protected by law, because these students need to be given valued recognition for their efforts.
Good point, Paul. I think a valued recognition is good, but as a first step of getting familiar with what working looks like, it can be a different story.

I like this a lot. How cool of your office to let the kid experience so many different facets of this particular workplace. Whatever the kid chose, I'm sure this experience helped him in a positive way toward building his future.To build on this, I am a recent college grad, and have had the opportunity to see a lot of my friends try to get themselves into the workplace. It seems like they all are trying to get internships such as the one you describe, where they can split their time between learning about the company/industry, and doing productive work. However, more often than not, I've seen these end up as "unpaid labor", disguised as "paying their dues". Unfortunately, this results in them getting very little in the way of horizon broadening experience, and the employer is getting free labor for something they would otherwise have to pay someone to do. Often times they don't even care about the professional development of the intern, and otherwie ignore them except for when they are needed to do gruntwork, etc.What a shame internships have continued to slide more and more into this model of paying ones dues, and not toward broadening the horizons of the intern. I wonder if there could be more of a balance here.I don't know if I have a solution to this yet, but I can't help but wonder how these types of arrangements impact the 18-24 year old crowd? Does anyone have any thoughts on this?

Interesting thoughts. The case I described was really intended, also from the school's teaching program, to get insight in the going-ons of a workplace. That's how his visit was planned.I think there are different levels. From a first 'getting-to-know' phase to more 'experience-the-work'. If someone adds value through that, I think it's fair they should get some compensation.

work_experience_as_part_of_secondary_edu.title: Work experience as part of secondary education

job_vlog.description: Job Vlog = personal video of an occupation. This community will expose young adults to different types of jobs via online videos, and help build students' professional network, which can lead to meaningful internships and/or mentorships.
job_vlog.creator: d910aa696a1fbe9d89fa0f5005c8650b

comments.text: Interesting idea. You should definitely link it with the uninternship concept (that's how I found your concept). I like how you thought through many of the practical issues and details to take into account as a sharer. Re. your comment about the company, I could see the person not mentioning her / his company. However, it would be always quite easy to find out where is the person working.I am wondering if there are not 2 concepts in one and what are the connections between the seekers and the sharers.You could either consider having 2 concepts, or maybe articulating more the 2 aspects of the concept.

Hi Anne-Laure, thank you for your comment. Yes, there are two driving factors in my concept. From previous discussions with new grads, I believe there are two major problems that are preventing young adults from finding a fulfilling job. The first problem: Many students do not know what type of job they want to pursue. I hoped to mitigate this problem by providing a collection of online videos, which show the inner workings of each profession. These videos may narrow down or reveal options that are aligned with the student's skills, goals, and interests. The second problem: students do not have access to mentors or people already in the industry to help them get their foot in the door. Some students may already know where they want to go in their career, but are having a difficult time entering into the industry for whatever reason. I wanted to build an online community that will support the future generation by offering meaningful advice or pointing a qualified Seeker in the direction of a job opening.I incorporated two phases (an initial discovery/job sampling phase and an ongoing mentorship/networking phase) because I approached the problem as a whole. Not only did I want to help students figure out what they wanted, but also facilitate the job acquirement. I felt that the cycle to increase employment levels is incomplete without the second component. I drew up a simple cycle to visually show both phases described in my idea. I hope that clarifies why I have two factors in one. Also, I will think of a better way to organize my description so that the two phases and relationships between the Seeker and Sharer are more obvious.

job_vlog.title: Job Vlog: find your passion with an insider

_skunkworks_projects_for_youths_.description: Every company has a few ideas "on the backburner" that aren't getting done for whatever reason. With this concept, companies would be able to recruit the services of small teams that have a diverse skillset that could be applied to these back issues.
_skunkworks_projects_for_youths_.creator: b92bcb1d34902944042a06194179d467

comments.text: Hi Imran -- I too am a real fan of this concept.  Its strategic, creative and collaborative.  It also gives young people an authentic and credible way to refine their talents and explore new skills and interests -- together.Its just the sort of thing I would imagine being nurtured at Lab 21.What if young people received a Skunkworks badge of honor of sorts for completed projects?  It would be one way to support confidence, build camaraderie and elicit further recognition.
That's a great idea Sasha, and I totally see this working in an environment like Lab 21!

Hi Imran...How are you?I'm still really in love with Skunkworks and would LOVE to incorporate it into the evaluation phase of LAB21.  It would be great to get some more thoughts from you on developing the concept further.  I think it could be a great starter project for LAB21.I was also thinking that Strengths Finder 2.0 would be a great starter tool to help each LAB21 member ascertain his or her particular strengths, talents, skills, etc.  Then he or she could glean some insight from his/her personalized strengths finder report.  Lab Stewards would then help connect students to the right Skunkworks projects based on a list criteria that would also give some weight to the strengths Finder results.  The point being that members would be matched to projects that play on their strengths and interests leading to greater opportunities for work/life balance.If you're not familiar, here's a link to strengths finder: http://www.strengthsfinder.com/home.aspxLooking forward to your response and possible builds ;-).

Great idea, Imran. A similar model was used in my engineering program, and the experience exceeded all expectations. In hindsight, I wish this collaborative-real world learning was incorporated more into my university studies. It would be exciting to see how this concept can be implemented into high schools as well. Perhaps, a club can be dedicated to these work endeavors? Students, faculty, mentors, and school board trustees can encourage participation from companies and any external clients looking for extra help.

I think this idea has great potential. Youth can be easily employed for the purpose of forming skunkworks teams and used for the purpose of organization experimentation. This would also help the organization retain a progressive edge.
Thanks Si Liang! I think this could definitely be a great idea.

Cool idea. How would the youth get teamed up? Would they be pre-existing, or should they be assembled for every individual project? Would there be a "pool" of youth to pick from, or would the youth pick the projects? I can sort of visualize some different options for how it could work, but what are your ideas?

Great idea Imran, and Ola - terrific questions! I'm also curious to think about what kind of organization is best suited to essentially "matchmake" between teams of young people and companies with these kinds of projects. Might it be its own nonprofit? Or is there a for-profit business model in here somewhere? Looking forward to seeing this concept develop.

Ola, Ashley - thank you so much for the comments!Ola - there's plenty of room for different strategies here, but I think that maintaining a pre-existing team would be the best option. Of course there would be room for changes within a team roster, but maintaining a team (particularly if that team is successful) would be a core component of this concept.  I think the youth would be able to pick the project based off of their interest, and project mentors would make sure that the team has a well rounded roster that include technical and managerial members. Initially, individual youth would select projects that they are interested in, but in subsequent projects it would be a team effort. Ashley - I think a separate entity that plays the role of "matchmaker" is essential. Whether or not that entity is a for-profit or non-profit is up the in the air. From a for-profit perspective, one business model that might work would be a model where companies would award a contract to a team and the business entity takes a piece of that money to cover expenses and keep building new teams. Thanks again for the comments, guys!

_skunkworks_projects_for_youths_.title: "Skunkworks" Projects for youths

data_driven_thinking.description: Wherever and whenever possible, data should be used to inform decision making. You don't have be a quantitative or statistical expert. Rather, everyone can learn to think  empirically and to analyze data to improve performance.

comments.text: I think this is incredibly important on many levels. The obvious one is the way data is becoming more important to our economy, meaning that data-literate young people will be more employable. But I also think it's empowering and confidence-boosting to be data literate - being better able to interpret the world around you.
I hope that understanding how to draw conclusions from data has become part of every school's curriculum!

I'll add that we should teach students how to collect data properly. Two handy rules for data collection: a set of data means nothing if more than one variable is changing at a time; and correlation is not causation.

when_i_grew_up_a_career_exploration_and_.creator: d1769ed2630f9e9feb43b057a0fa58ad

comments.text: I think this is a great concept, and definitely a tool that I wish had been available to me when I graduated college! I feel it would be especially beneficial to showcase the paths of young professionals who have only ten to fifteen years of work experience - around ages 28 to 33 - that students could relate to more. I also think that many young people today are encountering a work experience gap between their generation and their parent's generation, who most likely have had the same career for twenty or thirty years, so to feature a young professional who has had multiple roles would be important as well.

Ah, great concept! Thanks for drawing my attention to this. :-) I feel it is important for people to consider multiple aspects of our interests when asking these questions, especially when we are young. I enjoyed mathematics as a child, so naturally my father (who worked in an insurance company) suggested I explore being an actuary. That career path, however, is completely contrary to my nature! My meandering path during college got me on the right track. :-)

This is a great concept! I know that I would have appreciated this when I was in high school or completing my undergraduate degree, truthfully I would find it interesting and inspirational now too :). This could be something that really opens the world of possibilities for many people. Showing that success comes in many forms and it doesn't always come from following a standard path. It would be interesting if the successful people profiled served as online mentors for the young people using the site.

Cool concept Kade!  I wonder if you could also incorporate "featured paths" that highlight the roads that inspirational figures took to get where they are.  Becoming successful at something may seem much more achievable if we bring our idols "down to earth".

Hi Kade.I definitely like this inspirational aspect here. Personally, it was a bit of a journey to find out what I wanted to actually do and work in, and I was influenced and inspired by knowing what others were doing!
Congrats on being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Great thoughts about reality and success, Kade!

BTW: I won a Kentucky Fried Chicken colouring competition at age 6. I later wanted to become a doctor like both my parents. But I did a BA in Anthropology instead. Then I was missing colouring in and went to design school. I dropped out to start a job as a junior graphic designer. I then got fired for a mistake that it was later shown I didn't make. I started freelancing. I set up my own graphic design company. I started teaching graphic design globally. I stumbled on the field of design for social innovation & got interested in that. Somehow I ended up doing another stint in advertising and realised my heart was really no longer in it. I set up a consultancy which explored the intersection of communication, culture and creativity and my heart really was in it. As part of my research I check out OpenIDEO. They tweeted a job description for a Community Manager. These days I work as a Community Manager / Cross-pollinator on OpenIDEO, collaborating with switched-on folk from all over the world via my home on the Edge of Paradise in New Zealand. Maturity is not my strong point  but I guess this is what happened When I Grew Up!
That's one in the bank. Thanks for sharing, Meena!

I think this idea highlights a very important concept.  I love that it honestly showcases that life is a path of both successes and setbacks.  In the OpenIDEO challenge regarding entrepreneurship, there was a post about the need to share failures.  Indeed the job market today may be discouraging to youth, but I hope most will find this a minor setback and strive to move forward.  Your idea demonstrates that this is possible.  Well done, Kade!

how_a_teapot_and_twitter_got_me_a_job_of.description: When I graduated I realised that just sending out CVs and covering letters was not going to cut it in this job market.  I think that we should be encouraging youth to be a bit more creative in their job hunt, both from a school level, aswell as uni.
how_a_teapot_and_twitter_got_me_a_job_of.creator: db88445cd51ffb1c8e4141d0493ebfdc

comments.text: What a fantastic story - thanks for sharing with the community - I'm now following you on Twitter so this approach is still making a difference I guess! (@thulme)
Nice story, this really inspiring for all of the people that don't know how to connect their careers with what they loved or even what they are good at.

This is a fantastic story and so inspiring! I think the best takeaway is that traditional methods of job search and doing the minimum to be successful in school are not enough. For years, society has marketed a promise that higher education will lead to employment. Work hard, get into a good school, study and get good grades, earn a diploma, and you'll have a job waiting for you at the end of it all to reward your efforts. So many students feel cheated, now that they're graduated, that this so-called social compact hasn't paid dividends yet.What this promise fails to account for is that the number of college graduates with good schools, grades, and diplomas is growing every year, while the number of entry-level jobs is most certainly not. Doing the bare minimum will not differentiate applicants from a crowd of hundreds and thousands of fellow graduates who look exactly like on paper. Of course, we shouldn't encourage every student to start shipping off bits and bobs and teapots because that's the easy answer! Each job seeker's "solution" to the job search problem should come from their own individual strategy and be tailored to their desired industry.Your initiative, moxie, and creative outside-the-box thinking in your job hunt showed that you were a risk-taker, that you had a desire above and beyond book learning to enter the field you were interested in pursuing, that you'd planned your targets carefully and strategically, and that you're capable of follow through on those plans. That's a far stronger narrative than any resume/CV alone. Bravo!Paper achievements are no proxy for creativity, ingenuity and initiative. We need to train and encourage self-starters. Education and careers cannot be a passive pursuit. Nothing gets handed to us anymore.

Thanks James for sharing your story! I applied for Founder's assistant at Twitter.  I took my resume deconstructed it into 140 character bits put them inside of Easter eggs. Nested those amid blue Peeps and set the entire thing off to Ev. Turned out he filled the position 24 hours prior to getting my "resume," but I did stand out and he emailed me the same day it was delivered.  I also sent a chocolate high heel nestled in a box of feathers that were colored in Zappos brand colors. My cover letter was an entry into their culture book as if I had worked there for 10 years. I also redrew the logo mark as a dance step that spelled WOW (one of the brand values). I got a call in an hour and was kicked back to HR. HR did not get me at all. It all turned out for the best! Get noticed and I think at some point the right fit will happen. Be bold and daring!

James, this is a great example of creativity in context + Persistence. The important part is that you tied your creative CV to something that contextually mattered and made sense to them.Really cool man. Thanks for the inspiration for when I start my job search.

Nice story James. It's a great example of the principle of 'optimize, not maximize'. The thoughtfulness and attention you exhibited in the job-hunt process is as much or more relevant in professional practice. ..resonate with your target audience. Connect on an emotional (or in this case, sensorial) level. Good stuff.

Great story James! Understanding your audience and persistence (and use of different media) were key. Yet, even more important I believe was understanding what you really want to do and what you could bring to a company.

James, this is such a fun and inspiring story! What I love best - which I think is worth calling out - is the fact that you took time to really study and understand the people, culture and company you were trying to reach out to. It's one thing to be creative about how to present yourself; it's another to do it in a way that shows you're picking up on cues and paying attention to the details. Great job!
Great story, James. It illustrates perfectly the gap between workplaces and education. Especially the part about integration of campaigns.
Such an inspiring story James,  I can only commend you on your effort and hopefully one day I can be as persistent of achieving my goals as you :)

how_a_teapot_and_twitter_got_me_a_job_of.title: How a teapot and twitter got me a job offer after graduating

youthcafe.description: For young people who are in the middle of job seeking and may be suffering from isolation in front of their computers, YouthCafe is a bi-weekly meetup where young people in similar situations can get together and work on projects or share stories.
youthcafe.creator: e271b7c6ed709feca8776fd4f9b91e86

comments.text: Update on YouthCafe: The OpenIDEO Student chapter at NYU-Poly, inspired by the YouthCafe at IDEO New York, is launching their own YouthCafe: A series of workshops and networking events for students interested in learning skills necessary for employment and share stories.. More here: http://greenhousestories.com/
this is great Ashwin - do send across photos when you have them :)
Now that it has been a couple months, how it the workshop panning out? Is it what it was intended to be?
Photos and reviews are up from my prototype YouthCafe event on Wednesday night. Check it out: http://www.meetup.com/YouthCafe/events/82116972/

Hi!  I've given a nod to YouthCafe within LAB21.  Looking forward to seeing it thrive.  Also wanted to share the below with you but you're probably already looped in ;-).The Feast on Good Conference (http://worldwide.feastongood.com/)It made me think of the Young and Unemployed Conference but I also thought about what the YouthCafe would look like as a global movement and its something really amazing to look forward to.

The concept worth spreading! From my experience, as a consultant and coach, it is most challenging to get people motivated and sometimes "poking the box" (following Seth Godin) is the most difficult thing to do. What works really great in such cases is making a sort of obligation towards another person. It can aslo be a reciprocal obligation to do some work. People in pairs can promise each other to make some kind of research, plan or calculation in favour of other person. This means, all ideas or solutions will get a sort of validation from the outside, the motivation will be high as "I know she is doing it for me. I have to do it for her", and the "doing" part is going to happen.Cross my fingers for your first meeting in September! I wish I could be there :)

Really Great idea. There is a similar organisation called Meet Up in the UK that offer group meetings in several locations and across a massive variety of interests/skills. You can go along to meetings with people with the same interests or motivation as you, which can also allow more in-depth and focussed discussions. What can be quite daunting about them, however, is that there is not much discussion prior to meetings and young people are scarce. Could be an idea to have skills/interest-specifc meetings similar to that of Meet Up. These can be supported by an online forum to enable people to interact prior to meeting so that they don't feel they are going alone without knowing anyone. For example, a meeting for people interested in Marketing could be kick-started on an online forum by asking people to comment on a campaign by a company such as Apple. This can enable people to get into the right mind frame, feed off each others ideas, build confidence, and most importantly be motivated to go!Definitely worth persuing this idea!
Hi Nina, Thanks!I've just used Meetup.com to create an event for YouthCafe. Check it out http://www.meetup.com/YouthCafe/events/82116972/Would welcome your feedback.

Hey Haiyan, Great, sounds good! I think the first step is to provide a space - what I think most people do when starting out is to just take over a bit of a cafe or pub and have a generally discussion about a certain area where people could contribute and ask questions. Almost like a seminar set up but obviously more relaxed. Once you gauge how many people are likely to turn up, we could think about renting a regular space. I think keep costs low to start with and generate interest by posting what is discussed at each meeting. Could set up a Facebook group? I think you could structure it in one of two ways; you could either post a question such as "Evaluate the latest Marketing campaign by Barcardi" and people can get some ideas together to discuss at the meeting, then during the meeting the group can collaborate ideas and consolidate, then post the final idea on an online group for people to look at. Or, we could invite people to speak about the industry they work in, such as "A Day in the Life of......", for example your experience in a Design and Innovation company and how you got there, people with experience in Digital Marketing etc.Let me know what you think!
Hi Nina, please feel free to RSVP if you can make it: http://www.meetup.com/YouthCafe/events/82116972/

Great concept! I think many people would find value and comfort coming to a place to work together, even if they are doing the search on their own. This concept reminded me about ING Direct Cafes, which is a different take on the banking experience and just focusing on providing services and cafe atmosphere for people. Youth cafe helpers could be a resource and a speaker series would be nice to incorporate. I like the idea of sponsorship, which helps with the costs of hosting an event. It would be interesting if the Youth Cafes could change locations or host in different locations to reach more people too.
Thanks Annie! Check out the first YouthCafe meetup I've setup: http://www.meetup.com/YouthCafe/events/82116972/

I love this idea because it brings young people out of their comfort zone to quickly remind them that they are not alone in the search for meaningful, fulfilling and rewarding work. The ideal venue for this sort of community gathering sounds like it might just be the Next Door Cafes, brain-powered by State Farm and IDEO! I have been privileged to visit one in the Lakeview neighborhood of Chicago, and felt both welcomed and driven while in the space. I would gladly attend YouthCafe group meetings, and know many others who would be eager to join the network of like-minded people!

Hi Claire,Thanks for your feedback! I've just scheduled the first one on Sept 26 in London (not sure if you are here). It's on Meetup.com: http://www.meetup.com/YouthCafe/events/82116972/I love the idea of having a creative, dedicated space and wonder how this might translate to events that move from place to move. How can we imbue it with the same sense of a new environment?I'd welcome your suggestions for events or workshops that might be interesting.-Haiyan

Right on! Our development team have been busy fixing the Update Entry bug and we're back on track now. You'll now be able to edit your posts to add all that refinement-goodness to build out your concepts for improved impact. Bring it on, together!

We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Our developers are busy working on it. Meanwhile, if you're wanting to iterate your ideas, you can use the comments feature to promote further conversation from others. We'll let you know once the bug is fixed, then you can incorporate your refinement moves into your concept post. Let's be agile, together!

I love how this idea takes people away from the screen and promotes face-to-face interaction. To incentivize wary job seekers, we might want to incorporate specific focus to the meet ups so the attendees understand how showing up could lead to a job. Here are some thoughts:A.  The meetings should be age-specific so that there is an inherent sense of belonging to a group with the same struggle. There is a large maturity gap between 18 and 26, for example, and I doubt people on opposite ends of the spectrum would have a sense of value in workshopping together.A1. Certain meet ups could provide opportunity for older members to mentor the younger ones.B.  Each meeting should concentrate on a particular subject, broad enough so anyone would benefit from attending, but still focused so participants know they will gain new knowledge and skills from the event.B1. Guest speakers with careers in different industries could host or participate.C.  The organizing body should reach out to the professional community in order to encourage mentorship.

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:The panel described this concept as 'essentially a job centre but one that appeals to young people and is less intimidating.'  They like the way it builds on the MeetUp culture that is already emerging and helps to offset the isolation and lack of motivation that many jobseekers feel.  Although there were several concepts around physical space (including Lab 21 which has also been shortlisted) this concept was more structured than others around what would actually happen at these events.  WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:The challenge for this idea is to ensure that young people themselves feel motivated enough to self-organise and meet up.  For this to work, they really need to take ownership of this initiative so the panel are keen to hear thoughts on how to ensure this idea develops a momentum of its own...For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Write a practical idea... I propose the problem is getting them in the door in the first place. The significant number of unemployed youths are not the ones who are easy to reach and get to show up.
Write? I meant, Great practical idea... anyway.
Great way for community members to collaborate/mentor youth. I'd love to see a rotating *pop-up* in different neighborhoods, especially underserved communities.

I love this idea! Your idea of having businesses offer space and facilitation expertise is a jewel. This way youth can begin buiidling relationships with potential employers- which in turn keeps youth motivated because they know that there is potential for networking/getting noticed by people who can hire or refer them. How would this initiative outreach to different demographics of youth and ensure an inclusive and diverse environment?

Interesting concept. To me this sounds like bringing together the best of a Starbucks(lots of tables, chairs, outlets, beverages, food, etc), a library(town-center, hangout place), and a career center on a college campus(resources, events, etc specifically for business-people, job seekers, and professional growth oriented people.)I think in order for a concept like this to really take off, you may have to broaden the horizon of this just a smidge. Unemployment is cyclical, so what happens during a good economy? When there are limited job seekers, a place like this could go out of business. Just something to let bounce around in our heads for a bit. I don't really have a solution, just pointing out something to consider. Some possible ideas to build upon:1. Let parts of this place get rented out to professional groups like Toastmasters, etc.2. Host networking or recruiting events for companies, local businesspeople, etc. 3. Have study rooms to rent out, or collaborative spaces available. Check out what people are doing in Lower Manhattan at Hive 55- http://hiveat55.com/   or even http://sunshineny.com/  Its pretty cool, and certain aspects of these types of places could easily be integrated into a youth cafe like you are suggesting.4. Charge a modest membership fee so that people feel like they are part of a community, and also feel like they have some "skin in the game".4a. For members, immediately connect them with someone who is a mentor figure who can get the started on their professional growth, getting hired with the right company, taking advantage of the resources available at the youthcafe, etc. This is all just brainstorming stuff I'm throwing out there. Sparking any ideas?

Interesting, I read the concept more as something that people can organise in already existing locations. Sort of like the Open Coffee Club concept.As for your remark about the good economic times, maybe then YouthCafe can focus on next career steps.

Agreed Arjan and great concept Haiyan.Need not be an expensive exercise (I guess depending on venue).Most such venues probably have slow business times when perhaps such meetups could be scheduled.This could be the genesis of some OpenIDEO Local Chapters where there might be some focus on employment issues, some on local challenges and some on open challenges.

Bryan, I think point 4a could be a very important one. While building skills and relationships in this format is helpful, the reality is that without an experienced mentor that can vouch for the skills you've gained, it may not lead to jobs. Having someone to guide you and vouch for you is so important!
Great ideas Bryan. I would give more thought to charging a small fee as this may deter the youth who really need this kind of service.
Cool concept. And to start with the kit, I think we can use the OI Brainstorm Kit as starting point. Exciting.
Great idea! I wonder what should go into the kit. It's been a while since I left school :)

It has probably been longer for me than almost anyone on OpenIDEO, but I do like this concept. In addition to the virtual and paper components I am tempted to suggest a basic Lego kit, jigsaws and board games.Something that could encourage inter-disciplinary discussions would broaden outlooks too.I know I keep bringing this up in almost every concept but I think the IDEO/biology collaboration in the USGBC challenge is a great example of what can happen when disparate fields of endeavour are brought together.I often wonder too how many people know the origins of wi-fi (or going back further winsock).Sometimes the past as well as the present can stimulate thinking for the future.

Im just about going to finish my education in winter. During school teachers have a defined program they have to do. And during my school time the IT teacher was not always up to date. But there were some young people at school who were really good at it. So in my opinion everyone has a talent and something I can learn from him or her. In the young people going to the workshop in the cafs could find out what their talent is and share it with others. What about supporting with a kit:- at first what the young participants are good at- second help them prepare a workshop on their special talent- third support them in learning from each other during that workshop
Thanks for this perspective from the point of view of someone in the target cohort.

Haiyan, I would be happy to help you work something out from this.I agree with Bryan that there may be some promise in broadening the concept so that young people support each other as well in the early stages of new jobs. I know the idea of co-working is more about people working side by side who would otherwise work in an isolated way, but would it work for there to be connected meetups that offer a possibility of continuing interaction and mutual trouble-shooting for young people in the first stages of their first jobs? Various professions have supportive cohorts outside the work place where people can safely work through problems with people with similar jobs but not in the same organization. For example there are groups for teachers that cut across schools. There could even be a mentor or two attached to the meetup to assist in such trouble-shooting.

I like this concept a lot. Would really help networking and job mobility. Maybe those groups could get free meeting space/time if they host an event where they field questions/provide mentoring/connect with young people who want to break into those industries. For example, a teachers meeting group could host an event where people who have just graduated from college with a teaching degree can connect and help each other.
Great idea! I think communication is key in finding and preataring for a new job. Also it can be a great place to build young people's confidence leve.

Very nice! We often underestimate how isolation and lack of basic resources (internet, printer, phone, cash) can hold back someone looking for a job.I think in the USA there is something ran by the Government, at least this movie shows a place where unemployed ppl  go for help and counselling: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xa5qg7cB1ZQ.I would like to join this team btw!
Congrats for this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

py/tuple: IMPACT & REACH: How much impact and reach do you think this concept could have in helping young people transition into the world of work?
A great deal – something like this would really make a difference
A moderate amount – it’s certainly helpful but probably not a game-changer
Not very much – it’s unlikely to make a significant difference to young people seeking work

FEASIBILITY & RESOURCES: Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible will it be for your community to turn this concept into a reality?  (Hint: when you think about resources, think: people, money, time, technology, infrastructure, partnerships and any other inputs for implementation)
Highly feasible – resources wouldn’t be an issue for my community if we tried to implement this
Moderately feasible – my community could do it if we could get find assistance with some of our resource constraints
Not feasible – it would be almost impossible for my community to implement this concept; it's just too resource-intensive
SUSTAINABILITY & LONGEVITY: Does this concept feel like it could be sustained as a project, business or movement over years rather than just months? Will continue to be relevant in future?
Yes – this concept has enough momentum to stand on its own two feet and remain relevant for years to come
Maybe – it’s not clear how long it would take for this concept to stand on its own feet or how it will continue to be but there’s reason to feel hopeful
No – this concept will have trouble sustaining itself in the long-run and probably won’t be as relevant in years to come
ORIGINALITY: How new or innovative is this idea? Are there many different versions of this concept out there already or is this something more disruptive and unique?
Very original – I’ve not seen anything else quite like it
Fairly original – there are similar things out there but this particular version brings a new element to the table
Unoriginal – there are already too many other concepts out there that are similar to this one
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world
I liked it but preferred others
It didn't get me overly excited

comments.text: Dale has one of the best resource lists for self educating online. He was a Thiel Fellow, where Peter Thiel payed kids not to go to college.  Ill build on this and add their info.
Yes, and he wrote his own book: http://www.uncollege.org/book/
I thought I would add Dale's learning plan to this conversation. http://www.uncollege.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/PERSONAL-Learning-Plan-WEB.htm

Kind of funny when he says "We don't go to college knowing exactly what we want to major in." I explicitly chose 10 with my major and then majored in it. Due to the logistics of prerequisites and classes offered in the spring but not fall or vice versa, there's some majors you can't do unless you plan on it at the beginning of your four years' of college or however much longer it takes you.

comments.text: I can imagine there also being a feature which gives various career options if you enter what skills / interests you have. While I think it's fine that some people get fixed on a particular profession it might also be valuable to help people think sideways about the multiple potential paths based on their skills / interests too? I never could have imagined my current job as Community Manager /Cross-pollinator on OpenIDEO  but perhaps if I put in skills / interests like design, social innovation, collaboration, social media, communications, etc  then Online Community Management may have come up for me on a site like this?

That is a great idea to add this component. Making suggestions about potential jobs widen peoples mind and options. That is really helpful to use career path and success stories as possible role models. And to derive career suggestions from it.The idea behind showing more than one way to reach a goal is meant to be as motivation to take decisions. Having so many options to choose from can be quite difficult as well. During the talks with a lot of friends about the next steps after graduation, there is often the concern of doing the wrong decision. So it would be very helpful to show that there is not only a right or a wrong decision but different ways to go.

Great thoughts, Sabine. Feel free to incorporate any feedback & new thoughts that you're keen on into your actual concept post to acknowledge your idea is evolving through these collaborative conversations. Thank you for the feedback and the hints. Since this is my first challenge Im still exploring the platform. And I really like it!

Hey awesome find Waris! I checked out the presentation and will add this to my reading list this summer. Thank you!
