youth_force_a_small_project_job_market_f.description: Aimed as 16-24 year olds, the YouthForce could be an online platform where local businesses post up 'small projects' they are seeking help on. This could be something as simple as setting up a web page, or tutor employees about new technologies.
youth_force_a_small_project_job_market_f.creator: e271b7c6ed709feca8776fd4f9b91e86

comments.text: A great website for buying/offering services is Elance (https://www.elance.com/home).It works both ways. There are also some aspects that can be reused like experience, revenues, recommendations, customer feedback etc.Elance is great because it not only facilitates the transaction, but it also acts as a platform for the project itself.There are also aspects around payment etc. that works really well on Elance making it safe for all parties. A cool feature is the ability to create milestones, so you can break a project and payments down into smaller parts.You could do this with or without money involved.
This is a great idea and sounds similar to the business model of Catchafire, a skills-based volunteer social enterprise.Here is a link to their website: http://www.catchafire.org/
Possibly also learnings to be drawn for builds on this from Sparked: http://www.sparked.com/
Sasha, yes, I immediately thought of Catchafire as well. Catchafire also caters to established professionals though, and I like the idea on focusing on the young and unemployed.

Karella - you're right that Catchafire seems to sponsor pro bono services by professionals (who would already have a decent income stream) to assist businesses who (one assumes) cannot afford to pay for those services. I am concerned that using unemployed in a similar context would ultimately amount to exploitation.I'm sorry but I  can't think of a gentler way of putting it.
Hi Karolle and Paul -- Thanks for sharing and making those distinctions.
Yeah, Paul, I'm definitely in the pro-remuneration camp.

This concept is revolutionary: I think the game-changer here is the creation of an "on-demand job market".Open jobs can be streamed online, and pulled off the jobs feed once they have been allocated or their delivery time window expires.Plus the platform could be designed to support value-add benefits such as job delivery rating and virtual currency earnings.
Can we explore what you mean by virtual currency earnings please Eric. One of the needs of young people transitioning to work is real remuneration with appropriate value for work performed.

Hi Eric & Paul, thanks for your comments. Really encouraged that you think this is something new.I think it will need organisers who are passionate about the issues and making partnerships with local businesses. This may be the biggest hurdle.I do also believe, philosophically, that work in terms of what one would get compensated for should be compensated accordingly. So perhaps this is more likely to be a money-based system.

Perhaps there is a possibility of using James Moyer's incentive payment concept as a kick start process for longer term projects involving those who have been looking for work over extended periods.The Australian unemployment system incorporates a range of supports for the unemployed including covering the costs of short courses (eg MYOB), purchase of protective clothing or essential tools. Whilst these are paid on behalf of the person seeking the work to overcome difficult capital expenses a similar payment scheme might be instituted to cover job or project orientation.

The "virtual currency" refers to client-awarded satisfaction points for each job delivered.  This feature adds per-job compensation as an incentive and differentiates this concept from volunteer networks.Points earned could be redeemable within the network by using them to buy consulting services or specialist knowledge.  For example, I could train a user on Java programming for 3 hours and pay for an hour of Spanish language lessons with "time dollars" earned.  The reward system fosters reciprocal value and real-world personal experience growth.If the virtual currency is transferable then third party trading mechanisms can be built to convert it into hard cash.  Being a mostly peer-regulated currency, some controls would be needed to  prevent abuse.

Hi Eric, coincidentally I have another concept on OpenIDEO I'm trying to get off the ground called Advisorful (http://www.openideo.com/open/web-start-up/concepting/startbarter-a-barter-economy-for-startups/) and it started out life as a bartering scheme for web entrepreneurs to find out.I did some research into barter exchanges for this project and it turned out there are some laws in the US and UK that label bartering as a commercial transaction which should be taxed.In the US, this means the barter exchange service has to issue a tax form to the users for each transaction and the users should report it as tax.Really interesting stuff. Made me want to steer clear of 'bartering' per se and think of some other form of reciprocation that didn't immediately call bartering to mind.Still mulling over it! Would love to get your thoughts.
Hi Paul & Eric, I've also just added you to my Virtual Team. Thanks for your comments!

Thanks Haiyan!Bartering is taxed in Australia too, in an attempt to keep it out of the illegal cash economy. They tend not to chase the incidental stuff like if I help you with your tax return for free without expectation then later you mow my lawn: but anything formalised is taxed (and can be subject to GST/VAT).When we were looking at that for the web entrepreneur challenge I did some research into Barter Card which, although international, is probably the most popular of the Australian bartering systems. I also looked into the Brixton Pound, which is a local currency, restricted to a limited geographic area, only available for transactions between registered businesses and still subject to tax. Its advantage seems to be in encouraging local inter-trading I don't think there is anything intrinsically wrong with bartering or token based remuneration but I suspect the tax implications are unavoidable (at least in USA, UK, Australia and probably Canada too). Maybe someone from other parts of Europe can advise on those jurisdictionsThe main advantage I can see to bartering is that access to capital/cash is not necessarily required (apart from the tax component). It constitutes a form of credit without interest.I don't know much about incubators but perhaps the interchange of expertise during start-up can help entrepreneurs to leverage limited capital in other important directions.

Thanks!We could explore the possibility of solving the barter-tax issue by billing consulting clients 1$ per job per hour - this amount can be subject to taxation and the virtual credits earned treated like non-taxable "loyalty points".  What do you think of this approach?Check out the Education Time Bank idea on:http://www.ideasproject.com/community/en/treasury/efaI'll be glad to partner both openideo and later on ideasproject (once Nokia and UNESCO provide a schedule on the Education Time Bank implementation).

Hi Haiyan, this is an awesome idea. I think this can expand to the government sector. Due to fiscal crisis, many countries, especially in Europe, have downsized their government agencies. This could be a platform for young people to serve their country and learn important and meaningful skills. Hopefully, this will allow government agencies to innovate with young minds and continue to provide quality service to their citizens.

Hi Haiyan, really like this idea. It's a great way for young people to gain hands on 'experience'. Couple of builds... (1) Could we boost learning by designing a way to give constructive feedback? (2) Could we build in ways that young people could link up and work together as teams on bigger projects?
Hi Philip, Thanks for your fantastic feedback.This gets me thinking if these jobs could form part of a larger program, like perhaps a 'virtual internship'.It's interesting to think about!

In addition to feedback, how about a badge system? Companies highlight the skills essential for a particular project, and you earn badges for those skills when the project is completed. Badges are displayed on each user's profile and supplement the evaluation/feedback.

Hi Haiyan, great concept. Id just like to share some thoughts which came to my mind. - Can we integrate the employees of the companies joining? They can feel the benefit in getting to know future colleagues before they are hired. So they perceive the projects as recruiting activity. It would be a pity if they would perceive the young participants as rivals. (This happened with 1-Euro-Jobs in Germany in some branches of industry.)- What about giving a perspective to the young people and to include success stories? Measuring the percentage of young people hired after a project or the fixed contracts resulting from the activities for example could motivate. The participants are motivated in finding a job and companies hiring get positive advertisement.Im curious how the concept will evolve!

I like the idea of letting businesses post small projects that they do not have time or focus on to execute. I think the idea can be extended with a real life component alike the concept of Rising Generation Study by Brad Gill. Unemployed youth can subscribe to a project that fits their interest and skills. A group of unemployed start working on the project together coached by a mentor with experience in the topic of the project. The win/wins are: - Businesses get high quality input for their projects (and possible may want to pay for this)- Businesses get a feel for which youth might fit their company needs (alike assesment centre)- unemployed youth get experience with real work issues and thus can start building their portfolio- unemployed get a sense of purpose since they deliver valuable contributions- unemployed get insight in their own strengths/weaknesses because they are working on achieving a goal
Thanks for your comment Anita. Really great feedback.In this case I think the question is what kind of projects these could be. For me, this is a toughie.

The biggest advantage that youth have is that they are part of a new generation that is not yet familiar for most companies. This means that projects could be interesting for companies that target youth. By involving youth in creating a new product/service they have a much higher chance on succes. For companies that do not target youth, projects could be about getting a fresh perspective from people with different and possibly more digital native background on their portfolio and how it could evolve in the future.
I just saw this! Similar, if not exactly what I just posted :-)
Hi Caroline, are you talking about Interactive & Virtual or Career Day--> Career Year?I believe those concepts are both quite unique and pretty cool!

youth_force_a_small_project_job_market_f.title: YouthForce - a 'small project' job market for young people

don_t_tell_kids_they_re_smart.description: The idea that telling children they're smart may be bad for motivation has been gaining increasing credibility. Instead, should we be praising effort -- something that is within their control -- motivating them to work harder?
don_t_tell_kids_they_re_smart.creator: 6310488e06ba0c3829352dece5c2a064

comments.text: Check out this terrific article by Jonah Lehrer called "The Truth About Grit."It's a great scientific piece about how hard work is a better predictor of success than innate intelligence.http://www.rippowammiddle.org/site_2/Parent_Links_files/The%20Truth%20About%20Grit.pdf

Back in November I stumbled on a Harvard Business Review blog post by Heidi Halvorson about this study.  It has stuck with me ever since.http://blogs.hbr.org/cs/2011/11/the_trouble_with_bright_kids.htmlThe one thing that is not immediately obvious is how to apply this to all students, not just in hindsight.  We need to get many students out of their shells to actually make the initial effort that is praiseworthy.  You may be on to something with your point about applying this to parenting at home.  What happens at home has a huge influence on self esteem and personal motivation.

We try to guard against what I call the Caltech problem.  When students get to Caltech they are no longer the smartest kid in the room. They are at school with an entire community of people who are incredibly smart. It can be very unnerving. Since a lot of smart kids also have perfectionist tendencies they can undermine themselves. Lot's of exposure to things that are harder than their abilities helps tell the story that not everything in life will come easy. Most schools have cut funding to GATE programs, and these kids have unique learning issues that need intervention.  They often get praised and called to tutor other children. However, they don't get more challenging work. It can leave the child feeling that everything is really easy in life. You want to build an inner motivation and not praise seeking behavior.

I think that the larger issue is not providing challenging work and instilling a drive to solve problems. Ellen Winner wrote about gifted childrens' "rage to master" where they focus on an interest with an uncanny single-mindedness. It would be interesting to find out how to replicate that in an academic situation. One caveat being that the student must actually be interested in the subject.
Of course, this is all assuming that telling a child that he or she is smart causes a lack of confidence and unwillingness to try difficult tasks.
Sounds great, good to see Malcolm Gladwell on the issue....Video 1: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QCt1Wc8Kx4UVideo 2: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nf3NalDYIT8
Great share, James. Love watching it. Very interesting. And, the reference to the Beatles is good here particularly, I think: you need to put in the work to succeed.

Interesting research. However, I think there's a cultural aspect to it as well. And a personal one: not everyone reacts the same. To me, the most important lesson from research like this, is that children react differently to praise, and educators should be aware of that, and stimulate children in the way that suits the child best, and to teach them respect for other ways of working (so that effort is not stigmatized, nor talent).

I think that this phenomenon has to do with promoting a "growth" mindset rather than a "fixed" mindset.Those with a "fixed" mindset believes most traits are innate -- they worship at the altar of so-called "talent", so to speak. People with a fixed mindset believe that, no matter how hard they work, they will never be as good as those who have more innate talent than them.Those with a "growth" mindset, on the other hand, believe that with hard work, they can improve and surpass those who they believe have more talent than they do. How to we promote a growth mindset? Value it. Value those who try their hardest, fail, and work on building themselves back up in order to succeed. Encourage students to assess themselves, seeing what they're strong or weak at, and how they can improve on both. Practices like that will go a long way in promoting the idea that talent is largely a myth and will encourage students to improve themselves.

don_t_tell_kids_they_re_smart.title: Don't tell kids they're smart?

comments.text: Looking at the video makes so much sense once you've actually experienced these things.I think it's very important for students to realize and see internships as "previews" of the application of whatever they're learning in school. Not only of the area in which they are focusing themselves on in order to build a career path, but in the satisfaction they obtain from working in whichever field they are.As a recent grad, I had the opportunity to intern once, and if I knew then what I know now... I would have tried to have as many internships as possible from the beginning.

I am very ambivalent about internships as they exist in many places.As long as interns are fairly remunerated for the work they perform I am in favour - where remuneration consists simply of experience gained I believe it is more appropriately incorporated as a part of gaining the qualification. Work experience is very valuable certainly, but demeaned if one has to take a second job to provide for living.

I completely agree with you. Whenever I see things like "unpaid work" or, "use this internship to build your portfolio," it makes me cringe.However, the paid/unpaid marker serves as a very important indicator. From the beginning a light will go off like a warning, anticipating what kind of job you'll be doing and how that place regards and values the contributions of an intern.

Very good point!Perhaps this opens an opportunity for a concept (for this challenge) based around supporting organisation with a fair approach to internships.Sadly, never having graduated from university myself I can't speak from experience but I have seen others benefit from fair internships and bonded scholarships too.

I also prefer a fair remuneration for internships, however, there's a catch. In some countries (like the one I live in now), it's not the norm. Don't ask me why, but it isn't. And everybody is happy with that, to a certain degree.Also, I know that in some countries, educational programs focus more on theory than on practice. Internships are valuable for young people to gain experience they need to distinguish themselves in the job-market. So, apart from a salary, the internship has value.But I also think that internships can have different goals. If it is to 'get a look in the kitchen', it might be that it costs a company more than it delivers. Showing someone around, having them tag along with the workers etcetera. This can be a short internship, where the student does not add value to the company. In these type of internships, I don't see the need for a salary.If the student is not only developing skills and gaining experience, but actually adding value to a company, I think it's fair to give that student some compensation for the effort, other than 'cv-building'.

delivering_happiness.description: Do profits and passion work together? When a student is in passionate pursuit of knowledge opportunity will follow, success is obvious, and information is found. How do we inspire young people to passion?
delivering_happiness.creator: c385cf3f4cd658b158f8f5fa55ca6978

comments.text: I agree wholeheartedly with this inspiration's message.Too many students evaluate career options by the potential paychecks waiting for them at the end of the road. That's putting the cart before the horse by asking what your profession can do for YOU instead of what YOU can do for your profession.If the only satisfaction derived from studies is that it will lead to money at the end, then we're not maximizing our potential happiness. Studies and careers should be informed by our innate interests. Money disappears, but the accomplishments and knowledge derived from following our professional passions remain. As we increase our knowledge and capabilities -- which should be an enjoyable and active process -- then achievements and successes build, and that money naturally follows. We should spread the message that money doesn't equate into being a happy and successful person. I've held jobs where I made an extremely generous salary, and was miserable, disconnected and disinterested in my professional life despite being able to buy whatever I wanted. I've also held jobs where I couldn't wait to get to work every day and was an active participant in my professional development...and it paid less than half of those other gigs. Guess when I was happiest?

delivering_happiness.title: Delivering Happiness

comments.text: This is a great idea and could be a powerful tool. Maybe this is something that mentor companies should help setup. Personally I would be more likely to mentor a teen online than in person. Maybe it could have people sign up from different industries and be kept in a big database or connected with LinkedIn. You could have the possibility to say whether you were available weekly, if you fit the criteria for a certain teen.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

I love it! This is so cool. When can we Google Plus hangout to discuss? I think I know a few others that might like to join the party to listen to your concept live, test it out and maybe build on it together!
I like how you've suggested incentives & onwards collaboration here. And we're digging the graphic you've created!

Plus would be great if you feel like chiming in on Rob's idea: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/openideo-live-with-google-plus-hangouts-on-the-air/ There's clearly a resonance around leveraging the existing Hangouts platform and many possible directions we might collaboratively build concepts around this. young_adult_mentor_mentee_network.description: When you're looking for work, it can be easy to feel lost, directionless or like your search will never end. How can we assure young people there's light at the end of the tunnel? Match job seekers up with successful job 'attainers' for mentoring!
young_adult_mentor_mentee_network.creator: 884b3f632f6af8e3f87b26795b8a4f31

comments.text: Great idea, my design program has peer counseling (partly because of budget cuts on staffing) and it's popular because students prefer talking to other design students about studio classes, portfolios, etc. Perhaps places like The Hub (http://www.the-hub.net/) could host the meet-ups. Or perhaps there could be a Hub specifically for younger people.

"When reading through inspirations, I was struck by how it feels like there's a gap between young people looking for work, and young people who were able to successfully find work"  Great line!I feel that you are also commenting on a larger societal trend that in this age of increased connectivity (i.e. Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIN) that students are finding it more difficult to make meaningful connections (i.e. career mentors).  Would you agree?
Really great insights Porter. Online connections are important and valuable, but sometimes face-to-face is best!

Good idea! i actually have a couple of friends who do this here in Sao Paulo as a volunteer job and they are so amazed by its life changing potential. It is something quite simple to do and does make the difference.

Maria, I'm glad to hear this concept is already being 'proven' in the real world! I wonder if your friends would have any suggestions or feedback to make this idea even better. Maybe they want to join our conversation?

Cool concept. I can definitely see the online aspect of both matching seekers and mentors by industry or location and organizing meet-ups etc. The big nut to crack would of course be visibility/spread, but perhaps it could start spreading to jobseekers through job-seeker agencies and on the mentor side perhaps through employers, talent networks and young-professional networks. Then it could probably become more viral once there are success stories and word-of-mouth to build on. I think many job holders would be willing to "give back" once they've passed the first hump of getting into a new job.This could probably be easily apped as well, making it potentially even more accessible to match, connect and implement the mentoring, whether irl or online.
Great input Ola, thanks!

Great idea! I find exchanging experiences is always very helpful in whatever life situation... taking it online it could be a webbased plattform where young professionals can register. students/graduates could then filter for their location, preferred company/industry etc.
Oh I like your build Nina! It's fun to think about how this could be an online system as well - with mentoring happening on Skype too! I'll add that to the concept.
I would add that the function be able to filter along industry/theme/profession, but would then match you with peers from other countries to foster cross-cultural collaboration and idea-sharing
I think it's a great idea. It's good for young people to exchange experiences. Plus, this can amplify a networking effect, putting job searchers in contact with those that already have a job.

Thanks for this Ashley I noted the existence of the starter concepts but didn't explore them until now.I can see an element of this being part of the "great employer" concept as a point for successful appointees to share both their experience and what is "great" about the organisation(s) they work for.Will begin to modify my concept to reflect this tonight.
There is something already here on this http://youthmentoring.org/

Hi Kirpal, thanks for letting me know. My goal was to get Concepting started by adding an idea that people could build upon. I'll check out Youth Mentoring and see if there are additional lessons or tactics we could learn from and/or incorporate into this idea.

comments.text: Similarly after graduating I struggled to find a job, so decided to get on my bicycle left my front door and cycled 3400miles across Europe over two months. The best experience of my life, a chance for self reflection, understanding what I was good at and identifying weaknesses, developing key skills and doing something I was proud of. Put something like that on your CV and you stand out from the rest of the candidates!
Really nice! while reading the start of your story I could just see myself on it. Really hope to give it a big great twist like you! thanks for the fresh air! :)

the_new_grad_hiring_process_feedback_is_.description: Employers should respond to every applicant (especially those looking for entry-level positions) with constructive feedback, both out of civic responsibility and self-interest in tailoring potential employees.
the_new_grad_hiring_process_feedback_is_.creator: ed5e9a3a957487af8681dec9b8774f5f

comments.text: Hey Josh, this sounds wonderful! You should check out Nathan's concept of Job interviews as teaching moments: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/job-interviews-as-learning-moments/and Paul's great employer registry: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/the-great-employer-register/I think both have really interesting ideas that you can incorporate into your concept.
Thanks for those recommendations! Nathan's idea is directly related, but I'm not sure how Paul's "Great Employer Registry" would apply to this concept; could you elaborate?

So Paul's idea could provide a possible way of incentivizing employers to do what you are talking about. By having a yelp-esque site for employers, job applicants could review employers on a number of aspects including whether they provided constructive feedback after the interview/application, didn't send their resume into limbo and actually responded, etc. Employers would want good reviews to attract applicants and so might be more inclined to provide helpful feedback.

Instead of providing constructive feedback by email or web I think it's better to invite the applicant for coffee or a short meeting at the studio/ work place. This solves two problems, first the applicant must show some commitment to the job to deserve a feedback. Second, communication in person is more efficient and more engaging, it can show the employer how smart the candidate really is. I think a yelp style web application will increase employer stress, which is something no one would like to have. Employment is about connecting people, not connecting services to people then back to services.

Love the idea.   Camping on to your idea -- maybe have a dry run of the new-grad-hiring 2-3 years in advance of the the hiring process.  When a company gives feedback, then the student may need to re-adjust their learning/training objectives.

Great thinking Josh! I especially like the information you've outlined in your third image  where you talk about how employers could provide this feedback. I think the toughest part would be helping employers and recruiting teams find the time to respond to everyone. While you ideally want personalized feedback, form/template letters are more likely to make sense. Perhaps there's some sort of back-end online database that lists commons skills/areas for development that the recruiter could select from, and automatically populate a semi-personalized form letter? It could even integrate with online HR application sites?

That is an excellent idea. I know some job boards (Dice, for example) give users the ability to tag their profiles with skills they can bring to potential employers, and I've seen online job application forms that ask explicitly if the applicant has certain skills. Maybe this is just a question of closing the loop?I do sincerely believe that there's even more wasted time (and money) dealing with the repeated influx of inexperienced applicants to positions that they are ill-suited for, who are likely to continue filling HR's inboxes until someone gives them a clue. "If you don't have time to do something right, how will you find the time to do it twice?"

I agree with both of you - that a checklist that populates into a semi-personalized letter will eliminate a huge barrier (time), and that the huge influx of inexperienced applicants could potentially make that time investment worthwhile.  The trick is getting the person who has to fill out the feedback checklist to see it that way!  What they "see" is their short-term loss (time to fill out survey), less emphasis on their long-term gain (saved time from fewer inappropriate applicants).  Not sure if there is some sort of incentive that could be thrown in to get people to at least try out the system.  I would love to see something like this as a standard part of recruiting software, but until it reaches saturation/becomes the norm, what is available to entice the innovators or early adopters into testing it out?

the_new_grad_hiring_process_feedback_is_.title: The New Grad Hiring Process - Feedback is Key

The learning you will acquire through this as no equivalent. Failing is a huge part of the learning process... We finally didn't really fail, but found a way to don't success...

comments.text: I think this is a good idea. It's something in the right direction, but I wonder if there might be a point in looking not only at available jobs, but also available skills with the possibility of pure exchanges of services between people.
So in addition to an "Jobs" layer, we'd have layers for things like "Craigslist" or "Oddjobs"?
Something along those lines, but I was thinking even jobs that you wouldn't think to post on craigslist or other sites. In a way these jobs would depend on using a different credit system than money.

Love the idea. Have you considered linking it to career networking resources like linkedin? It would be nice for young people to see if they know someone who works at the potential employer. If they do not have any contacts it would be a reminder of the importance of building a network. Perhaps you prompt them to take that step.

I mentioned linkedin in the flipside of my original idea, but I think you're touching on something different here. If I understand your suggestion correctly: when the user puts their mouse cursor over the icon of a key company, along with the key statistics of the company, it'll show "5 of your friends work here". If the user doesn't have a "1st" connection friend working there, then it'll show the "2nd" and "3rd" connections, so that user knows through whom he/she has connections to people at that company.

blind_date_find_the_unexpected.description: Often it is difficult to define exactly what you are looking for. Blind Dates can be used to find new, unexpected and surprising new contacts.
blind_date_find_the_unexpected.creator: 8082a75025cb51e513aff379783121c9

comments.text: Interesting thoughts Sabine  looking forward to hearing more developments on this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post it again there too  and meanwhile you might like to check out the Feed Your Idea section here: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire Hoping to see more of you on OpenIDEO.

Outside of recruiting, this is actually a good idea -- for networking and meeting people outside of your field of expertise. I can also see this concept working well for "underqualified" candidates who don't have the requisite work experience, but have skills that would be very attractive to an employer.However, I foresee there being problems -- what if the person doesn't have the right credentials for the job? Then they shouldn't be taking up a recruiter's time in the first place. That's the reason why submitting a resume is so important.

Thank you for sharing your ideas and your valuable feedback. Maybe there are also other ways in using this concept for recruitment, like combine with speed-dating. In this way the consumed time would be limited but also people who seem to be under-qualified have the opportunity to present themselves.

I think this is a good idea both inside and outside of recruiting. I've actually been on several "blind dates" of sorts with companies as part of the job interview processthey do exist. Here's how they went and what came out of them:Relatively recently I applied to one of the world's leading product design companies. I did what any other hopeful candidate would do: submit a resume, send a cover letter and link to my online portfolio. In-person interviews took place at the company's office, as expected. Both parties involved wanted to learn more about each other. Conveniently, the company involved was hosting a studio open house that upcoming weekend which my interviewer invited me to. The following week, I was invited to swing by the company's office after work hours (they were near where I was working at the time), to catch up and have a few beers with the design team. Days later, I visited their office again and this time went out to lunch with their team. In all instances, I had the opportunity to mingle with my potential future coworkers and boss. I learned more about them, they learned more about me. There is only so much information that can be extracted during a 60 minute interview. "Blind dates", whether going out to lunch or casually talking beyond the initial interview, allow both sides to get to know each other better. After all, the employer isn't going to be hiring your resume. They're going to be hiring YOU. It would only make sense then that they should invest more time in knowing you better...and oh yeah, I wound up getting to do consulting work for the company in the end. :)Before that company I worked for a smaller design boutique in Chicago. The interview process was standard. We decided we liked each other and wanted to give it a go. However, I didn't come on board full time right away. The company had a practice of "dating" you before they "married" you. So instead, I worked for the company on-site for a week and was compensated as a freelance designer would be. From that point, job candidates would either continue on with the company or part ways with no hard feelings. This week-long date enabled me to get a real taste of the office culture and get to know who I would be working with. It also confirmed that the company was right for meat which point I continued on with the company. In short, I think this is an interesting opportunity area to explore what these blind dates could be like. Where should they take place? Who should be involved? What should take place?

Thank you for sharing your experience on this topic. Looking for a job takes a lot of time on both sides - on the recruiter's/the company's side but also on the candidates side. But since you spend a lot of time together afterwards, some dating should be done to get to know each other.Taking the chance and having a date at the future job side as in your case is a great opportunity to find out, if the surroundings fit to you as well as the company's culture in general. To meet future colleagues as well as the future boss in advance gives both sides the chance to find out if the chemistry is right. Failing early can save a lot of time and money on both sides.An interesting question could also be, if the blind dates could be supported by a third party, which built up a candidate pool. Or to link this with a candidate network, where they can exchange their experience on their dates.

blind_date_find_the_unexpected.title: Blind Date - Find the unexpected

Good story. I remember in the city where I grew up, there was a fastfood place with a name that would translate into 'Freedom'. It was located in the central station district, where many offices and ministeries are located as well. It closed for one hour per day, but other than that, there were always people eating. During the day office people and government workers, at night Taxi drivers and clubbers.The name was derived from the fact that the owner started it after serving a jail sentence, and the story was that many of the staff were ex-convicts.The beauty of it: no-one cared and the place had an amazing reputation. apprenticeships to train young adults in careers that are hands-on.These companies would get a tax break. We would diversify the work force.
everything_old_is_new_again.creator: cd77699605b9775a410790d45fbd7b23

comments.text: Interesting thought. And I think a good idea. Be sure to hold on to it for the concepting phase!
I enjoyed your video. I wonder...did anyone help you realize that publishing wasn't for you? A mentor...a navigator

No, not really. The guy responsible for my internship in the publishing house was great, but focused on the industry. I learned a lot form him, but it was also the information I got from industry magazines etcetera. Maybe if I had a mentor, or guidance, I wouldn't have gone it that direction.

I do think that a lot of things could use the craftsman or artisan model.  I also think we need to rethink the stigma against vocational jobs, some people would find passion in tinkering with motorcycles for their career. Why should they only be encouraged to go to college?
yes! the vocational path needs to be seen as an option not a last resort

everything_old_is_new_again.title: Everything Old Is New Again!

professionals_as_sometime_teachers_advis.description: A rotation of professionals come into schools to "teach" a class each week (or month) about what they do in their job, as well as some of the softer things about working.
professionals_as_sometime_teachers_advis.creator: 49d75f861bdf99e6736c5f3f85e41b62

comments.text: This is a really great idea but not only for high school students but also university students as well. I am currently in my final year at Newcastle University reading Business Marketing and Management. During three years of study I have been lucky enough to have to opportunity to attend talks by a number of prestigious business professionals, including recently Chris Townsend the Commercial Director for LOCOG. Listening to real professionals take you through their career paths has inspired me and helped me in understanding concepts of my degree, such as market research. Guest speaker talks at Newcastle University Business school are currently optional, but I think some should be compulsory.

Hello Jessie,I have to say this is a wonderful idea, not just to solve the challenge at hand but also for education reform. Based on my experiences of how public schools operate and create lesson plans to meet benchmarks and ultimately meet State and Federal standards. These meetings with business men and woman would have to be integrated into the lessons in the class and could compliment the topics being taught.For example if the speaker is a gardener and is talking to a math class about their job they might end with a little math problem they have to solve when designing a garden. Something like how to estimate the cost of material, or a problem on how to measure and space plants efficiently to maximize harvest.

Hi Jessie,I know that I'm a bit late to the party, but I think that your concept is great.  I think that evolving previous concepts of "career days" in schools would be a real way for students to connect to various industries and careers that they might not have known existed.  I believe that this is also a great idea in terms of providing equitable opportunities for lower socioeconomic schools where opportunities to meet professionals could be more challenging for administrators to pull off.  However, I feel that to be truly successful in implementation, the students themselves need to be greater stakeholders in partnering with the professionals themselves.  Instead of instituting this initiative as part of the curriculum, perhaps it can be assigned as a project where students can research various industries and then present their findings to the rest of their class, all culminating in a visit by a representative from that industry.  I believe a key in skills acquisition comes from the indirect aspects of projects such as the communication and collaboration that takes place working alongside peers that add value to future.  If these skills are coupled with the mentorship from professionals, I think we have a winning combination on our hands!

Hi Jessie,I really love the part that we can invite people from all industries to talk with students and give them larger exposure of different kinds of jobs. My concern is how we can reduce sample bias as different people may have different perspectives and experience towards the same occupation. How can we prove their authenticity? Maggie

This idea is not new of course but I certainly feel it deserves to have reached this phase of the challenge - it is simple, sustainable and brings great value. One of the big attractions for me is that it is sustainable because the 'professionals' benefit from it too - whether from self-fulfillment or because it meets some sort of annual objective they might have.Having been involved in similar schemes, one key to success is matching the right professionals with the young people. If the professional is, to put it gently "too experienced" then it can make it very difficult for them to connect as mentors. The best successes I have seen are when the professionals are the vibrant and enthusiastic folks with 5-10 years experience who know enough about real life but yet still have enough empathy with the 'youth' to convey it effectively.

Having worked as a teacher and having attended numerous presentations and workshops and training sessions, teaching really is a skill, no matter what age group you are working with from toddlers to adults. Asking professionals to teach is like asking them to take up and hone their skills in an area that is for most entirely out of their realm. That being said, I do believe there is much opportunity and much to be gained from professionals who decide to pair up with students in mentoring capacities. Some of the other concepts have addressed industry selection and internships of a different kind. This could be more of a rotation. As students begin to experience different industries, they are paired up with a professional in that industry as their mentor who guides them through challenges. Then they move on the to next. Some students will tend to gravitate toward particular mentors and particular industries. There are many things that would need to be honed and coordinated - how to match up students/professionals, sourcing industries/professionals/students, managing the program, student safety, screening, etc. (to be fair, I was trying to submit this idea under the Concepting phase, but was unable to because of technical difficulties. I do believe there could be a blend of different concepts here. This one puts the professional into leadership roles. I am suggesting some tweaks.)

I am a big fan of the mentorship concept - I think close, two-way relationships are the best way to develop skills - however I feel that the current mentorship model is overly narrow; that is to pair young, inexperienced professionals with those who have significant experience and have already achieved great success.  The reality is that there is often a disconnect between expectations between these two groups.  My proposal would be to pair new graduates looking to develop skills and information not with established (ie. decade+ experience) professionals, but with young professionals with 3-7 years experience; I believe this would be a more mutually beneficial relationship.  The mentees would be able to get advice from people who are less further removed from their life position, and likely navigated a more similar macro-environment; their mentors would also probably have a lot more time available.  These younger mentors would also have more motivation to participate as they are also in a stage of their careers where they are looking to develop skills (or strengthen resumes).  For example, if one of these mentors was about to enter a stage in their career where they begin to manage people, a fairly structured mentorship relationship like this would be a great way to develop the requisite skills.Granted that I am a sample size of one, but I spent the summer as an MBA intern at a company also employing a number of undergraduate interns and built a number of strong relationships with these interns.  I enjoyed being in a mentor role and I know a number of students I spent time with enjoyed my accessible and credible point of view.

Certainly teaching is a skill that requires training, application and dedication. I think the point of this is to expose kids to some of the current occupations that may be available within nearby communities. I wouldn't be 'teaching a subject or discipline' but simply relating experience and some of the practical (soft) skills necessary to do common jobs. A guy I went to school with was heavily into sport in 10th grade as what he thought his only option might be until we spent a day having various professionals talk about their jobs. Despite being academically challenged during 11th and 12th grades he actually gained a law degree and a successful local practice. Certainly he applied himself but the 'spark' was supplied by exposure to real life within the learning environment.

Certainly, not every child (or even adult) learns in the same manner. Spark is extremely important. Thank you for emphasizing that. Learning and "spark" can happen in a variety of different ways. There exists the additional issue of... and I ask for some license in addressing this... legal protections and safety of underage students. I also have a background in Corporate Human Resources. More simply put, there is a great deal of potential here (I, too highly value mentorship). Much planning, screening and safeguarding need to be considered.

I would definitely sign up to this. My company sent me to a school recently to spend 2 days working with a group of high school students on professional skills and I thoroughly enjoyed it. I believe the kids benefited too from the 'working world insights' and details of my industry. I was also able to share information about my degree and why I chose to do it and how I ended up in my current job. Furthermore  I was able to do the same for a lot of the degrees and professions that the group was interested in because I know people who have done those degrees and gone into those professions.

Great idea Jessie, sounds quite similar to Work&Teach and a few other schemes? http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/workteach-connecting-the-worlds-of-work-and-education-to-the-benefit-of-both/

We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Our developers are busy working on it. Meanwhile, if you're wanting to iterate your ideas, you can use the comments feature to promote further conversation from others. We'll let you know once the bug is fixed, then you can incorporate your refinement moves into your concept post. Let's be agile, together!

Right on! Our development team have been busy fixing the Update Entry bug and we're back on track now. You'll now be able to edit your posts to add all that refinement-goodness to build out your concepts for improved impact. Bring it on, together!

Great idea! Maybe not a bad idea to make it a vice versa concept? Professionals teaching students, but also teachers working at the professional's work place. Many teachers start working in the education system and never leave it again. So this gives a bunch of teachers with unlimited theoretical knowledge but that do not have the faintest idea what is to work at an office in an organizational and social context. At the same time teachers then can give employees advice on how to further develop the talent of young employees and how their minds work. It is difficult to explain to a fifty year old manager that a 24-year old graduate expects a big income, med. Insurance and a car if possible. This expectation behaviour is indeed not normal, but if the manager is given knowledge why this is (generation Y) it makes him/her look differently at the young employee.

I agree with the OpenIDEO feedback and I like the fact that this idea is so simple. Regarding the development of some "digital component" to it, I recommend taking a look at something like http://www.horsesmouth.co.uk/ for ideas. Good luck and give me a shout if I can help with anything.

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:Although this concept hasn't been developed in much depth, the premise is certainly compelling; most young people would benefit from more exposure to people in industry/employment.  The panel also felt that it was much more implementable and scalable than some of the other ideas that were similar but would require a much higher degree of commitment.WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:Basically, we'd love to see this idea developed further to incorporate some of the great feedback it's already received (e.g. could this be supported by a digital component in some way, what age range is this intended for? etc).  It's charmingly simplistic but we'd love to see a bit more meat on the bones...For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine

I think my previous contribution might be helpful to lowdown on refinement. And more flexible ways could be developed to spread the conception.http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/open-the-second-class-together-with-enterprises/

Simple & great! When I was a design school (average age: 18  24) we had a thing called Contextual Studies every Friday afternoon. Basically a professional from industry would come & talk with us & also provide feedback on anything we were working on at the time. For me it was formative in terms of getting a feel for what lay beyond the school walls in terms of work. It was especially insightful when visitors came from non-traditional roles or jobs. It was also great for faculty and professionals to mix and share thoughts from their respective realms.

I think that 'contextual studies' would be really useful built into the learning for 12-18 year olds in high school to show how learning could be applied / useful in work.  This is more achievable if the curriculum has a cross-curricular emphasis so that students benefit from holistic learning rather than learning in rigid subjects.  Curriculum for Excellence in Scotland seeks to do this:http://www.educationscotland.gov.uk/thecurriculum/whatiscurriculumforexcellence/index.asp.

Wow, Tony! There's some great stuff on that site. I notice that the link didn't come up as active. Here it is again for folks who want to check it out: http://www.educationscotland.gov.uk/thecurriculum/whatiscurriculumforexcellence/index.asp Well worth a look!

This is a nice and simple idea, that I know works for me. I'm a student, and at my school, all my teachers work in companies. We can ask them anything we want, and hear all about their current projects. Every monday we also have "Design in connection" where artist, designers, architects, even older students come and talk about their work. The school is really good at getting people from all over the world, and giving us insight in work and projects.  So your idea is a good way of getting information and inspiration out to students!
Do you have an age group in mind? The end result can be quite different depending on whether your concept is applied to primary, secondary or tertiary classes.

I think it should be open for all age groups.I`would make a difference in which people are teaching on what age group. (not everybody is able to teach every age group, and there have to be some "drivers lecens" to teach) The themes should be chosen by the children. I think it should not be preselected by the teachers. If teachers preselect it, there would not be the effect you want to reach with this concept. It would be more like the "parents present there job day" in school.I think the subdivision in primary school.... is not good for this project.

Maybe companies could partner with schools to do this? More and more companies are seeing the value in forming closer partnerships with colleges and universities and are coming in to teach classes (e.g. Capital One taught a class at Rice University). These partnerships are mutually beneficial as companies can use them as pseudo-recruiting tools and students get more real-world exposure from practicing professionals.Also, to expand on your mentorship idea, check out fjr's Mentoring Wishing Tree concept: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/the-mentoring-wishing-tree

Could you extend this beyond the classroom and have an online platform to support it?I am thinking that the online platform could also act as a point of reference and support after the students leave school and find themselves in need of help.I could definitely see myself as a teacher in a setup like this.
That's a great idea! You could see it being a portal that really supports people in those tricky years after finishing school.

With flexible classroom time, students would have more opportunities for pursuing more interactive learning ops
the_sports_team_model_of_tactile_educati.creator: 16747c3cf58007edc9ddbe7b80010761

comments.text: I think your concept hear is starting to hit upon a very worthwhile idea I recently came across.  The best way I know to describe it "choose-your-own-modality learning".  The idea is that we all learn best, differently.  Some of prefer more hands-on, tactile, kinesthetic learning, while others like a book and traditional classroom lectures.   A new and growing approach to education is offering students their preferred modality of learning.  If you want to learn more about this wonderful approach, which is achieving amazing results, check out the story of one NYC school here:   http://www.freakonomics.com/2010/05/12/freakonomics-radio-how-is-a-bad-radio-station-like-the-public-school-system/

Sounds great, Porter! Anyone up for suggesting names for this kind of class? Sports classes are called things like Phys. Ed. where I grew up. Not that catchy, I know  but am wondering whether folks might come up with suggestions for the kind of thing which Porter is describing which could be used widely to push the idea? Do chime in! ;^)

How about 'Projectory' or 'Projectories Class'? (A combination of 'project' and 'trajectory'). Wouldn't that describe it rather nicely while still covering a very wide range of possible activities? Also, 'Projectory' nicely resonates with other school subjects like 'History' or 'Chemistry' I think.

Hm, according to a quick google search, some other people have already come up with the same idea (the same neologism, that is). One would probably need to check if any of them have reserved the copyright...
Loving the Projectory idea, Hannes!

Funny, I've been sittimg with a similar idea for some time, but more focused on the after school time, i.e. Using the successful model of sports teams and activities to, on a very regular basis, practice those other skills that you mention. I am intrigued by the possibility of it becoming as natural to "go to entrepreneurship practice" as going to football practice/ballet/chess etc. The other aspect I've been trying to get my head around is the "coach" aspect. I like the idea of a community pitching in here. There will be university students, entrepreneurs, young professionals, experienced seniors, etc already in a neighborhood or community who would be willing to help young people develop useful life/professional skills. How could that be harvested and organized? I think I've been trying to mentally keep it outside of the schools since they are usually rather regulated by curricula, guidelines, etc (at least in Sweden where I am from). But it certainly think it's intriguing to integrate it more and it will probably depend a lot on place and context, but could likely fit very well in many situations too.

Hi Ola, I am wondering if it necessarily has to be an entrepreneurship practice per se. It could be offering the possibility to work on projects (which could be within the school or the community, or more business related) and learning from the coaches, and having time during school to work on these projects. You could imagine having some workshops to teach some of the basic skills (accounting, business plan, or more technical skills related to a project: sketching, programming).  This does not take away the practical aspect of how to implement it.

Absolutely Anne-Laure, I wrote that as an example. It could just as well be "skills practice" or talent or passion :) I can definitely imagine what you mention. And it makes me smile :-)The way I see it, the core is the young people who are bored/frustrated/thirsty for alternatives. Given that, it takes a concept (like were starting to sketch out here), interested people and preferably already existing programs (in line with Porter's comment about utilizing existing programs), and some passionate people in schools and/or community. Lastly, and very implrtantly, it takes connectors with the networks and tenacity to mobilize, connect and inspire the involved parties with the vision and tools to execute and build successful colaboration.

My idea is to leverage existing programs that have the infrastructure and experience to deliver these types of experiences for students.  Organizations such as FIRST Robotics, Lego, and NASA, Competitions like Intel's science and entrepreneurship challenges, and other entrepreneurship programs such as General Assembly and HP Learning Initiative for Entrepreneurs.  Its time we start moving students from a consumer of standardized education to a creator of their own education, let them select which programs pique their interests.  My experience in education suggests that it is significantly more efficient to scale existing programs than to formulate new ones.  This is why I emphasize piloting this idea in areas with existing programs that could immediately come in to complement school programming.  Areas with a large pool of existing afterschool programs typically have larger populations and greater potential for volunteers, mentors, and coaches.  I agree that the idea of a "coach" is critical because it is an ideal opportunity to reduce the student teacher ratio from a standard 20-1 to approximately 5-1; a major differentiator in student learning.  Ola, school systems in America are classic resistors to change as well.  While my goal may be large scale implementation, my initial goal is proof of concept.  There are plenty of mid-tier private schools that are looking for competitive advantages to boost enrollment numbers who may be willing to participate in trials.  My experience also suggests that bottom-up adoption of new education concepts is more effective than top-down.  Also, leaders in education won't change anything unless you show them data.  "Young Americans learn how to innovate most often despite their schoolingnot because of it." TONY WAGNER Thank you for all of your responses!  This is fun!

Cool, that sounds like a smart and strategic way to go - piggy backing off of established programs/initiatives, providing new/added value and establishing proof of concept that is replicable/scalable. I think that the clever area of  also agree that

oops, that was prematurely posted... I meant to say that the clever area of opportunity is both the "joint effort" for the larger cause of prepping youth with the skills they need, and doing it in a way that builds momentum similar to the sports model. Would you still want to "package" the concept under its own brand (which could be used in the replication/scaling process) or would it essentially be about building the stronger connection between existing programs and the schools?
Really interesting thoughts here Porter. It's thought-provoking to consider how the entire school day/schedule could be disrupted to give students more time to practice these important skills.

Very interesting idea indeed. I think that beyond disrupting the school day, it is also about changing our views on what schools are supposed to teach students. For the scheduling purposes, some middle schools (based on my knowledge of the NY public school system) have talents such as drama, dance, arts, music and technology. You could imagine adding another type of talent. Also my son's school is organized around an exploratory curriculum http://www.ms447brooklyn.org/exploration-program.html. Each semester they work on a theme - NYC plan for 2030, green technology and design, aquatic studies -  where all disciplines are brought in (science, maths, social studies, ELA). They do field trips, museum visits and they have professionals coming to talk to them. They then put together what they learnt in developing a project (which often includes some modeling, sketching, wwhich includes budget and practical constraints).You could imagine having  a program that would be more focused on entrepreneurial aspects. What I also like is the multidisciplinary aspect: showing kids that what they learnt at school is useful and can be put to practice.

Great idea, Porter. On personal aspect isn't hard to execute this idea. On another thought, what if the students, starting from middle school, don't know which skill to start training from? The kids deciding and moving on fast will benefit, but the flustered ones will be definitely late. From personal experience, it's quite hard to get on my track from the beginning. Of course, the process of training may guide students to know if it's right for them or not.
I didn't like the name either, but wanted to publish my comment.  This site could benefit from having a SAVE button to facilitate the creation process before just PUBLISHING
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

We are starting to explore this very concept at my school. Its starts with finding time to shut down the machine and look at the talents and interests of students.  We have also added a teacher whose sole job is to try to expand our project based instruction to start looking giving kids more access to internships, indpendent studies and enrichment.

comments.text: So true, I wonder though if it is sustainable to always be in the growth mindset.Will the growth mindset wear our brains out? I think the journey of testing that hypothesis would be a enlightening one.Really neat find here Steph, this will help me articulate a point I am going to make at work tomorrow ;)

this one is extra tough because most of the traits on the left seem to be natural human tendencies, ones most people would have to expend effort to overcome. it could definitely get tiring, but i do believe that the more you get used to thinking in a certain way, the more natural it becomes. like playing guitar.. hurts at first, until your fingers start to harden :)

Love this Steph  and glad you've posted it here! Can you add a link on your post to the original full size source so folks can check it out in detail? Here's a closer look with some breakdown notes: http://michaelgr.com/2007/04/15/fixed-mindset-vs-growth-mindset-which-one-are-you/

what_color_is_your_parachute_find_your_p.description: To find a job, one needs to have acquired the right skills. Yet, what if we had the right skills but did not know? What if we were looking for the wrong job based on what we think we can do? The FYP toolkit can help you answer these questions.
what_color_is_your_parachute_find_your_p.creator: 893f53c159eab9178ab181bad8da4262

comments.text: An awesome idea, and very inspiring stories too! The apathy and confusion that some of our youth encounters comes from enduring someone else's recipe for being "the right candidate." In light of Ken Robinson's and Richard Bolles's work, introspection is a powerful asset. The paradox too is that no external source can concretely define how that path of introspection turns, splits, and weaves. The FYP toolkit could be a potent trigger to empower them with confidence in devising what their alternative paths may look like. Gathering up the skills from past contexts and concocting them into the present is actually very brilliant.To accompany the mapping and brainstorming, maybe the personal business model canvas may work? It was modeled after the business model canvas by Alex Osterwalder, but it also works well in envisioning how personal aspirations and aptitudes fit and flow together.
Thanks Bryann. I'm going to check the business model canvas as I have to admit I'm not familiar with the notion. Thanks!
Fab focus on passions and helping young people find the many paths that these might lead to.
Thanks Meena. I've been thinking about this aspect since the inspiration phase and was trying to see how we could help apart from reforming the curriculum.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Great concept Anne-Laure! It is so true that a lot of people don't know their passion.  Mostly it is because of the way they were raised by the society to think and they can't look past the 9-5 guarantee job.  It will be great to have courses that teach you to break away and create your own.

Thanks Sana. Glad it resonates with you. Some aspects could and should be included in courses. There is also a change implied at the society level. I remember when I decided to study philosophy. My parents never said no, but I know they were worried about what I will do. While I thought that I just wanted to study philosophy and that I will figure out later on what kind of job to do. Maybe I've been lucky, but I don't regret my choice. In this case, more than a course, I'm thinking of a tool kit with a series of activities targeted at making people realize that they might have more skills than they think (or different skills). You might never have thought of yourself as a potential project manager, but maybe you've been involved in various projects at schools or have done small jobs where you in fact have done a lot of coordination and planning, as well as interacting with people.You will have a set of questions, scenarios, and other activities to make you think about your skills. An activity that I used in one of my courses is to have students ask a certain number of people (about 10) who know them well to describe what they think are these persons strengths. This is often a great learning experience for people.The second part would be to make people reflect about what they really want to do: of course, in terms of activities, but also where (in a city or in the countryside, in a big or small company, in the public or private sector)... Maybe I should clarify this in my concept. I'll try.

what_color_is_your_parachute_find_your_p.title: What color is your Parachute ? Find your passion  (FYP) toolkit

partner_young_people_with_mid_career_wor.description: There are many people currently in the workforce who are willing to scale back a bit on their careers, either because they need to balance work and home life or because they are at a transition.  Can these people "job share" with new, young talent?

comments.text: Interesting idea, some speculate that experienced workers delaying retirement is part of what is driving up unemployment among young adults.http://dailycaller.com/2011/07/22/long-term-trends-delayed-retirement-youth-unemployment/This could be away to counter this trend.

Agreed, and thanks for that comment. This approach allows mid-career types to consciously down-shift in order to let the next generation step in. There are so many ways this could be win-win, but a lot of logistics to get through. Let me know if you have any ideas about that!

I agree the logistics are the difficult part. Hospitals have residency programs, and other corporations have mentoring programs, but they all essentially make more work for the mentor. A program like you're describing would need to be very streamlined, with very little paperwork. Maybe employees could sign up for a program where they get an assistant in exchange for longer weekends or extended vacations. The assistant would learn by doing, the employee would have more time to pursue other career building endeavors (masters degree, independent consulting), and the company would get to try out new talent with little risk.
great thinking Megan! this reminded me of something from back home: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/the-secret-to-germany-s-low-youth-unemployment/
This is excellent, Stefan, thanks for posting. It is going to take some coordination by employers to get this idea off the ground. Are there laws that support this in Germany?

Experienced teachers often take on student teachers in part for this reason. The relationship can benefit both parties, though the mentoring component can be more taxing and more work for the mentor than doing the whole job herself.

Provocative thoughts Megan  looking forward to hearing more on this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post it again there too  and meanwhile you might like to check out the Feed Your Idea section here: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire Hoping to see more of you on OpenIDEO.

the_dna_of_a_job.creator: 6d6bc76c5c7da502c99a5c5b5a11d28b

comments.text: This is great! Often people may feel forced to figure out what "transferable skills" they have rather than directly relateable skills to the job in question.  American schools often focus on a broad, liberal arts education style that can make it challenging to figure out a career.  I believe European schools make an effort to narrow the educational focus at an earlier age so kids start to get the hard skills needed for their chosen career.  Both system has pros and cons, but it's nice to know before you start going after something to know what you need to get there.

I like this - I agree that often with classes, "knowing what careers they each unlock is difficult to see".Would there be potential for this actually being offered as an introductory course?  For example - on the "intro" day at school - just before students have decided their course curriculum - the teachers present the importance of each of their subjects, and then relate it to a range of real-world careers?  It could even be an inspiring video - where schools can show where each subject can ultimately take a student.  I can see the video being a total hit!
Hi Matt, I really like the wiki style website idea. I hope this can become real soon. great concept!

Cool! I know of a project in Sweden where they've developed something called the DreamMap where they mentor students and basically break down the trajectory with them as a map to reach their dream, making it much more tangible to understand what good each class could do. Perhaps that could help as inspiration or model.http://www.mydreamnow.se/index.php?p=1_6_In-English
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Rocking video, Matt! And I'm digging the wiki idea as the job market is changing rapidly so new kinds of jobs are emerging which students may not have previously thought of.

comments.text: Dear Hayo, good idea. As you mentioned, the fear for 'loss of face' when deciding against a chosen subject at university can be tremendous.A re-thinking (or at least some good marketing campaigns) to eliminate such stigma as well as the university's efforts to support finding the right subject is essential to make it work.

Hey Joachim! Thanks for the input! The idea shown here is in the "inspiration phase". It was my first post, so I fully understanding the concept of openideo.Look here to see the concept:http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/first-semester-open-doors/#c-053c8b1abe2008b1f20de74be5931fb3

Hey Hayo, we had the same hunch :)I was thinking more in the line of internships and professional careers. What about all the young people that don't go to university?As of last March, 30.4 percent of people over age 25 in the United States held at least a bachelor's degree (from the NYT).And the US has the second highest university completion rate after Norway: http://www.conferenceboard.ca/hcp/details/education/university-completion.aspxcould we create a Bauhaus-semester for the other 70%?

This sounds like a good idea. In countries where government supports students, but with a time-limit, there should be something organised about not losing study credits. In Europe, especially the Erasmus scheme, there is something similar. Many students take a semester or so outside their own university, and often outside their own country, as part of their program. What if something similar was done in the first year with a part in a different study field. Would also help in making students see another side and prepare them for collaboration with others in the future. There's a good concept hidden in this one.
I know a few people who participated in the Erasmus programme, and they all agree that it was a very enriching experience that, at least partly, shaped their future career aspirations.
Really good inspiration. Because is not only about giving people opportunities, but for them to give something back to society!! Totally love it!
