what_are_my_options.description: How can young people succeed when they don't even know where to start?
what_are_my_options.creator: 0d2b4e40166b7446d1b8f2833b3bfb00

comments.text: I started to get excited when I started reading your post because I thought your concept was about to hit upon one of my strongly held beliefs, but then your concept made me think of a different idea.  I think you are identifying a really important problem with youth not knowing what they should be studying in high school and college.  The question is what should determine their course of study? I think you are suggesting that their career-of-choice is what should mostly drive this decision process.  I would agree.  I myself earned a undergraduate degree that was very practical due to the fact that it qualified me for a wide range of jobs in business and elsewhere, but I knew so many people who didn't know what their passion was, much less where they wanted to work after graduation.  I think it is a shame that so many of us go to school without a career in mind and a motivation (other than being afraid of working at McDonalds) for why we want the higher education.  So many people go to school to get an education because that is what people tell us to do.   To go through university without an appreciation for why the education is valuable seems kind of backwards and not ideal to me.  That is comment #1.Comment #2 is that I think career ambitions should only indirectly drive our curriculum choices.  That is because our intrinsic personalities should drive our career ambitions, and then the career ambitions will guide our curriculum choices.  I think the most critical thing for all of us to do is understand ourselves and our strengths.  In many ways, college helps us discover ourselves and our strengths, but--as someone who discovered his true passions and strengths only after receiving my BA and who has met many such young people who do not know themselves well enough--I think the first and most critical step is true self-discovery.  If we simply give youth the inspiration and means for discovering how they can use their strengths and interests to develop economically valuable skills, they will naturally do so many of the things necessary to successfully pursuing a career.   I therefore think the best and most effective ideas for ensuring an employable and career-focused generation of youth is to help them understand their own strengths and what kinds jobs would be a good fit for someone with these strengths.  This is simple in concept, but hard to execute, but I think some of the concepts posted in this challenge have tried to identify this as critical first step.  One such concept posted for this challenge is the "What color is my parachute" concept:  http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/what-color-is-your-parachute-find-your-passion-fyp-toolkit/

This is a marvelous suggestion.We used to have career counseling within high schools and in primary schools there is some focus on broad occupational areas.Here in Australia most of the universities outline the types of occupations and employment opportunities associated with each subject offered but they are just lists with very little detail of the jobs themselves.When I started university almost 45 years ago the situation was largely the same. Unless you had a passionate idea of what you wanted to be the motivation to pursue study could easily lead to poor results.There is a challenge with requiring students to make choices too early in the education process but integrating some aspects of ways in which to apply what is being learned early in schooling is essential. Ironically in rural and regional schooling this tends to flow naturally from the circumstance whereas increasing urbanisation has also meant increasing detachment.

I absolutely agree that "There is a challenge with requiring students to make choices too early in the education process."  I was in the British education system for a bit where early profession tracking and testing are a huge part of the process. For me I felt that it left too little room for creativity and forced many students in directions that may not suit them 2, 3, 4, 5 years down the line.  It also made it incredibly hard for kids who were not great test takers to pursue more rigorous course loads.With that said, I do see on the other end of the process friends (who tracked well) emerging from school with a confidence in their abilities and a clear direction and surety in the job hunt.  How do we take something of this idea of tracking and infuse greater flexibility in the process and make the focus more on helping kids make the choices rather than pushing them into tracked fields according to how they test?  I think this mobile clinic of sorts might be the first step...I also am really intrigued by your comment  about how increased urbanization has led to increased detachment among youth.  I think this speaks to human unhappiness when presented with too many choices.  We are overwhelmed with finding the perfect option and end up unhappy with our choice as we inevitably wonder what better decision we could have made.Perhaps kids in urban settings with infinite job choices find themselves so overwhelmed by choice that it becomes easier to detach. Maybe a path for thought is how do we narrow the field for kids so the best choices according to the student are presented rather than EVERY job option available?

I agree with the idea that youth unhappiness partially stems from the overwhelming amount of choices - I think it is compounded by an increase in what they think is "expected" of them based on the comparisons that are now so easily at their fingertips with social media. I love you idea of helping set a baseline of what youth should expect and help them prepare for getting on the right path.

I support your concept that we need to give young people an "informed, practical understanding of the work landscape", so that they "find jobs they are challenged by, excel in and ultimately enjoy." My concern is that the business world changes very quickly; the information that is preemptively taught early on is likely to change by the time they graduate. Thus, in addition to the preemptive teaching, I believe we should use the internet and mobile apps to keep graduates (as well as those already in the workforce) regularly updated about the changing employment structures, the changing demands of employers, salary breakdowns, etc.The interactive tool to keep people updated can be something like what has been suggested here: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/concepting/interactive-and-virtual-/

I absolutely agree that things change quickly (the US recession comes to mind) and I think the challenge is always the sustained impact of a in-person education program like this.  You don't want it to be a one off and then quickly forgotten.Using platforms online and a interactive app like the one you reference seem to be the right direction to ensuring this.  Figuring out what you want means you are able to really take advantage of such a tool.  I like it! I think in conjunction with this earlier education program this tool offers a means for students to perhaps take a courageous (but informed) jump into a new city, something I have come to believe is challenging but incredibly rewardingThank you for sharing this!

comments.text: Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

Brad, I think goals are great, but measurable goals as you mention, are the rub.  In this instant world where you can even buy your way out of waiting at Disneyland and 30 second rice has replaced minute rice, young people grow inpatient of even their own goals. I think "alligators" as I call them force this, i.e. parents, bill collectors, society in general.  We tell them to get a job any job, and as a result, they end up in that same job 10 years later, unhappy, unfulfilled, and having given up on their dream.  See my next post on junk food jobs.

The typical school environment fosters impatience. In my district teachers have to follow a time table and change subjects at a prescribed time. If a student happens to be engaged in anything, she is required to move on. Why bother? Visit a museum when there is a school tour.  You will hear teachers constantly telling kids that they have to hurry and move on. The tone is panicked and rushed. The teacher and her students are not listening to the docent, intaking any information; they are merely moving on.
Let's keep things solution-focused in true OpenIDEO style :^) Check out more tips on our Guiding Principles: http://bit.ly/youth-guide
Great personal reflections, Brad!

comments.text: Fantastic! Thanks for sharing. I had never heard BUILD and don't believe there is anything like this in France... at least when I dropped out myself to start a company!
Awesome. I wish I knew about this when I was in high school.Thanks so much for sharing this, Sally!

I'll attempt to spark some discussion with a question, also: how can we get programs like BUILD to expand? Many of the amazing initiatives that have been posted as inspirations so far are only active in a few major metropolitan areas, leaving kids outside of the urban bubble behind. How can we ensure kids that are not from major cities -- which are often areas where opportunity is lacking -- get a chance to engage in the same types of programs?

This is amazing! Nothing like getting a taste for the real thing to get you excited about starting a business.  It would be great to talk to students a couple of years after they have participated in BUILD to see how they are faring.
Absolutely-- here are some stories from their website from students who have just finished the program. http://www.build.org/page.aspx?pid=362
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
I love BUILD! Thanks for sharing this with us Sally.

model_city_schools.description: My daughter went to Garehime and ran her own business in 1st grade. She took that experience and sold crayons to a birthday party provider.
model_city_schools.creator: c385cf3f4cd658b158f8f5fa55ca6978

comments.text: Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
Thanks so much for picking us! Doing the branding for Garehime was really engaging and I absolutely love telling their story.

This is amazing, I wish I could have studied in a place like this.Lost of questions in my mind now: do they have Alumni? are they doing any good? how do they manage with the regular qualifications? if a business from a child makes money who owns it? Did your daughter love it too?Thanks for sharing!

I will also say that my daughter wanted more of the Model City and less of the state standards(she thought they were easy and boring). I can imagine a school that acted like an incubator, and I see tremendous value in that.

They have a close economy so the money is all their own and right now there is no way to cash out of the system. I have always wanted to partner the school with a bank so that the kids could "cash out" into maybe a college fund.  My daughters next goal is to start a microlending program at the school, so that the students who cant afford to run a business (parents unable to purchase supplies) can do so. She imagines a Shark Tank contest in the school. It is challenging to run this program with the testing pressures that burden all school districts.    I think the program would be even more amazing if they were unburdened by bureaucratic pressures. One telling thing about the school if that the last time they had to surplus a teacher (has to be the teacher with the shortest amount of time in a given school) she has been there for 6 years. Ill try to see if I can load some of the profit and loss statements the kids have to report to the business licence agency.
Wow  Monera! So many really telling insights here.

comments.text: Hear, hear, Matthew! When I was teaching design I liked to emphasise the soft skill of engagement. (I guess this would come under Personality here though I often framed it as part of presentation skills) I've seen many great designers do badly in not being able to communicate & engage clients over their amazing idea  and many mediocre designers do well through being convincing. So I was always keen to encourage students to hone their skills around engaging others in their designs.

peace_corp_meets_local_public_service.description: By combining the structure and depth of Peace Corp projects with local public service, we can enable new graduates to gain experience while providing value to their communities.  E.g., design graduates re-designing spaces at a local retirement home.
peace_corp_meets_local_public_service.creator: 9b40c7f0ba48e086c3630115cd16775c

comments.text: I love this idea. There's clear evidence that programs like the Peace Corps are rewarding on both a personal and professional level. Why not bring that to young people? A key difference in my mind is that in many of these programs have intensive training programs that, once complete, result in participants going off and working on their own. While I believe autonomy should definitely be a goal of your program concept, mentorship I'd assume is one of the key benefits. It could be interesting to create spin-off internships from existing programs like a http://codeforamerica.org/. These programs already bring together small teams of the most experienced professionals working together for a common cause in the community. Could be great to collaborate. Just a thought...

Great idea Ami, I like the thought of different spinoffs.  Did a quick search online and found Design for America - http://designforamerica.com/.  Looks like they bring students and mentors together to apply human centered design to address community issues, pretty cool.  Would be interesting to extend this to different professional fields.I think you're right that mentors are critical to the concept and would be a key benefit.  The recruits in these programs will probably gain great value and learning from an experienced hand and guidance through important milestones.
How does this compare to Vista/Americorps in concept and potential finding?

Great question fjr.  In many respects this would be very similar to the Americorp Vista program - recruiting and paying young people to work on community development projects.One point of differentiation could be the type of work and structure of the project.  For example, recruiting people with specific skills in areas like design, architecture, marketing, and technology.  Recruits can then gain experience in their chosen field of study in order to further develop their careers.Taken a bit further, this value proposition can be offered to local businesses / community organizations that are seeking low cost upgrades and are interested in providing young professionals with real world experience.

Really nice idea Joe! It reminds me a bit of some of the pro-bono volunteering programs I've heard of (like the Taproot Foundation) but with a very cool and rewarding spin on it for young people and community enrichment. Do you have an idea of how these efforts would get funded? Maybe organizers would apply for grants? Or would the businesses (libraries, senior centers etc) provide a small stipend for supplies, tools, salaries etc?

Thanks Ashley.  Yep as a Taproot volunteer myself, I can definitely see the similarities =)   Agree with both you and Si Liang, I think funding is a question mark.  It would be great to pay young graduates, in order to do so the businesses would need a budget, albeit a smaller one, to provide supplies and salaries.Maybe part of it is directly government funded.  Or once the program gains in reputation, companies will pay for it and receive some "corporate social responsibility" benefits.  Or even as project managers earn a reputation, companies may seek out specific PMs for their projects...

From a purely learning perspective, it would actually be good to divide these projects up and assign them to teams. These voluntary projects could help to develop empathy, ownership and leadership in the youth. Of course, funding for these projects need to come from somewhere.Youths can raise funds for the projects on their own or they would have to be granted some percentage of it. Great idea!

peace_corp_meets_local_public_service.title: Peace Corp meets Local Public Service

stanford_s_art_of_living_classes_2014_fr.description: In "The Art of Living," a first-year Introduction to the Humanities course, three humanities professors from Stanford examine great works of philosophy and literature to explore what it might take to lead a well-lived life.
stanford_s_art_of_living_classes_2014_fr.creator: ce4f0f52ce7b650578499cc00bda3f6d

comments.text: I love this inspiration as a reminder that having a "big picture" helps us be resilient and helps us make connections among the things we know and experience. Both these skills or dispositions- resilience and ability to make associations- are invaluable for the job hunt and the workplace.

Yes. Yes. Yes.I think we should all take a step back and realize that, while we're teaching kids to do better work and learn more so they appeal to employers, we aren't teaching them how to live a good life. In fact, the prevailing culture is telling students to work longer and harder hours, committing their lives to work as if that's the only thing that should define them.There's more to life than a career. We should educate people on how to live a fulfilling life, not just how to make a living.

subby.creator: 5f67d5ad03248803f33c1b43645bd5e3

comments.text: We're currently facing a bug which may prevent you from being able to directly update your concept post. Our developers are busy working on it. Meanwhile, if you're wanting to iterate your ideas, you can use the comments feature to promote further conversation from others. We'll let you know once the bug is fixed, then you can incorporate your refinement moves into your concept post. Let's be agile, together!

Right on! Our development team have been busy fixing the Update Entry bug and we're back on track now. You'll now be able to edit your posts to add all that refinement-goodness to build out your concepts for improved impact. Bring it on, together!

Stephen, great visualizations and I really like the system map! I'm currently working on a separate project that involves employment and find that many people find a lot of value out of in-person meetings and context of the actual workplace to learn about the culture. If there are ways to incorporate videos of the organization and people who work there, it can be an added-value for graduates to see if it's fit (remotely).

Congrats on this idea moving on to our Youth Employment Challenge Refinement phase Top 20!WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL LIKED:Another concept aimed at matching demand and supply, the panel felt the 'video interview' feature is what distinguishes this idea because attending interviews is often prohibitively expensive for the candidate and not best use of time for the employer.  Although there are many recruitment sites out there, the particular execution of this concept seems particularly appropriate for younger job-seekers.WHAT THE EXPERT PANEL WOULD LOVE TO SEE EXPLORED:The challenge for this app is clearly around acquiring and then maintaining the data so the panel would love to hear your thoughts on who will be responsible for this and how it can be done!  They'd also love to seem some more of your great visualisations that really help bring this concept to life...For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, check this update on how the shortlist was chosen http://bit.ly/youth-top20 and and the Lowdown on Refinement: http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Is this app created and in the app store? What OS is it built on?

Hello Chelsea, the concept i am putting up is this app, if the people here liked it enough and it got support it could be a working app in the app store which thousands of inspired youth could use to secure potential opportunities. I like that you think it could be real, thank you!

Wow! Incredible visualisations, Stephen. I imagine features which foster trust could be added like being able to add testimonials. And I wonder if there could be a place where you could read stories of success of Subby members to encourage you to keep at it?

Meena, you are absolutely correct! A feedback system which both fosters pride in the employee and metrics for potential employers would be part of this system. I imagine it would be more critical to a sub contracting style of work, but to kick-start careers it may not be as high on the feature list. Regarding case studies and application testimonials which inspire, this too would be a feature as part of a stats package showing the overall success and industry growth feedback. I would look at showcasing this in a future concept. Thank you very much for the kind words.I may add these in an additional concept soon as I ran out of time, and will be sure to reference your comment.
Bring on the builds & fresh concepts! We love ideas on the move :^)
You will find an additional image illustrating some of this, I will look to mocking-up a couple screens illustrating it in practice.
Awesome! Do you ever sleep??
Putting the concept together graphically was 2 hour exercise, but the thought behind it is what counts and viability being the key, the graphics just reinforce that. Thanks for the kind words!

py/tuple: IMPACT & REACH: How much impact and reach do you think this concept could have in helping young people transition into the world of work?
A great deal – something like this would really make a difference
A moderate amount – it’s certainly helpful but probably not a game-changer
Not very much – it’s unlikely to make a significant difference to young people seeking work

FEASIBILITY & RESOURCES: Thinking about the resources needed to implement this concept, how feasible will it be for your community to turn this concept into a reality?  (Hint: when you think about resources, think: people, money, time, technology, infrastructure, partnerships and any other inputs for implementation)
Highly feasible – resources wouldn’t be an issue for my community if we tried to implement this
Moderately feasible – my community could do it if we could get find assistance with some of our resource constraints
Not feasible – it would be almost impossible for my community to implement this concept; it's just too resource-intensive
SUSTAINABILITY & LONGEVITY: Does this concept feel like it could be sustained as a project, business or movement over years rather than just months? Will continue to be relevant in future?
Yes – this concept has enough momentum to stand on its own two feet and remain relevant for years to come
Maybe – it’s not clear how long it would take for this concept to stand on its own feet or how it will continue to be but there’s reason to feel hopeful
No – this concept will have trouble sustaining itself in the long-run and probably won’t be as relevant in years to come
ORIGINALITY: How new or innovative is this idea? Are there many different versions of this concept out there already or is this something more disruptive and unique?
Very original – I’ve not seen anything else quite like it
Fairly original – there are similar things out there but this particular version brings a new element to the table
Unoriginal – there are already too many other concepts out there that are similar to this one
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world
I liked it but preferred others
It didn't get me overly excited

when_did_we_stop_wanting_to_be_an_astron.description: When we were children, we wanted to be astronauts, doctors, cowboys - we had a career perspective. When did we lose this perspective and became undecided? More important: how can we gain the perspective back?
when_did_we_stop_wanting_to_be_an_astron.creator: 83bce7e537e2315f717ea45929861a7a

comments.text: Nice inspiration. It is true that most of the people don't know how to connect the passion, skills and job opportunities. Because most of the time, we only think about gaining money.

I think the whole concept of a job might change in the future. Maybe people form temporary groups based on shared beliefs and visions and after reaching a result move on to a next project with members from different companies or self employes people.

I can't stop thinking about this idea.  Does that mean we will all be generalists? Projects could range from three weeks to ten years?  Can this idea apply to most of the work in the world (including subsistence farming, trade work, investment banking)?

Interesting Joachim. I think that it may also be a case of thinking broadly about one's passions & emerging skills without having a fixed notion of what specific profession they might fill. I never could have imagined my role as a Community Manager / Cross-pollinator on OpenIDEO 5 years ago  yet made a firm decision to focus on certain passions and developing skills in areas I felt enthusiastic about. It was actually because I didn't have too fixed an idea about a specific profession that I was ripe for this role  and continue to enjoy the always-in-beta approach we embrace at OpenIDEO.

I like where you're going with this, Meena.  Maybe a good formula is PASSION (what gets you excited/makes you feel fulfilled?) + POSSIBILITY (what are the outlets for that passion?)  + ROAD MAP (what do you need to try some of those options?).  Sounds simple but I think it might be easy to get frustrated with any one of those elements.  Even passion.

Carla, I really like your comment. I think you have tapped into three key "ingredients". As Meena said, you don't necessarily want a totally fixed idea of what your career will be, but you do need to figure out what skills you need to start working on until that job that makes all the pieces fall into place comes along.Maybe another key ingredient is aptitudes/talents... identifying some of your natural abilities and putting those into the "equation" too? I've been inspired by the "Hidden Talent" post :)

I'm glad someone brought this up because I was just about to! It seems everyone wants to save the world when they are young. And then they grow up and choose a career path that is more "realistic"...or they continue following their dreams and become designers :) Indeed, we need to start reaching out to students and addressing their dreams at a younger age, before moon boots are traded for brief cases.

One of the scariest things From Seth Godin's Stop Stealing Dreams 15. When I grow up, I want to be an astronaut assistantJake Halpern did a rigorous study  of  high  school  students.  The  most  disturbing result was this:When you grow up, which of the following jobs would you most like to have? The chief of a major company like General MotorsA Navy SEALA United States SenatorThe president of a great university like Harvard or YaleThe personal assistant to a very famous singer or movie starThe results:Among girls, the results were as follows: 9.5 percent chose the chief of a major company like General Motors; 9.8 percent chose a Navy SEAL; 13.6 percent chose a United States Senator; 23.7 percent chose the president of a great university like Harvard or Yale; and 43.4 percent chose the personal assistant to a very famous singer or movie star. Notice that these kids were okay with not actually being famousthey were happy to be the assistant of someone who lived that fairy tale lifestyle.  Is this the best we can do? Have we created a trillion-dollar, multimillion student, sixteen-year schooling cycle to take our best and our brightest and snuff out their dreamssometimes when theyre so nascent that they havent even been articulated? Is the product of our massive schooling industry an endless legion of assistants?

It's because we're taught to be risk-averse and not challenge the status quo. All of my years in primary school, I was frustrated with the rigid grading systems, lack of creativity, and lack of meaningful challenge -- even as I excelled. Even though I was very good at taking tests, I felt that I was let down by my education because it didn't push me to be a leader. It required me to shut my mouth and do what I was told, and nothing more.  I think more oversight, more intense curricula, and more rules are not the solution. They're the problem.Instead, we should give students more autonomy and choice in HOW to learn. I foresee a future where kids can still learn what they need to learn in class, but through collaboration with other students and their teachers that teaches them how to lead, plan, execute ideas, and cultivate an understanding of the material.

In Montessori teachers are really anthropologists who observe students and help if asked.  Montessori materials are self correcting so if an error is made the child will discover it and try again. Report cards are really field studies given orally to parents.  "We notice that your daughter seems to prefer maths but we are working with this motivation to introduce some more grammar experience. We are playing sentence equation games. Could you reinforce this at home by playing these games?"

when_did_we_stop_wanting_to_be_an_astron.title: When did we stop wanting to be an astronaut?

a_story_of_an_internship.description: Inspired by the video in the IDEO London team inspiration, I wanted to share the story of how my internship changed my ideas about my career.
a_story_of_an_internship.creator: 6fed0e6f1ba44f0520bc14fceee3663d

comments.text: Arjan, great question!"How can we make sure that people can get re-educated later on in life if they find out after their 1st few years in the job that this specific job or industry isn't for them?"Not sure whether I'll face this problem after a few years, but if I do find out that a specific job/industry isn't for me, then the next question might be - "Do I know what kind of job/industry I'm interested in?" If yes, how do I get there? If no, how do I figure out where my passion lies?

to build on this story more stories like this. After highschool I had a break year because I didn't know I had to apply 18 months before the university year starts to that university. I volunteered, worked in big companies. This changed my view on work... I think it should be in society people have a break year around their 20s. Before university choice.

I think work experience is very valuable, and should be in some form, be part of different stages of education. From the take your son and daughter to work days (as posted by Ashley), to exploration weeks, to internships to apprenticeships.

This is both a great insight Arjan and good advice for would be university students. I began university at 17 in 1968 with no real idea of what I wanted to do, and never really recovered from this. A year off might have given me a better perspective. All of my children have made either educational or career changes early in their lives and appear to have found their respective niches.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
Hurray! Thanks. That's a big honour :).
Nice one, A! And we hope this might inspire others to post video reflections too :^)
Exactly! That was my hope, too :)

Thanks for sharing Arjan! I like the fact that while the internship was a great experience, it led you to decide to move to another field. It reminds me a conversation I had with one of my students who told me about an internship she had during her undergraduate studies in what she believed at that time was her "dream company". After working there, she realized she did not want to work in manufacturing. I found very interesting your point about the possibility of shifting careers. I've heard many stories of my friends who feel stuck in their jobs and don't think (and some have tried) they really have a chance to change jobs. I'm also worried when I see the age at which kids have to take decisions in terms of fields and specialties. I feel that sometime while there is a claim that we need more agile multidisciplinary people in organizations, the educational system (and even internships sometime) asks you to be super specialized.

Thank you, Anne-Laure. And thanks for sharing the story of that student. I think it's important for people to learn and experience what they're good at and what they're passionate about to do. Change is often hard on people, especially later in your career when there's a lot depending on your income. But sometimes it's good to stay open to opportunities, explore a field in your free time, and see where it leads you. Availability of internships or apprenticeships is key to that, I think. I, for one, would love to do an internship at a butcher. But mainly to improve my cooking. Which is a hobby. So, completely different. But still :).

Arjan this is great insight, there have been a few comments on another post regarding internships and many things that come with that, like fair compensation, deciding whether it's a sustainable initiative on behalf of the company, etc.Once we reach the concepting stage, it'd be great to initiate a phase addressing an efficient, fair internship platform sponsored by companies throughout the world as prospective platforms for future / recent grads.The comments can be found in this thread: http://www.openideo.com/open/youth-employment/inspiration/-if-you-could-go-back-and-give-yourself-advice-as-you-were-leaving-school-what-would-it-beVery worthwhile checking out.
Thanks, Sarah. I've seen the discussion there. I think it's great, and have been contributing to it. I really feel we could find some good concepts in these inspirations.
Great video Arjan!
Thanks, James!
Way to go Arjan! Thanks for sharing your story - it's great to hear your experience and lessons.

job_discovery_path.description: Summer camps and after school programs help youth develop better character and other qualities. This program could be built like the Boy/Girl Scouts of America with volunteers and badges for accomplishing different subjects  surrounding employment.
job_discovery_path.creator: 16069a5ec35b9894143dcb2d9864fe9f

comments.text: I really like this idea of embedding career discovery into children and/or teens at a young age. Perhaps you can include the teen's parents into the program so his or her guardians can play a role in fostering a positive support system along with the mentors, volunteers, and counselors. Keeping parents in the loop can help their children identify, explore, and strengthen career desires and opportunities. Also, I almost want to say that this program should be mandatory for all students attending summer school. Today, I passed by a local high school during lunch, and many students were outside smoking and fooling around. It may be good to help these grade 9 students focus on their future and get them back on track for the new school year.

Yes, I was envisioning parents stepping in and volunteering like they do with girl scout outings and activities. I wonder what would be the best age to start children with this. Maybe junior high 7/8th graders while they still have a pretty open mind?

I remember getting all those "what do you want to do when you grow up?"; "what are your dreams?"; "how do you want to help the world?" questions consistently in grade 5. I think grade 5 students are mature enough to begin exploring what they like/don't like, and the careers that correspond with their interests. Grade 5 is a good time to ease the teens into the concept of career discovery. However, grade 7 will be the time to ramp up the number of activities that will guide the student's career discovery. Especially since it is only two years away from high school; students will feel more confident going into high school with a rough plan. I had a Careers course (half a semester) in grade 10, and I thought that was very late and ineffective. The course did not provide the needed support. It essentially labelled you as someone who is interested in the math & sciences or arts.

I love it! Do you have any ideas for how to start building the curriculum? The US Bureau of Labor Occupational handbook was used by my high school and undergrad, but it leaves something to be desired...All jobs are described in terms of expected growth and income ranges, but don't shed much light on the day-to-day work or the other intrinsic motivators that are so powerful.Your mention of LinkedIn is probably a good starting point; they surely have some amazing behind-the-scenes data  and insight on career paths and people's self-described strengths

Great point! Maybe a place to start for more insight on top of the US Bureau handbook would be from job descriptions that are posted for open positions. It would bring in current information, but I'd guess the most accurate information would come right from those who do that day to day work. Oh yes! ... LinkedIn could assign a questionnaire for everyone who completes their profile. That might be an easy way to implement a massive questionnaire like that. The information then could be organized and interpreted for multiple outlets.

This is AWESOME Tara! For name titles how about:Camp Courageous (empowering youth)Making my PathCamp Rally Camp JobCore (maybe it is a club?) Careerification Overnight (maybe its an overnight weekend event?) Start your Mark (Playing up the game concept alongside Career)I will keep brainstorming but this concept is exactly what I needed in middle school & high school!

Oh these are great!. Some others after I saw them Mark your path, On your Mark (" get set, go!"), Make your mark.I think I might go with Mark-It, with a slogan like "Route (or discover) your path & make your mark!" Would it be cool or cheesy to use a graffiti typeface as a play on words? It might just confuse things.
Digging that the 'journey as destination' notion going on here!

Am wondering if the name Job Discovery Path is a bit direct. What about Path to Success or merely The Journey? Or what other names might others here suggest for this initiative? We're keen to hear from you!

I think I labeled this Job Discovery Path because I wanted to make sure the concept is understood by this Open IDEO community. If we want to name this in a clever thoughtful way, I would totally love to brainstorm. Let's see if I can get my ideation friend Shaina Lurie, she's brilliant. What do you think about any of these?...Steps to SuccessWalk of LifeCareer StartCareer DiscoveryJob DiscoveryJob JourneyJob PathCareer PathPath of DevelopmentDiscovery Path

Nice one. Let's see if others join the conversation too  then it's up to you to decide what might work best. I'm mostly here to plant seeds and encourage you guys to collaborate & build out your ideas ;^)

Completely agree with your Journey Documentation concept.  Student's should manage their own portfolio of real-life experiences that can be applied to professional settings.  Coaches and mentors, as you mentioned, are critical to helping students connect their experiences to real-world skills.

Real life experiences are important, they also need to have time to reflected on those experiences, either with communication to peers/mentors, or even just documenting on their online "journey profile". Keeping track and connecting the dots through reflection is one of the most important parts of learning about one's self.

job_discovery_path.title: MarkIt — Route your Path & Make your Mark ( fka: Job Discovery Path )

the_co_space_a_two_year_living_program_.description: Mixing students with professionals, connecting them with mentors and offering them opportunities for learning by doing, collaborating and experimenting.
the_co_space_a_two_year_living_program_.creator: 893f53c159eab9178ab181bad8da4262

comments.text: Hi all,Thanks for sharing about the co.space. My name is Spud and I'm one of the founders of the co.space. We just purchased our first property in State College and are doing the renovations this summer. It's been an exciting process and we can't wait to open the doors soon. Let me know if you have any other ideas that would make the concept better or more applicable in different settings - we're always open to hearing new suggestions!Spud

Speaking of questions that get stock in your head: "Can we create situations, environments that trigger or support the development of a passionate mindset?" is a great question. I am sure we can. It will not be exact science. ie it will not mean that "doing A will automatically trigger B", but there should be a way in which doing A serves as a helpful and supportive platform to create. period. Whether it is creating B or C or E. Once you take the end result out make the goal be helping and supporting creativity you will succeed in creating something I do not know what that something would be.

Daniella I think you can develop a passion mindset by surrounding yourself with passionate people.  I do think that one of the failures of the education system is that only credentialed teachers are allowed access to students.  It would be great for students to meet people who were passionate about their field. How much better would you do in a biology class if your teacher absolutely loved the subject? Someone who knew why their subject was important and bring in their own stories of what it was like to be a biologist. Democratic Freeschools run on this model.

I agree with you %100 Monera, but it is difficult to find the "cure" for people's career choices. If everyone worked and did what they loved doing for a living, the world would look different, I am sure. However there are other things that interfere us from realizing our dreams, and therefore it is difficult to insert passion into everything you do in life when in fact many people feel forced and trapped into doing what they do.
Trickle this down to middle and high school and you are looking at the future of education!
I think this is a FANTASTIC concept and could be adapted to fit with a host of different places/spaces/opportunities.
it would also be great if this concept can be made to work in Africa!

This is an interesting concept. It got me thinking thoughmost college dormitories act in a similar fashion: many students from different backgrounds living under a single roof. The only thing that's different is the mentors on site and the experience and opportunities they bring. I imagine then that the co.space concept could be widely applied to colleges everywhere because they already have the base living quarters and people in place. They would just need to advance and evolve what they already have started. And I wonder how readily industry professionals will buy into the concept. Time will tell?

Hi Andy, I agree that it has a dorm aspect although it made me think of the English system where you stay in a house and have faculty attached to the colleges, and who have regular, formal and informal, interactions with students. It seems from the description that they offer a lot of "learning by doing" opportunities.However, I think there might some ideas on how to introduce some of this in dorms...It could also be that just by creating a context where people have to reflect and apply, you already make them more aware and willing to apply their skills in context.  Time will indeed tells about how much involvement they will get from industry professionals.

I actually think that Silicon Valley is hugely successful because it is essentially an extension of Stanford.  A shared culture and value system that was forged both at school and in the CS industry, makes it a hard place to leave.
It would be great, but not in all countries do colleges and universities have dormitories or campuses. Especially in those places something like this could be a very valuable initiative.
Good point Arjan. This could be a great model for countries with a different universities model and no dorms.

the_co_space_a_two_year_living_program_.title: The Co-space: a Two Year Living Program

from_the_military_to_the_workforce.description: IAVA supports veterans in the transition from the military into the workforce-- with job training, job fairs, and political action to increase employment opportunities.
from_the_military_to_the_workforce.creator: bd34caa34f0ec84a453fdf791b977fec

comments.text: A topic I am incredibly passionate about! With one million Gulf War era2 veterans transitioning back to civilian life over the next five years this is a an issue thats needs to be adressed. This demographic represents one of the greatest untapped assets of our country. The young veterans that have served over seas possess unique leadership and communication skills that have been tried and tested under the most austere and hostile conditions. They are mission focused, disciplined and accustomed to life or death team work..... Are these skills not applicable in the private sector? The issue: For every solider we loose in Iraq or Afghanistan we loose twenty-five to suicide at a rate of 17 per day. The unemployment rate for male veterans 18 to 24 is 29.1% vs. 17.6% to their civillian cohorts. Orgs. like IAVA are tremendous and are doing incredible things on the advocacy front but what has not been adressed well and in a holistic manner yet are platforms that adress the issue physically. Overnight veterans loose their structure, community, and mission clarity, and are thrust into an unstructured world they have had very little experience with. Helping them transition to the private sector will not only help them but it will save lives, and ad exponential value to the private sector. It is about bridging a cultural gap and cross training veterans to teach them how their skills are applicable in the private sector and educating private side organizations about the true skills acquired in the military.    An org I work with / love that is providing a physical / tangible transition model: www.teamrubiconusa.org
Great example looking at an analogous transition!

from_the_military_to_the_workforce.title: IAVA: From the military to the workforce

howard_gardner_s_multiple_intelligences.description: Those who don't excel in the three R's are left feeling inadequate and "stupid." But are they really?
howard_gardner_s_multiple_intelligences.creator: 55396b7895d28d1618bd9e8fa381897f

comments.text: In my opinion this is an interesting approach. Now Questions come to my mind regarding young people who are searching for a job: How can they present their special talents? How can you include them in a CV? Are they valued in the same way in companies? How an you find out your "hidden" talents?

Gardner's theory is indeed interesting but I agree with Sabine, there are two implications with this research: one is how to develop and support these different intelligences at schools (there are several attempts although I think we are still far from being successful); the other is (whether you were able to develop them or not) how do you build on these different types of intelligence when it comes to looking for a job? Except if you have a very strong talent, and you end up looking in the field of your talent - sport, music, etc. - the world of work is to a certain extent very similar to the education system in terms of the type of skills they tend to recognize. That will be an interesting idea to explore in the concepting phase.

It is possible that every individual's profile has differing levels of ability and the specific gift of an individual may lie in the combination and weightings of Gardner's  intelligences. Today's world provides the opportunities for many different profiles to find fulfillment. Part of the challenge would be to help children identify, explore, and nurture their special profiles. We have to ask ourselves if our teachers are trained to do this - assuming it is necessary.

howard_gardner_s_multiple_intelligences.title: Howard Gardner's Multiple Intelligences
